Sport", "title": "How the Indian women\u2019s hockey team went on to become a potential gold-winning squad", "title_full": "How the Indian women\u2019s hockey team went on to become a potential gold-winning squad", "published": "2018-03-24T16:05:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "IN", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "http://www.thehindu.com/sport/article23333301.ece/ALTERNATES/LANDSCAPE_615/25SMHOCKEY13", "performance_score": 1, "domain_rank": 806, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 107, "comments": 0, "shares": 107}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "7b18555c9de2fac54696b14f526fc35bcd9263e9", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg9YBD4zSwJdl2k_EbfTSBpdyYfsZ.t2qvUW99G1xA4Jpj0fAofemn.Nx5fs0IcTS9PlnJGV5.av0rgbO_uHRzIUi3tolP8gzh2jVJFHm_f1PhIWuR7Ov8sWrFfV1q2kkHw6.9ZiOyRT.ym6g8M1pwfS7fKPkQ5XWrPMu5.ApDG0fDj2qbm3_VmF", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Uthra Ganesan", "published": "2018-03-24T16:05:00.000+03:00", "title": "How the Indian women\u2019s hockey team went on to become a potential gold-winning squad", "text": "March 24, 2018 16:30 IST Updated: March 25, 2018 09:08 IST more-in Rio Olympics 2016 The women are gearing up for the Commonwealth Games that will begin in Australia next month \nHarendra Singh, coach of the Indian women\u2019s hockey team , is a stickler for rules. The day I land in Bengaluru to spend a day with the players training at Sports Authority of India\u2019s (SAI) Centre of Excellence, there is only one stipulation from him: don\u2019t be late. \nWith the team of 30 that Singh is training to compete in the upcoming Commonwealth Games (CWG) in Gold Coast, Australia, punctuality, however, is never an issue. This has been his easiest outing yet, the coach admits. \u201cTheir focus is amazing. If the training is to start at 8 a.m., they are on the ground five minutes before time. If it ends at 10, they hang around for another 10 minutes, discussing the session,\u201d he says proudly. No looking back: Skills apart, the team has worked on building confidence and motivation. | Photo Credit: K. Murali Kumar \nIt\u2019s all part of the dream the 30 women have together: to get into the top six in the world, to be counted as serious competitors, and win the big medals, starting with the CWG and going on to the World Cup and the Asian Games. More importantly, it\u2019s a fight for recognition, a desire to find their place in the sun, so long the preserve of the Indian men\u2019s hockey team. \nIt\u2019s attitude that sets the women apart from the men\u2019s side. Even though the intensity is as high, the men\u2019s training is often fun-filled. Not here, where even a minor game between two groups of trainees has the women going all out to outwit the opponent. \u201cWe all feel it is important to stay focussed. If it is a 60- or 90-minute training session, I don\u2019t see why anybody should have a problem concentrating completely on the game for that period of time. We are free the rest of the day anyway, right? Not that we don\u2019t have fun, especially when it is light training,\u201d says goalkeeper Savita Punia, one of the seniormost and key players in the side. \nThe team\u2019s scientific advisor, Wayne Lombard from South Africa, is proud of the work the women have put in over the past few months. \u201cYou talk about fitness, I have the data for Great Britain, China, South Africa, Ireland and Australia. And these girls are on par with them. In every sense. There has been a complete cultural change in training. Normally, I would prefer to test the girls every quarter but here it is done more often. And every time I test them, there is an average 0.2% improvement in their fitness levels, which is too good even at the highest level. They are amazing girls,\u201d Lombard says, one eye on his laptop, tracking the GPS coordinates of the players on field. A Chak De! moment \nThis women\u2019s team first made news in 2016 when they played at the Rio Olympics, qualifying for the quadrennial event for the first time ever \u2014 the only previous appearance in 1980 was invitational. There was little hope but even so, no one expected a last-place finish. Not even the women themselves. \n\u201cWe still believe we were better than what the results showed in Rio, but it wasn\u2019t our best performance. We learnt a lot from that experience,\u201d says 23-year-old Rani Rampal, captain, and one of the seniormost in the team, having made her India debut at 15. Also Read \nIndia\u2019s hockey pride: 2017 may well be the turning point for our women\u2019s team \nThe learnings, however, came later. In the immediate aftermath, it was shock and doubt that surrounded the women. Did they even deserve to be on the world stage? Were they the laughing stock of the hockey world? How could they face the questions back home, from family, friends and complete strangers? \n\u201cShah Rukh Khan in the beginning of Chak De! India must have felt something like that,\u201d the women joke, but the pain is still alive in their voices. \n\u201cIt was bad and it took us some time to recover, yes. But after a while, we decided we had to look at the future, not worry about a past that cannot be changed. Mind se hata diya Rio ko ,\u201d says Deep Grace Ekka, defender and self-proclaimed team chatterbox. \nSays Rani, \u201cMaybe we would never have started on the road to recovery if we had not experienced that loss there. We collectively decided to think two years ahead, to the Asian Games and the CWG. And then, maybe 2020, when we would not be newbies any more.\u201d The women are busy training for the upcoming Commonwealth Games in Australia. | Photo Credit: K. Murali Kumar \nThese are young women, most of them, and they have mostly stayed away from the media glare. And it shows in their attitude and temperament. Singh says one of the things he has insisted on is that players address each other by their names. And everybody has to ask questions during team meetings. \u201cIt is inherent in their upbringing, the respect for seniors and coaches. But hierarchy in a team cannot win you titles. Now they are slowly coming around,\u201d he says. Largely, though, he prefers to stay in the shadows, allowing the women to tell their own tales. \nAnd they have begun doing so. Forward Vandana Katariya says earlier it was confusing on the field when everyone shouted \u2018 Didi, didi \u2019 for ball possession; that\u2019s changed. \u201cThe coach insists we call each other, and him, by name. We haven\u2019t exactly reached that stage, but we do add a name before \u2018 didi \u2019 now,\u201d she laughs. \nSingh is relentlessly pushing the women to break out of their shells. A month before our meeting, when I contact him to schedule my visit, he is eager and says he looks forward to outsiders visiting. \u201cThe more unscheduled questions the girls are asked, the more they will be forced to think for themselves,\u201d he says. The women admit it has helped. \u201c Thodi daring aa gayi hai ab . Now we know even if we are wrong, they will explain it to us and correct us,\u201d says reserve goalie Rajani Etimarpu. \nSingh knows the importance of routine and repetition. He is also a big fan of the haka (M\u0101ori war cry or ceremonial greeting) and its effect in psyching the opposition on the field. The girls have a chant: \u2018We dream the same dream. We think the same thing. We are the dream team. We are the Indian team. We are a champion team.\u2019 They say it before and after every game, and at every break, every time. It\u2019s amazing how, for a bunch that is as comfortable with English as an emu in flight, these lines just roll off the tongue. And there is no embarrassment; the women shout out at the top of their voices. \u201cI want any team that plays us to know we are in it to win and we will do anything for it. No more shoving us around or walking all over this team any more,\u201d says Singh. \nThe confidence has trickled down to the youngest players. From Namita Toppo and Rajani to Deepika Thakur and Savita, each one believes she is no longer there to simply make up the numbers. \u201cWhen we went to the Asia Cup, everyone was determined to win gold and qualify for the World Cup,\u201d Rajani says. \u201cWe all know what it means to play for India.\u201d Turning point \nIt was during the Europe tour before the Asia Cup, where the women did reasonably well even against the Belgian junior men\u2019s side, that they first believed they could win. The real turning point, however, was the Asian Champions Trophy three months after Rio, where the Indian women won their maiden gold. \u201cThat\u2019s when the first spark was ignited; that even though Rio wasn\u2019t great, we were ending the year on a high and could begin the new year with a new confidence,\u201d says Rani. Skills apart, the team has worked on building confidence and motivation. | Photo Credit: K. Murali Kumar \nIndividual brilliance versus team effort has always been a tricky issue in Indian hockey. While most former greats continue to insist that Indians should rely on individual excellence because that\u2019s what they are good at, a series of foreign coaches have tried to build a firm team structure. \n\u201cOn and off the ground, we are working on improving our understanding of each other. Earlier, there was some selfishness in scoring, but in the past 7-8 months, since Harendra sir took over, most of our goals have come from the second post. The structure has changed a lot. We have actually started playing as a team with everyone thinking of the team result and not the scoresheet,\u201d says Vandana. \n**** \nIt\u2019s half past noon, and training and lunch is over. The women troop in in twos and threes for their daily neurotracker session. It\u2019s an activity they love, the highlight of their day, and perhaps the one thing that has seen their focus and peripheral vision shoot through the roof. \nThe target is simple: eight balls in constant motion on the screen, with four of them picked randomly to change colours. 3D glasses make it more real. The women have to keep tracking the balls that change colour, and identify them every time they stop moving. Each correct attempt increases the speed of the balls, wrong ones slow them down over a set of 30 attempts. The difficulty levels are from basic to advanced. \n\u201cSome of these girls have improved by more than 150% in their focus and performance here. In fact, only P.R. Sreejesh (the men\u2019s goalkeeper) has been able to keep up with them in terms of advancement. These girls are simply amazing,\u201d says SAI psychologist Priyanka Prabhakar. \nDeep Grace loves the activity the most. She operates the software. \u201cWhen Grace is around, all of us just chill. She is the lord and master of this set-up,\u201d laughs Priyanka. \nSingh is also working on making the women up-to-date on all the latest rule changes in international hockey, and the loopholes they can exploit on field. \u201cIt is important to be smart \u2014 you need to decide whether to work your a** off like a donkey or be a smart worker like a horse. International sports is not just about skill and strength, it is equally about smartness,\u201d Singh says. Battle against self \nOn field, the women get grilled for even the slightest signs of indiscipline. \u201cDiscipline is a habit, just like winning and losing are. Small things add up to big achievements. We know it all, but the past few months, we have been working on getting it into our subconscious. The pace at which hockey is played today, the absence of even one player for just two minutes can be critical. Sometimes, we concede soft goals because of it,\u201d Rani says. \nAll this progress, topped with the Asia Cup, where India got the better of three stronger, higher-ranked teams, has finally brought the team in the spotlight. For the first time in recent history, the women\u2019s team received more coverage and appreciation than the men. \nIt has made them more confident but there is no pressure of performance, they say. \u201cEarlier, hardly anybody came to watch women\u2019s games and not many knew of our matches, but now Indian supporters come to watch us; they came in Singapore, Korea and Japan too. It feels good to have that support. But there is no pressure. It only motivates us to do better,\u201d Vandana says. \u201cWe are now determined to do even better in the Commonwealth Games and prove ourselves. This year is very important for us and for women\u2019s hockey to claim its rightful place,\u201d says Rajani. \nIn absolute terms, the journey from a last-place finish at Rio to winning the Asia Cup was not very long. For the women who were part of both campaigns, however, it was a battle they had to fight, and win, against themselves. \nAs Rani says, \u201cLosing all the time had eroded our self-belief and motivation. We had to start from zero and understand that we have to win to convince both ourselves and others that we are good.\u201d \nThey were given few shots to do so, but that absence of spotlight seems a blessing in hindsight. They did not have a coach for more than a month, then three coaches were changed within a year and a half, one halfway through a European tour. But all that churn has seen them emerge even more self-reliant. They now carry that confidence into Gold Coast next month.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "singh", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "harendra singh", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "cwg", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "sports authority", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "gold coast", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "bengaluru", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "australia", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "india", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-24T16:18:43.014+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "5f98f9ddcb281b7013397b5d31cd29182a547ff5", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/DyQaNGXlfMpq8HEnNTp9633LOQohzWJQbtEF77zD0zBDEauHdefDldwgwuQjH.D48w5ap.rYBWk7WPCKh4NMs5zkhoQ2ViAGrYxugBehPe6ggW0Ko6snnAA3tEm477podZlhkpZHqulPBnKubDvsc3ajRdKumH2qL6hKID2VI0cncw9W5I59lP7mHFWr9boG", "site_full": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "site": "indiatimes.com", "site_section": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bangalore", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "Bangalore News, Latest Bangalore News Headlines &amp; Live Updates - Times of India", "title": "Karnataka Assembly polls: Karnataka election to be webcast, monitored in Bengaluru and Delhi | Bengaluru News", "title_full": "Karnataka Assembly polls: Karnataka election to be webcast, monitored in Bengaluru and Delhi | Bengaluru News - Times of India", "published": "2018-03-23T03:00:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "IN", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://static.toiimg.com/thumb/msid-63424441,width-1070,height-580,imgsize-1774881,resizemode-6,overlay-toi_sw,pt-32,y_pad-40/photo.jpg", "performance_score": 0, "domain_rank": 116, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 3, "comments": 0, "shares": 3}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "5f98f9ddcb281b7013397b5d31cd29182a547ff5", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/DyQaNGXlfMpq8HEnNTp9633LOQohzWJQbtEF77zD0zBDEauHdefDldwgwuQjH.D48w5ap.rYBWk7WPCKh4NMs5zkhoQ2ViAGrYxugBehPe6ggW0Ko6snnAA3tEm477podZlhkpZHqulPBnKubDvsc3ajRdKumH2qL6hKID2VI0cncw9W5I59lP7mHFWr9boG", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "B V Shivashankar", "published": "2018-03-23T03:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "Karnataka Assembly polls: Karnataka election to be webcast, monitored in Bengaluru and Delhi | Bengaluru News", "text": "BENGLAURU: The Karnataka assembly polls are set to go hi-tech with plans afoot to digitize the entire process, from managing electoral rolls to monitoring polling stations, through Internet Protocol (IP)-based webcasting and live-streaming of the counting of votes.\nAn Election Monitoring Dash Board (EMDB) will be set up at the offices of the chief election commissioner of India in New Delhi, the chief electoral officer (CEO) in Bengaluru and electoral officers at all district headquarters. EMDB will enable online monitoring both at polling and counting stations.\nWebcast was used on an experimental basis to monitor a few polling stations in the elections in various states between 2014 and 2018. It is the first time that the technology is being adopted to digitize the entire electoral process in a state. \u201cMost of the elements of our tech initiative are being used for the first time in India,\u201d said Sanjiv Kumar, CEO for Karnataka.\nAll 56,994 polling stations in the state will be GISmapped and linked with voters\u2019 Electoral Photo Identity Cards (EPIC).\nAlerts will be sent to mobile phones of voters about their polling station and how to reach there, while a digital atlas of all 224 assembly constituencies will be created.\nSanjiv Kumar said 36 lakh mobile phones of Karnataka\u2019s 5.96 voters have been linked to the web portal so far. \u201cEfforts are on to link all mobiles to the portal before polling,\u201d he said.\nThe functioning of all EVMs and voter-verified audit trail (VVPAT) systems will be monitored. There will also be a software to keep a tab on candidates\u2019 expenditure. While social media accounts of the candidates will be closely monitored, it has been made mandatory for them to give details of their Facebook and Twitter accounts, and WhatsApp number.\n\u201cUnlike the pilots where laptops were used, digitization of the election process is going to be complete this time and servers will be hired for the purpose for the first time in India. The de-duplication analytic that eliminates redundancy in all stages will bring in high-level efficiency to the whole process,\u201d said Surya Sen A V, joint chief electoral officer in charge of technology adoption.\nWhile 10,000 polling stations considered to be sensitive will be facilitated with IP-based webcasting, the rest would be webcast through live videography. Voters can air their grievances online with ECI\u2019s App Sumadhan, while App Suvidha will be used to issue online permission to parties and candidates for public rallies, and use of vehicles for campaigning.\nTimes ViewAn election is always rife with speculation of cash and liquor for votes, trouble at booths, security issues and a host of other undemocratic happenings. In such an atmosphere, live streaming of the proceedings should come as a welcome change. In this digital era, it is good that the election authorities are adopting technology to make the process of both balloting and counting transparent, and hopefully, more free and fair. This should immediately reduce malpractices. It is hoped that this technology is adopted to ensure voters\u2019 names don\u2019t go missing, as is often the case. It is, after all, a citizen\u2019s right.\nPART DIGITIZATION OF POSTAL BALLOTS\nFor the first time, postal ballots are being sent to army and security personnel online. \u201cActually, this is partial digitization of the postal ballot. While soldiers can download ballots on the ETBS portal, they have to send them by post. This step is taken to ensure data security,\u201d said Sanjiv Kumar.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "emdb", Bengaluru on March 28 to showcase use cases of artificial intelligence across sectors.The event will feature discussions around the benefits of artificial intelligence (AI), and how this can be used "2018-03-23T09:02:00.000+03:00", "title": "Vodafone brings 4G VoLTE to Karnataka and UP West", "text": "Home / Vodafone brings 4G VoLTE to Karnataka and UP West Vodafone brings 4G VoLTE to Karnataka and UP West By: MyMobile Team | March 23, 2018 Views 0 \nSpreading the reach of its 4G VoLTE services to more cities in India, telecom operator Vodafone has now introduced the services to Karnataka and UP West. \nTo recall, the Vodafone 4G VoLTE services are currently available in Delhi-NCR, Mumbai, Gujarat, Maharashtra and Goa and Rajasthan, Haryana. \nThe services are available in Bengaluru, Mysore, Belgaum in the state of Karnataka and in Agra, Aligarh, Bareilly, Bijnor, Budaun, Bulandshahar, Dehradun, Etawah, Firozabad, Roorkee, Hardwar, Haldwani, Mainpuri, Mathura, Meerut, Moradabad, Muzaffarnagar, Rudrapur, Rampur and Saharanpur in the state of UP, and will eventually reach out to more cities in India. \nCommenting on the launch, Amit Kapur, Business Head \u2013 Karnataka, Vodafone India said, \u201c We have been making significant investments to expand, upgrade and modernise our network to ensure that we provide the finest service experience and seamless connectivity to our valued customers. We are delighted that Vodafone is now launching VoLTE services in Karnataka with cities like Bangalore, Mysore & Belgaum and will soon extend it to other key cities. \u201d \nFor those who don\u2019t know, the 4G VoLTE services allows users to make high-quality video as well as voice calls on a 4G network. \nCommenting on the launch, Dilip Kumar Ganta, Business Head \u2013 UP West, Vodafone India said, \u201c As a leading telecom services provider in UP West, we have been making significant investments to expand, upgrade our network and to deploy new technologies, so as to ensure that we provide the finest service experience to our valued customers. We are delighted to inform that Vodafone is the first GSM service provider to launch VoLTE services in UP West circle beginning with Meerut, Agra, Dehradun, Bareilly, Saharanpur, Aligarh, Haldwani & Moradabad. "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-23T16:43:00.000+03:00", "title": "Wohneigentumsbildung und Mietwohnungsmarkt parallel st\u00e4rken / F\u00fcnf Punkte zur Bau- und Wohnungspolitik in den n\u00e4chsten Monaten", "text": "Haus & Grund Deutschland Wohneigentumsbildung und Mietwohnungsmarkt parallel st\u00e4rken / F\u00fcnf Punkte zur Bau- und Wohnungspolitik in den n\u00e4chsten Monaten (Berlin) - \"Die neue Bundesregierung nimmt die F\u00f6rderung selbstgenutzten Wohneigentums ernst. Das ist ein sehr ermutigendes Signal\", kommentierte Haus & Grund-Pr\u00e4sident Kai Warnecke die heutige Regierungserkl\u00e4rung von Bauminister Horst Seehofer und die daran anschlie\u00dfende Debatte im Bundestag. Er ermunterte die Gro\u00dfe Koalition, parallel den Mietwohnungsmarkt in den Fokus zu nehmen und zukunftsgerichtet weiterzuentwickeln. Haus & Grund wies darauf hin, dass der Erwerb von Wohneigentum die Mietwohnungsm\u00e4rkte entlaste. Wohneigentum sei zudem die beste Vorsorge f\u00fcr das Alter. Da jedoch viele B\u00fcrger die Mietwohnung den eigenen vier W\u00e4nden vorz\u00f6gen, seien ebenso Ma\u00dfnahmen zu ergreifen, um Mietwohnungen zukunftsf\u00e4hig zu halten. Verbandspr\u00e4sident Warnecke forderte die Bundesregierung auf, die folgenden Punkte z\u00fcgig anzugehen: 1. Erwerb von Wohneigentum effektiv f\u00f6rdern: S\u00e4mtliche im Koalitionsvertrag verabredeten Ma\u00dfnahmen m\u00fcssen z\u00fcgig umgesetzt werden. 2. Erwerbsnebenkosten senken: Es ist Aufgabe von Bund und L\u00e4ndern, gemeinsam eine Senkung der Grunderwerbsteuer anzupacken. Steuersenkungen d\u00fcrfen nicht zu einer Utopie verkommen. 3. Modernisierungen erleichtern: Kleine Modernisierungen von Mietwohnungen mit einem Investitionsvolumen von bis zu 10.000 Euro je Wohnung m\u00fcssen k\u00fcnftig unb\u00fcrokratisch umgesetzt werden k\u00f6nnen. 4. KfW-F\u00f6rderung st\u00e4rken: Die KfW-F\u00f6rderung f\u00fcr das altersgerechte Umbauen von H\u00e4usern und Wohnungen muss langfristig gesichert werden. 5. Mietpreisbremse abschaffen: Die Mietpreisbremse ist gescheitert. Statt den Mietwohnungsmarkt immer weiter zu regulieren, sollten die B\u00fcrger ermutigt werden, Wohneigentum nicht nur zur Selbstnutzung zu erwerben, sondern auch, um es zu vermieten. Haus & Grund ist mit rund 900.000 Mitgliedern der mit Abstand gr\u00f6\u00dfte Vertreter der privaten Haus-, Wohnungs- und Grundeigent\u00fcmer in Deutschland. Den Zentralverband mit Sitz in Berlin tragen 22 Landesverb\u00e4nde und \u00fcber 900 Ortsvereine. Die privaten Immobilieneigent\u00fcmer verf\u00fcgen \u00fcber 80,6 Prozent aller Wohnungen in Deutschland. Sie bieten 66 Prozent der Mietwohnungen und knapp 30 Prozent aller Sozialwohnungen an. Sie stehen zudem f\u00fcr 76 Prozent des Neubaus von Mehrfamilienh\u00e4usern.   Alexander Wiech, Mitglied der Hauptgesch\u00e4ftsf\u00fchrung Politik und Kommunikation Mohrenstr. 33, 10117 Berlin Telefon: (030) 20216-0, Fax: (030) 20216-555 E-Mail:", "highlightText": "", | 7 Comments 3/23/2018 \u2013 Fabiano Caruana had to face his most persistent pursuer in Berlin, Shakriyar Mamedyarov, in the tenth round with the black pieces. Both players wanted to win the game and thus take a huge advantage into the remaining games, but ultimately played to bare kings. The tournament is still completely open at the top. On the other end of the standings table, Vladimir Kramnik staged a small comeback after several bruising defeats, by winning against Levon Aronian. Both the remaining games, Ding Liren vs So and Grischuk vs Karjakin were drawn. | Photo: Niki Riga ChessBase 14 Download Everyone uses ChessBase, from the World Champion to the amateur next door. Start your personal success story with ChessBase 14 and enjoy your chess even more!Along with the ChessBase 14 program you can access the Live Database of 8 million games, and receive three months of free ChesssBase Account Premium membership and all of our online apps! Have a look today! More... Kramnik still kicking \nThree draws, including between the top two leaders Caruana and Mamedyarov meant no change at the top of the standings. Caruana clings to a half point advantage with four rounds to play. But one of the other big stories of the tournament has been the rollercoaster ride of \"Big Vlad\", who has been involved in the most decisive games of the tournament \u2014 four losses but now after beating Levon Aronian for the second time this tournament \u2014 also three wins. The Armenian is on the verge of becoming the first player to be mathematically eliminated. German football legend Felix Magath scored the winning goal in the 1983 European Team Championship, and is also a chess fan | Photo: World Chess Mamedyarov \u00bd-\u00bd Caruana \nChessBase contributor IM Marco Baldauf explains in detail in his game commentary how the two top players today tried to secure an advantage, but in the end were unsuccessful: The Catalan: A complete repertoire for White! The Catalan is one of the most solid openings for White. It forms part of the large and strong fianchetto family in which White builds his strategy mainly around the bishop on g2. The current DVD covers all of Black\u2019s replies to the Catalan, some of which can even transpose to other openings such as the Tarrasch System and the Queen\u2019s Indian. The author\u2019s idea is, as it was in previous DVDs he has published in this area, to help White against all classical setups for Black. Though the DVD is aimed at players of the white pieces, it still might be useful for those who have Black so that they will better understand the coming threats. It would make little sense to mention all the strong players who include the Catalan in their repertoire. Suffice it to say that the Catalan rules! Video running time: 5 hours 29 minutes. GM Daniel King also takes a crack at it for his Power Play Chess channel Kramnik 1-0 Aronian \nVladimir Kramnik had a lot of plans for this tournament \u2014 you could see that easily from his furious start. As the fortunate beneficiary of the wild card, he received a fresh chance to vie for the highest title once more. But his enterprising play has ended in catastrophe one too many times, and Kramnik's win today is but cold comfort. idw - Informationsdienst Wissenschaft", "title": "ESMT Berlin and the Doha Institute launch dual degree program in Qatar", "title_full": "ESMT Berlin and the Doha Institute launch dual degree program in Qatar", "published": "2018-03-23T11:36:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 0, "site_type": "news", "country": "DE", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "", "performance_score": 0, "domain_rank": null, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 0, "comments": 0, "shares": 0}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "4380a7b750095bf8e11d4bc45fd709598bf57fd8", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZTu0694ZQqmDICFom8UgooMpO9UzsairYT_9brbqXynxw--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-23T11:36:00.000+03:00", "title": "ESMT Berlin and the Doha Institute launch dual degree program in Qatar", "text": "ESMT Berlin and the Doha Institute launch dual degree program in Qatar Ulrike Schwarzberg Corporate Communications and Marketing European School of Management and Technology (ESMT) \nThe Doha Institute, through their School of Public Administration and Development Economics, and ESMT Berlin are offering a dual Executive Master of Business Administration/Master of Public Administration (Executive MBA/MPA) degree from autumn 2018. The new Executive MBA/MPA is a two-year program and will be taught jointly by the two universities at the Doha Institute\u2019s campus in Qatar. \nThe program, held in English, provides experienced leaders from private, public, and non-profit sectors the opportunity to develop their management skills across all of these areas. While leading universities in the U.S. have been increasingly forging such alliances, this is the first time such a program has come to the Middle East. The program builds on the Qatar National Vision 2030, which seeks to diversify the economy by enhancing the private sector, thus encouraging and maintaining its competitiveness. This results in greater interaction between the public and private sectors and the need for professionals with the skills, knowledge, and flexibility to work and lead in either sector. Graduates from the program will be equipped with sound theoretical knowledge and expertise as well as advanced analytical and management skills. They are expected to hold leadership positions at the interface of business and governance. \u201cIn an increasingly interdependent world, we need responsible managers who can lead effectively at the interface between politics, business, and society. We are delighted to be the first to bring this exceptional dual degree to the Middle East. It combines the profound expertise and knowledge of our two highly recognized universities,\u201d said ESMT President J\u00f6rg Rocholl. The Executive MBA/MPA combines two internationally renowned, successful programs: the EMBA from ESMT and the EMPA from the Doha Institute. The two-year program is modular and can be completed while continuing to work. Modules will take place once per month over three or four days. Most of the courses will be held in Doha, with one core module in Berlin, as well as the opportunity for participants to study at partner institutions in ESMT\u2019s network. Application requirements include a university degree, professional experience of at least five years, as well as very good English skills. The program will start in September 2018. Applications are currently being accepted by the Doha Institute. Press contact Martha Ihlbrock, +49 (0)30 21231-1043, Ulrike Schwarzberg, +49 (0)30 21231-1066, About ESMT Berlin ESMT Berlin was founded by 25 leading global companies and institutions. The international business school offers a full-time MBA, an executive MBA, a master\u2019s in management, as well as open enrollment and customized executive education programs. ESMT focuses on three main topics: leadership and social responsibility, European competitiveness, and the management of technology. ESMT faculty publishes in top academic journals. Additionally, the business school provides an interdisciplinary platform for discourse between politics, business, and academia. The business school is based in Berlin, Germany, with Schloss Gracht as an additional location near Cologne. ESMT is a private business school with the right to grant PhDs and is accredited by the German state, AACSB, AMBA, EQUIS, and FIBAA. http://www.esmt.org Weitere Informationen: \nhttps://press.esmt.org/press_release/dual_degree_program_qatar - Link to press release https://www.esmt.org/degree-programs/emba-esmt-berlin - More information about the EMBA program at ESMT Berlin https://www.esmt.org/ - More information about ESMT Berlin \nMerkmale dieser Pressemitteilung: Journalisten, Studierende, Wirtschaftsvertreter, Wissenschaftler, jedermann Politik, Wirtschaft", "Michalina", "published": "2018-03-22T05:52:00.000+02:00", "title": "A Guide to Syrian Creatives, Projects & Places in Berlin", "text": "photo: Bernhard Musil \nFor a new feature from our series of articles presenting different cultures in Berlin that already featured the Greeks , Poles , or the Turkish people we want to showcase some of the most interesting things that Syrian people have brought to Berlin. Our listicle is simply brimming with versatile talent \u2013 among others we\u2019ve got a Youtuber, several artists, writers and dancers, and \u2013 of course \u2013 a DJ. \nWe also highlight a bunch of great social initiatives created either by or in cooperation with Syrians that you shouldn\u2019t miss. Last but not least, scroll right to the bottom of the article to find the best locations for Syrian food that Berlin has to offer! People \nHanin Elias \nBerlin loves Hanin Elias \u2013 after all, this Syrian German musician is a riot grrrl with a penchant for industrial and techno. She first gained recognition as a member of Atari Teenage Riot, and has never backed down since then \u2013 continuing to create music under her very own label, Fatal Recordings , and collaborating with the likes of Le Tigre, Thurston Moore, J Mascis, Alexander Hacke, Merzbow, and Alec Empire. photo: Hanin Elias \nFiras Alshater \nFiras Alshater is one of the most iconic Berlin personalities. He came to the city back in 2013 when he was 22. His arrival was preceded by events that would crumble many. Back in Syria, he was captured multiple times and tortured by Assad\u2019s secret police because of his videos documenting the progress of the events that commenced with the Arab Spring. When he was granted an asylum in Germany, he continued to express himself with a camera, and \u2013 astonishingly \u2013 he was able to employ comedy even when tackling some very important issues. You might have already seen the video of him standing blindfolded on Alex with a sign that said: \u201dI am a Syrian refugee. I trust you \u2013 do you trust me? Hug me!\u201d. Unsurprisingly, his YouTube channel got him quite a following and now Firas has also written an autobiography \u2013\u201dIch komm auf Deutschland zu: Ein Syrer \u00fcber seine neue Heimat\u201d. photo: Firas Alshater \nWafa Mustafa \nWafa was born in 1990 in Syria and came to Germany in 2016. Before that, she lived in Turkey for a few years after having escaped Syria where she was starting to experience ruthless repercussions of her involvement in activism. In Berlin, she\u2019s a journalist and a student at the Bard College, where she has exhibited her unique video installation featuring literary texts \u2013 you can read one of the text included in the installation here (in German). Here you can find out more about Wafa herself. photo: Tamar Maare \nHaidar A. Darwish \nThe talented and charming Haidar A. Darwish is spicing up the queer scene of Berlin even more with his belly dance performances! He arrived in Berlin in 2016 and managed to balance out the everyday life struggle of a newcomer with honing his skills as a dancer fusing different styles such as voguing, hip hop and traditional belly dance. He\u2019s already performed all over the city, participated in the Berlin documentary film Berlin Is Burning and is part of the newly formed House of Arise. If you want to see him perform check out his monthly show with Drag Queen Judy La Divina at Silverfuture. photo: Kiko Dionisio \nKhaled Barakeh \nKhaled Barakeh is a graduate of the Faculty of Fine Arts in Damascus, Syria who completed his MFA at Funen Art Academy in 2010 in Odense, Denmark. He\u2019s an internationally acclaimed artist whose works have been exhibited at numerous galleries, including the K\u00fcnstlerhaus Stuttgart; Kunsthalle Brandts; Ovegarden, Denmark and Smack Mellon in New York City among others. He\u2019s the founder and director of Syria Cultural Index , an online platform founded in response to the sudden displacement of Syrian cultural producers. The SCI functions both as an online gallery and a professional social network, emerging as a valuable tool for Syrian creative practitioners. photo: Gav Connolly \nWidad Nabi \nWidad Nabi was born in the Syrian city of Kobani in 1985. After acquiring a business degree from the University of Aleppo, she focused on literature and poetry, including writing many contributions to Arabic newspapers and magazines. Widad has published two books \u2013\u201dTime for love, time for war\u201d in Aleppo in 2013, and \u201dSyria and the futility of death\u201d in Beirut in 2016. You can read her article \u201dIntegration is the search for common ground\u201d translated into English here . photo: Widad Nabi \nRafat Alzakout \nRafat Alzakout was born in Syria and graduated in 2003 from the Higher Institute of Dramatic Arts in Damascus with a degree in theater acting. He then commenced his professional career as a theater actor and director. In 2012, he started working on \u201dHome\u201d\u2013 his first featured documentary touching on friendship, hope, and artistic expression all affected by the Syrian political turmoil. Since November 2015, Alzakout lives in Berlin. In 2017, he directed \u201dYour Love is Fire\u201d \u2013 the world premiere of the new play by ayoung Syrian author Mudar Alhaggi. photo: Rafat Alzakout \nAnna Banout \nAnna Banout is a Syrian-Polish designer who\u2019s based in Berlin. She\u2019s passionate about design in all of its forms and it shows in her diverse projects. Some of them include the elaborate award winning project SYRIA 2087 , a short film on identity and a zine that cherishes the memories evoked by different corners of the world . You should definitely check out the QANANI project, which combines the traditional craft of weaving with upcycling technology. The idea behind it is empowering Syrian women by providing them with ways to handcraft aesthetically appealing objects of everyday use from plastic waste. photo: Kinga Budnik \nSyriantal \nAlaa Khalil was born in Damascus. In Berlin, he became working as a DJ and musician. His stage name \u2013 Syriantal \u2013 merges \u201dSyria\u201d\u2013 his country of origin and \u201doriental\u201d\u2013 his favorite music genre, two words that were vital in shaping his identity. The list of venues he\u2019s played in is expanding all the time, and already features classics like Ritter Butzke, Birgit&Bier, or SO36. photo: Syriantal \nIman Hasbani \nIman Hasbani is an installation and performance artist. She was born in Swidaa in Syria and studied at the Damascus University. Over the years, she took part in numerous collective exhibitions in multiple Syrian cities. Before she came to Berlin, Iman Hasbani was working using art therapy to help children who had been affected by the war in Syria and later took up an artist residency in Beirut. You can watch her 2013 art performance in Art Residence Aley here . photo: Iman Hasbani \nMedhat Aldaabal, Moufak Aldoabl, Amr Karkout \nAfter studying at the Higher Institute for Dramatic Arts in Damascus the three Syrian dancers Medhat Aldaabal, Moufak Aldoabl and Amr Karkout all arrived in Berlin to find a new destiny for themselves and their art. \nIn addition to dance, Medhat also studied medicine and made his long and difficult way to Berlin by foot through Macedonia and Serbia. Moufak worked at the Jollanar Dance Theatre in Damascus before having to leave the country in 2015. Apart from teaching at his art school and choreographing for the opera, Amr was dancing for the Sima Dance Company and Koon Theater Group. With the latter, he came for a guest appearance to Brandenburg and decided to stay in Germany. \nIn December 2017, with the support of choreographer Nir de Volff , the three of them adapted their stories for the dance piece \u201cCome As You Are\u201d performed at DOCK11 (next shows on June 10 & 11, 2018). In July you can also see Medhat and Moufak as part of the piece AMAL (\u201chope\u201d) at Radialsystem V. Come As You Are, photo: Bernhard Musil \nInitiatives \nBaynatna The Arabic Library \nBaynatna, the Arabic Library functions like a typical library, granting people access to literature in Syrian, German and English, but at the same time, it serves an even higher purpose. It is a non-profit association focusing on civil education, a meeting point promoting cultural exchange through various events like readings, concerts and workshops. One of its initiators is the activist Muhannad Qaiconie who studied Translation at Tishreen University in Syria, and is now studying Humanities, Arts and Social Thought at Bard College Berlin. \nBaynatna The Arabic Library , Breite Str. 36, 10178 Berlin \u2013 Mitte photo: Baynatna \nQueens Against Borders \nQueens Against Borders is a fabulous Berlin initiative to show solidarity with trans and queer refugees. It\u2019s a semi-regular fundraiser performance party hosted by Olympia Bukkakis and Diva Magay and always headlined by some of the town\u2019s most cherished queens and performers \u2013 several of them from Syria. The event promotes connections between drag, trans* and queer performance artists among refugees and drag and queer performers who are already familiar with the city. The next edition is coming up on March 29th in SO36! Needless to say, you should be there \u2013 not only will it be pure pleasure but also for a great cause! . Food \nKonditorei Damaskus \nThe Konditorei Damaskus at Sonnenallee 93 was opened by Tamem Al Sakka from Syria. Together with his family he left the city of Homs 5 years ago to flee from the war. It took them 2 years to get to Berlin through Lebanon and Egypt. Back in Homs, Tamem Al Sakka used to run a bakery with his family. He tried to do the same in Berlin and it turned out to be a sweet success! Try it for yourself \u2013 you can choose from a variety of delicious home made pastries and sweets, including all traditional Mabrumah with pistachios, Baklava, Shaybiyat and Asabe. \nKonditorei Damaskus, Sonnenallee 93, 12045 Berlin \u2013 Neuk\u00f6lln . \nKreuzberger Himmel \nThe \u201dKreuzberg Heaven\u201d is a unique place which fosters integration of the community like few others. How so? The team preparing and serving the traditional Syrian food includes refugees from Syria, Pakistan, Iraq and Afghanistan. The organization behind this wonderful project is Be an Angel \u2013 striving to help people with the integration process for over two years now. \nKreuzberger Himmel , Yorckstra\u00dfe 89, 10965 Berlin \u2013 Kreuzberg photo: Kreuzberger Himmel \nBerlinaskus \nThis cool booth appearing on Street Food Thursdays at the renowned Markthalle Neun merges the taste of Damascus with Berlin\u2019s inventive approach. The results include delicious creations such as crunchy nuts knafeh, vegetarian fatteh or toshka sandwich. \nBerlinaskus , Eisenbahnstra\u00dfe 42/43, 10997 Berlin \u2013 Kreuzberg photo: Berlinaskus Shaam \nRumors are circulating that this here is the hands off best Shawarma place in town. Needless to say, the menu also includes fries and even a veggie falafel for the vegan souls out there. \nShaam , Karl-Marx-Stra\u00dfe 177, 12043 Berlin \u2013 Neuk\u00f6lln photo: Shaam \nMandi \nEven if you don\u2019t live in Wedding, this Syrian cuisine place will reward your commute. It\u2019s not a cheap fast food place, but rather a relaxed restaurant where you can try authentic middle eastern dishes. \nMandi , Seestra\u00dfe 57, 13347 Berlin-Wedding photo: Mandi", Afghanistan Europe By our dpa-correspondent and Berlin (dpa) - The German Army\u2018s missions in Iraq and Afghanistan are to be expanded and topped up with more troops after being approved in the German Parliament on Thursday.In Iraq, the fight against the terrorist militia Islamic State will be expanded to the whole country. Until now the training mission has been limited to the country\u2018s northern Kurdish region. The total number of German soldiers to be involved in the Iraq mission will be 800. In Afghanistan, the number of German troops will boosted from 980 to 1,300. It is the second such increase since NATO officially ended its operation in the country in 2013.In two separate votes, a majority of German parliamentarians voted to approve the changes.", "author": "abongard@automotiveIT.com", "published": "2018-03-22T13:02:00.000+02:00", "title": "VW CIO cites big potential of artificial intelligence for car industry", "text": "VW CIO cites big potential of artificial intelligence for car industry March 22, 2018 VW CIO Hofmann says AI \u201cwill make completely new things possible\u201d \nBERLIN \u2013The auto industry, with its growing complexity, offers \u201cnearly perfect conditions for applied artificial intelligence,\u201d VW Group CIO Martin Hofmann said Thursday. \nThe German carmaker, is involved with various projects all aimed at implementing new AI Technologies. These should be used to complement human workers and not take their place, Hofmann said. \n\u201cAlgorithms should not replace humans, but should take over assignments that cannot be solved by humans,\u201d he said. \nThe VW executive expressed optimism about the technology\u2019s potential. \u201cAI will make completely new things possible,\u201d he said. \nHofmann cited inspiration from Isaac Asimov\u2019s 1950 book \u201cI, Robot,\u201d which described a future with multitude of tasks assumed by robots. Asimov stated three basic principles for robots: They should never injure humans, obey orders and protect their own existence. These three principles also broadly apply to AI, Hofmann said. \nThe VW CIO also discussed the potential of Quantum computing-based machine learning, a new area that would allow machine learning to progress faster than is currently possible. Such an approach could help deal with growing data volumes in the auto industry. \nAI can also help when relatively few data are available for analysis, Hofmann said. -By Arjen Bongard", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "isaac asimov", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "hofmann", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "asimov", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "vw cio", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "vw cio hofmann", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "vw", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "vw group cio martin hofmann", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "berlin", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T03:08:24.009+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "8a2dc93c34946dbf03be62c71f5cca4affa3c47d", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZTafqxhGxxJJr6vLYsHhBr4.CvP9U0Sj_BARLB2OkQhckSE7HtAMxIWgyaEAziAqT.b1fiFQTyUfMJTCDf2Li5P0RIcm.EGmQV.Q_4_Q3L6cjoLsO1KvyLpedbVH7IA8h.JC9.ggr1fSa7wCpfokZGyPH2rzKZZoIA-", "site_full": "www.mdr.de", "site": "mdr.de", "site_section": "http://www.mdr.de/Media/podcast/4268635-podcast.xml", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "MDR KULTUR Peter Zudeicks Woche in Berlin", "title": "Peter Zudeick - Die Woche in Berlin vom 23. "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Anna Harrington", "published": "2018-03-23T22:49:00.000+03:00", "title": "Katie Brennan: Western Bulldogs captain called up on stage, AFLW Grand Final", "text": "IF Katie\u2019s Brennan\u2019s arduous week took its toll on the Western Bulldogs, it didn\u2019t show on grand final day. In bizarre scenes during the week, the Bulldogs cited Bob Murphy missing the 2016 grand final triumph as a reason Brennan should be allowed to play.\nAnd while Brennan\u2019s suspension was held up, on Saturday, the Bulldogs captain had her chance to emulate Murphy.\nThe Bulldogs, led by stand-in skipper Ellie Blackburn, turned on a brilliant third quarter to defeat Brisbane by six points.\n ", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": ["http://pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/clk?id=4609140175&iu=/7414"], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "katie brennan", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "katie", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "brennan", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "bob murphy", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "murphy", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "ellie blackburn", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "western bulldogs", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "bulldogs", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "brisbane", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-24T13:06:07.006+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "df134267badfe5d5678022e643d2ba8f929484e3", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg9V_QWj8UdBdroWTkaxDr0z1ga0RrcXrhmkJ9JgWC0Aal4x6P43rOi2k8U_B2EhoR4V.vbCAcMaNbqHskkHQDqAvmWrnfHz59Poh58DKLd3VSYWpZZAcN2mSDwyic5W5pmg1uXNzTERJaKoQElRKHS45tBYLlJeFAc-", "site_full": "www.couriermail.com.au", "site": "couriermail.com.au", "site_section": "http://www.couriermail.com.au/?nk=5162a072513ccc481add9bdcc46645ed-1521882555", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "The Courier Mail | Breaking News Headlines for Brisbane and Queensland | Courier Mail", "title": "Miles: QLD\u2019s coal seam ghost town | Photos | The Courier-Mail", "title_full": "Miles: QLD\u2019s coal seam ghost town | Photos | The Courier-Mail", "published": "2018-03-23T18:06:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "AU", "spam_score": 0.003, "main_image": "http://cdn.newsapi.com.au/image/v1/aaf6868ecf0f8771c8d9aa472b949026", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 14432, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 1273, "comments": 0, "shares": 1273}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "df134267badfe5d5678022e643d2ba8f929484e3", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg9V_QWj8UdBdroWTkaxDr0z1ga0RrcXrhmkJ9JgWC0Aal4x6P43rOi2k8U_B2EhoR4V.vbCAcMaNbqHskkHQDqAvmWrnfHz59Poh58DKLd3VSYWpZZAcN2mSDwyic5W5pmg1uXNzTERJaKoQElRKHS45tBYLlJeFAc-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Gemma Clarke, news.com.au", "published": "2018-03-23T18:06:00.000+03:00", "title": "Miles: QLD\u2019s coal seam ghost town | Photos | The Courier-Mail", "text": "Close The ghost town of Wittenoom 3:51\nThe Project takes a look at the WA ghost town of Wittenoom, officially closed due to asbestos contamination but still home to a few dedicated souls. Courtesy The Project\nMay 17th 2015 3 years ago /display/newscorpaustralia.com/Web/NewsNetwork/Network News/National/ The ghost town of Wittenoom Mining Miles: The Coal Seam Ghost Town Gemma Clarke, news.com.au March 24, 2018 12:06pm\nIT\u2019S 32C in Miles, Queensland, and everyone on the bus is in desperate need of a swim.\n\u201cThere\u2019s a pool,\u201d said Ken Brown, gesturing out the window.\nHe\u2019s not joking: In front of the skeleton of a house he\u2019s driving past, there is a ladder and a rim of coping tiles. But the pool is filled with dirt and scattered with weeds.\nBorn and raised in the Western Downs, Mr Brown is a full-time bus driver. Today, he\u2019s showing a group of farmers around his hometown, Miles, 330km northwest of Brisbane.\nUnlike Mr Brown, these farmers are not from Queensland. They live on properties in New South Wales and South Australia that may soon be impacted by coal seam or shale gas infrastructure. Many are on the high pressure pipeline route from Santos\u2019 controversial proposed Narrabri Gas Project.\nAwaiting the approval of such projects, the farmers are embarking on a four-day tour of southwest Queensland for a first-hand look at its gas infrastructure and the social consequences of boom-bust mining economies.\nmedia_camera Unfortunately for Miles, abandoned houses (and pools) are now common. Picture: Gemma Clarke\nThough it\u2019s not a mining town, Miles was part of southwest Queensland\u2019s coal seam gas construction boom. The explosion in exploration and mining activity in its surrounding areas saw a huge influx in workforce demand and fly-in-fly-out workers from around 2010.\n\u201cGISERA (The CSIRO\u2019s Gas Industry Social & Environmental Research Alliance) put out these fantastic figures,\u201d said David Sweetapple. He\u2019s a real estate agent and land developer in Miles, and has lived in the region for 60 years.\n\u201cThey said they would need accommodation and infrastructure built, and feeding and entertaining. They said we will live locally and buy locally. So the town went wild. The banks lent us all money \u2014 the council spent $30 million in Miles alone on water sewerage and waste management,\u201d Mr Sweetapple said, referring to the time around 2008 when the initial presentation from APLNG (Australia Pacific LNG, Origin Energy\u2019s joint venture with ConocoPhillips and Sinopec) was made.\nExisting homeowners with a patch of backyard to spare subdivided their blocks into two, and towers of flats began to loom over old Queenslanders. Developers and investors flooded in from all over Australia, and there was a surge in new housing with 1500 new homes approved.\nmedia_camera Even new homes have little chance of being sold, at least for nowhere near what they were purchased for. Picture: Gemma Clarke\n\u201cIt was like being caught in a gold rush,\u201d said local Rachel Kerwick. She\u2019s president of the Miles & Districts Chamber of Commerce, a role she has shared since its inception in 2005 with fellow community member John Hoffman.\n\u201cThere were investors from Melbourne and Sydney, well-educated people who did their homework and believed the literature the government and the CSIRO all put out,\u201d Ms Kerwick said.\nThat literature included an environmental impact statement, a future directions statement, and a social impact management plan, a detailed document that outlines how APLNG would mitigate the social impacts that arise from their work in the Western Downs region.\nMiles\u2019s population was projected to increase to 5000 people, and a growth in the workforce was predicted to continue until 2034.\n\u201cThey were talking about the town of Miles and Chinchilla actually merging,\u201d said Mr Sweetapple.\nFor locals leasing housing, the immediate effect of the boom was a rent increase.\nMr Brown set a scene as the bus winds through a half-finished estate behind the racecourse.\n\u201cImagine you\u2019ve got a son who finishes school and wants to stay around. He gets a job at the local council, where he can make a weekly salary of $700, and he doesn\u2019t bother buying, because he can rent for $300 a week. His wife works at the tuckshop; the kids are in the swimming club. Then the miners move in, and the agent knocks on his door and says, \u2018Sorry mate, but we can get $800 for this place now.\u2019 So your son and his family leave town.\u201d\nAccording to Mr Sweetapple, one look at property and housing prices during the boom will show that Mr Brown\u2019s scenario is not hard to picture.\n\u201cYou\u2019d buy a block for $200,000,\u201d Mr Sweetapple explained, \u201cand spend $450,000 on a really nice house; put in Colorbond fencing and paving. The rent at the time was $800 to $1000 a week.\u201d\nAt the peak of the boom, even a space at one of the local caravan parks crept up to nearly $1000 per week. Long-term residents who could no longer afford the rent moved out.\nBut when the construction phase of all major coal seam gas projects progressed to the export phase, many mining contractors and employees were laid off. And once the Condabri workers camp that many of them were living in was emptied, the overflow of those renting in Miles were shifted to fill the camp\u2019s 400 beds.\nmedia_camera Not only have houses been abandoned, but businesses as well. Picture: Gemma Clarke\n\u201cOrigin walked into our real estate office one day at the end of 2013 and said, \u2018We\u2019re cancelling every lease of the houses we have. If anyone wants a job, they have to live in the camp,\u2019\u201d said Mr Sweetapple. \u201cVirtually overnight, in December 2013, the town just drained out of people and they never came back.\u201d\nAs per APLNG\u2019s social impact management plan, construction workers are often accommodated in temporary facilities like Condabri to help ensure that community demographics in regional towns are not negatively impacted from an influx of new residents. But given that more than 100 workers were initially housed in Miles to begin with, their absence was felt immediately.\n\u201cWe had hundreds living in a camp less than 25km from our town for years,\u201d Ms Kerwick said, \u201cand they never even came in. They might have driven through the community on their way to work, and occasionally, if we were doing a community event like the races, they\u2019d send a busload of people in, but that was it.\u201d\nMr Sweetapple too is frustrated about the mining companies\u2019 failure to engage with the town in the way they promised in the APLNG documents published in 2010 and 2011.\n\u201cHaving told us they were going to live local and buy local, they then said, \u2018Local for us is camps out of town. We\u2019re living in the area.\u2019 As for buy local, they said, \u2018We\u2019re a multinational company. We\u2019re APLNG and local for us is Australia and New Zealand, not Miles and Chinchilla.\u201d\nFor its part, an Origin spokesman told news.com.au: \u201cOrigin, as Upstream Operator of Australia Pacific LNG, is proud to have committed tens of millions of dollars to support local communities such as Miles, and remains committed to the region by continuing to provide incentives for our staff to live locally and by sourcing local goods and services through our \u2018Regional Buy\u2019 program.\u201d\nHe added Origin has spent millions of dollars to benefit the local community, including investing $2,000,000 into a community skills scholarship, providing up to $13,500 to apprentices within the gas fields region to help them complete their apprenticeships locally. Since 2007, more than 150 scholarships have been awarded. Origin has also invested in housing, plus water and sewage upgrades in the region, and upgraded the local airport to the tune of $20 million among other projects.\nAccording to Mr Brown, the only people who will benefit from a boom are publicans, local councillors, real estate agents and investors.\n\u201cThe local drapery store won\u2019t, [the mining workers] won\u2019t buy shirts from there. They\u2019re nomadic. They move around all the time and follow the work. And if someone does bring his family, do you think his wife is going to work in the school tuckshop?\u201d\nAfter the last of the mining workers were shifted out to Condabri, the vacancy rate in Miles rose to 45 per cent, where it stayed at for several years.\n\u201cRents were down to $150 a week for those fortunate to have it,\u201d Mr Sweetapple said. \u201cThat was furnished apartments, furnished houses.\u201d\nAccording to Ms Kerwick, some people just walked out, and those who stayed all suffered financially.\nmedia_camera Farmers from NSW and SA inspecting the coal seam projects near Miles. Picture: Gemma Clarke\n\u201cWe\u2019re left with people whose businesses went bankrupt and who lost their homes because they took the punt and invested in building another one. Mortgages and repossessions are happening at least once a week,\u201d she said.\nThe incomplete estate behind the racecourse Mr Brown drives through is owned by Mr Sweetapple. It still has four stages of completion to go, but construction has halted.\n\u201cIn my estate, there have been three of four mortgage and repossession sales, and they\u2019ve sold for $20,000 to $22,000 a block,\u201d the real estate agent said.\nToday, Miles\u2019 population stands at just 1800, a number that now has to front the cost for the $30 million worth of infrastructure they no longer actually need. Mr Sweetapple said the rates on the properties he owns in town have doubled in the last four years.\n\u201cWe have even less people than we did before [the boom],\u201d said Ms Kerwick. \u201cThe Miles community itself was almost decimated. Brand new homes that cost the investor $700,000 to build are being sold for $200,000.\u201d\nMr Brown tells a story about his neighbour, a woman from interstate who bought the house next door to his for $400,000.\n\u201cShe subdivided the block and developed it, then just sold them both: one for $200,000 and the other for $160,000,\u201d he said.\nAccording to Mr Sweetapple, the aftermath of the mining boom completely killed the market.\n\u201cThe rents plummeted, the property values plummeted and they kept the camp full. That\u2019s when I read very carefully through all the Origin lease documents and the approvals granted by the Coordinator-General,\u201d he said.\nIn 2016, Mr Sweetapple discovered a condition in Origin\u2019s 2010 Environmental Impact Statement that said under no circumstances can a temporary workers accommodation facility exist beyond five years.\nmedia_camera The town has been left with plenty of vacant lots when businesses left town. Picture: Gemma Clarke\n\u201cThey were in breach already. [The Miles & Districts Chamber of Commerce] got more and more politically active, and we met with [Origin\u2019s] CEO eight times. He basically said that if you make it difficult for us, we\u2019ll make it doubly difficult for you.\u201d\nThen in May 2017, after months of negotiations, the multinational corporation announced that it would close its Condabri workers camp for good later that year. Origin\u2019s remaining operations staff would have to move into local accommodation arrangements in Miles, as well as in neighbouring towns such as Chinchilla.\n\u201cHad we not as a community fought that very hard, they\u2019d still be in that camp,\u201d said Mr Sweetapple.\nIn August last year, the Queensland government legislated against workforces on large resource projects within 125km of regional communities being 100 per cent fly-in-fly-out workers.\nAccording to the government\u2019s social impact statement, the Strong and Sustainable Resource Communities Act was introduced to \u201censure that residents of communities in the vicinity of large resource projects benefit from their construction and operation\u201d.\n\u201cStraight away you could see the difference,\u201d said Ms Kerwick. \u201cThey can still build a camp, but it has to be within the town. In Chinchilla, the camp is in the fringes of the community, so the people can go to the town gym, use the town pool, go to the pub a couple of nights a week if they don\u2019t want to have tea at the camp.\u201d\n\u201cIt\u2019s a massive positive,\u201d said Mr Sweetapple, \u201cbut it hasn\u2019t come without its own problems.\u201d\nWhile in the camp, a worker\u2019s living expenses are completely covered.\n\u201cYou\u2019re flown in and out, you\u2019re given whatever you want to eat or drink. Your electricity, your cleaning, your internet is all covered. You want for nothing.\u201d\nBut now that workers in the Miles region are no longer allowed to reside in a camp away from town, living away from home allowances have been slashed.\n\u201cBy the time [the workers] pay tax, they end up with $153 extra a week. That\u2019s got to provide [everything]. They come into our office and say, \u2018How the hell am I going to survive on this money?\u2019\n\u201cIt\u2019s already hard \u2014 they\u2019re away from their families trying to make a living, and suddenly they\u2019ve got to come up with this extra money to compensate for what they had in the camp.\u201d\nWhen Mr Brown is asked who is left in Miles, and what he thinks of the town\u2019s future, he is largely optimistic, though complains about the lack of social services in place to support many of the low-income earners who have moved in to take advantage of the cheap rent.\n\u201cThere\u2019s a good vibe mostly,\u201d he said. \u201cThere are just too many empty houses. Who is going to live in them? There\u2019s no work.\u201d\nmedia_camera The town is more than half an hour drive from Chinchilla, and with little work in town, many locals have abandoned Miles.\nBut Mr Sweetapple said new projects are on the horizon.\n\u201cMiles is in the Goldilocks zone \u2014 we\u2019re very close to the power grid and we get the most sunlight. All those substations are in place to receive some of the renewable energy that\u2019s being produced by the solar farms,\u201d he said.\n\u201cYou\u2019ve got massive upgrades to the power infrastructure to receive all this solar energy. The rail line has to be built from Miles to Banana, Nathan Dam has to be constructed and a big pipeline is needed to droughtproof the town.\u201d\n\u201cThere is a bit of optimism around again \u2014 not enough for spectators, but enough.\u201d\nAs for the gas industry?\n\u201cOrigin has offered [its workers] a very generous incentive,\u201d Mr Sweetapple said. \u201cThe average guy will get about $35,000 extra a year if he buys locally. But no one is doing it because they don\u2019t know week to week if they\u2019ll have a job. There\u2019s been a big restructuring \u2014 Origin is trying to wind back its costs, so they\u2019ve laid off hundreds of staff. The last thing any workers want to do then is buy a house in Miles and get caught with it.\n\u201cUnless [the workers] are forced to pay for their flights in and out or the government intervenes, I don\u2019t think there\u2019ll be any change. [The coal seam gas industry] has been a complete and utter disaster for the town.\u201d\nMr Sweetapple said he recently received a survey from a company contracted by Santos to assess its community impacts. In 2007, Santos created the GLNG project, which converts natural gas from the Surat and Bowen Basins into LNG for export to Asia.\n\u201cIt said, \u2018Santos has donated $630,000 to the region. Do you agree, disagree or strongly disagree?\u2019 If they\u2019d said, \u2018Santos has spent $630,000 \u2014 can you see where it\u2019s gone?\u2019 or, \u2018What impact has this company had on your community?\u2019 it would have been good, but there was nothing like that.\u201d\nmedia_camera Tony van Lubeck and Tony Smith inspecting a property outside Miles while researching what can happen to a former boom town.\nInstead, Mr Sweetapple made his own survey, and circulated it among 100 people in Miles. Using a company statement that discussed the mitigation of impact on communities, he apportioned the exact wording of the text with a line down the middle.\n\u201cI asked \u20181 out 10, how well did this company do in Miles?\u2019 The highest score they got was a 4. I sent that to the Coordinator-General. He said, \u2018Oh no, that\u2019s not an official survey.\u2019\u201d\nAccording to the APLNG\u2019s community investment action plan, the multinational corporation is dedicated to funding social infrastructure, as well as sponsoring and donating to local organisations\u2019 projects or events. They also aim to foster dialogue with communities, which is a commitment Mr Sweetapple said Origin\u2019s regional manager, Tim Ogilvie, has fulfilled.\n\u201cTim has been very understanding of [Miles\u2019] cause \u2026 he attends Chamber meetings and has met with us regularly. It\u2019s directives from senior executives that have caused so much financial and emotional hardship.\u201d\nMs Kerwick said big players like Origin have failed to adequately assist the community.\n\u201cThey splashed their money and gave some clubs laptops, but they never built any sustainable projects,\u201d she said. \u201cOnly now that [The Miles & Districts Chamber of Commerce] has fought for money we can do a few legacy projects, but the whole thing was handled very poorly.\u201d\n\u201cYou can see why the community feels like it does,\u201d said David. \u201cThe gas companies have damaged the very fabric of our town. We were all encouraged to gear up to provide for 40 years of partnership with the resource companies. But they only use tier-1 and tier-2 contractors \u2014 they don\u2019t use the locals.\u201d\nAs the bus tour winds down, Mr Brown returns his passenger to the local museum so they can continue on to Roma. The mood in the car is sombre.\n\u201cThe gas industry\u2019s claims are pretty false that there\u2019s not much impact,\u201d said Tony Smith of Broadwater in Warren, NSW. \u201cIt\u2019s as much social as it is environmental. If you look at the town of Tara, it didn\u2019t seem to gain. The destruction of Miles is terrible. Greed got in the way, and now there are all those empty houses.\u201d\nMs Sweetapple said that farmers like Mr Smith, who will be directly impacted by the proposed 450km pipeline that will link the Moomba Sydney Pipeline to the planned Narrabri Gas Project, should think very carefully before signing anything.\n\u201cWhat\u2019s happened in the town is the most devastating thing,\u201d he said. \u201cIf any community was considering it, I\u2019d seriously say don\u2019t do it. Don\u2019t get involved. Don\u2019t believe a word they say. Don\u2019t believe anything Treasury says. It\u2019s all a gross misrepresentation.\u201d\nNews.com.au has contacted ConocoPhillips for comment.\n Ghost town: Everyone\u2019s gone\n ", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZS85jFjidQBhn_NLTwMkhniGI0PfstnNcr6tc3HQzXz_wmfBIv_pGPe4KAMpGmvGR5JCiJB0Pkc.JRogyjiGcaLQmFyu34AGh3wBqosmjiuqQ90RUk.oGqS4pjpxZM.ubi9_jPkSBRb6yNE86zwhmwhsU2T67_azDo-", "site_full": "www.smh.com.au", "site": "smh.com.au", "site_section": "http://feeds.brisbanetimes.com.au/rssheadlines/top.xml", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "Brisbane Times - Latest News", "title": "'We got it wrong': NRL says match-gifting penalty shouldn't have been given", "title_full": "'We got it wrong': NRL says match-gifting penalty shouldn't have been given", "published": "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Adrian Proszenko", "published": "2018-03-24T04:26:00.000+03:00", "title": "'We got it wrong': NRL says match-gifting penalty shouldn't have been given", "text": "'We got it wrong': NRL says match-gifting penalty shouldn't have been given By Adrian Proszenko & Adam Pengilly 24 March 2018 \u2014 12:26pm Larger text size Very large text size The NRL has conceded the match-deciding penalty call against Wests Tigers on Friday night against Brisbane was \"incorrect\" as the whistleblowers come under further scrutiny after a controversial start to the season. Referee Ashley Klein penalised Tigers forward Robbie Rochow for not standing square at marker in the sixth minute of golden point. Broncos winger Jamayne Isaako kicked the penalty goal to hand his side a 9-7 victory. The decision stunned Tigers coach Ivan Cleary and shattered his side\u2019s hopes of an unbeaten start to the season. Play Video Having reviewed the decision, referees\u2019 boss Bernard Sutton declared his officials got it wrong. \"Ultimately, the penalty was incorrect,\" Sutton told Fairfax Media. \"There are a couple of contributing factors to how the referees came to that decision. Advertisement \"Initially, Robbie Rochow doesn\u2019t start square, but he does adjust as the play-the-ball happens. \"The other thing is when [Joe] Ofahengaue plays the ball, after playing it he steps towards the left. It gives the illusion to the referees that [Robbie] Rochow is standing standing beside, but he actually does adjust to the point where the ball is to be played. \u201cUltimately, it\u2019s incorrect.\u201d Sutton contacted Cleary on Saturday morning to inform the club of the NRL\u2019s verdict on the call. \u201cIvan and I have a reasonable relationship, we talk on a regular basis. We will continue to chat,\u201d Sutton said. \u201cEveryone (Klein and assistant referee Matt Noyen) matched up their information in arriving to that decision. There is no one person responsible.\u201d Asked if either whistleblower was facing the axe given it was a match-deciding blunder, Sutton said: \u201cCertainly we are not considering that at this point. We have another five games to go from the weekend. The big thing for us is to get through the weekend and then sit down on Monday and assess how we have come through each of the eight games. \"Then we can set some direction going forward. We won\u2019t make any consideration on that until we get to the end of the weekend.\" The other man at the centre of the storm, Robbie Rochow, conceded he wasn\u2019t sure if he had transgressed. \"I played every minute of that game and you just don't know,\" Rochow said after the game. \"You're out on your feet - especially during golden point - and I just did my best to get to the kicker. Whether I left early or wasn't square I'm not sure. I didn't know if someone was offside and it's just the decision on the day, isn't it? An exciting finish ended up a fizzer after a penalty, now deemed incorrect, was given. Photo: Dean Lewins \"Once the decision is made - whether it's right or wrong - you can't change the decision. The game was over. Whether he justifies it or not it doesn't matter. \"Just winning off a penalty in golden point is not a thrilling way to win I guess. \"A game like that, the way we played and the way it went at the end I would have been happy with a draw. [Golden point] has obviously got a place in our game, but whether it's during our week to week rounds is up to the game to decide.\" The Broncos were the beneficiaries of another close call when Isaako may have put his foot on the sideline. Sutton said, on the evidence available, he was satisfied with the decision for the touch judge not to put up his flag. There has been a spate of penalties in the opening rounds as officials crack down on the play-the-ball and the 10 metres. The stoppages have upset fans and commentators who feel free-flowing footy has been stifled. However, Sutton remained unapologetic. Loading \"The work they have done on the 10 metres has been really good and what the competition committee has asked us to do,\" Sutton said. \"We\u2019re actually enforcing the rules and have had the same approach to the play-the-balls. What he have seen over three weeks is that the play-the-balls have improved. They are the standards we need to maintain and keep the referees making decisions and refereeing with confidence.\" Sutton said he was still reviewing the Panthers-Bulldogs game and that a verdict hadn\u2019t been reached on whether Moses Mbye\u2019s opening try was the result of an obstruction. Frustrated Panthers coach Anthony Griffin said players would be left with no choice but to take dives to ensure the call went their way.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "2018-03-24T03:31:00.000+03:00", "title": "Bodies found washed up on beach north of Brisbane", "text": "Death of pair found washed up on remote Bribie Island beach being treated as suspicious Updated March 24, 2018 22:35:54 \nThe discovery of the bodies of a man and a woman washed up on the beach at Bribie Island, north of Brisbane, is being treated as suspicious by detectives. Key points: Police say the pair were in the water up to 24 hours Injuries found on bodies, police treating deaths as suspicious Jet ski being linked to the pair found on calm side of island \nThe pair, thought to be aged in their 30s or 40s, were discovered by a passer-by who was inspecting turtle nests on the northern tip of Bribie Island just after 8:00am. \nSenior Sergeant Scott Wiggins from Sunshine Coast police said the bodies were found about 3 kilometres from the northern tip on the ocean side at the high tide mark, and had been in the water for up to 24 hours. \n\"The jet ski that we're linking to this male and female was found on the calm side, the Pumicestone Passage side of the island,\" Sergeant Wiggins said. \n\"By all accounts from some locals around this area, it's fairly common for people to park their tinnies or jet skis in the calm waters of the Pumicestone Passage and walk across Bribie Island to the open side and go for a swim in the surf there.\" Video: Police treating deaths as suspicious after two bodies wash up on Bribie Island (ABC News) \nHe said there were marks on the bodies that detectives were concerned about. \n\"There are some injuries to the bodies but ... we are conducting examinations in relation to those injuries to see if they were caused by the environment.\" \nSergeant Wiggins said the bodies have been removed from the island. Photo: Detectives examining one of the bodies found washed up on Bribie Island. (ABC News) \n\"The most important thing we're trying to do at the moment is try to identify the next of kin ... to let them know what we have found.\" \nThe northern end of Bribie Island is a thin, rugged strip of land that stretches north to a thin passage of water that separates it from Caloundra. \nFour-wheel-drives are only permitted up to a certain point, north of which is a protected environment. \n\"It's a magic part of the world and it's a very sad thing for the community to have something like this happen,\" Sergeant Wiggins said. \nPolice are trying to piece together the movements of the pair immediately before their deaths. \nThey are appealing for information from the public to help them confirm the identity of the man and woman, in particular whether anyone has not returned from a trip to or from Bribie Island.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [], "organizations": [], "locations": [{"name": "brisbane", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "bribie island", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "queensland", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-24T03:56:01.009+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "711d5d85364395d3c73cd4e87e262b3386b2ef60", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZQ5XXeFXTk11mTUs7NkZF3X6llCpdpJdkoB2CoyrwqvvDQ0P5o4H7dEDLBGYgGeOTstXzMGNDWNqGJpwLn8nZlPl8SXIFf20C27m9JGFgLy34rp8j8Vi2kPn7CiTETPUJzF7BABqnBKPp4Oce2FgDdWR8DcFK2NKHrEsa0Y7CyhhNIH7YfaYfk3tWEVufJq2fSiXYNw6RAywVKefrKrndM8IuTIbNlrdpQ-", "site_full": "www.foxsports.com.au", "site": "foxsports.com.au", "site_section": "https://www.foxsports.com.au/nrl", "site_categories": ["rugby", "sports"], "section_title": "NRL | NRL Live Scores | NRL Ladder &amp; "https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/77cc26d0fc8b0f9e8d935a3663c1b1f09d59c578/0_87_3000_1801/master/3000.jpg?w=1200&amp;h=630&amp;q=55&amp;auto=format&amp;usm=12&amp;fit=crop&amp;crop=faces%2Centropy&amp;bm=normal&amp;ba=bottom%2Cleft&amp;blend64=aHR0cHM6Ly91cGxvYWRzLmd1aW0uY28udWsvMjAxOC8wMS8zMS9mYWNlYm9va19kZWZhdWx0LnBuZw&amp;s=730e8e474ae77278de3a98fc2e3e40ba",
