Home", "title": "Underage drivers a menace on roads", "title_full": "Underage drivers a menace on roads", "published": "2018-03-22T21:48:00.000+02:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "IN", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/article23326785.ece/ALTERNATES/LANDSCAPE_615/th23stopcol", "performance_score": 1, "domain_rank": 806, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 116, "comments": 0, "shares": 116}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "db6677753ec2cca7f43df906ccb419558329cc3c", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg9YBD4zSwJdl2k_EbfTSBpdggltjiAzkXfUExY5Ns5BIxVgUEzk_QCs4rUgHwU3YnEoyHlMt7Fs0sJ.Nbj9v62ZahUH0CiOIH._z.zxJsbradhOfb8Go6RcW100v7Vf4S4-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "R. Sivaraman", "published": "2018-03-22T21:48:00.000+02:00", "title": "Underage drivers a menace on roads", "text": "March 23, 2018 01:18   18:49 IST more-in Police complain that nabbing them is not easy and persuasion does not work; onus is on parents, say activists \nJust three days ago, two Class XII students on a high-end bike were caught under the wheels of a container lorry and crushed to death instantaneously on the Ennore Express Highway. \nM. Abhishek of Vysarpadi was riding the bike back home, after finishing the board exams at his school in north Chennai. P. Raj was riding pillion. \nCrashing into the lorry, the duo was thrown off and came under the wheels of the vehicle, and died on the spot. \nTraffic Investigation Officer Chitra said, \u201cThe parents told us that the boys did not pay heed to their words. At least the school could have prevented them from driving the vehicle to the school premises. The accident could have been prevented.\u201d \nOn March 4, a 17-year-old boy, who was riding a high-end bike, knocked down senior citizen who was walking in Tiruninravur, resulting in his death. \nOn January 12, a 16-year-old boy who took his father\u2019s bike hit a 61-year-old woman in Tirumangalam. She was badly injured. \nCause of snarls \nUnderage driving is a major cause of traffic snarls in the city and causes danger to other motorists and pedestrians on the roads. The menace continues unabated, despite efforts by police to spread awareness among students, schools and parents. \nYoung boys in school uniforms are often found driving high-end bikes in a reckless manner, criss-crossing arterial roads and exhibiting their daredevilry, say police. \nThey hide behind big cars or heavy vehicles to escape the attention of the police at signals. \nSchool girls ride bikes too, but they do not race and are not reckless, police officers said. \nM. Radhakrishnan, co-ordinator of Thozhan Foundation, an non-governmental organisation that works for traffic awareness, said, \u201cMany parents feel proud of their children driving motor vehicles on public roads. They think that if their wards learn to drive a vehicle, they can help in doing household chores by running errands and also drive family members to where they want to go. There are many who buy two-wheelers for their children after they pass Class X and four-wheelers after Class XII. Many parents are not aware of the traffic rule that their wards who are under 18 should not drive any motor vehicle above 50 cc.\u201d \nNot an easy task \nRoad users and activists blame police personnel for their inaction in nabbing errant underage drivers but police personnel have different accounts. \nA traffic police inspector said: \u201cNabbing the minor riding a bike is not an easy task. If we chase them, they may fall or skid. That can result in injuries, even death. Also, juveniles cannot be prosecuted like adults. So most youngsters do not understand the seriousness of the issue at all.\u201d \nGiving various suggestions, Vijay Mehta, secretary of Citizens for Safe Roads, a voluntary organisation, said, \u201cParents are providing vehicles to their school-going children and encouraging them to ride. This is very dangerous behaviour. The heads of schools or educational institutions do not bother about law or safety. Police ask the school authorities to prevent the menace. Schools are a better place to check this practice, not the roads. Their parents can be summoned and prosecuted for the offence.\u201d \nAccident compensation \nV.S. Suresh, an advocate, pointed out that it is usually a Herculean task to get compensation for road accident victims in cases of accidents involving vehicles driven by underage persons. \nOn their part, teachers say parents should also be held responsible. \nAjeeth Prasad Jain, adviser, Chennai Sahodaya Schools, said: \u201cMany students park their vehicles at least half a kilometre away from the school and walk. If they bring the vehicles to school, we certainly will take action against them. Parents must be educated first on this and police should initiate action against the owners of the vehicles.\u201d", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "chitra", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "m. abhishek of vysarpadi", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "p. raj", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "ennore express highway", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "tiruninravur", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "chennai", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-22T22:29:56.053+02:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "ceeb1d46ecf4f99ea24adfcc1b8658c24707f8a9", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZTXpRWbKZZiPxvV9jmX_8X26mT_0PetBLV6ihsmPo.8FYiXj3qxy2LhddzN8Z.mr1hpxzAwe8NdokYEvlml0bnzqr_VzOrZvQCyDf0aW_efD5PJnNQgKlr_ERk9Q.GjgOZ8BxoQ3c3K9g--", "site_full": "www.thehindubusinessline.com", "site": "thehindubusinessline.com", "site_section": "http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/?service=rss#", "site_categories": ["financial_news", "finance"], "section_title": "Business Line - Home", "title": "Mumbai, NCR most affected by real estate slowdown", "title_full": "Mumbai, NCR most affected by real estate slowdown", "published": "2018-03-22T18:29:00.000+02:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "IN", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/article23325072.ece/ALTERNATES/LANDSCAPE_615/BL23STATESCENTRALMUMBAI", "performance_score": 0, "domain_rank": 8954, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 23, "comments": 0, "shares": 23}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "ceeb1d46ecf4f99ea24adfcc1b8658c24707f8a9", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZTXpRWbKZZiPxvV9jmX_8X26mT_0PetBLV6ihsmPo.8FYiXj3qxy2LhddzN8Z.mr1hpxzAwe8NdokYEvlml0bnzqr_VzOrZvQCyDf0aW_efD5PJnNQgKlr_ERk9Q.GjgOZ8BxoQ3c3K9g--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Rashmi Pratap", "published": "2018-03-22T18:29:00.000+02:00", "title": "Mumbai, NCR most affected by real estate slowdown", "text": "Developers offering attractive discounts to woo buyers Mumbai, March 22 \nIndia\u2019s two sought-after living destinations \u2013 NCR and Mumbai \u2013 have been the worst hit by the current real estate meltdown. While property prices in Mumbai have fallen for the first time in recent history, NCR has seen the rates plummeting by 6 per cent since 2015 amid waning investor interest and builders sitting over incomplete projects. \nBengaluru and Hyderabad have seen some appreciation, while in Chennai, the price rise has been less than 5 per cent, according to data from the real-estate consultancy, Liases Foras. \u201cNCR has been the worst affected because investor participation, as well as black money deployment, was very high. Prices were absolutely speculative as Delhi has enormous land availability. Moreover, uninhabitable locations were being sold at high prices. The bubble had to burst,\u201d Pankaj Kapoor, founder and MD, Liases Foras, told BusinessLine . \nAmit Oberoi, National Director at Colliers International, points out that investors made up for almost 50 per cent of the buyers in NCR until 2013. \u201cEven before a project was completed, it was flipped twice or thrice between investors, leading to an increase in rates. These people are no longer participating in the market. So sales are shrinking,\u201d he says. \n\n\nSanjay Sharma, Managing Director of Gurgaon-based real-estate consultancy, Qubrex, says the Real Estate (Regulation and Development) Act (RERA) has not been effectively implemented in NCR. \u201cHence, that injection of confidence has not happened. In many places, the property is ready but physical and social infrastructure around it has not developed, depressing the prices,\u201d he says. \nMumbai\u2019s woes \nHowever, Mumbai Metropolitan Region\u2019s (MMR) story has been different. The financial capital saw a rapid rise in new launches from 2009 to 2014, with slum rehabilitation projects bringing in new supply. The proposed Navi Mumbai airport fuelled a real estate boom in the twin city and, along with new development beyond the suburbs, led to a supply glut. \n\u201cIn MMR, the unsold inventory is the highest in the country (2,69,230 units or 48 months). An efficient market maintains 8 to 12 months of inventory, indicating a downward pressure on prices,\u201d said Kapoor. Put simply, MMR requires four years to sell off the existing unsold units. \nSamantak Das, chief economist and national director at Knight Frank India, says: \u201cFor the first time, we have seen a fall in quoted/asking price in Mumbai in 2017. The asking rate in Delhi fell in 2016 itself. The effective price discount through waivers in GST, stamp duty and registration is 10 to 12 per cent in Mumbai and 15 to 17 per cent in Delhi.\u201d \nHe points out that while only 10 to 15 per cent of the projects were earlier giving this discount, now about 85 per cent of the projects are doling them out to improve sales. \u201cDevelopers are trying to complete the projects for which they need to clock sales. There is price resistance in Mumbai, and this price has cracked for the first time. This will infuse a lot of demand,\u201d he says. \nEconomic condition \nSharma says the overall economy is slowing down. \u201cThere is not much money with individuals or businesses to invest. As 2019 elections are approaching, the uncertainty in the market will increase and property prices will be in a limbo,\u201d he says. \nKapoor believes that prices will not rise for the next two years. \u201cI don\u2019t see price rise across markets, as prices are still unaffordable and the pace has to grow further for the market to be sustainable,\u201d he says. \nAccording Knight Frank\u2019s affordability index, the price of a house should not be more than 4.5 times the family income. In Mumbai, it is 7.5 times, and even in Gurugram, it is more than 5 times. These indicators point to a long overdue correction in the market and it seems to be happening finally. "author": "IANS", "published": "2018-03-23T08:23:00.000+03:00", "title": "India to launch communication satellite GSAT-6A on March 29", "text": "Home / India / India to launch communication satellite GSAT-6A on March 29 India to launch communication satellite GSAT-6A on March 29 \u2014 By IANS | Mar 23, 2018 10:53 am FOLLOW US: Chennai: In the field of space technology, India will close this fiscal with the launch of the GSAT-6A, a high power S-band communication satellite, on March 29, the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) said on Friday. According to the space agency, the satellite with a life span of around 10 years will be put into orbit by the Indian rocket, Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle (GSLV-F08). The rocket is expected to blast off from the second launch pad at the Sriharikota rocket port in Andhra Pradesh at 4.56 p.m., on March 29. The ISRO said that the GSAT-6A was similar to the GSAT-6. The satellite will provide a platform for developing technologies such as demonstration of 6m S-Band Unfurlable Antenna, handheld ground terminals and network management techniques. These are useful in satellite-based mobile communication applications. ISRO Chairman K.Sivan had earlier told IANS that the GSAT-6A would be followed by the launch of navigation satellite which will be in the next fiscal. In the union budget for 2018-19, the Department of Space has been tasked with three earth observation space crafts ready for launch; four Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle (PSLV) flights; one each of Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle MkII and Mk III. Kolukkumalai is 7,130 ft above sea level.\nBut for a forester S.Jeyasingh who was suspended for negligence, the state government seems to have washed its hands off the incident by putting the blame on the trekkers. The state government said the trekkers didn't get permission from the forest department and took a route which was prohibited for trekking.\nSome serious grievances of the forest department such as questioned by the police in connection with the incident.\nHowever, the Atulya Misra commission constituted to probe the tragedy has started inquiries with officials and people.\nAtulya Misra is Greenberg", "published": "2018-03-25T03:25:00.000+03:00", "title": "Loyola 78, Kansas State 62: Ramblers blast on through to the Final Four", "text": "@SLGreenberg | Sign-Up for our Newsletter Sign-Up ATLANTA \u2014 Loyola senior Ben Richardson was fouled while making a three-point shot early in the second half of the South Regional final Saturday against Kansas State. He plopped down on his back, smiled like a guy who knew something \u2014 and darn it if he didn\u2019t do a little snow-angel maneuver right there on the court. Richardson completed the four-point play to give the Ramblers a 15-point lead with nearly 17 minutes to go, but maybe that was it right there. Maybe this Elite Eight no-contest was over. Maybe it was over before it even started. Loyola destroyed the major-conference Wildcats 78-62. The Ramblers toyed with them, messed with their minds, stole their souls. By God, Loyola \u2014 for the first time in 55 years \u2014 is going to the Final Four. \nLoyola's Ben Richardson in the midst of his second-half four-point play. (Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images) \nRELATED STORIES Final Four-bound Loyola is the Cinderella story that won\u2019t stop being told \u2018\u2018Chicago, you can be really proud,\u2019\u2019 coach Porter Moser said from the postgame stage at halfcourt, confetti falling. Proud, yes, and thankful, too. Chicago is something of a basketball wasteland nowadays without the 32-5 Ramblers, owners of the most victories \u2014 by three and counting \u2014 in school history. Save the tank talk about the Bulls. Let Northwestern and Illinois fight over the right-now-meaningless moniker of \u2018\u2018Chicago\u2019s Big Ten Team.\u2019\u2019 The Ramblers are Chicago\u2019s Big-Time Team. They\u2019re national darlings. They darn sure deserve to be local treasures. \u2018\u2018Oh, my gosh, yes, these guys deserve that,\u2019\u2019 said a beaming Jerry Harkness, 77, the star of Loyola\u2019s 1962-63 national-championship squad, as players younger by two generations cut down the nets. \u2018\u2018These guys are awesome. I am so proud of them and so happy that I got to be here for this.\u2019\u2019 Les Hunter, 75, the center on that great Ramblers team, shook his head in bewilderment. \u2018\u2018I was hoping they would make another run like this in my lifetime, but I didn\u2019t think I\u2019d see it,\u2019\u2019 he said. Who could have seen all this coming? But the better team \u2014 the much better team \u2014 punched its ticket to San Antonio on a Saturday instantly seared into Ramblers lore. Kansas State coach Bruce Weber wrote two words on the grease board in his locker room before the game: \u2018\u2018toughness\u2019\u2019 and \u2018\u2018discipline.\u2019\u2019 A fat lot of good that did him. \u2018\u2018They were tougher than us from the get-go,\u2019\u2019 Weber said. \u2018\u2018They were physical, very disciplined.\u2019\u2019 They were the team they\u2019ve been all season. Let it be known that Moser\u2019s famous jacket came off sometime in the second half and that Sister Jean, the 98-year-old nun and team chaplain, was her lovely, cheerful self before the game. But let\u2019s dispense with the romance for a moment and ponder what once was unthinkable: Loyola isn\u2019t merely back in the Final Four; it has a chance to hold its own there and even run away with the trophy. Have you been watching this tournament? If you have, then you know anything is possible. The Ramblers are going back to Texas, where this incredible Big Dance started. Against Kansas State, they went back to the way they\u2019d started in the first round against Miami: by jumping out to a nice lead and announcing to the world that they belonged and to their opponents that the next two hours were going to be hard as hell. Not even five minutes into the game, the Ramblers led 12-5 and all five starters \u2014 Clayton Custer, Marques Townes, Donte Ingram, Cameron Krutwig and Richardson \u2014 had scored. All game long, they drove and shot with the sort of decisiveness and alacrity that 300 Division I coaches only wish they had on their squad. Another close call? Not a chance. After winning their first three tournament games by a combined four points, the Ramblers said enough. It was time to make an opponent from the big-boy Big 12 suffer. \u2018\u2018We had no answer for them,\u2019\u2019 the Wildcats\u2019 Cartier Diarra said. \u2018\u2018So all credit to them. They are a great team, and hopefully they make it all the way.\u2019\u2019 Next up is Michigan at the Alamodome next Saturday. Chicago\u2019s Big Time Team will be ready. \u2018\u2018When it\u2019s time to lock in, they are locked in,\u2019\u2019 Moser said. \u2018\u2018It\u2019s because they want to win; it\u2019s in their genes. They are winning young men.\u2019\u2019 And they\u2019ve won over their city. Moser was sure to give a tip of his Final Four cap to the school paper, which has been there from the beginning. \u2018\u2018It\u2019s been quite a metamorphosis,\u2019\u2019 he said, \u2018\u2018because the Loyola Phoenix was the only one in the press conference for about 20 games.\u2019\u2019 We\u2019re all here now. And San Antonio can\u2019t get here soon enough. \nFollow me on Twitter @SLGreenberg. \nEmail: sgreenberg@suntimes.com", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "ben richardson", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "kevin c. cox/getty images", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "kansas state", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "loyola", "sentiment": "negative"}], "locations": [{"name": "south region", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "san antonio", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "chicago", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "illinois", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-25T03:36:51.015+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "eccb07cb371c3d0cce0c5e9fe83aecab7b0e2a4c", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZQwU97HLU2a07uKU_WMx1OgW0izAs9LRh84iNfaSeusHnYAYN4KyINnvu0KfJDKS2.CARa3ZQ4lHWUj3za79vRvdHb9b0gmDoioTDHrJ6y4wvjT6UiLqGRKyQzPq_cwrIrzXCMqFgOyW2vJgrrnLyngkPlsgj91HJI-", "site_full": "www.washingtonpost.com", "site": "washingtonpost.com", "site_section": "", "site_categories": ["media", "law_government_and_politics", "politics"], "section_title": "", "title": "The 6 most memorable speeches at the March for Our Lives in D.C. - The Washington Post", "text": "March 24 at 6:13 PM Email the author Yes, there were some celebrities at the March for Our Lives event in Washington. But the most memorable moments came from the students.\nThe Chicago high schooler who was threatened with a gun and told to say nothing \u2014 who then shared her story with the world. The Los Angeles teen who lost her brother to gun violence. The Parkland survivor who brought the rally to a standstill for 6 minutes 20 seconds.\nWe\u2019ve collected these and other notable moments:\nEmma Gonz\u00e1lez stands in silence\nThe final speaker of the rally stood in silence for 6 minutes 20 seconds to mark the amount of time it took for a gunman to kill 17 people and injure 15 at her high school.\n\u201cIn a little over six minutes, 17 of our friends were taken from us,\u201d Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School senior Emma Gonz\u00e1lez said. \u201cEverybody who has been touched by the cold grip of gun violence understands.\u201d\nGonz\u00e1lez listed the students who died and then stood in silence, staring straight into the crowd. A few minutes into the silence, the crowd started to chant, \u201cNever again!\u201d\nWhen the time elapsed, Gonz\u00e1lez told the crowd, \u201cFight for your lives before it\u2019s someone else\u2019s job.\u201d\n\u201cI have a dream that enough is enough.\u201d\nYolanda Renee King, 9, the granddaughter of Martin Luther King Jr., made an appearance with her own dream at the rally.\n\u201cI have a dream that enough is enough,\u201d she said, \u201cand that this should be a gun-free world. Period.\u201d\nShe then led the crowd in a cheer: \u201cWe are going to be a great generation.\u201d\n\u201cToday is the March for Our Lives, but it\u2019s also the birthday of Nick Dworet.\u201d\nOne of the survivors of the Parkland shooting went on stage to sing \u201cHappy Birthday\u201d for her deceased friend, Nicholas Dworet, who would have turned 18 on Saturday.\n\u201cIt is also the birthday of Nick Dworet. Somebody who was senselessly murdered in front of me,\u201d said 18-year-old Samantha Fuentes, who was shot by the gunman Feb. 14. Dworet was a senior at Stoneman Douglas and a competitive swimmer at the high school. He was planning to attend the University of Indianapolis on an athletic scholarship.\nFuentes asked the crowd to sing \u201cHappy Birthday\u201d for her friend, and they did.\n\u201cI have been personally affected by the lack of gun control\u201d\nMya Middleton, a 16-year-old student from Chicago, spoke about her own harrowing experience with gun violence. When she was a freshman in high school, Middleton went to pick up some items from the store when an agitated customer began grabbing items and causing a commotion.\n\u201cWhen he finally turns to me, he comes toward me, and I couldn\u2019t breathe, I couldn\u2019t move, I couldn\u2019t talk, I couldn\u2019t think,\u201d she recalled.\n\u201cHe pulls out this silver pistol and points it in my face and said these words that to this day haunt me and give me nightmares. He said, \u2018If you say anything, I will find you.\u2019 And yet I\u2019m still saying something today.\u201d\n\u201cGuns have long scared our children,\u201d she said. \u201cJoin me in sharing my pain and my anger.\u201d\n\u201cI learned how to duck from bullets before I learned how to read.\u201d\nEdna Chavez, 17, from south Los Angeles, lost her brother in a shooting. \u201cRicardo was his name. Can y\u2019all say it with me?\u201d she asked the crowd.\nThe protesters began chanting \u201cRicardo! Ricardo!\u201d as tears began to stream down Chavez\u2019s face.\n\u201cThis is normal. Normal to the point where I\u2019ve learned to duck from bullets before I learned how to read,\u201d she said. \u201cMy brother was in high school when he passed away. It was a day like any other day. Sunset going down on South Central. You hear pops thinking they\u2019re fireworks. They weren\u2019t pops. You see the melanin in your brother\u2019s skin turn gray.\u201d\n\u201cThis march is not the climax. It\u2019s the beginning.\u201d\n\u201cWelcome to the revolution,\u201d said Cameron Kasky. One the most visible of the Parkland students, Kasky urged young people to use their voices to \u201ccreate a better world for generations to come.\u201d\n\u201cPoliticians, either represent the people or get out. Stand for us or beware: The voters are coming,\u201d Kasky said. \u201cWe must stand beside those we\u2019ve lost and fix the world that betrayed them. \u2026 We the people can fix this. For the first time in a long while, I look forward and see hope.\u201d\n\u201cThe march is not the climax of this movement. It\u2019s the beginning,\u201d he said.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "teddy amenabar", "sentiment": "published": "2018-03-24T07:42:00.000+03:00", "title": "March For Our Lives Isn't Serious About", "text": "It seems fairly evident that nobody on the gun control side of the aisle wants to have a serious talk about guns and gun violence. What they want is an easy win. They want to cast the National Rifle Association as the epitome of evil. An army of children is marching on Washington this weekend, and they want to take semi-automatic rifles away, specifically, the spooky AR-15 rifle.\nIf they were actually serious about gun violence, they\u2019d be talking about places like Chicago and they\u2019d lobby for further regulation of or outright ban on the sale of handguns. Yes, the real numbers actually show rifles are among the safest firearms for an American to own. According to the FBI, Americans are roughly 20 times more likely to die at the end of a handgun.\nYet, handguns are definitively not part of the script the media follows when a mass shooting occurs in America. First, blue check marks start tweeting for gun control while the bodies are still warm. Second come the spin masters like Bloomberg\u2019s anti-gun Everytown USA , which got basically the entire media to repeat a wildly false statistic that 18 school shootings had occurred in 2018. Third come the \u201cthoughtful\u201d and \u201cpowerful\u201d opeds, lately from veterans quick to use their service as a lecturing device.\nFinally, the big brands come out to play.\nWe get scary posts on the AR-15 like this one from a two-time Pulitzer recipient at The New York Times , which notes that \u201c173 people have been killed in mass shootings in the United States involving AR-15s, according to a New York Times analysis.\u201d Of course, the article \u2014 which reads like a less dishonest version of a press release from Everytown \u2014 is missing the context on handguns. How else would they have fit in the swipe at the NRA, the Quote: from a military veteran for gun control, and all the terrifying language about the infantry\u2019s use of AR-15s?\nIf we\u2019re to restrict gun deaths to just mass shootings, according to Statista (which uses the FBI\u2019s methodology), handguns are about twice as likely to be used as rifles . We saw the results of handguns on soft targets in the Ft. Hood and Charleston church shootings. Except that it\u2019s much easier to conceal a handgun, there is virtually no difference between a semi-automatic handgun and a rifle when it comes to attacking a close-quarters, defenseless environment like a school or a church.\nThe \u201c173 deaths since 2007\u201d number is also highly misleading out of context. Roughly four times that number died by gunfire in Chicago in a single year.\nStill, not a word about Chicago gun violence from the media and gun control advocates in this recent cycle, while they loudly claim to be the white knights of gun violence.\nTheir proposed regulations also fit the typical script in that they will have almost no effect on the problem. Raise the age of sales to 21? Average age of a mass shooter is 32. Ban the sale of AR-15s? There are dozens of magazine-fed carbines on the market. Ban the sale of semi-automatic rifles? Most mass shootings occur with handguns.\nNo no, you\u2019ll hear at their march on DC Saturday, their mascot is definitively the AR-15. Mostly because they just have to do something. But the numbers they carry with them are misleading or false. Their propositions, like banning the AR-15, won\u2019t prevent a determined mass murderer.\nBut, they assure you, they\u2019re totally serious about the problem.", "highlightText": "", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Rick Morrissey", "published": "2018-03-25T05:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "Final Four-bound Loyola is the Cinderella story that won\u2019t stop being told", "text": "Loyola is going to the Final Four. There must be something in my eye because, as I read that sentence back, it looks like I wrote, \u201cLoyola is going to the Final Four.\u2019\u2019\nCan\u2019t be.\nRELATED STORIES\nLoyola\u2019s Ben Richardson has \u2018magic\u2019 night; Porter Moser lost in sea of hugs\nLoyola 78, Kansas State 62: Ramblers blast on through to the Final Four\nA month ago, the Ramblers were somewhere on the edge of college basketball\u2019s consciousness. Heck, a month ago, they were on the outskirts of Chicago\u2019s consciousness, which generally is where college basketball resides in this city.\nLoyola's Ben Richardson cuts down the net after his team defeated Kansas State on Saturday to earn a trip to the Final Four. (Photo by Ronald Martinez/Getty Images)\nNow they\u2019re going to San Antonio to play in a national semifinal game against Michigan. It means that everything you think you knew about anything is wrong. If Loyola can be one game from a chance to win an NCAA title, you\u2019d be wise to re-examine your entire life.\nThe Ramblers beat Kansas State 78-62 Saturday in Atlanta, continuing their ridiculously fun ride. Where it will stop, nobody with a working brain knows.\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t even feel real,\u2019\u2019 guard Ben Richardson said afterward.\nNo, it doesn\u2019t.\nAfter watching Loyola win four games in the tournament, we shouldn\u2019t be surprised anymore. But the Ramblers are an 11 th seed, and no matter how capricious March Madness can be, what they\u2019ve done is still stunning.\nThey\u2019ll beat you any way you want. Where they beat Nevada on Thursday with layups, they beat Kansas State on Saturday with a barrage of three-pointers. Where they won their first three games of the tournament with last-gasp shots, they won Saturday\u2019s game with a relentlessness that built a 23-point lead and then with a steel-reinforced confidence to overcome a Kansas State comeback.\nThe Ramblers do two things very well. They move the ball, and they play hard defense. Throughout the tournament, they have made opponents look slow. That\u2019s not supposed to happen, but they have made a lot of things happen that weren\u2019t supposed to happen. It\u2019s tiring just watching them run around the floor.\nFor the longest time, the ninth-seeded Wildcats couldn\u2019t keep up. And it didn\u2019t look like they had anyone who could score, which in basketball is what is called \u201ca problem.\u201d Then they came roaring back, going on a 14-3 run to cut a 61-38 lead to 64-52 with 4:19 left.\nA lesser team, a team that might have started to believe it didn\u2019t belong \u2013 basically, any team not named \u201cLoyola\u2019\u2019 \u2013 might have caved in. Not this team. The Ramblers bounced back.\nMarques Townes, the hero of the Nevada game, made two free throws and converted a three-point play to push the lead back up to 17. And they stayed the course and played their game and did all the corny things that coaches tell their teams to do. That\u2019s what mature players do.\nThe Ramblers don\u2019t have one big star. They have six lesser stars, and the wattage is superior. When big man Cameron Krutwig backed into the poor guy trying to defend him, it looked like he was using his butt to close the refrigerator door during a late-night raid. The Wildcats didn\u2019t know what to do when he set screens.\nThe Ramblers have point guard Clayton Custer, who has a name like a gunslinger from the Old West and shoots like one, too. They have Richardson, who had a career-high 23 points. Everybody who gets playing time for Loyola can score. The Ramblers shot 57.4 percent from the field and were 9-for-18 on three-point attempts.\n\u201cThe ball usually finds the hot hand,\u2019\u2019 Richardson said.\nNo, it\u2019s not the greatest basketball. It\u2019s not the NBA. But in terms of execution, in terms of setting picks, making the right pass and playing shrink-wrap defense, it\u2019s terrific. In terms of excitement, in terms of gnawed fingernails, shared experiences and school pride, it\u2019s all that\u2019s right with the game.\nThe Ramblers have won 14 straight games and 21 of their last 22. We didn\u2019t see them coming, and we should have. They were exactly the type of team that could do damage in the NCAA Tournament. Five players averaging double figures, two guys who had played high school ball together and a group of people that seemed to err on the side of unselfishness, if there is such a thing as that. That\u2019s what Loyola is, and that\u2019s why it\u2019s going to San Antonio.\nIt\u2019s the Ramblers\u2019 first trip to the Final Four since 1963, when they won the national championship.\nIt doesn\u2019t matter whom they play, even third-seeded Michigan. They\u2019re an 11 th seed and not anything close to an underdog.\n\u201cIt\u2019s an unbelievable group,\u2019\u2019 coach Porter Moser said. \u201cIt\u2019s amazing when you believe. They\u2019ve believed and believed and believed.\u2019\u2019\nIn terms of self-belief, they\u2019re a No.1 seed.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Jennifer Calfas", "published": "2018-03-24T03:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "Martin Luther King's Granddaughter Speaks at March | Time", "text": "\u201cI have a dream that enough is enough.\u201d\nNine-year-old Yolanda Renee King invoked the famous words of her grandfather Martin Luther King, Jr. \u2013 and gave them a 2018 twist \u2013 as she spoke to the tens of thousands of protesters demanding gun control at the March for Our Lives in Washington, D.C., Saturday.\nIn a surprise appearance amid a series of speeches from students impacted from gun violence in Parkland, Chicago, southern California and elsewhere, Yolanda spoke on a similar platform as her grandfather did 55 years early when he inspired generations with his historic \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d speech at the March on Washington in 1963.\n\u201cMy grandfather had a dream that his four little children will not be judged by the color of the skin, but the content of their character,\u201d said Yolanda, standing alongside Parkland shooting survivor Jaclyn Corin. \u201cI have a dream that enough is enough. And that this should be a gun-free world, period.\u201d\n#MLK and #CorettaScottKing \u2019s granddaughter, Yolanda Renee King, speaking at #MarchForOurLivesDC . Yolanda will be at our April 7 #KingCentennialsSpeak . Join us. Register: https://t.co/Hdyewm5orI . #MarchForOurLives . #MLK50Forward pic.twitter.com/hZIo6Dyd8W \n\u2014 The King Center (@TheKingCenter) March 24, 2018 \n\u201cWill you please repeat these words after me?\u201d Yolanda asked the crowd. \u201cSpread the word, have you heard? All across the nation we are going to be a great generation.\u201d\nBut one repetition of her rallying cry wasn\u2019t enough. \u201cNow, I\u2019d like you to say it like you really, really mean it,\u201d Yolanda said before launching into the affirmation once again.\n\nYolanda was one of many young speakers at the rally in Washington, D.C. \u2014 and at 800 other protests around the world Saturday \u2014 to advocate for stricter gun control amid a growing number of mass shootings at schools, churches and other venues around the country.\nYolanda\u2019s aunt Bernice King attended the March for Our Lives in Washington, D.C., as well, and posted tweets that quoted student speakers whose messages echoed those of her late father\u2019s.\nHere. #MarchForOurLives #GunControlNow #Enough #MLK50Forward #Chicago #Parkland #Orlando pic.twitter.com/JduDsVhH6D \n\u2014 Be A King (@BerniceKing) March 24, 2018 \nPowerful, powerful words from #DeAngeloMcDade , #Chicago ! \u201cViolence cannot drive out violence. Only peace can do that.\u201d He also mentioned the first principle of my father\u2019s nonviolent philosophy: \u201cNonviolence is a way of life for courageous people.\u201d #MarchForOurLivesDC #MLK \n\u2014 Be A King (@BerniceKing) March 24, 2018 \nIn a Facebook post , Bernice King wrote that she was a \u201cvery proud Aunt\u201d after Yolanda\u2019s speech. \u201cMy niece, Yolanda Renee King, truly represented the King family.\u201d\nAfterward on CNN, alongside her father Martin Luther King III, Yolanda said her school had a lockdown drill on Friday.\n\u201cWe do all these lockdown drills because it\u2019s unfortunate that people have guns and they use them to hurt people,\u201d she said.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "author": "Emily Buder", "published": "2018-03-25T01:57:00.000+03:00", "title": "Students March for Reducing Gun Violence in Chicago and Philadelphia - The Atlantic", "text": "Hundreds of thousands of people rallied in Washington, D.C. on Saturday to express outrage at recent mass shootings in American schools, and to push Congress to enact stricter gun laws. But for many students in the U.S.\u2014and especially students of color\u2014gun violence at school isn\u2019t the only problem. Rather, it\u2019s the violence they face regularly in their homes and yards, in their neighborhoods and communities.\nThere hasn\u2019t yet been a worldwide march focused on that kind of violence\u2014so they made this one their own.\nLatest from Politics How John Bolton Views U.S. Allies and Adversaries \n\u201cI came all the way from Chicago to help change the violence that\u2019s going on with school shootings,\u201d said 16-year-old Kaiseona Lockhart. \u201cAnd to let everyone know that there\u2019s violence in Chicago.\u201d Lockhart, who lives in Englewood, on Chicago\u2019s south side, recently lost an uncle to gun violence. She\u2019s part of a violence-prevention youth group affiliated with St. Sabina Church. \u201cThey\u2019re trying to put us against each other. They\u2019re trying to say that mass shootings and shootings, they don\u2019t connect, but in reality, they both happen by a gun. We both want to change that.\u201d\nIn the past month, the gun-control movement has found its voice in a ragtag group of eloquent, Twitter-savvy teenagers from suburban Florida. They survived the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School this past Valentine\u2019s Day that killed 17 of their peers and teachers and have since appeared on countless cable-news segments and magazine covers calling for stricter gun legislation.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "kaiseona lockhart", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "john bolton", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "lockhart", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "congress", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "st. sabina church", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "washington, d.c.", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "chicago", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "philadelphia", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "u.s.", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "englewood", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-25T01:15:52.015+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "0f10a40c09ffbb6b8d012c8d0bf4088dc5b086db", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZSPfVRrC83GDKJbKDRbkYjxNRdF1HRthPAYAh4xkr.72.k9PE46bl3JqBcQCw8lJoGMGyBNls9CTQ--", "site_full": "www.nytimes.com", "site": "nytimes.com", "site_section": "", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "", "title": "At Rallies, Students With a Different View of Gun Violence: As Urban Reality - The New York Times", "title_full": "At Rallies, Students With a Different View of Gun Violence: As Urban Reality - The New York Times", "published": "2018-03-25T03:31:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 0, "site_type": "news", "country": "US", "spam_score": 0.378, "main_image": "https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/03/25/us/25dc-baltimore/25dc-baltimore-facebookJumbo.jpg", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 98, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 1786, "comments": 0, "shares": 1786}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "0f10a40c09ffbb6b8d012c8d0bf4088dc5b086db", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZSPfVRrC83GDKJbKDRbkYjxNRdF1HRthPAYAh4xkr.72.k9PE46bl3JqBcQCw8lJoGMGyBNls9CTQ--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Noah Weiland", "published": "2018-03-25T03:31:00.000+03:00", "title": "At Rallies, Students With a Different View of Gun Violence: As Urban Reality - The New York Times", "text": "  Students from Baltimore, as well as young people who attended a rally in Chicago, were vocal on Saturday about the need for steps to reduce gun violence, much in the same way as students from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., where a gunman killed 17 people last month. But they had a different idea of the problem. Destini Philpot, another student at Baltimore City College, was joined on Saturday in Washington by Carrie Zaremba, a student at the Friends School of Baltimore, a predominantly white Quaker institution. The two said they had helped organize a citywide walkout this month that involved both public and private schools. \u201cIt shouldn\u2019t take a mass shooting in a predominantly white area like Parkland to start caring about gun violence,\u201d Ms. Zaremba said. Ms. Philpot said that many of those at the rally were thinking of gun violence in the only way they knew how: as mass shootings. Video \u2018We Are the Change:\u2019 Teenagers From Chicago\u2019s South Side Stand With Parkland Survivors Ke\u2019Shon Newman\u2019s brother was shot nine times on Chicago\u2019s South Side, where gun violence is a daily threat. Now, Ke\u2019Shon is heading to Washington to march with high school students from Parkland, Fla. By SAMEEN AMIN and YOUSUR AL-HLOU on Publish Date March 22, 2018. . Watch in Times Video \u00bb embed \u201cWhen they talk about gun violence, they\u2019re talking about schools,\u201d she said. Private donors paid for 60 buses that carried around 3,000 Baltimore students to the Washington event. Some Baltimore organizers skipped their city\u2019s satellite march to attend the one in the capital, hoping to reach an audience largely unfamiliar with the kind of violence that visits them with gruesome regularity. One of those organizers, Erricka Bridgeford, has helped work on a campaign called Baltimore Ceasefire, which holds quarterly \u201ccease-fire\u201d weekends that call for a stop to killings for a three-day period. On Saturday, she recalled what had brought her to Washington: the lasting agony from losing her brother, stepson and friends to gun violence. \nAdvertisement   \u201cI\u2019ve seen dead bodies and blood,\u201d she said. \u201cThese are things you never recover from. You learn how to live your life differently, because the air looks different once you experience that kind of trauma. I have to do something with the pain. I don\u2019t want to be a prisoner to it.\u201d Ms. Bridgeford said shootings were a never-ending feature of life in her Baltimore neighborhood. \u201cThere\u2019s no such thing as post-traumatic stress in a lot of communities in America, because there\u2019s no \u2018post,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cYou don\u2019t get a chance to experience the aftermath before there\u2019s another trauma because of gun violence.\u201d One of the students walking with Ms. Bridgeford was Shanika Walker, who attends the Excel Academy at Francis M. Wood High School in Baltimore, which recently lost seven students to homicide in 15 months. Newsletter Sign Up Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. "author": "Sun-Times Staff", "published": "2018-03-24T02:05:00.000+03:00", "title": "DuShon Monique Brown, starred on \u2018Chicago Fire\u2019 has died: Report", "text": "Actress DuShon Monique Brown, who stars as Connie, Chief Boden\u2019s (Eamonn Walker) assistant on \u201cChicago Fire,\u201d has died. She was 49 years old.\nThe Cook County medical examiner\u2019s office confirmed Brown passed away at 12:11 p.m. Friday at Franciscan Health in Olympia Fields. An autopsy Saturday did not rule on her cause and manner of her death pending further investigation.\nMs. Brown\u2019s manager, Robert Schroeder, revealed via statement that she died of natural causes.\n\u201cWe are very sad to announce the untimely death of beloved Chicago actress DuShon Monique Brown. DuShon, most affectionately known to many as Connie on NBC\u2019s \u2018Chicago Fire,\u2019 died suddenly Friday morning of natural causes. We are devastated by the loss of a very talented and kindhearted soul. DuShon was a film, television, commercial and voice-over actress who also graced the stages of many Chicago theaters. She brought laughter and joy to many and will be greatly missed. At this difficult time we ask that the privacy of the family and loved ones be respected.\u201d\nEarlier in the evening, TMZ.com reported the actress suffered an apparent heart attack, citing show sources who claimed Miss Brown recently complained of chest pains.\nIn a statement, \u201cChicago Fire\u201d executive producer Dick Wolf said, \u201cThe \u2018Chicago Fire\u2019 family is devastated to lose one of its own. Our thoughts and prayers are with DuShon\u2019s family and we will all miss her.\u201d\nIn a 2016 interview with hiddenremote.com , Miss Brown said she saw Connie as a mother figure to the show\u2019s eclectic troupe of characters: \u201cHer crazy fits right in. She\u2019s the mother crazy right there. I think she thinks for the most part, particularly with the younger crew, she\u2019s the sort of maternal, aunt, teacher figure to them. Eamonn Walker [who plays Chief Boden] and I, we joke around when I\u2019m on set that Connie is the chief\u2019s work wife and everyone else is sort of the kids. They\u2019ve written Connie as, she\u2019s this very maternal figure that everyone seems to run from.\u201d\nPictured in the 2008 production of \u201cBecause They Have No Words\u201d are Jennifer Coombs (from left), DuShon Monique Brown, Sean Walton, Tim Maddock, Lawrence Grimm and Marla Caceres. | Christopher Ash Photo\nMiss Brown also starred as Nurse Katie Welch on the Chicago-based series \u201cPrison Break.\u201d\nShe previously had worked as a school counselor and head of the Drama Starz acting program at Kenwood Academy High School on Chicago\u2019s South Side. Her local theater credits included productions at Steppenwolf, the Goodman Theatre, Chicago Dramatists and Piven Theatre.\nThe medical examiner\u2019s office listed her home address in south suburban "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Marlen Garcia", "published": "2018-03-24T07:34:00.000+03:00", "title": "Happy 90th birthday, James Lovell, Chicago\u2019s space pioneer", "text": "\u201cHouston, we\u2019ve had a problem.\u201d\nJames Lovell was the astronaut who famously uttered those words after an explosion aboard the Apollo 13 spacecraft in 1970. He was the flight commander charged with landing on the moon. After an oxygen tank exploded, Lovell, Jack Swigert and Fred Haise had to call off their mission and figure out how to get back to Earth.\nTwenty-five years later, actor Tom Hanks played Lovell in a Hollywood film about their epic journey.\nApollo 13 astronauts Fred Haise, James Lovell, and John Swigert (left to right) leave a helicopter to step aboard the carrier Iwo Jima in the Pacific Ocean after their successful recovery. | AP\nWe\u2019d like to give this American hero, who lives in a north suburb of Chicago, a shout-out as he turns 90 Sunday. Chicago\u2019s Adler Planetarium is celebrating Lovell\u2019s achievements in a yearlong campaign , encouraging space fans to write Lovell notes to let him know what kind of impact his space travels had on them.\nEDITORIAL\nLovell\u2019s name is synonymous with Apollo 13, but we\u2019ll never forget his Apollo 8 mission in 1968. It was the first manned flight to break from the Earth\u2019s orbit and travel around the moon.\nRELATED: Lovell spoke to Sun-Times reporter Robert Herguth about his faith in a podcast last year.\nWe asked author Robert Kurson, whose book \u201cRocket Men: The Daring Odyssey of Apollo 8 and the Astronauts Who Made Man\u2019s First Journey to the Moon\u201d will be out next month, to give a few good reasons to celebrate Lovell today. Here\u2019s his excellent list:\nJim Lovell donated many of his coolest space-related memorabilia and artifacts to the Adler Planetarium, giving Chicagoans and other visitors an intimate glimpse into the early years of space travel and exploration. He is a wonderful explainer and storyteller who often makes himself available to media and others who are interested in NASA, space, the Moon, and the future of space travel. He is a devoted husband, father and family man who has been married to the same woman, Marilyn, for 65 years. (Astronaut life was notoriously hard on marriages. In fact, the crew of Apollo 8 \u2014 Frank Borman, Lovell, and Bill Anders \u2014 is the only crew from either the Gemini or Apollo programs whose marriages all survived intact.) He is not just one of the nicest astronauts you\u2019ll meet, he\u2019s one of the nicest people you\u2019ll meet, a reputation that goes back to his earliest days with NASA. Unlike some astronauts, he dreamed as a kid of flying on rockets into space and exploring the cosmos, and he seems to have lost little of that boyhood wonder for exploration to this day. He had a golden retriever that liked to watch the Apollo 13 movie when it played on television at his home. Happy Birthday, Commander James Lovell. You continue to make Chicago proud.\n ", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "james lovell", "sentiment": High School Dies After Being Taken Off Life Support CBS Baltimore 1:25 Prince Harry and Meghan Markle send out wedding invitations CBS News 2:44 Could Throwing Rocks Stop a School Shooter? Associated Press 0:55 Trump Continues to Shake Up the Administration Bloomberg 2:22 Congress Approves $1.3 Trillion Spending Bill Associated Press 0:44 How to work out like 'Notorious RBG' The Washington post 1:32 Mandalay Bay releases footage of Las Vegas gunman FOX News 2:31 How a series of deadly Russian apartment bombings in 1999 led to Putin's rise to power Business Insider 4:07 New details about Austin bombing suspect's cellphone statement CBS News 3:01 Teen Wounded In School Shooting 'Brain Dead'; To Be Taken Off Life Support CBS Baltimore 0:38 Stoneman Douglas students featured on cover of TIME magazine Sun Sentinel 0:50 UP NEXT CRESTON, Iowa \u2014 The bodies of an Iowa couple and their two children were found in a rented condo in Mexico on Friday, though it wasn't immediately clear what caused their deaths, according to investigators.\nThe family was reported missing by relatives in their hometown of Creston, Iowa, earlier in the day, about a week after the family left for vacation. Creston police contacted the U.S. Department of State, and the bodies were found during a welfare check at the condo in Tulum, on the Yucatan Peninsula.\nIn Mexico, the Quintana Roo state prosecutors office tweeted that the bodies were found in a tourist compound. The office said that \"no signs of violence were found on the bodies or in the room,\" though authorities said it wasn't immediately clear what caused the deaths. Autopsy reports were pending.\nIowa authorities identified the family as 41-year-old Kevin Sharp; his wife, 38-year-old Amy Sharp; and their children, 12-year-old Sterling and 7-year-old Adrianna.\nReached Friday, the developer of the condo complex where the deaths occurred declined to comment.\nThe Creston News Advertiser newspaper in Iowa reported that the family flew to Cancun, Mexico, on March 14. According to her sister, Amy Sharp texted their mother the next day to say they'd reached Tulum, but relatives hadn't heard from the family since then.\nThe sister, Renee Hoyt, said the Sharps were scheduled to return to the U.S. this week. They were scheduled to depart from the Cancun airport on Wednesday and fly to St. Louis on a non-stop flight. The family had planned to then drive about 200 miles (322 kilometers) to Danville, Illinois, to watch a basketball game Thursday, Hoyt said.\nWhen the family didn't arrive in St. Louis, family members "2018-03-23T12:16:00.000+03:00", "title": "Spring art and other events in Copenhagen", "text": "Spring art and other events in Copenhagen \u2018Even\u2019 the photographer is having a hard job remembering what this is (photo: overgarden. dk) March 23rd, 2018 10:16 am| by Douglas Whitbread \nThis coming month\u2019s art schedule provides a wide range of options for gallery visitors. \nIn the exhibition #Whatif? (Kunsthal Charlottenborg, from March 17) internationally-renowned artists such as Renzo Martens, Lara Baladi and Forensic Architecture ask hefty questions such as \u201cWhat if art could eradicate poverty?\u201d and \u201cWhat if we could live without fossil fuels?\u201d \nHieroglyphs \u2013 Symbolist Drawings 1890-1910 (Statens Museum for Kunst, from April 19) demonstrates the importance of draughtsmanship to the Danish artistic scene at the turn of the 20th century. The exhibition elaborates upon an age of creativity in which symbolism became prominent within the country. \nThe annual presentation from the graduates of the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts (Kunsthal Charlottenborg, from April 14) will display the work of 26 budding talents who\u2019ve recently completed six years of academic education. Artists will use a variety of mediums including video, film and sculpture. \nLea Gulditte Hestelund is interested in how human bodies are ascribed meaning in contemporary western societies. In her solo exhibition, Consumed Future Spewed Up As Present (Overgaden, from April 7), she explores this topic through mysterious scenarios taken from science-fiction plotlines. \nDanish digital artist Christoffer Birkkj\u00e6r and Portuguese visual artists Duarte Filipe regularly collaborate to explore the intersection between classical drawing and computer visualisation. In their new installation, Even (Overgaden, from April 7), the artists examine landscape features such as mountains, cliffs, rivers and valleys. \nFirst day of the racing season April 6, 18:00; Klampenborg Galopbane, Klampenborgvej 52; 60kr; galopbane.dk Enjoy the fun and competitive spirit of Klampenborg Racetrack as it begins its 2018 season. Enjoy a flutter or two, listen to music and enjoy some great food and racing at the track. (MA) \nBig Quiz Nights March 22, April 5 & 19, 19:30; The Globe, N\u00f8rregade 43, Cph K; 30kr, five per team April 9 & May 7, 19:30; Kennedy\u2019s, Gammel Kongevej 23, Cph V; 25kr, four per team The winners get 1,000 kroner at the Globe, and 800 at Kennedy\u2019s. And who knows, the odd rollover has been known to go too. \nDesigner Forum April 6-8; Forum, Frederiksberg; 50-120kr; designerforum.dk At Denmark\u2019s largest outlet event, save up to 80 percent on leading brands for both men and women, which fortunately for us would cost more to send back to the supplier than give away at these prices. Go VIP on Friday and get first dibs. "2018-03-23T12:56:00.000+03:00", "title": "F1 a step closer to Copenhagen\u2019s streets", "text": "F1 a step closer to Copenhagen\u2019s streets \nA plan to bring the entire F1 circus to Denmark is still on the cards In a couple of years Kevin Magnussen might be coming around a street corner near you (photo: Morio) March 23rd, 2018 10:56 am| by Stephen Gadd For some time now, Copenhagen has been branding itself as a green city full of happy cyclists. So it was perhaps a little surprising when the former minister, Helge Sander, and former bank boss Lars Seier Christensen floated the idea of bringing a Formula 1 grand prix to the streets of the capital. \nREAD ALSO: Copenhagen looking to host a Danish Grand Prix in 2020 This has now come a step closer. As a result of a request from the finance minister, Kristian Jensen, on Thursday this week, the idea was debated by the city council\u2019s Borgerrepr\u00e6sentationen. A slim majority consisting of Socialdemokratiet, Dansk Folkeparti, Venstre, Konservative and Liberal Alliance voted to enter into a dialogue with the government regarding the plan, reports DR Nyheder. Minimising the damage However, there are strings attached. \u201cIt is dependent on a number of conditions, amongst which are that it should not cost Copenhagen\u2019s taxpayers a penny,\u201d said Copenhagen\u2019s mayor Frank Jensen. The state will have to become a formal partner in the project and the municipality must not incur any extra expense. In addition, the inconvenience such an arrangement will cause must be minimised. On top of that, the race should be open to all and create job opportunities in Copenhagen. Not so green, perhaps One of the parties that voted against the plan is Enhedslisten. \u201cWe believe that Copenhagen should have a green profile. We would like to attract the tourists and companies that come to the city because of that,\u201d said Ninna Hedeager Olsen, the deputy mayor for technical and environmental matters. As far as the timeframe for a possible grand prix goes, it could take place in 2020 or 2021 if all the conditions are met. "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Christian W", "published": "2018-03-23T15:50:00.000+03:00", "title": "Danish burger chain sold for supersized amount", "text": "Danish burger chain sold for supersized amount \nCock\u2019s and Cows passed on to Finnish hands in 164 million kroner deal Finn-ished? Nah, just getting started (photo: Cock\u2019s and Cows) March 23rd, 2018 1:50 pm| by Christian W \nThe big Copenhagen-based burger chain Cock\u2019s and Cows has been acquired by the Finnish restaurant giant Restamax in a mammoth deal. \nThe 164 million kroner agreement also includes the Finns assuming control of The Bird gin bars, which is also part of the Nord Group, which was founded by Daniel Vesti Knuttel, Lasse Wiwe and Adam Hjorth in 2010. The burger chain operates seven restaurants in Copenhagen today. \n\u201cIt\u2019s the biggest restaurant business in the Nordics and they naturally have a lot of competencies and knowhow that we can benefit from. They\u2019ve tried growing from where we are now to something that is greater and we need to suck up all that knowledge and learn from it,\u201d Knuttel told Finans.dk. \nREAD MORE: Danish burger joint named among best in the world \nBurger boom As part of the deal, Restamax will assume 75 percent of the ownership, while the Danes will retain 25 percent of the business and will continue to be in charge of operations. \nCock\u2019s and Cows is just one of several burger joints that have risen to prominence in Copenhagen in recent years. Others include the likes of Halifax, Jagger and Grillen. \nRestamax owns 130 restaurants across Finland, including eateries like Wayne\u2019s Coffee, Gringos Locos and Mura Sushi. Eriksholm Research Centre is part of Oticon. \nLearn more about Eriksholm Research Centre: www.eriksholm.com \nThis 6-month, full-time position (37 hours/week) and the salary will be according to qualifications and experience. You will be based at the Eriksholm Research Centre, Denmark, about 40 km north of Copenhagen. Here you will be part of the vibrant Eriksholm research team, driving innovative research for all divisions of William Demant. \nAbout the position We are seeking a researcher to develop and implement speech separation algorithms for hearing devices utilizing recent advances in machine learning, particularly deep neural networks (DNN). The new researcher should have strong experience within the fields of machine learning and speech processing combined with passion for applied research, good programming practice and innovation. \nEriksholm develops technologies to compensate for hearing problems to the best possible level, even under adverse and challenging listening conditions. Particularly the proverbial \u201cCocktail Party\u201d challenge of competing voices, but also spatial hearing, speaker separation, signal classification and cloud-based learning of user preferences are in our focus. Advanced digital signal processing and novel technologies like deep neural network are tools for our research. Eriksholm utilizes new technology, access to next generation hearing device platforms, and tight connections to people who use hearing devices to quantify real and significant problems for people with hearing problems and subsequently develop the optimal compensation. \nEriksholm\u2019s audiological research is focusing on three Megatrend areas: Augmented Hearing, Cognitive Hearing Science and eHealth. Eriksholm\u2019s research has a strong international track record in applied science. We closely collaborate with leading universities around the world for finding the best solutions for the hearing healthcare of the future. Our efforts aim at implementing clinical audiology solutions supported by electronic processes and communication. We focus on the needs of people with hearing impairment and their clinicians. Our research does not only generate publications and patents, but also transforms the clinical practice and the operations of large health care providers. \nYour background We are seeking candidates with a PhD or M.Sc. degree in machine learning, deep neural networks, speech separation, signal classification or a related discipline. A dedication to good programming practice and some experience with relevant software tools e.g. Python, Tensorflow, Keras and Matlab is important. Knowledge of audiology and hearing aids is a plus. A strong interest in interdisciplinary and application-oriented work, familiarity with experimental work, as well as good English language skills are required. Apart from initiating cutting-edge research leading to journal publications, the new researcher is expected to be a part of the research group at Eriksholm and Oticon. \nWant to join the Eriksholm Research Centre? If this opportunity appeals to you, then submit your application as soon as possible and no later than April 30, 2018. We will start interviews as applications come in. Please include the following documents: Letter of motivation; CV including a list of publications, and; 2 -3 references (if possible). \nIf you would like to know more about the position, you are welcome to contact Lars Bramsl\u00f8w, Project Manager in Augmented Hearing on +45 4829 8928. "2018-03-22T20:05:00.000+02:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 0, "site_type": "news", "country": "DK", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "", "performance_score": 0, "domain_rank": null, "uuid": "360410ec0697eb1e75fbbc8953de49d0079e819d", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/snFTpiOKdJUFl13pARZGewDr3m5jPPcHbvWcptQ.P2ff_GuZ2q2BGA--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-22T20:05:00.000+02:00", "title": "Postdoc in Microbial Dark Matter in Technical Systems (P21830)", "text": "Stork\u00f8benhavn Sydvestjylland (Esbjerg) \nAt the Faculty of Engineering and Science, Department of Chemistry and Bioscience two positions as postdoc in Micobial Dark Matter in Technical Systems is open for appointment from 01.07.2018-30.06.2021 or soon thereafter. The Department of Chemistry and Bioscience consists of five sections of which three are situated in Aalborg with research and teaching in Biotechnology, Applied Chemistry and Biology & Environmental Science, one in Copenhagen on Sustainable Biotechnology and one in Esbjerg on Chemical Engineering. The position is located within the section of Biotechnology with working place in Aalborg. \nJob description The research is a part of the project \u201cIllumination of Microbial Dark Matter\u201c funded by the Villum Foundation. In our ongoing world-wide investigations of microbial communities in wastewater treatment systems and anaerobic digesters, we have revealed core communities of few hundred unique novel species (including candidate phyla) about which nothing is known about their physiology, ecology, and their importance for carbon, nitrogen, or phosphorus removal, or for bioenergy production. The aim of these projects is to identify these microbes, characterize their ecophysiology, and reveal essential interactions so a comprehensive ecosystem model can be established for informed control of the technical systems. The studies may also include eukaryotes. Novel high through-put methods will be developed and applied including full-scale surveys, meta-omics, single cell microbiology (e.g., Raman microspectroscopy) and isotope-based process studies. We seek outstanding scientists with a proven research record in studies of microbial communities and with experience in either meta-omics-related work, comparative genomics, metabolic reconstruction, single cell microbiology, or process studies using isotopes. \nLimited teaching within the area can be expected, but also in other study programmes at the University. \nYou may obtain further professional information from Professor Per Halkj\u00e6r Nielsen, phone +45 2173 5089, email: phn@bio.aau.dk \nQualification requirements: Appointment as Postdoc presupposes scientific qualifications at PhD\u2013level or similar scientific qualifications. The research potential of each applicant will be emphasized in the overall assessment. Appointment as a Postdoc cannot exceed a period of four years in total at Aalborg University. \nThe application must contain the following: A motivated text wherein the reasons for applying, qualifications in relation to the position, and intentions and visions for the position are stated. A current curriculum vitae. Copies of relevant diplomas (Master of Science and PhD). On request you could be asked for an official English translation. Scientific qualifications. A complete list of publications must be attached with an indication of the works the applicant wishes to be considered. You may attach up to 5 publications. Dissemination qualifications, including participation on committees or boards, participation in organisations and the like. Additional qualifications in relation to the position. References/recommendations. Personal data. \nThe applications are only to be submitted online by using the \"Apply online\" button below. An assessment committee will assess all candidates. \nWe wish to reflect the diversity of society and welcome applications from all qualified candidates regardless of personal background . \nFor further information concerning the application procedure please contact Hanne Skovrider by mail est-ef-hr@adm.aau.dk or phone (+45) 9940 9631. Information regarding guidelines, ministerial circular in force and procedures can be seen here. \nAgreement Employment is in accordance with the Ministerial Order on the Appointment of Academic Staff at Universities (the Appointment Order) and the Ministry of Finance's current Job Structure for Academic Staff at Universities. Employment and salary are in accordance with the collective agreement for state-employed academics. \nVacancy number", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "crawled": "2018-03-23T09:16:43.000+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "e26ff4c636339f3fe66cc00fbad852f8e2ed2c5d", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/snFTpiOKdJUFl13pARZGewDr3m5jPPcHYs7bHi4CM6EHF2EUs1L0bQ--", "site_full": "nyuddannet.dk", "site": "nyuddannet.dk", "site_section": "http://go.dk//job/newsfeed.asp?days=2", "site_categories": ["job_search", "jobs", "career_planning"], "section_title": "Job  fra Nyuddannet.dk", "title": "Postdoc in Healthcare Systems Design", "title_full": "Postdoc in Healthcare Systems Design", "published": "2018-03-21T20:12:00.000+02:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 0, "site_type": "news", "country": "DK", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "", "performance_score": 0, "domain_rank": null, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 0, "comments": 0, "shares": 0}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "e26ff4c636339f3fe66cc00fbad852f8e2ed2c5d", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/snFTpiOKdJUFl13pARZGewDr3m5jPPcHYs7bHi4CM6EHF2EUs1L0bQ--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-21T20:12:00.000+02:00", "title": "Postdoc in Healthcare Systems Design", "text": "\u00d8resundsregionen \nFrist 8. juni 2018 \nThe Post-Doctoral Research Associate will be part of the research division of Engineering Systems, Department of Management Engineering, Technical University of Denmark (DTU), north of Copenhagen. The division is growing fast and is characterised by collegial, energetic staff and strong research collaborations with leading universities and industry worldwide. \nOur research focuses on understanding and improving the ways in which complex sociotechnical engineering systems are designed, managed, and operated throughout their life cycles. Our research spans the boundaries of 1. interdisciplinary engineering design, 2. engineering project, program and portfolio management, and 3. related policy, public engagement and strategic processes. By focusing on the themes of complexity, human behaviour, and uncertainty, we develop understanding, knowledge, methods and tools for public and private organisations to be more effective in the design, construction and operation of large-scale socio-technical engineering systems. Examples include applications in healthcare (e.g. development and integration of transformative technologies) or energy generation and distribution (e.g. design of industry cooperation networks). We believe that good design can deliver widespread benefits to society\u2019s challenges of health and wellbeing in the 21st century. \nThe Post-Doctoral Research Associate will be working in healthcare systems research at the intersection of design, technology, human behaviour, and health research. He/she will take a leading role in driving the research in healthcare system design forward, by engaging in the relationship between design and wellbeing, by bringing a systems perspective to health and care services, and thus by designing for life. \nKeywords include healthcare systems design, healthcare design, design for behaviour change, personalised health technologies, collaborative care, healthcare innovation, eHealth, Digital Health, healthcare analytics, behaviour monitoring, user-friendly and accurate visualisation of healthcare data. \nResponsibilities and tasks Technology is transforming healthcare. We are moving from centralised hospital care towards a more distributed connected care model that is widely accessible, personalised and collaborative. Mobile health applications and wearable sensing are empowering patients (and healthy users) to track and manage their own health, wellbeing and lifestyles. Data from medical and health/welfare technology can help care providers to understand and visualize trends, broadening their focus from diagnosis and treatment to prediction and prevention. The healthcare data landscape in Denmark is rich and accessibility for researchers among the best in the world. \nThe Post-Doctoral Research Associate is interested in leveraging technology both in the ways we conduct healthcare research and in the ways design can help to develop, adapt, and integrate technology and mobile health solutions into healthcare. The Post-Doc will have the opportunity to work in close connection with and build on ongoing university-hospital collaborative research on the adaptation and implementation of technology in cognitive rehabilitation, for active ageing, and for chronic disease management, with the long-term vision of improving the design of health care systems for connected and collaborative care. \nOverall, our healthcare research takes an engineering systems design perspective to integrate people, processes, and technology for more effective, personalised, collaborative, connected, and sustainable healthcare delivery and -improvement. We are motivated by the opportunities offered through the accelerating pace of technological innovation to ease the increasing burden of chronic disease. With a human-centric focus, we study how innovative technology and processes may be woven into existing health and care systems to improve treatment as well as early diagnosis and prevention. Our objectives are to develop conceptual design frameworks for healthcare improvement and to apply these frameworks to the real-life health and care challenges of our society, be it in the general population or in patient groups via collaborations with clinicians. Our ambitions are to provide both better and more cost-effective health care. In particular, all of our current projects aim to push the boundaries of how the interaction between people and novel Information and Communications Technologies (ICT), mobile-, and wearable technologies can help re-model care practices, especially in the fields of mental health, elderly care and active ageing, and hypertension. \nOne of our projects is exploring how wearables might be adapted to match the needs and capabilities of the dementia care network, how technologies and data might be used to understand patient behaviour and support clinical research, and how these findings can reinforce or rethink current care practices. Another of our initiative is related to the Stanford Medicine X Precision Research Challenge, for which we have been selected as one six finalists worldwide and enabled us to pursue a pilot study with more than 50 elderly participants enrolled. Another project explores how personalisation, patient apprenticeship/situated learning, and shared-decision making between patient and providers may promote behavioural change in hypertensive patients towards their increased engagement in therapy. The project will develop a conceptual healthcare design framework applied to the design, implementation and field trial of an ICT-solution for collaborative hypertensive care. \nSpecific tasks include the dissemination of knowledge in the form of peer-reviewed journal and conference contributions and the focus on acquisition of research funding for the group. \nThe Post-Doc will be working with partners from academic, health and industrial sectors. In particular, researchers from the Engineering Systems Division are active members of the Copenhagen Center for Health Technology ( cachet.dk ), connecting with researchers from other DTU Departments, health researchers from the Copenhagen University, representatives from the Municipality of Copenhagen and the Capital Region, neuropsychologists, doctors, nurses, patient organisations, caregivers and patients, and many more. The Post-Doctoral Research Associate will enter and continue to build health and care research and industry relationships across DTU, Denmark, and worldwide. \nQualifications Candidates should have a PhD degree or equivalent. \nThe interdisciplinary nature of the project means that applicants from a broad range of technical backgrounds will be considered. Applicants should have (or expect to obtain by the start date) a PhD degree, preferably in design, design engineering, engineering, computer or systems science, health sciences, computational social science, etc. Preference will be given to those candidates with a high level of English (and also Danish language skills) who can demonstrate an aptitude for conceptual and empirical work, modelling and programming, and the confidence to network within academic, public, and commercial organisations. \nFurther qualifications include: Excellent scientific dissemination skills and passion for writing. Excellent communication skills, fluent written and oral English; Danish language capability is a plus. Outstanding in analysis and synthesis. Well-versed in interaction with manifold stakeholders in academia, public healthcare institutions, patients, funding bodies, industry, design- and service consultancies Ability to work under deadlines with a result-driven attitude. Team spirit and excellent collaboration skills. Knowledge in academic writing in a popular language. Passion for and mastery of visual communication design, graphic design, multimedia is a plus. \nWe offer DTU is a leading technical university globally recognized for the excellence of its research, education, innovation and scientific advice. We offer a rewarding and challenging job in an international environment. We strive for academic excellence in an environment characterized by collegial respect and an academic freedom tempered by responsibility. \nSalary and terms of employment The appointment will be based on the collective agreement with the Danish Confederation of Professional Associations. The allowance will be agreed with the relevant union. The position is full-time, with a fixed term of three years. \nThe employment period starts from 3 September 2018 or as soon as possible thereafter. The workplace will be at DTU Lyngby Campus, Building 424. \nYou can read more about career paths at DTU here . \nFurther information Further information may be obtained from Professor Anja Maier; email: amai@dtu.dk or tel.: +45 4525 6045. \nYou can read more about the Engineering Systems Division on www.es.man.dtu.dk . \nApplication procedure Please submit your online application no later than 8 June 2018 (local time) . Applications must be submitted as one PDF file containing all materials to be given consideration. To apply, please open the link \"Apply online\", fill in the online application form, and attach all your materials in English in one PDF file . The file must include: A letter motivating the application (cover letter) Curriculum vitae (CV) List of publications A brief description of your own research activities and ideas for future research in the field (max 3 pages) Two reference contacts Copies of your original (B.Sc, M.Sc, and Ph.D.) diplomas, certificates, and lists of subjects with your results as well as their official translation into English \nApplications and enclosures received after the deadline will not be considered. \nAll interested candidates irrespective of age, gender, disability, race, religion or ethnic background are encouraged to apply. \nDTU Management Engineering contributes actively to the development of management tools and optimization of processes by using and re-thinking theoretical engineering perspectives, models and methods. Through our research and teaching, we ensure an innovative, competitive and sustainable organization and use of technologies within areas such as energy and climate, transportation, production and health, both domestic and abroad. DTU Management Engineering has 340 employees; including an academic staff of 190 and 68 PhD students. More than 20% of our employees are from abroad and in all 38 different nationalities are represented at the department.DTU is a technical university providing internationally leading research, education, innovation and scientific advice. Our staff of 5,800 advance science and technology to create innovative solutions that meet the demands of society; and our 11,000 students are being educated to address the technological challenges of the future. DTU is an independent academic university collaborating globally with business, industry, government, and public agencies.
