"published": "2018-03-23T10:38:00.000+03:00", "title": "English language becoming a force in Danish universities", "text": "English language becoming a force in Danish universities \nAlmost half of graduate students have classes in English Well, perhaps a bit more complicated than that (photo: Pixabay) March 23rd, 2018 8:38 am| by Christian W \nUniversity students in Denmark are increasingly finding themselves having to read and speak English in the classrooms. \nAccording to figures from the national statistics keeper Danmarks Statistik, 43 percent of the 64,700 current graduate students in Denmark received classes in English. \nAt some universities, such as at Copenhagen Business School and ITU in Copenhagen, English has superseded Danish as the dominant language of use. \nThe same is the case at the Technical University of Denmark (DTU), where all graduates have been taught in English for the past decade, and it\u2019s no coincidence. \n\u201cWithin engineering, English is the international language of choice, so by offering it we ensure we equip the Danish students with a level of English that makes them competitive internationally,\u201d Anders Bjarklev, DTU rector, told DR Nyheder. \nREAD MORE: Danish universities taking hard look at sexual harassment \nDI delighted The figures also reveal that 57 percent of the graduate students who chose English-language educations are Danish citizens. Meanwhile Roskilde University has the fewest graduate students studying in English. \nThe national confederation for industry, Dansk Industri (DI), is pleased with the development as it provides higher-quality educations. \n\u201cWe get some students that can obtain knowledge from all over the world and benefit from research environments that are outside Denmark,\u201d Rasmus Dahl, a spokesperson for DI, told DR Nyheder. \n\u201cWe think that it\u2019s wonderful that Danish students are also aware that attaining knowledge in a foreign language is actually a plus in terms of their careers.\u201d Related News", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "danmarks statistik", "sentiment": "none"}, the Alveo Ironman 70.3 Davao at the Azuela Cove.\nDAVAO CITY \u2014 Timothy Reed of Australia has won at every level in triathlon, including three Ironman 70.3 titles in the Philippines, but considers the Alveo Ironman 70.3 as probably one of the toughest competitions out there.\nReed, 33, will face a brusing challenge in today\u2019s main event as he goes up against former world champions and fellow Australians Craig Alexander and Ben Allen, Mauricio Mendez of Mexico and Bradley Weiss of South Africa that begins and ends at Azuela Cove.\nAccording to Reed, the 2016 world champion, the participant who is in tip-top shape and his ability to endure the hot weather, would play a crucial role in his bid.\nThe 44-year-old Alexander is a three-time Ironman world winner, while Allen, Weiss and Mendez, who placed second in Cebu last year, are former Xterra world champions.\n\u201cAnything can happen,\u201d said Reed, whose last swim-bike-run event was last November when he won the 5i50 Bellevue Resort Triathlon in Bohol. \u201cThe heat condition will have a lot to do on who is tough.\u201d\n\u201cThe outcome is not so important to me, rather just to really enjoy. First time in Davao, if there is any race in the Philippines I would love coming here. It\u2019ll be very difficult for me not to race,\u201d he said.\nMendez, for his part, said that he\u2019s hoping for back-to-back titles in two weeks following his successful stint in Chile, although he too considers it to be a tough competition.\n\u201cI feel great. It\u2019s just amazing to be here, I love the people. I\u2019m super excited for the race. As you see it\u2019s a tough field, I just to do my best,\u201d said the 22-year-old Mendez. \u201cIt\u2019s going to really hard, it\u2019s going to be a really tough race. I\u2019ll do my best to win the event.\u201d\n\u201cI raced in Chile before coming here, which is part of my preparation. I won, so winning back-to-back titles in two weeks would be great. That\u2019s the goal,\u201d added Mendez.\nAlexander, who bagged Ironman world titles in full Ironman in 2008, 2009 and 2011, as well as 70.3 Ironman world championships in 2006 and 2011, thinks that Reed and Mendez, together Australia\u2019s Tim Berkel are the \u2018men to beat\u2019 in this competition.\n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot\u2026 Tim Berkel, Tim Reed, Mauricio (Mendez),\u201d he said. \u201cA lot of good guys here.\u201d\nAs for his chances, Alexander, who has competed in Subic and Cebu in previous years, said it would be nice if he can have a podium finish considering his seven-month layoff following a bike crash\n\u201cI broke my collarbone and four ribs, but all the indications in training were very good. discovered in a shipment which was only declared as used dump truck and tractor head, Commissioner Isidro Lape\u00f1a revealed on Thursday.\nInvestigation showed that the shipment was consigned to 429 Entreprises with office address at Purok 5 Km 24 Bunawan, Davao City. It arrived at the Port of Davao on March 10. A certain Juvy Buctuanon was identified as the customs broker who processed the importation of the shipment.\nAccording to the BOC-Davao, the shipment passed through the red lane and was immediately examined by customs agents on March 12.\nThe agents discovered that aside from 295 packages of used completely knockdown (CKD) dump truck and tractor head, the shipment also contained undeclared used SUV.\nA warrant of seizure and detention was then issued against the shipment by District Collector Erastus Sandino Austria.\nAustria said the importation violates the Executive Order No. 877-A or the Comprehensive Motor Vehicle Development Program, Department of Trade and Industry Administrative Order No. 08 or the Guidelines for the Mandatory Accreditation of Rebuilding Centers, and Section 1400 May 23 to 27 in the provinces of Davao del Sur, Batangas, and Iloilo pitting Gilas Pilipinas against a selection team representing Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. ADVERTISEMENT\n\u201cYou know, during the President\u2019s birthday, all he does is to lock himself up at home,\u201d Roque told reporters on Thursday\nBut there could be a celebration in the succeeding days, he said.\nFor the other days of the Holy Week, Mr. Duterte would just stay in his home province.\nThere is no work in government offices beginning Maundy Thursday to Easter Sunday.\nOn his birthday last year, Mr. Duterte spent the day at home as well and took the opportunity to catch up on sleep. But in the afternoon, he got a visit from his grandchildren, who woke him up and gathered around him. \u2014 LEILA B. Teresita Gaspan, the city police spokesperson, said also seized during the buy-bust operation conducted on Thursday at a motel on Cabaguio Avenue was suspected shabu valued at P1.44 million.\nShe identified the arrested suspects as 26-year old Cader Macud, and 23-year-old Arsalic Gamba, residents of Tagum City. ADVERTISEMENT\nAccording to Gaspan, Macud is a member of the MNLF while Gamba is a college student.\nGaspan said a combined team from the city police and the Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency (PDEA) in Southern Mindanao conducted the buy-bust operation, acting on information that an alias \u201cKadir\u201d was selling shabu inside the motel.\nGaspan said the anti-drug sting was carried out around 5:30 p.m. Thursday. A poseur-buyer transacted with Cader and managed to acquire a sachet of shabu using a marked P1,000-bill.\nUpon the agent\u2019s cue, law enforcers entered the room where the alleged buy-bust was being held, and arrested the two suspects.\nInside the motel room, Gaspan said authorities found sachets of shabu, a cellular phone allegedly being used in the drug transaction, and other items, including cash.\nWhen frisked, Cader also yielded an MNLF ID, according to Gaspan.\n\u201cThe suspects were considered High Value Target,\u201d she also said.\nCader and Gamban were temporarily being "author": "", "published": "2018-03-25T11:25:00.000+03:00", "title": "Xterra world champ Mauricio Mendez, Radka Kahlefeldt rule Davao Ironman 70.3", "text": "From: The Wires March 25, 2018, 04:25 pm MEXICO\u2019S Mauricio Mendez and Radka Kahlefeldt of the Czech Republic broke the Aussies\u2019 domination of Philippine triathlon, winning the pro divisions of the first Alveo Ironman 70.3 at the Azuela Cove in Davao. The 22-year-old Mendez rallied in the closing stage of the 1.9K swim, 90K bike, 21K run event to beat three-time Philippine Ironman 70.3 champion Tim Reed and Tim Van Berkel. \u201cThat was a hard battle,\u201d said Mendez, the reigning Xterra world champion. \u201cI was in second place until the final 13 kilometers. The effort was just too hard.\u201d From fifth in the opening swim part, Mendez worked his way up in the bike stage then outlasted his veteran rivals in the grueling run event to nail his first Ironman 70.3 victory in 3:50:32. Reed clocked 3:52:26 to finish second while Van Berkel came in third in 3:53:45 followed by five-time world champion Craig Alexander, also of Australia (3:56:24) and Bradley Weiss of South Africa (3:58:37). But while Mendez needed to unleash a strong finishing kick to snare the crown, Kahlefeldt dominated the women\u2019s pro side and completed a wire-to-wire triumph in 4:25:38. She came out on top in the swim leg then sustained her charge in the bike and run, posting a more than 11-minute victory for her sixth career championship. Japanese Naomi Washizu took runner-up honors in 4:36:53 while many-time Philippine triathlon champion Dimity Lee Duke settled for third in 4:39:12. Lisa Tyack, also from Australia, clocked 4:41:01 and placed fourth in her first pro race while Kirralee Seidel, also from Down Under, timed 4:53:04 for fifth in the event held in Mindanao for the first time in a decade of triathlon staging by Sunrise Events, Inc. Mendez still trailed Reed in the early part of the run stage but grabbed the lead in the last seven kms and stayed ahead all the way to the finish. \u201cWhen I passed him, I never looked back,\u201d said Mendez. Reed rued dropping his bottle of power drink off his bike in one of the humps and opted not to stop to get it back in fear of losing precious time. \u201cI couldn\u2019t afford to stop,\u201d said Reed who also thanked countryman Berkel for sparing a couple of (power) gels. Rounding out the top 10 of the elite pros were South Africa's Bradley Weiss (3:58:37) and Kyle Buckingham (4:01:43), Australians Sam Betten (4:03:36), Eric Watson (4:13:59) and Ben Allen (4:18:08) and Canada's Brent McMahon (4:20:38). Jorry Ycong emerged as the top Filipino finisher in the race that generated so much interest and a monstrous traffic in and around the city on race day. He locked 4:24:15, followed in the Filipino elite category by August Benedicto (4:25:02), Banjo Norte (4:25:07), Jumalil Paul (4:36:24) and Benjamin Rana (4:40:42). ADVERTISEMENT - CONTINUE READING BELOW Moya Johansson from Australia topped the 25-29 category in 4:52:00 and Great Britain\u2019s David Watson topped the 35-39 group in 4:31:21 in the event sponsored "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Joko Magalong-De Veyra", "published": "2018-03-25T06:06:00.000+03:00", "title": "Bizu welcomes summer with Pinoy-flavored macarons", "text": "(Top left clockwise) Ube, Malagos Chocolate, Durian, Queso macarons from Bizu. Jeeves de Veyra MANILA -- Besides celebrating World Macaron Day on Saturday by giving away free macarons to their customers, Bizu Patisserie also launched four new macaron flavors for the summer.\nThis French confection has garnered a following in the Philippines, thanks in large part to Bizu, which helped popularize macarons in the early 2000s. Whether eating them with tea or coffee, or on their own, these melt-in-your-mouth treats are always a delight, especially now that they come in local flavors.\nThe Malagos Chocolate macaron uses 65% dark chocolate from Davao, creating a great interplay of sweet and slightly bitter -- ideal for those that like it not too sweet.\nWith local cheese and white chocolate ganache sandwiching yellow almond meringue discs, the Queso Macaron has a very light cheese flavor.\nThe Ube Macaron, meanwhile, has purple and white discs, and a dark violet Bohol yam infused buttercream filling. Ube is the world\u2019s flavor de jour of the moment, and Bizu\u2019s macaron is unapologetically ube\u2014a great representation of our favorite local yam.\nLast but not the least, fans of Davao\u2019s pungent fruit will love the Durian Macaron. With durian-infused buttercream, one can tell Bizu didn\u2019t scrimp on the flavor with just a whiff.\nThese summer macarons will only be available until April 31.\n ", "highlightText": "", "2018-03-24T03:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "Davao to host Alveo Ironman 70.3 triathlon", "text": "DAVAO CITY \u2014 After years of waiting, the region of Mindanao gets to stage a top caliber triathlon competition as Davao City hosts the 2018 Alveo Ironman 70.3 set tomorrow here.\nAccording to Sunrise Events chief Wilfred Uytengsu, the competition has been staged in parts of Luzon and Visayas, but this marks the first time that Mindanao is holding the event.\n\u201cThis is our 10th year anniversary with Sunrise and now that we\u2019re here in Mindanao, Ironman is truly in the Philippines,\u201d Uytengsu said yesterday during a press conference at Azuala Cove.\nDavao City Mayor Sara Duterte-Carpio said that Uytengsu has approached her regarding the possibility of hosting the event in the past, but it was only this time that they are staging the event.\n\u201cI have been wanting to do this (Ironman) since my first term in 2012,\u201d Duterte-Carpio said. \u201cI\u2019m very happy and we \u2013 the Davaoe\u00f1os \u2013 are very excited for the next three days.\u201d\nThe daughter of the President likewise assured that security is not an issue considering that the local government has made the necessary preparation with the help of the region\u2019s Philippine National Police and Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP).\nThe event already started with the 5k run IronGirls around the Azalea Cove yesterday, while the IronKids is set today, while the main swim-bike-run event is scheduled tomorrow.\nAt least 1,800 participants from 39 countries are vying in the first Mindanao Ironman, including Australian Tim Reed, the World Ironman titlist in 2016, Mexico\u2019s Mauricio Mendez and Bradley Weiss of South Africa, the Xterra world champions in 2016 and 2017, respectively, and three-time Ironman winner Craig Alexander.\nOthers vying are equally talented women triathletes Anna Eberhardt of Hungary and Dimity Lee Duke of Australia in this event backed by 2Go Express, Powerade, Wilkins Pure Purified Water, Sportswear, TYR, GU, Aboitiz Power, Davao Light, David\u2019s Salon, Intercare, Davao Metro Shuttle, Prudential Guarantee, HyperHD on Cignal, AsiaTri.com, FinisherPix, TriLife and The Philippine STAR, Alaska, AlcoPlus, ApoAgua, Cetaphil, Daylong, Devant, Fern-C, Penong\u2019s Barbecue Seafood and Grill, Sanicare, Storck, Timex, Seda, Park Inn, Waterfront, Marco Polo and Active Network. All of this happened in a span of three seasons.\nOsweiler lit it up against the Indianapolis Colts on Thursday Night Football late in the 2017 season, launching him into a brief, stratospheric flight before crashing back to earth the next week in a 27-11 loss to Washington. It was the last Denver would see of Osweiler, who drifted into free agency after the close to a disappointing season for the Broncos .\nOsweiler resurfaced in Miami, where he took a Thursday visit and will backup Ryan Tannehill , who missed the entire 2017 season with an ACL injury. Most Dolphins fans will want to forget the brief Jay Cutler era and return to Tannehill as the driver. Now they'll have the added knowledge -- no, not comfort -- of Osweiler's existence on the bench, where he hopefully won't be denied garbage-time snaps like he once was by Peyton Manning .", "author": "Kyunghee Park", "published": "2018-03-23T06:48:00.000+03:00", "title": "These Are the World\u2019s Best (and Cleanest) Airports", "text": "\nTerminal 4 at Changi Airport in Singapore. Photographer: Nicky Loh/Bloomberg \nAsia has the world\u2019s best airports. Still. \nThat\u2019s according to the latest ranking by Skytrax, which sees Singapore\u2019s Changi taking the top spot for the sixth year in a row. It\u2019s followed by Seoul\u2019s Incheon International Airport , Tokyo\u2019s Haneda, Hong Kong International Airport, and Doha\u2019s Hamad International Airport. Munich Airport, in sixth place, was the highest ranked among airfields in Europe. \nU.S. hubs were absent from the top 10 list based on an airport customer survey that\u2019s been conducted annually since 1999. Changi Airport -- which handled a record 62.2 million passengers last year -- has been expanding its capacity to meet rising demand for air travel. The airport is building its fifth terminal, a third runway, as well as a shopping-and-dining facility called the Jewel as passengers increase. \nAt number 14, Vancouver was the highest ranked airport in North America. Denver, down one spot to 29th, was the best placed among U.S. airports, while New York\u2019s JFK fell six places to 69th. \nAsia also dominated Skytrax\u2019s list of the world\u2019s cleanest airports, led by Haneda, Nagoya in Japan, and Incheon. \nIn a separate ranking of airport terminals, London Heathrow\u2019s terminal 2 placed first, followed by Munich\u2019s terminal 2 and Changi\u2019s terminal 3. \n\u2014 With assistance by Adrian Leung Before it's here, it's on the Bloomberg Terminal. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: https://usat.ly/2Gm0ddY Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs School district will move to 4-day weeks. No Monday class for these Colorado students USA Today Network Alexander Kirk, KUSA-TV, Denver Published 8:23 a.m. ET March 23, 2018 By changing to a 4-day school week, Superintendent Chris Fiedler said the district hopes to save around $1 million in three key areas. (Photo: KUSA-TV, Denver) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE DENVER \u2014 A Colorado school district will transition from a five-day week to a four-day week beginning in August. Brighton-based School District 27J announced Monday the four-day week will entice quality teachers and allow for the allocation of resources to items more critical to the district's \"primary purpose.\" \"We're confident it's going to attract teachers and keep them,\" District 27J Superintendent Chris Fiedler said. \"I haven't had teachers say that this is a horrible idea.\" Other hopes for the four-day week are that it will \"reorganize and create time to support teacher development and preparedness,\" create a school calendar that increases instructional time and is \"clean, clear and concise making it less difficult for families to manage.\" \u201cI realize this will be a significant change for our students, their families, and the communities we are so fortunate to serve, but our district can no longer be expected to do more with less financial resources,\u201d the release continued. The new schedule follows the district's six failed attempts to get more money through bond elections. With the new change, Fiedler said they hope to save around $1 million in three key areas. By not running school buses on the days with no classes, he said the district estimates to save around $700,000. School District 27J plans to tack on a couple hundred thousand more dollars by not paying for substitute teachers. The final big saving, Fiedler said, would come from utility costs, but it's unclear how much that might be. While the school district plans on saving money, some parents will have to pay a little more for child care. Fiedler said the district offers child care services on the days kids won't be in school. It costs $30 a day which he admits isn't as great as the option parents currently have when their students are in class. More: Hey, boss: Moms get it done. Here's how to keep them around The district has picked Monday as the day kids won't have class. \"We really feel like Monday is the day to prepare and to be better for kids,\" Fiedler said. \"This will give people a chance to have a weekend and then come in on Monday \u2014 whether they're paid to or not because they're doing that work anyway to be prepared for kids and to be better for kids.\" Teachers will still have to work on one Monday of each month, however, it will only be half a day. Fiedler said the new schedule also gives them an extra hour each day to catch up on work, which is something they don't currently have. \u201cWe are 100% committed to providing our students with the necessary skills and competencies that will enable a future far beyond graduation. To that end, I believe it is in our students\u2019 best interest to provide high quality, engaged teachers using 21st Century tools for learning four days a week rather than not have them five days a week.\u201d School District 27J serves 18,000 students in Brighton, Commerce City, Henderson, Thornton and Aurora. "Brock Osweiler reportedly agrees to terms with Dolphins, will reunite with Adam Gase Brock Osweiler is taking his talents to South Beach \u2022 1 min read \nBrock Osweiler is taking his talents to South Beach. \nAccording to ESPN.com , Osweiler is going to sign with Miami in a move that reunites him with Adam Gase. The Dolphins head coach has played a big part in Osweiler's development during the quarterback's first three years in the league (2012-14). During Osweiler's rookie year in Denver, Gase was the Broncos ' quarterbacks coach. In 2013, Gase was promoted to offensive coordinator, which was his role in Denver until he left to take the same job with the Bears in 2015. \nWith the Dolphins, Osweiler will likely provide insurance for Ryan Tannehill , who has had some trouble staying healthy over the past two years. The Dolphins starting quarterback has suffered a total of two ACL injuries over the past two seasons and it's still unclear when he might be 100 percent. Tannehill has only played in 13 of 32 regular season games over the past two seasons. \nOsweiler is coming to Miami from Denver, where he spent the 2017 season. Although the terms of Osweiler's deal haven't been released, we can probably safely assume the numbers will be nowhere close to the contract he received after leaving Denver following the 2015 season. \nIn March 2016, Osweiler signed a massive four-year, $72 million contract with the Texans that included $37 million in guaranteed money. After an ugly year in Houston, the Texans unloaded Osweiler (and his contract) in a March 2017 trade that sent him to Cleveland. However, Osweiler never actually played a regular season game with the Browns in 2017 because he was cut before the regular season started . \nThe 27-year-old quarterback visited with the Dolphins on Thursday and Miami clearly liked him enough that they didn't let him leave the building. With both Jay Cutler and Matt Moore no longer on the roster, the Dolphins were in desperate need of a quarterback. \nOsweiler, who was a second round pick in the 2012 NFL Draft , has a 13-12 career record as a starter after going 0-4 with the Broncos last season. Prosecutors claim Bahktiyor Jumaev developed a closeness with fellow Uzbek Jamshid Muhtorov when the pair shared an apartment and that the two men discussed joining the IJU through phone calls and emails by using code words such as \u201cwedding\u201d to describe jihad.\n\u201cIt\u2019s a crime to send money or property to a terrorist organization,\u201d said prosecutor Gregory Holloway at a courthouse in Denver. \u201cThat\u2019s why we\u2019re here.\u201d\nIn 2011, prosecutors say Jumaev sent $300 to Jamshid Muhtorov and later admitted to FBI agents that he knew it was going towards the IJU.\nHowever, Jumaev\u2019s attorney David Barry Savitz argued that the FBI illegally extracted a false confession from him by arresting him after a night\u2019s work and interrogating him for three hours.\nHe went on to claim that his client merely intended to pay back Muhtorov for a $500 bond required to get Jumaev out of jail and was not related to the IJU.\n\u201cHe considered himself trapped. He was scared. He was exhausted,\u201d Savitz said in his opening statement. \u201cIt was strictly intended to pay his debt and has nothing to do with the IJU.\u201d\nThe FBI\u2019s tough questioning allegedly reminded Jumaev of an experience he had in 1999 where Uzbekistan National Security agents questioned him before severely beating him.\nIn January, Jumaev\u2019s lawyers asked a judge not to allow the prosecution to show jurors a video showing the beheading of FBI agents found on Muhtorov\u2019s computer.\n\u201cThere is no evidence that Mr. Jumaev viewed any or most of the Muhtorov electronic evidence, particularly the most violent ones,\u201d the motion read.\nMuhtorov was first arrested before boarding a flight in Chicago back in 2012 and is currently being tried separately. He has already served five years in jail without trial, and a decision last year to release him on bail was eventually reversed by a federal judge.\nThe men are two of a number Uzbek migrants charged with terrorism-related offenses in the past year. Last August, 22-year-old Uzbek-American Abror Habibo pled guilty to charges of agreeing to fund terrorist activity, after buying another man a plane ticket to Syria in order to join the Islamic State.\nUzbek migrant Sayfullo Saipov also faces charges of terrorist after carrying out a truck attack that killed eight people and injured at least a dozen others in the city\u2019s deadliest attack "author": "Noelle Phillips", "published": "2018-03-23T06:27:00.000+03:00", "title": "Denver police shot man who was wrongly identified as jail escapee \u2013 The Denver Post", "text": "Three Denver Police Department officers mistakenly thought they were pursuing a jail escapee on Monday night when they fired shots into an SUV with two men inside.\nProvided by Denver Police Department Mauricio Venzor-Gonzalez The passenger in the car had been identified as Mauricio Venzor-Gonzalez, a man who previously has shot at police officers, said Commander Barb Archer, head of the department\u2019s major crimes division. Venzor-Gonzalez had escaped custody from Denver Sheriff Department deputies during a medical transport Monday morning.\nVenzor-Gonzalez was not in the car.\nInstead, officers killed 27-year-old Steven Nguyen and wounded 23-year-old Rafael Landeros in the shooting, Archer said Thursday.\nEven though police shot the wrong person, Archer declared the shooting was justified because the officers reasonably believed they were pursuing Venzor-Gonzalez. The people in the car did not follow officers\u2019 orders and appeared to be searching for something as officers yelled for them to show their hands, she said.\n\u201cOfficers knew that Venzor-Gonzalez had been arrested in November for attempting to kill a police officer,\u201d Archer said. \u201cThey believed the actions being made inside the car were efforts to locate a weapon. So fearing for their safety the officers fired.\u201d\nThe shooting, which happened near East 40th Avenue and Albion Street, remains under investigation by the Denver District Attorney, Denver police and Aurora Police Department. District Attorney Beth McCann ultimately decides whether a police shooting is justified under state law. The police department\u2019s internal affairs bureau will investigate whether officers followed department policies in the pursuit and shooting and why the men in the car had been incorrectly identified.\nMeanwhile, Venzor-Gonzalez remains on the lam. Police consider him to be dangerous, and a manhunt involving multiple law enforcement agencies is ongoing. Venzor-Gonzalez engaged in a shootout with a Denver police officer in November after a car chase.\nAt the time, Venzor-Gonzalez was wanted for abducting a woman and her toddler. During the shootout, Venzor-Gonzalez was struck multiple times and was at-large for two days before police found him inside an Aurora home with high-powered weapons.\n\u201cHe\u2019s a very dangerous individual,\u201d Archer said. \u201cHe remains our top priority. The community isn\u2019t safe with him out there.\u201d\nRelated Articles February 14, 2018 Denver police officer fired at suspect in November shooting in self-defense, DA concludes March 21, 2018 DA clears Denver police officer who shot bank robber on the 16th Street Mall March 19, 2018 Inmate held on attempted-murder charges escapes from Denver Health January 29, 2018 2018 Colorado officer-involved shootings On Monday night, officers were conducting surveillance outside a home, and an SUV with two men inside repeatedly circled the block. Police received information that led them to believe Venzor-Gonzalez was in the passenger seat, but when they tried to stop the car, the driver fled, Archer said.\nOfficers were given permission to pursue the fleeing SUV. When the SUV stopped, officers ordered the occupants to show their hands. The occupants ignored them, Archer said. Officers fired their guns.\nThe car then rolled down an embankment, and officers said they could see the occupants continuing to look for something. They fired a second round of shots as the car was coming to a stop, Archer said.\nDenver police officers are allowed to shoot at moving vehicles under very limited circumstances.\nAfter the shooting, officers founded a loaded handgun in the car.\nThe officers, who have not been identified, have been placed on desk duty, Archer said. There is body camera footage of the shooting, but the police department declined to release it.\nLanderos is being held at the Downtown Detention Center on arrest warrants out of Adams County, Archer said. Investigators have not determined whether he will be charged in connection with the incident Monday night, she said.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": ["https://recirculation.spot.im/spot/sp_sXPv48AD"], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "venzor-gonzalez", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "archer", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "steven nguyen", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "mauricio venzor-gonzalez", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "barb archer", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "rafael landeros", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "denver post three denver police department", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "denver sheriff department", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "denver police department", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "denver", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T01:05:14.003+02:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "02fac980f40ae607da1561f44e2e40d2377611fa", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg.vil7cudDECT7PWlxaY5AJY8OWgh7gXICgVJthgurQ5i7eTxKUOwdDQLRzbOYMME.k5.uY2.DtlX.Z7dtteB8jq.kW6kKbwmvKkAByHAuK65roQkykJFXtd9gePEkp8fA-", "site_full": "www.nfl.com", "site": "nfl.com", "site_section": "", "site_categories": ["football", "sports"], "section_title": "", "title": "Brock Osweiler visiting Miami Dolphins today - "Holly Graham", "published": "2018-03-23T06:35:00.000+03:00", "title": "SeaQuest Interactive Aquarium expands to Denver suburb", "text": "Have you ever wanted to pet an otter? Later this year, you\u2019ll get your chance. About 1,200 animals \u2014 300 species \u2014 will soon call Littleton\u2019s Southwest Plaza mall home.\nSeaQuest Interactive Aquarium is expanding its reach to the Denver suburb. It already has locations in Las Vegas, Fort Worth, Texas, and Layton, Utah.\n\u201cThe mall reached out to us,\u201d said Elsa Macdonald, national marketing director for SeaQuest, as part of an effort to boost the shopping center\u2019s industry. All of SeaQuest\u2019s current locations are inside malls.\nTeams of construction workers are creating a 20,000-square-foot aquatic world on the plaza\u2019s lower level, next to Dillard\u2019s. By late spring, the concrete slabs will mimic tropical forests, underwater utopias and frigid, arctic expanses. Room to room, visitors will be able to feed and touch animals from around the globe.\n\u201cWe\u2019re trying to transition throughout the entire world,\u201d general manager Grant Carter said of the upcoming exhibits.\nCarter said he expects visitors will get the chance to come face-to-face with species they may have never heard of, including his favorite, the coatimundi, which he described adoringly as a \u201craccoon-monkey.\u201d Additionally, visitors will be able to swim with stingrays, take selfies with sharks and snuggle with snakes.\n\u201cThe kids just light up when they\u2019re able to touch the animals and interact with them,\u201d Carter added.\nWhat makes SeaQuest different from other aquariums? It is designed to be hands-on \u2014 not only with animals, but also with the community. Macdonald said SeaQuest hopes to be an integral part of nearby neighborhoods by supporting local nonprofits, hosting field trips for kids, working with STEM students of all ages and even acting as a tropical pet rescue for animals such as parakeets and iguanas.\nEducational stations throughout the aquarium will teach visitors about several topics, including different climates and the importance of conservation.\nMore than 400,000 people visited SeaQuest locations last year, Macdonald said. She hopes to increase that number with the addition of the Littleton location and another in Southern California.\nRelated Articles Horse trapped in rocks near Boulder trail had to be euthanized after unsuccessful rescue attempts Zinke supports restoration of grizzlies in North Cascades U.N. reports see a lonelier planet with fewer plants, animals Australian volunteers save 5 of over 150 stranded whales The Denver Zoo\u2019s new baby sloth has a name \u2014 and it\u2019s as sweet as candy So, if you\u2019ve ever wanted to work at an aquarium, now\u2019s your chance.\n\u201cMermaids are real at SeaQuest,\u201d Carter said, hinting at an available job title. \u201cThe hiring process (for several positions) will be ramping up within the next few weeks.\u201d\nPresale and discounted passes are available online until the end of the month at littleton.visitseaquest.com . Regular day passes begin at $8.95 per person at other SeaQuest locations. For more information, go to visitseaquest.com .\nSeaQuest Interactive Aquarium: Southwest Plaza, 8501 W. "2018-03-25T01:01:00.000+03:00", "title": "Sony Hypes Up its PS4 Exclusive Line-up in New Video", "text": "\nBy creating an account, you verify that you are at least 13 years of age, and have read and agree to the Comicbook.com Terms of Service and Privacy Policy Search Sony Hypes Up its PS4 Exclusive Line-up in New Video By Tyler Fischer 0 \nThere's no denying Sony Interactive Entertainment knows how to make a good hype video. They've been doing it for years, and are good for one every few months. That said, this week it released a new one, this time using the hype to highlight its PlayStation 4 exclusive line-up. \nLike past videos, the new one clips together footage of multiple games -- complimented by hype-inducing music and big text -- all showing off a range of games Sony is \u00e2\u0080\u009cproud to say are only on PlayStation.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \nIf you seen one of these trailers, you've seen them all. This specific one includes both games already available exclusively on the platform, as well as ones slated to hit it soon. The following games are spotlighted: Spider-Man, Horizon: Zero Dawn, Uncharted: The Lost Legacy, Detroit: Become Human , The Last of Us Part II, God of War , Days Gone, Shadow of the Colossus, Gran Turismo Sport, The Inpatient, Concrete Genie, Dreams, Blood and Truth, Hidden Agenda, and Bravo Team. \nAs you would expect, there was no love for the PlayStation Vita, and only a little bit of love for PlayStation VR, with much of the hype-train powered by PS4 games. \nWhether there is meaning behind the absence of games like Death Stranding, Wild , or Ghost of Tushima , is hard to say. There could be a calculated reason for their absence, or none at all. After all, other games such as Moss and Persona 5 are also missing, as well as many other titles. \nNonetheless, the purpose of the video is to simply build some marketing hype, which it successfully does. And given that Sony has Detroit: Become Human, God of War, Spider-man , and more coming this year, it has a reason to be excited. 0 comments \nPersonally, of Sony's line-up I'm looking forward to God of War the most. The combination of everything I've seen looking impressive and the huge marketing push from Sony has me excited and anticipating a game of game of the year material. \nGiven that's already almost April, this very well might be the last hype video we see before E3 in June, which is fine, the more hype saved for E3 the better. ", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "zero dawn", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "tyler fischer", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "sony", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "comicbook.com terms of service", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "sony interactive entertainment", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "detroit", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-25T16:34:10.012+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "670450640626dcaf96fc2b823a73aa7cc91664a3", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZS4vWGx0nMOif_YXnAvfCPcGAjSSbmzmZ_531tlFLOzDg_7QYiQxQ.eQMuMq4SlGQnLvhwLvZ6qfQ1S0YAE9LakOoAHZ3tzlIHuebIJ6RYJoGMghy0id4Y2ODP4DZ5Vt2Y-", "site_full": "www.freep.com", "site": "freep.com", "site_section": "http://rssfeeds.freep.com/freep/home", "site_categories": ["real_estate", "buying_selling_homes"], "section_title": "GANNETT Syndication Service", "title": "General Motors&apos; private car museum has been a secret for years", "title_full": "General Motors&apos; private car museum has been a secret for years", "published": "2018-03-24T15:33:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "US", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://www.gannett-cdn.com/-mm-/cd1ac3acfb550eb17be7f5be99815d3cebee7481/c=0-122-2400-1478&r=x1683&c=3200x1680/local/-/media/2018/03/23/DetroitFreeP/DetroitFreePress/636574173317198063-GM-HeritageMuseum-032018-20.JPG", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 2980, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 2068, "comments": 7, "shares": 2068}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 7}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "670450640626dcaf96fc2b823a73aa7cc91664a3", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZS4vWGx0nMOif_YXnAvfCPcGAjSSbmzmZ_531tlFLOzDg_7QYiQxQ.eQMuMq4SlGQnLvhwLvZ6qfQ1S0YAE9LakOoAHZ3tzlIHuebIJ6RYJoGMghy0id4Y2ODP4DZ5Vt2Y-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Detroit Free Press", "published": "2018-03-24T15:33:00.000+03:00", "title": "General Motors&apos; private car museum has been a secret for years", "text": "Last Slide Next Slide The unpublicized collection is somehow attracting visitors recently from Sweden, Australia, Poland, Kuwait, Egypt and Sudan. They\u2019re driving to the building just off Mound Road, between 15 Mile and 16 Mile roads. The dreary route is riddled with potholes. There\u2019s no big sign directing anyone to anything in particular. The setting is an industrial park. Secret handshake? Viewing is by appointment only. Callers schedule visits months and years in advance. While access at the locked front door doesn\u2019t require a secret handshake, it probably should. \"Holy smokes. I've never seen anything like this,\" said Robert Wall, 89, a Detroit native who has attended every Motor City auto show since 1937. \"I had no idea this existed. I couldn't have imagined this in my wildest dreams. I could stay forever.\" He was rationed to 90 minutes. To those who know nothing about cars or think they care little, well, there are simply no words. This is a design mecca. Everything is labeled with historical explanation and auto industry impact. Buy Photo \nA 1966 Oldsmobile Toronado is in the collection of the GM Heritage Center in Sterling Heights, photographed Tuesday, March 20, 2018. (Photo: Mandi Wright, Detroit Free Press) Over there is a 1951 LeSabre and a 1931 Cadillac V-16 and Corvettes from 1953 to 2005 and the very first Oldmobile Toronado ever made. Plus, the Firebird I, II and III gas turbine concept cars from the 1950s. All this chatter about electric vehicles and innovation? Check out the enormous battery under the hood of the 1966 Electrovair II Experimental car. Buy Photo \nA 1966 General Motors Electrovair II experimental car is in the collection of the GM Heritage Center in Sterling Heights, photographed Tuesday, March 20, 2018. (Photo: Mandi Wright, Detroit Free Press) GM may be considered a front-runner on electrification today, but it\u2019s clear the institutional knowledge spans decades, said Greg Wallace, who has helped develop the collection over the past two decades as manager. (On this day, he was filming segments for the History Channel.) A study in innovation \"The collection tells a story of the history of the automobile and our fascination with car culture,\" said Jonathan Klinger, a spokesman for Hagerty, the world's leading classic car insurer based in Traverse City. \"You're actually able to study the thinking and innovation of the company and see how things were applied or not applied to production vehicles.\" Oh, and those Smart micro cars that tuck neatly into puny parking spaces in New York and San Francisco? Don\u2019t miss their predecessor, a 1969 512 Electric Experimental. Buy Photo \nA 1969 General Motors 512 electric experimental car is in the collection of the GM Heritage Center. Built to be an urban two seater with fiberglass body and steel chassis, it utilized special Delco-Remy lightweight lead-acid batteries taking 7 hours on a complete recharge from a 115-volt household outlet. The car\u00d5s range at 25 miles an hour is 58 miles. (Photo: Mandi Wright, Detroit Free Press) Visitors learn that the word \u201ccranky\u201d comes from drivers in the early 1900s having a bad day crank-starting the car. The crankshaft would kick back and break a thumb or a wrist and, on occasion, come out of the crank hold and hit the operator in the head, Wallace said. Vehicles from the 1900s have headlight covers that open to reveal a lantern wick inside. Steering wheels in 1912 were on the right, not left. (Ford put so many steering wheels on the left side that eventually everyone else did too, Wallace pointed out.) Matt Anderson, curator of transportation at The Henry Ford in Dearborn, said classic car junkies can't help but savor trips to the Heritage collection. \"All of the significant show cars are there \u2013 the Y-Job, the Le Sabre, the Firebirds \u2013 as well as the company\u2019s iconic production cars \u2013 the Tri-Five Chevys, the 1959 Cadillac, the split-window 1963 Corvette, the 1977 Pontiac Trans Am Special Edition,\" he said. \"But there\u2019s also a strong collection of technologically significant cars \u2013 not as flashy but equally important.\" The first V8! Cars like the 1912 Cadillac, the first auto with an electric starter; the 1915 Cadillac, with the first mass-produced V8 engine; and the 1966 Oldsmobile Toronado, the first front-wheel drive American car since the 1930s. The first electric starter meant people of smaller stature, who lacked upper body strength, could start cars for the first time on their own. And the V8 engine created a new industry standard for more powerful vehicles. Buy Photo \nA 1912 Cadillac Touring, the first of its kind to have an electric self-starter, is in the collection of the GM Heritage Center. In 1912, Cadillac won the Dewar trophy for the electric starter and electric lights. (Photo: Mandi Wright, Detroit Free Press) \"I admire GM for saving examples of less-than-stellar products, too,\" Anderson said. \"One of my favorite vehicles at the GM Heritage Center is a 1976 Chevrolet Chevette \u2013 no one\u2019s idea of a collector car today, but one that sold in the millions in its time. Cars like the Corvette made GM\u2019s image, but cars like the Chevette made its bottom line.\" In the beginning, the goal was just to try and preserve history, Wallace said. \"I had no idea it would turn into what it has,\" he explained. \"Once history is gone, it's gone. I wanted to make sure we could tell our story down the road.\" Now visitors can track a nation's highs and lows, changes and progress. \"You can see prosperity and optimism through the '40s, then where the industry was in hiatus from '42 to '47 for the war and then it all starts back up again. Wealth and prosperity was growing,\" said Mike Simcoe, vice president of global design for GM. \"You see the industry wrestling with the change of fuel economy targets in the late '70s, with more stringent safety requirements, crash requirements, and the way some of those regulations were applied and how it impacted the structure of the vehicles. The '80s were an odd period, in fashion and style generally. I can say this in confidence, I have photos of myself.\" Unlikely to be public Some visitors whisper their desire to see the GM collection turned into a public exhibit on the Detroit riverfront one day, a stone's throw from the company's world headquarters in the Renaissance Center. \"It would be amazing,\" said Eddie Alterman, editor in chief of Car and Driver magazine. \"At the height of its power, GM was seen as the trailblazer \u2014 the Tesla of its time. And the company continues as an innovation leader in ways people don\u2019t fully appreciate.\" The vehicles are so carefully maintained and protected that there's no plan to make the exhibit public, though it can be reserved for group tours, conferences and special events. Despite being a secret, 300-plus events and tours were held in 2017. More: https://www.gmheritagecenter.com/ Near the door of the showroom, there's a small case with photos of non-auto engineering accomplishments that include the B-25 Bomber, P-51 Mustang Fighter and FM-2 Wildcat Fighter; diesel-electric freight locomotives that essentially ended the use of steam; and a 1952 mechanical heart pump that made possible the world's first open heart surgery, developed and donated by GM at no cost to the heart surgery team at Wayne State University in Detroit. \"Mind-boggling,\" Wall said, reading the display. \"Just mind-boggling.\" Contact Phoebe Wall Howard: 313-222-6512 or phoward@freepress.com. Follow her on Twitter@phoebesaid CONNECT 3 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Share your feedback to help improve our site experience! From The USA TODAY NETWORK These sites are part of the USA TODAY NETWORK. "author": "Detroit Free Press Pop Culture Critic", "published": "2018-03-24T02:01:00.000+03:00", "title": "JoAnne Purtan delivers heartfelt goodbye to WXYZ viewers", "text": "Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email JoAnne Purtan delivers heartfelt goodbye to WXYZ viewers The 20-year veteran of Detroit's Channel 7, which is facing cutbacks, thanked her viewers during her final noon newscast at WXYZ. Post to Facebook JoAnne Purtan delivers heartfelt goodbye to WXYZ viewers The 20-year veteran of Detroit's Channel 7, which is facing cutbacks, thanked her viewers during her final noon newscast at WXYZ. Check out this story on Freep.com: https://on.freep.com/2GknxZO Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 9 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs JoAnne Purtan delivers heartfelt goodbye to WXYZ viewers Julie Hinds , Detroit Free Press Pop Culture Critic Published 1:18 p.m. ET March 23, 2018 | Updated 7:01 p.m. ET March 23, 2018 Buy Photo (Photo: Detroit Free Press) Buy Photo CONNECT 9 COMMENT EMAIL MORE WXYZ-TV's JoAnne Purtan said goodbye Friday with a heartfelt message to her viewers of the past two decades. The Channel 7 veteran, whose contract was not renewed by the Detroit station, was choked up as she signed off for her final noon newscast. So was meteorologist Hally Vogel, who was delivering the weather for the noon news. \"JoAnne, you are a wonderful person, coworker, friend. And just to say you will be missed is a sore understatement,\" said Vogel, fighting back tears. \"We truly love you and are going to miss you.\" Broadcasting from Channel 7's glass booth inside the downtown Detroit Qube building, Purtan briefly thanked her friends and colleagues at the station and, in particular, all of the people watching at home. \"I thank you for inviting me into your homes for the last 20 years and, by the way, for all the heartfelt sentiments and well wishes on social media,\" she said. \"I want you to know I have read each and every comment on my Facebook page. I am truly grateful for, really, your love and support.\" Purtan posted March 9 on her Facebook page that she would be leaving the E.W. Scripps-owned television station because of corporate restructuring. Scripps has been making job cuts across its media properties. Her social media announcement was flooded with 5,300 Facebook responses representing a wave of disappointment and anger that Channel 7 was not renewing her contract. \"No way! What a mistake WXYZ! Joanne \u2014 you have always been my favorite \u2014 and the best female anchor \u2014 always a lady with class! WXYZ will lose me as a news viewer now,\" wrote Bevery Grau. An Emmy-winning anchor and reporter who juggled several duties at the station, Purtan also co-anchored \"The Now Detroit\" 4 p.m. newscast, served as a consumer reporter for \"Don't Waste Your Money\" segments and provided weekly profiles of local female entrepreneurs for \"Mom's a Genius\" segments. Also read: Maddox out at WXYZ following harassment suit Purtan's tenure at WXYZ began in 1998. As a prominent Detroit TV figure, she joined the family media tradition of her father, iconic Motor City radio deejay Dick Purtan. Earlier this month, her father shared his pride for his daughter's career and his feelings about her departure on his official Facebook page. \"This is a speed bump in a wonderful career \u2014 and her mother and I have no doubt that there will be much smooth sailing for her down the road,\" he wrote. Facebook | @Dick Purtan's Official Fan Page Dick Purtan's Official Fan Page And with her on-air goodbye, Purtan told viewers she would keep them posted about her future. In her March 9 Facebook post, she indicated she plans to remain in metro Detroit. \"I'm excited about what the future has to bring, but I will particularly miss this time together over the lunch hour every day,\" Purtan concluded. \"Thank you for watching and God bless.\" Contact Detroit Free Press pop culture writer Julie Hinds: 313-222-6427 or jhinds@freepress.com. "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Brooke Singman", "published": "2018-03-23T00:00:00.000+02:00", "title": "Victoria Toensing joins husband Joseph diGenova on Trump's legal team in Russia probe", "text": "Email \nJoseph diGenova, left, and his wife and law partner Victoria Toensing, right, will represent President Trump in the Russia probe. (Fox News) President Trump retained the law firm diGenova & Toensing this week to represent him in Special Counsel Robert Mueller\u2019s investigation into Russian meddling and potential collusion with Trump campaign associates in the 2016 presidential election, sources told Fox News on Thursday. Reports this week suggested Joseph diGenova had joined Trump\u2019s outside legal team, alongside Jay Sekulow, but a source confirmed to Fox News that his wife and law partner, Victoria Toensing, also would represent the president. \nToensing served as deputy assistant attorney general in the criminal division of the Justice Department under the Reagan administration, and as an assistant U.S. attorney in Detroit. Toensing was chief counsel for then-Sen. Barry Goldwater, who sat as chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. \ndiGenova and Toensing, together, were appointed by the House of Representatives in 1997 as special counsel to investigate the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The two also were retained to investigate former New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer in the Democrat's political surveillance controversy, also known as Troopergate. Victoria Toensing reacts to indictment in Uranium One case \nThere have been concerns of a potential conflict of interest with diGenova and Toensing representing the president in Mueller\u2019s investigation, after Toensing\u2019s representation of former key witnesses in the probe. \nRecently, Toensing represented Mark Corallo, an ex-spokesman to former Trump attorney Marc Kasowitz, in his interview with the special counsel\u2019s team. Toensing also represented Sam Clovis, a 2016 Trump campaign associate who supervised George Papadopoulos, in Clovis' Mueller interview. Papadopoulos pleaded guilty last year to making false statements to the FBI as part of the special counsel\u2019s probe. Toensing also represented Erik Prince, a former informal adviser to Trump, who allegedly attended a meeting in January 2017 with a Russian investor in Seychelles, that Mueller reportedly is investigating. \nBut Corallo told Fox News on Thursday there was no conflict of interest. \n\u201cI signed a waiver acknowledging I see no potential conflicts with their representation of the President,\u201d Corallo told Fox News in an email on Thursday, explaining it was a \u201cstandard\u201d waiver of \u201cpotential conflict.\u201d \nA source close to diGenova and Toensing told Fox News that Corallo, Clovis and the president signed a waiver. \n\u201cThe conflict is owned by the client. The conflict privilege is owned by the client,\u201d the source told Fox News. \u201cIt\u2019s the clients who have the privilege to waive. And the president waived it too.\u201d Toensing: FBI, DOJ sought to clear Clinton, frame Trump \nThe source told Fox News that when one attorney at a firm is retained, the entire firm is retained, and when one attorney has a conflict, the entire firm as a conflict, pointing to Ted Olson. \n\u201cIf one lawyer has a conflict, they all do. Ted Olson, who wanted to join the team couldn\u2019t\u2014his law firm represents Fusion GPS,\u201d the source said. \nOlson, a former solicitor general, was invited to join the president\u2019s legal team but declined, a source with knowledge of the outreach told Fox News. Olson's firm, Gibson Dunn, represents Fusion GPS\u2014the research firm behind the now-infamous anti-Trump dossier. \nThe news of Toensing\u2019s addition to Trump\u2019s team came after the president\u2019s lead attorney John Dowd resigned, and Trump \u201cgraciously accepted.\u201d \nDowd had voiced strong opposition to the president doing an interview with Mueller. \nBut on Thursday, when Trump was asked if he wanted to testify before the special counsel\u2019s team, the president responded, \u201cYes. I would like to. I would like to.\u201d \nFox News\u2019 John Roberts contributed to this report. \nBrooke Singman is a Politics Reporter for Fox News. Follow her on Twitter at @brookefoxnews . Trending in Politics", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "joseph digenova", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "victoria toensing", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "toensing", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "digenova", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "barry goldwater", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "robert mueller", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "jay sekulow", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "reagan", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "trump", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "trump", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "justice department", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "senate select committee on intelligence", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "fox news", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "house of representatives", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "digenova & toensing", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "russia", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "detroit", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "u.s.", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T00:27:07.012+02:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "ee513bf13b88e6048972c2d04cb684055071d6d4", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZS_z3bhhMmPW5HyCYgydj3AL1ozAUTh.cO4iwdwL37BD2Cp6BpHWDgeydH_bsle8ue7g2LTDTOmcKvcJUN6X4reBP3xslDKNSvmHj8ETpA2yZxVrI_7VT6eNk.ygXyNmXJUqhmV5PA5GWNRQtsL6Kyv0utMlUaJCm13KYN.Z_fN0Q--", "site_full": "www.bostonglobe.com", "site": "bostonglobe.com", "site_section": "", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "", "title": "Hundreds of thousands expected in Washington protest - The Boston Globe", "title_full": "Hundreds of thousands expected in Washington protest - The Boston Globe", "published": "2018-03-24T16:38:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 0, "site_type": "news", "country": "US", "spam_score": 0.933, "main_image": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/rf/image_585w/Boston/2011-2020/2018/03/24/BostonGlobe.com/National/Images/AFP_1342OD.jpg", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 2402, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 2113, "comments": 0, "shares": 2113}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 1}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "ee513bf13b88e6048972c2d04cb684055071d6d4", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZS_z3bhhMmPW5HyCYgydj3AL1ozAUTh.cO4iwdwL37BD2Cp6BpHWDgeydH_bsle8ue7g2LTDTOmcKvcJUN6X4reBP3xslDKNSvmHj8ETpA2yZxVrI_7VT6eNk.ygXyNmXJUqhmV5PA5GWNRQtsL6Kyv0utMlUaJCm13KYN.Z_fN0Q--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-24T16:38:00.000+03:00", "title": "Hundreds of thousands expected in Washington protest - The Boston Globe", "text": "Read: Watch: Today\u2019s rally in Washington, D.C. \nProtesters denounced the National Rifle Association and its allies and complained that they are scared of getting shot in school and tired of inaction by grown-ups after one mass shooting after another. \nThey called for such measures as a ban on high-capacity magazines and assault-type rifles like the one used by the Florida killer, tighter background checks and school security, and a raising of the age to buy guns. \n\u2018\u2018I'm really tired of being afraid at school,\u2019\u2019 said Maya McEntyre, a 15-year-old high school freshman from Northville, Michigan, who joined a march by thousands in Detroit. \u2018\u2018When I come to school, I don\u2019t want to have to look for the nearest exit.\u2019\u2019 Advertisement \nShe added: \u2018\u2018I want to get to the problem before it gets to me.\u2019\u2019 \nIn Atlanta, Ben Stewart, a 17-year-old senior at Shiloh Hills Christian School in Kennesaw, Georgia, took part in a march in Atlanta to press for what he called \u2018\u2018common-sense gun laws.\u2019\u2019 \n\u2018\u2018People have been dying since 1999 in Columbine and nothing has changed. People are still dying,\u2019\u2019 Stewart said. \u2018\u2018It could be prevented.\u2019\u2019 \nCallie Cavanaugh, a 14-year-old at a march in Omaha, Nebraska, said: \u2018\u2018This just needs to stop. It\u2019s been going on my entire life.\u2019\u2019 \nPresident Donald Trump was in Florida for the weekend. A motorcade took him to his West Palm Beach golf club in the morning. As of early afternoon, he had yet to weigh in on Twitter about the protests. Advertisement \nThe NRA went silent on Twitter in the morning, in contrast to its reaction to the nationwide school walkouts against gun violence March 14, when it tweeted a photo of an assault rifle and the message \u2018\u2018I'll control my own guns, thank you.\u2019\u2019 \nAbout 30 gun-rights supporters staged a counter-demonstration in front of FBI headquarters in Washington, standing quietly with signs such as \u2018\u2018Armed Victims Live Longer\u2019\u2019 and \u2018\u2018Stop Violating Civil Rights.\u2019\u2019 Other gun-control protests around the country were also met with small counter-demonstrations. \nOrganizers of the big rally in the nation\u2019s capital hoped their protest would match in numbers and spirit last year\u2019s women\u2019s march, which far exceeded predictions of 300,000 demonstrators. \n\u2018\u2018We will continue to fight for our dead friends,\u2019\u2019 Delaney Tarr, another survivor of the Florida tragedy, declared from the stage. The crowd roared with approval as she laid down the students\u2019 central demand: a ban on \u2018\u2018weapons of war\u2019\u2019 for all but warriors. \nThe Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.\u2019s 9-year-old granddaughter Yolanda Renee King gave a rousing speech at the Washington rally, drawing from the civil rights leader\u2019s most famous words. \n\u2018\u2018I have a dream that enough is enough,\u2019\u2019 she said. \u2018\u2018That this should be a gun-free world. Period.\u2019\u2019 \nIn Parkland, the police presence was heavy as more than 20,000 people filled a park near the school, chanting slogans such as \u2018\u2018Enough is enough\u2019\u2019 and carrying signs that read \u2018\u2018Why do your guns matter more than our lives?\u2019\u2019 and \u2018\u2018Our ballots will stop bullets.\u2019\u2019 \nGun violence was also fresh for some in the Washington crowd: Ayanne Johnson of Great Mills High in Maryland held a sign declaring, \u2018\u2018I March for Jaelynn,\u2019\u2019 honoring Jaelynn Willey, who died Thursday two days after being shot by a classmate at the school. The classmate also died. \nRallying outside the New Hampshire Statehouse in Concord, 17-year-old Leeza Richter said: \u2018\u2018Our government will do more to stop us from walking out than it will to stop a gunman from walking in.\u2019\u2019 \nSince the bloodshed in Florida, students have tapped into a current of gun control sentiment that has been building for years \u2014 yet still faces a powerful foe in the NRA and its supporters. \nOrganizers hope the passions of the crowds and the under-18 roster of speakers will translate into a tipping point starting with the midterm congressional elections this fall. In addition to pushing for tighter gun laws, the students have been working to register young people to vote. \nPolls indicate public opinion in the U.S. may be shifting on the issue. \nA new poll conducted by The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research found that 69 percent of Americans think gun laws in the U.S. should be tightened. That is up from 61 percent in 2016 and 55 percent in 2013. \nOverall, 90 percent of Democrats, 50 percent of Republicans and 54 percent of gun owners now favor stricter gun laws. \nAt the same time, the poll found that nearly half of Americans do not expect elected officials to take action. \nAssociated Press writers Terry Spencer in Parkland, Florida; Jacob Jordan in Atlanta; and Holly Ramer in Concord, New Hampshire, contributed to this report . Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Detroit March For Our Lives: 5 things you should know Detroit Free Press staff Published 9:51 a.m. ET March 23, 2018 | Updated 12:12 p.m. ET March 23, 2018 CLOSE Vanderbilt students speak on why they will participate in March for our Lives Michael Schwab Martin Luther King Jr. High School students march across campus as part of a national walkout on Wednesday, March 14, 2018 in Detroit. Schools across Michigan and the country are walking out in a call to Congress to pass gun safety legislation to keep schools, communities and places of worship safe. (Photo: Elaine Cromie, Special to the Free Press) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE Thousands of people are expected to fill the Detroit RiverWalk Saturday during the Detroit March For Our Lives. The 11 a.m. march, a sister event to the main march being held the same day in Washington D.C., is part of a continuing rallying cry for gun control following a school shooting in February at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida. Here are 5 things you need to know if you plan to go: Where to go The Detroit march begins at 11 a.m. at Rivard Plaza, 1340 E. Atwater, heads west along the RiverWalk, crossing Jefferson to head north to Campus Martius and then back south to the RiverWalk, where speakers will address marchers near the Renaissance Center, according to the event\u2019s Facebook page . Speakers are to include local students, Congresswomen Debbie Stabenow and Brenda Lawrence, as well as state legislators and others from activist organizations. Also read: B'ham church plans lock-in to prep for march Huge turnout expected More than 3,000 people have indicated on the event's Facebook page that they plan to attend the Detroit march and more than 8,000 people have indicated they are interested. There are other marches being held across metro Detroit Saturday, too. To find one, click here . Grab a Lyft Car service Lyft is offering free rides to March For Our Lives events across the country, including the one in Detroit. Click here to figure out how to get a free ride. \nLyft passengers and driver. (Photo: (Photo: Lyft).) Dodge traffic troubles Driving yourself? Remember there have been numerous road and lane closures for pothole repairs. Check MDOT\u2019s web site for updates. Here\u2019s information about the RiverWalk and Rivard Plaza, including nearby parking, from the Detroit Riverfront Conservancy. Under sunny skies Expect a clear, crisp day in Detroit Saturday, with a high of 39 degrees according to a forecast from the National Weather Service. A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 3 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs First pitch thrown at former Tiger Stadium site, now home to youth league Hasan Dudar , Detroit Free Press Published 5:06 p.m. ET March 24, 2018 | Updated 8:38 p.m. ET March 24, 2018 CLOSE March For Our Lives participants in Detroit chant in Hart Plaza. Aleanna Siacon/Detroit Free Press The new Corner Ballpark presented by Adient during the first game after the grand opening on Saturday, March 24, 2018 in Detroit. (Photo: Elaine Cromie, Special to the Free Press) CONNECT 3 COMMENT EMAIL MORE A sacred site in the sport of baseball opened a new inning Saturday morning at the corner of Michigan and Trumbull in Detroit. \u201cIt\u2019s amazing,\u201d youth-league pitcher Trenton Newby, 17, said shortly before his first anticipated game at the same location where the Detroit Tigers played from 1912-1999. \u201cLike, Willie Mays played on this area. It\u2019s just crazy, like can\u2019t believe it\u2019s really happening, but it\u2019s happening today.\u201d The grand opening and ribbon-cutting ceremony for the Detroit Police Athletic League\u2019s new field \u2014 the Corner Ballpark and the Willie Horton Field of Dreams \u2014 occurred on the grounds of the old Tiger Stadium in Corktown. The site will serve as the new headquarters and stadium for Detroit PAL, a non-profit that provides athletic, academic, and leadership programs for thousands of children each year. \u201cWe hope this serves as a shining example of what kids in Detroit deserve to have,\u201d Detroit PAL CEO Tim Richey said at the ceremony. \u201cWe hope this corner is a beacon for corners across Detroit.\u201d Eight children who won the Detroit PAL First Pitch Essay Contest threw ceremonial first pitches before an afternoon game between two PAL teams: the Aztecs and another team consisting of the Stars, Greyhounds, Detroit Yankees and Detroit Hurricanes. \nThe PAL mascot gets ready to toss a ceremonial pitch during the grand opening ceemonies of the Corner Ballpark presented by Adient on Saturday, March 24, 2018 in Detroit. (Photo: Elaine Cromie, Special to the Free Press) Later, Newby planned to take the field as starting pitcher for West Bloomfield High School. His mother, Yolanda Moore, 43, of Royal Oak described it as a \u201cblessing\u201d to get to see her son take the mound Saturday afternoon on the historic grounds versus Martin Luther King, Jr. High School of Detroit. \u201cIt\u2019s truly a blessing to see the hard work that we put in,\u201d Moore said. \u201cBut to be able to give back to the community and be down here and see everyone fellowship and just be able to do something positive for the face of Detroit, it\u2019s awesome.\u201d Read More: Could train depot be Ford's millennials magnet? PAL secured more than $20 million in donor gifts to build the Willie Horton Field of Dreams and the 8,500 square-foot headquarters and banquet hall, according to a PAL news release. The field is 9.5 acres and maintains the dimensions of the former field. Construction began in June 2016, and the former Major League Baseball stadium was razed in 2009. There was some controversy surrounding the development, including concerns about the turf -- which replaced the grass field -- and over whether the new site would leave enough time for youth leagues and the general public. The Free Press previously reported that Richey told residents at least 51% of activities will be devoted to youth, and that PAL will ensure there are daily public hours. But it will offer the field for private use during daytime hours when children are in school. Former United States Senator Carl Levin told the crowd on Saturday that he fought in the senate to protect the field, even though the stadium was lost. \u201cThis land was unique,\u201d Levin said. \u201cThere was only one field like this in the world.\u201d Bob Selwa, who had attended games at the old Tiger Stadium from 1951 until 1999, said it wasn\u2019t until Saturday morning that he had a chance to step out on the field and walk the bases, one by one. "site": "freep.com", "site_section": "http://rssfeeds.freep.com/freep/business", "site_categories": ["real_estate", "buying_selling_homes"], "section_title": "GANNETT Syndication Service", "title": "Detroit car insurance: Why Cleveland has it way cheaper", "title_full": "Detroit car insurance: Why Cleveland has it way cheaper", "published": "2018-03-23T23:15:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0,
