"published": "2018-03-24T14:30:00.000+03:00", "title": "Irish demonstrators to gather in support of major US gun control campaign", "text": "11:06 24 Mar 2018 Michael Staines 1 day ago \nRallies are due to take place in Cork, Dublin and Belfast this afternoon in solidarity with a major gun control protest in the US. \nOver 800 protests are taking place across the US calling for stricter gun control laws. \nMeanwhile solidarity protests are being held in 27 countries around the world. \nThe 'March For Our Lives' (MFOL) protest was organised by survivors of the Valentine's Day shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. \n17 people were killed when a former student opened fire at Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, just north of Miami. \nIn the weeks since the attack, the MFOL movement has gained a number of celebrity supporters, raised money and even persuaded various businesses to cut ties to the National Rifle Association (NRA). \nThe biggest gathering is due to take place in Washington DC later today. Gun control demonstrators gather in Washington on 23-03-2018. Image: Jacquelyn Martin/AP/Press Association Images \nIn a statement, rally organisers Democrats Abroad Ireland said the Irish demonstrations aim to global support for gun control movement in the wake of the Florida attack. \nIt said it hoped to, \u201cshow the US government that the world is watching; to fight for our right to safety in the US; and to hold lawmakers accountable and demonstrate that the majority of [US] voters want gun reform now.\u201d \nThe Washington demonstration will get underway at 4pm (Irish time) this afternoon, with 500,000 people are expected to march. Gun control demonstrators gather in Washington on 23-03-2018. Image: Jacquelyn Martin/AP/Press Association Images \nPeople in other time zones have already been showing their support. \nAround 100 people held a rally in Sydney, Australia this morning to show their support for the US teenagers. \nProtester Jennifer Smith said she had been inspired by the young people who had stepped forward to say \"enough is enough\". \nShe added: \"Sadly, they're doing the jobs that adults have not been able to do, and I think this is really going to be the turning point where people stand up, they listen and it's going to change a lot of things.\" \nMarches also took place at a number of cities in New Zealand, organised by university students. \nOther marches are due to take place in Asia, Africa, South America and Europe. \nThe Dublin rally gets underway at 3pm outside the Us Embassy in Ballsbridge. 11:06 24 Mar 2018 Michael Staines 1 day ago 4 Related articles", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "BreakingNews.ie", "published": "2018-03-24T23:57:00.000+03:00", "title": "Meet the people in cities around the world who stood with US teenagers for the March For Our Lives", "text": "\u2014 March For Our Lives Dublin (@DublinMFOL) March 24, 2018 \nArchaeologist Dr Kelli Malone, 59, says she chose to march on Saturday as she is against gun ownership on any level and is \u201csickened by the suffering caused by gun violence\u201d. \nThe rally in Ireland\u2019s capital was organised by Democrats Abroad Ireland and the Women\u2019s March, and took place outside the US embassy in the city. \n\u201cThe powerful messages and courage of the Parkland students, and those students everywhere who \u2013 often alone \u2013 stood in protest and walked in support of Parkland, has set an example for us all to aspire to,\u201d Malone said. \n\u201cThis is an opportunity for the world to unite against violence.\u201d \nGreg Johnson, 25, chair of Democrats Abroad Ireland and one of the rally\u2019s organisers, shared his experience of growing up in a country where gun violence is so prevalent. \n(Greg Johnson) \n\u201cGrowing up in suburban Atlanta, my elementary school would hold \u2018intruder drills\u2019 to prepare us for the possibility of shootings on campus,\u201d he said. \n\u201cWe were trained to lock the classroom door, turn off the lights, hide in the corner, and hope for the best. I didn\u2019t realise these types of school drills were largely unique to America until I moved abroad. \n\u201cI want to help build an America where these kinds of drills don\u2019t need to happen anymore.\u201d \nJohnson said he would like the marches around the world to remind Americans that \u201croutine mass shootings just don\u2019t happen outside of the US\u201d. He is calling on elected officials to work across the aisle to protect people from gun violence. \nOslo \n(Sandi Salus/PA) \nActivist and scientist Sandi Salus, 45, helped to bring the Oslo rally together. This wasn\u2019t her first foray into the world of protest \u2013 she has helped to organise Women\u2019s March Norway 2017 and 2018 and the March for Science Norway 2017. \n\u201cI ended up meeting a few other American expats here during the first Women\u2019s March and one of them had started up an organisation called PAAL (Progressive American\u2019s Action League) here in Oslo with the intent of fighting against social, racial, and environmental injustice happening back home in the US but also locally in Oslo,\u201d Salus explained. \n\u201cI got burnt out a bit after this last Women\u2019s March but the Parkland shooting just really hit hard. I had already had a hard time looking to the US from Norway and seeing all of this gun violence occurring year after year with nothing being done about it.\u201d \n(Sandi Salus/PA) \nWhen the Parkland students announced the March 24 event, Salus felt ready to throw herself into organising again, to show the students they had international support, and show lawmakers in the US that expats were watching. \n\u201cI also think that it is important that we share our perspective \u2013 that we have had the chance to live outside the US and see how another place deals with gun reform.\u201d \nAt Saturday\u2019s rally, attendees lit candles and Salus gave a speech \u2013 then the floor was opened to others who had points to make. \n\u201cOne young woman, an American, told of how her life has been touched by gun violence, including knowing gun victims as well as teaching young students in San Antonio, Texas and having to keep them calm and ease the students\u2019 fears as they had to undergo gun-violence drills,\u201d said Salus. \u201cIt was very moving.\u201d \nAlso in attendance was a survivor of the Ut\u00f8ya attack in 2011, when a gunman killed 69 young people attending a summer camp. According to Salus, \u201che has now committed his life to gun safety as well as helping with the mental health issues of those who have gone through a horrible incident of gun violence\u201d. \nMumbai #MarchForOurLives Tanushka (@_tanushka13) March 24, 2018 \n\u2019s protest will be held on Sunday March 25 and 17-year-old student and writer Mahek Chacha is planning to attend. \n\u201cAs an Indian, it is thankfully a far-fetched thought for an adolescent to purchase a gun and terrorise the lives of countless people, whatever the reason may be,\u201d she said. \n\u201cWatching such events unfold as an outsider, as someone who is not American, the cause and prevention of mass shootings is painfully obvious to me. \n\u201cRaising the age for gun licences, thorough background checks for potential gun owners, better security in public places, especially schools, are just some of the ways to easily prevent gun violence, yet at the hands of gun owners and the NRA itself, no such action has been taken.\u201d \nChacha says that as a student herself, she finds the idea of students fearing gun violence at school to be \u201cincredibly painful\u201d. Although she cannot relate to that feeling, she is joining the protest to support American teens in their quest for gun reform. \nBarcelona \n(Rebecca Gonzalez/PA) \n\u201cI am inspired by young leaders like Florida students who instead of staying home being afraid, overcame the fear and stood up for their rights,\u201d said Rebecca Gonzalez, 21, a political science student who attended a rainy rally in Barcelona\u2019s Placa Catalunya. \n\u201cI truly admire them so I want to stand up with them as a young student in solidarity.\u201d \nDespite the rain, more that 75 people attended the rally, during which speeches were given and 17 pairs of shoes laid out in a circle to represent those who were killed at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School on February 14. \n(Rebecca Gonzalez/PA) \nJessica Craig, 44, who organised the small gathering, said: \u201cThis was the first time I organised a demonstration around such an intense and painful issue. \n\u201cSome of the stories other women shared were so much more emotional than I was expecting. \n\u201cIt makes you realise the insanely large number of people who are impacted by gun violence when even a small demonstration so far away from the US ends up including people who have had a direct experience of a mass shooting or people who live each day worrying about this.\u201d \nMelbourne The rain didn\u2019t stop us! persephone nihil (@IDidThisMyself) March 24, 2018 \nYoung activist Persephone Nihil took it upon herself to organise Melbourne\u2019s March For Our Lives with a friend, inspired by the actions of Florida\u2019s Parkland students. \n\u201cNot only has America been standing by and ignoring their gun problem, so has the rest of the world,\u201d the 16-year-old said. \nNihil would like the outcome of the global marches to be \u201ca reflection on the consistent weakening of gun laws internationally, and the lack of gun laws in America, and finally seeing some change in gun laws and the deadly culture surrounding them\u201d. \nLondon \n(Stefan Rousseau/PA) \nIn the UK, concerned activists headed to Edinburgh and London to stand with students in the US. \nStephen James Rushbrook, 47, travelled from the Isle of Wight especially to add his voice to the hundreds of children and adults outside the US Embassy in Nine Elms. \nThe computer game artist said he took part in the rally \u201cbecause I believe the way the USA proudly treats its guns and the current, distorted reading of the second amendment as a fetish is sick and perverse\u201d. \n(Stefan Rousseau/PA) \nRushbrook said he has done his own research on shootings in the US and felt he had to support the building opposition against the NRA, gun lobby and the gun manufacturing industry. \n\u201cI am sensitive that a certain percentage of the USA will tell us to mind our own bloody business, but it is important that the industrialised world shows solidarity with the US\u2026 We\u2019ve all gone through this and made the choice that individual liberty to own guns is outweighed but the need to protect the most vulnerable in out community, our children.\u201d \nTokyo Reminder, if you are in Tokyo and wish to support the #NeverAgain movement, there will be a @AMarch4OurLives event tonight at the Hachiko statue in Shibuya at 5PM. \u2014 Kat Callahan (\u9b8e\u5ddd\u304d\u304a) (@JezebelKat) March 24, 2018 \nKat Callahan, 34, who was at high school when the Columbine shooting occurred and now lives in Japan, said the US is no different from other nations that have implemented gun control, there is just a lack of political will to do so. \nThe writer and teacher joined American expats and Japanese citizens in Hachiko Square in Tokyo. Attendees held signs bearing the names of victims of various school shootings in the US. \nCallahan feels teenagers are not taken seriously by adults when raising important issues about their welfare. Today, I joined the #MarchForOurLives in Tokyo pic.twitter.com/Z3P0vapkgg \u2014 \u265bRica (@luthorscanary) March 24, 2018 \nShe said: \u201cWhile many are finally listening to the students of Parkland, they are not unique. This is not to suggest they are any less amazing than they are, but it is to highlight the number of teens over the last 20 years that have tried to raise awareness only to be shut down, ignored, shouted over, and sidelined. \n\u201cRelatively recently black teens and other teens of colour have led their own protests to gun violence, including police violence, which has to be part of the conversation, and have not been given the same attention as the Parkland students, despite being just as active, passionate, and hard-working. \n\u201cI\u2019m really glad people are listening to the Parkland students, and teens more generally, but I gotta ask, where the hell have you been for the last 20 years?\u201d \nCallahan has been touched personally by gun violence. \n\u201cWhen I was in high school, my school bully and I got into a fight. He went home, grabbed his abusive father\u2019s gun, and while there was a raging debate inside his own head (from what we can glean from the note), he decided not to become a school shooter,\u201d she said. \n\u201cInstead he shot himself in the head. \n\u201cI consider him a victim of the same easy access to guns as any others. He should never have been able to so easily get his hands on a weapon, and he should not have been without the resources to get the help he needed.\u201d \nFor Callahan, international protests and support send a signal to elected officials. \nShe said: \u201cWe\u2019re watching. We\u2019re organised. We vote\u2026 Americans abroad are organised and part of this movement. We won\u2019t be left out. We can\u2019t do everything, but we can do something, so we are doing the things we can do.\u201d", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": "published": "2018-03-23T19:47:00.000+03:00", "title": "Protesters target Kinder Morgan's Calgary office on day of action against Trans Mountain", "text": "Protesters target Kinder Morgan's Calgary office on day of action against Trans Mountain Rallies are planned across the country, including three in support of the pipeline project By Drew Anderson, CBC News Posted: Mar 23, 2018 11:47 AM MT Last Updated: Mar 23, 2018 2:03 PM MT Pro- and anti-pipeline protesters clashed in downtown Calgary after a small group of protesters blocked the entrance to Kinder Morgan's offices. (CBC) Related Stories Police officers injured while arresting demonstrators opposed to Trans Mountain pipeline \nA small group of protesters blocked the entrance to the Kinder Morgan offices in downtown Calgary on Friday, in protest against the expansion of the Trans Mountain pipeline through British Columbia. \n\"We want to amplify the voices of many First Nations and communities along the route who are standing up to defend their land and water,\" said Hannah Gelderman, an organizer with Climate Justice Edmonton, the group behind the protest. 19 arrested at Trans Mountain pipeline protest site in Burnaby, B.C. \n\"This pipeline is a huge risk to investors; with all the opposition, the pipeline's not going to go through.\" \nThe small protest came on a day when rallies against the project were planned across the country. In Calgary, Edmonton and Winnipeg, rallies were also planned for those who supported Trans Mountain. Hannah Gelderman, an organizer with Climate Justice Edmonton, said members of her group blocked doors at Kinder Morgan's offices in Calgary to protest the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion. (Mike Symington/CBC) \nThe project would see the pipeline's capacity more than doubled to help ship bitumen from the oilsands to the West Coast. \nIt has faced intense opposition in British Columbia and has been tied up in the regulatory system and the courts for years. \nThe project has also led to threats of a trade war between B.C. and Alberta, and there have been ongoing protests on the West Coast, particularly in Burnaby. Inside the offices \nInside the building on Friday, a livestream broadcast on Facebook by Climate Justice Edmonton showed two small groups of protesters \u2014 five in total \u2014 on opposite ends of a hallway, blocking two different sets of doors. \nThe protesters chanted, sang and read statements from what Gelderman said were Indigenous leaders. \nOne of the protesters addressed the camera and said one source of frustration was the current NDP government in Alberta. Alberta betting on pipelines to balance budget \n\"As Albertans, we're also here to say when we voted for Rachel Notley, we voted for change,\" said the unidentified woman. \n\"They were looking for a transition and something that isn't tying us into this boom-bust economy, and what we've seen is the same old business as usual with Rachel Notley.\" \nIn Thursday's provincial budget, the Alberta NDP pegged a lot of their financial hopes on pipeline projects moving forward. Rallies for and against \nGelderman said Climate Justice Edmonton is a group of volunteers who want to show that there are Albertans opposed to the pipeline project. \n\"We can diversify our economy and there's a lot of potential in renewables and \u2026 we can't keep investing in a dying industry and an industry that has so much risk from climate and communities. That's not a sound economic investment.\" \nCalgary police say they handed trespassing notices to five people for the occupation, but no charges or fines were issued. \nThe occupation of the office was not the only Trans Mountain event on Friday. \nRallies organized by Lead Now, which is opposed to the pipeline, were set to take place outside 44 Liberal MP offices across the country. \nHere\u2019s another look of this heated demonstration of people for and against pipelines outside @kenthehr \u2019s #yyc offices. pic.twitter.com/LqidIqVUuQ \u2014 @ReidSouthwick \nAt Kent Hehr's office in Calgary, more than 100 people gathered from different sides of the debate. Those in support of the project vastly outnumbered those opposed. \nThe supporters were part of an effort organized by the pro-oil group Canada Action, which said rallies would take place in Calgary, Edmonton and Winnipeg. \nSteve Phillips said he was there to show support for Alberta oil. \n\"Heard about it, come down here to show my support for the pipelines. Sick and tired of Alberta oil being sold for half price. It's clean oil. It's ethical oil. It's better than getting our oil from some of these third-world countries,\" he said. \nPhillips was polite but critical of the anti-pipeline protesters. \n\"I think most of them, their hearts are in Economist Trevor Tombe on the provincial budget", "title_full": "'They blew it.' Economist Trevor Tombe on the provincial budget", "published": "2018-03-24T15:00:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "CA", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://i.cbc.ca/1.4589219.1521770166!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_1180/joe-ceci.jpg", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 1123, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 1786, "comments": 0, "shares": 1786}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "4fa0fbc427c97a7d395fba1f46a6585d3ba4e173", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg_O.Knfw.YDvY99G1Iu6YzXDa65f.ztMmog2M81G3OGS2Xd6eiHFqC9dMpYjy1IuuJCpXqqd7NqkXdOASvHUP7HDoocU_pIico6KnYoTIJZ.BiDQhIWs0d6s3ZopJ5RBA8-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "cbc", "published": "2018-03-24T15:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "'They blew it.' Economist Trevor Tombe on the provincial budget", "text": "Budget 2018 was a missed opportunity \u2014 in more ways than one.\n\n\nIt was an opportunity to present Albertans with a credible plan to balance the budget. To clarify what the government's \"compassionate cuts\" would be. To lay out a vision for how to get our province off the royalty roller-coaster.\n\nThese were the government's own clearly and repeatedly stated goals.\n\nAnd on each, this budget failed.\nRECAP |  The Road Ahead: All about the Alberta budget ANALYSIS |  Alberta's budget: You've heard the spin, now take a look at the real numbers \nIn her year-end interviews last December, Premier Rachel Notley said Budget 2018 would present \"a responsible, credible path to balance for 2023. We're working very rigorously on it and it will be responsible.\"\n\nAnd in his pre-budget shoes event, Minister of Finance Joe Ceci promised Budget 2018 would provide a \"detailed plan to balance the books.\"\n\nIt didn't.\nMinister of Finance Joe Ceci and Alberta Premier Rachel Notley hug after delivering the budget in Edmonton on Thursday. (Jason Franson/Canadian Press )\n\nInstead of a five-year plan to balance the books, the minister presented a three-year plan to a $7-billion deficit in 2020/21.\n\nThey missed a big opportunity to reduce uncertainty, build trust and \u2014 most important of all \u2014 show their prior commitments were genuine.\nMORE BUDGET NEWS |  Alberta premier calls B.C. complaints about high gas prices environmental hypocrisy \n\nBut they took a pass, and there's no good reason why.\n\nA high-level sketch \nThe budget did contain hints of a potential path to a balanced budget.\n\nIt described the total revenues, royalties and spending that the NDP government needs to balance by 2023.\nBut this does not constitute a plan. It lacks any credible detail. It's an aspiration (barely).\n\nIt's one thing to know where we have to go, but it's quite another to map out how to get there. Without that detail, fiscal uncertainty remains.\n\nThe government projects spending levels of $65.5 billion by 2023/24. But in what ministries or on which programs is not known.\n\nHow much for health, how much for education, how much for community services, and so on? And what of the compassionate cuts the government repeatedly referenced? Your guess is as good as mine.\nANALYSIS |  Glory days ahead vs. impending doom: The political rhetoric over Alberta's financial future \nThe same is true on the revenue side. The government needs $66.3 billion in 2023/24 to balance. Of that, $10.4 billion will be from resource royalties. But how much from income taxes, carbon taxes, gas taxes, federal transfers or user fees? We don't know.\n\nThis lack of detail is unusual.\n\nFormer Premier Jim Prentice released a detailed 5-year plan in Budget 2015. He even included a 10-year plan with more information that what we see in Budget 2018.\n\nAnd it's not just former government budgets that provided more details than what we got this time around \u2014 opposition parties have, too.\n\nBetter shadow budgets \nThe opposition shadow budgets from the Alberta Party and from Independent MLA Derek Fildebrandt both contained more information than the government's own numbers.\n\nWith an army of skilled and professional public servants, with a wealth of data and modelling at their disposal, I expected more. Much more.\n\nThere's no reason why they couldn't have presented a plan to balance. In fact, they appear to be on such a path already.\n\nFrom 2016-17 to 2020-21, program spending will grow an average of 2.1 per cent a year. That's less than population growth plus inflation \u2014 a useful benchmark for spending. And if it continues forward to 2023-24, it may be sufficient to balance the budget by then \u2014 if royalties grow to $10 billion or so.\nOPINION |  Why young men are being left out of Alberta's economic recovery ANALYSIS |  Alberta's debt is growing, so how much is too much for Albertans? \nMy own estimates \u2014 based on entirely independent, cruder methods \u2014 suggests this is enough. But why leave such analysis to people outside government? We don't have all the information, or the time, to put forward a credible plan \u2014 and no mandate to make tough choices.\n\nThe government has all this. So why not put some meat on the bones?\n\nMaking bold statements about future policy with little to no detail is what opposition parties do, not governments. Lofty rhetoric doesn't substitute for a credible plan.\n\nThis matters. A lot. Because what global credit agencies are looking for, this budget doesn't offer.\n\nA ratings downgrade? \nFor starters, Albertans have now seen five deficit budgets in a row.\n\nLow oil prices made this unavoidable. But with economic recovery underway, we must turn to balancing the books without relying on royalties. If not now, when?\n\nCredit rating agencies are also a factor.\n\nAlberta has seen many downgrades in recent years, but not because we're drowning in debt as some suggest. Alberta has the strongest balance sheet in the country, now and for the foreseeable future. From such a position of strength, Alberta's government can make far more careful, nuanced, and longer-term fiscal decisions. But they aren't.\nInstead, rating agencies worry about the risk of Alberta voluntarily exposing itself to volatile oil prices. By continuing to require substantial resource royalties to balance, this budget fails to address the core concern of investors.\n\n\"It appears to us that the government is partly looking to a recovery in oil prices to improve its fiscal position,\" wrote S&P in its report last year. And DBRS (another ratings agency) is concerned \"that the plan to return to balance relies on a recovery in resource revenues, rather than fundamental adjustments to the budget\u2026 [and] there is no clarity as to when the credit profile will stabilize.\"\n\nBudget 2018 fell short. It may even risk another downgrade. Yet again, the government kicked the fiscal can down the road.\n\nAnd it's only getting heavier.\n\nLooking to get lucky \nWe're as reliant on royalties as ever. Despite government claims to the contrary.\n\nIn Budget 2018, we need $12.6 billion in resource revenues to balance \u2014 an amount Alberta has only seen once before (in 2005/06). To shrink our reliance, we need to shrink the deficit without relying on royalties. And we aren't.\n\nBetween now and 2023-24, royalty growth delivers three-quarters of what the government is counting on to balance.\n\nHere's another way to think about it. Below I plot the fraction of government revenue we need to come from royalties to balance. If fewer royalties come in, we run a deficit. If we're lucky enough to have more, then we run a surplus.\nWe need roughly one in five dollars of government revenue to come from royalties in order to balance \u2014 and this will only modestly decline in the coming years.\n\nThe problem with Budget 2018 was not so much in what it contained, but in what it didn't.\n\nWorse, there was a complete divergence between public statements made by the premier and the minister of finance and what Budget 2018 ultimately revealed.\n\nIf the government wanted to provide a plan, they could have. They chose not to.\n\nMaybe there's a good reason. Perhaps they couldn't agree. Perhaps they're worried about making the tough choices. Regardless of the reason, the bait-and-switch the government pulled risks lowering its fiscal credibility further \u2014 at precisely the wrong time.\n\nWith fiscal challenges as large as Alberta's, a full and frank public debate is needed. With Budget 2018 as the last full budget cycle before the next election, this was their opportunity.\n\nThey blew it.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "trevor tombe", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "rachel notley", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "jason", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "joe ceci", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [], "locations": [{"name": "alberta", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "edmonton", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-24T18:07:02.026+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "893fb125d021617ff2a02374f0a464ce1340d982", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg_O.Knfw.YDvY99G1Iu6YzXDa65f.ztMmog2M81G3OGS2Xd6eiHFqC9dMpYjy1IuuJCpXqqd7NqkXdOASvHUP7HDoocU_pIico6KnYoTIJZ.PLUyBCD3n.E", "site_full": "www.cbc.ca", "site": "cbc.ca", "site_section": "http://rss.cbc.ca/lineup/canada-calgary.xml", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "", "title": "'They blew it.' Economist Trevor Tombe on the provincial budget", "title_full": "'They blew it.' Economist Trevor Tombe on the provincial budget", "published": "2018-03-24T15:00:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "CA", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://i.cbc.ca/1.4589219.1521770166!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_1180/joe-ceci.jpg", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 1123, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 1786, "comments": 0, "shares": 1786}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "893fb125d021617ff2a02374f0a464ce1340d982", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg_O.Knfw.YDvY99G1Iu6YzXDa65f.ztMmog2M81G3OGS2Xd6eiHFqC9dMpYjy1IuuJCpXqqd7NqkXdOASvHUP7HDoocU_pIico6KnYoTIJZ.PLUyBCD3n.E", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "cbc", "published": "2018-03-24T15:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "'They blew it.' Economist Trevor Tombe on the provincial budget", "text": "Alberta NDP 'blew it' on provincial budget, says economist Trevor Tombe 'What global credit agencies are looking for, this budget doesn\u2019t offer\u2019 By Trevor Tombe, CBC News   7:00 AM MT   1:41 PM MT Alberta President of Treasury Board and Minister of Finance Joe Ceci, delivers the budget in Edmonton on Thursday. (Jason Franson/The Canadian Press) About The Author \nTrevor Tombe \nTrevor Tombe is an associate professor of economics at the University of Calgary, and a research fellow at the School of Public Policy. \nBudget 2018 was a missed opportunity \u2014 in more ways than one. \nIt was an opportunity to present Albertans with a credible plan to balance the budget. To clarify what the government's \"compassionate cuts\" would be. To lay out a vision for how to get our province off the royalty roller-coaster. \nThese were the government's own clearly and repeatedly stated goals. \nAnd on each, this budget failed. ANALYSIS | Alberta's budget: You've heard the spin, now take a look at the real numbers \nIn her year-end interviews last December, Premier Rachel Notley said Budget 2018 would present \"a responsible, credible path to balance for 2023. We're working very rigorously on it and it will be responsible.\" \nAnd in his pre-budget shoes event, Minister of Finance Joe Ceci promised Budget 2018 would provide a \"detailed plan to balance the books.\" \nIt didn't. Minister of Finance Joe Ceci and Alberta Premier Rachel Notley hug after delivering the budget in Edmonton on Thursday. (Jason Franson/Canadian Press ) \nInstead of a five-year plan to balance the books, the minister presented a three-year plan to a $7-billion deficit in 2020/21. \nThey missed a big opportunity to reduce uncertainty, build trust and \u2014 most important of all \u2014 show their prior commitments were genuine. \nBut they took a pass, and there's no good reason why. A high-level sketch \nThe budget did contain hints of a potential path to a balanced budget. \nIt described the total revenues, royalties and spending that the NDP government needs to balance by 2023. \nBut this does not constitute a plan. It lacks any credible detail. It's an aspiration (barely). \nIt's one thing to know where we have to go, but it's quite another to map out how to get there. Without that detail, fiscal uncertainty remains. \nThe government projects spending levels of $65.5 billion by 2023/24. But in what ministries or on which programs is not known. \nHow much for health, how much for education, how much for community services, and so on? And what of the compassionate cuts the government repeatedly referenced? Your guess is as good as mine. ANALYSIS | Glory days ahead vs. impending doom: The political rhetoric over Alberta's financial future \nThe same is true on the revenue side. The government needs $66.3 billion in 2023/24 to balance. Of that, $10.4 billion will be from resource royalties. But how much from income taxes, carbon taxes, gas taxes, federal transfers or user fees? We don't know. \nThis lack of detail is unusual. \nFormer Premier Jim Prentice released a detailed 5-year plan in Budget 2015. He even included a 10-year plan with more information that what we see in Budget 2018. \nAnd it's not just former government budgets that provided more details than what we got this time around \u2014 opposition parties have, too. Better shadow budgets \nThe opposition shadow budgets from the Alberta Party and from Independent MLA Derek Fildebrandt both contained more information than the government's own numbers. \nWith an army of skilled and professional public servants, with a wealth of data and modelling at their disposal, I expected more. Much more. \nThere's no reason why they couldn't have presented a plan to balance. In fact, they appear to be on such a path already. \nFrom 2016-17 to 2020-21, program spending will grow an average of 2.1 per cent a year. That's less than population growth plus inflation \u2014 a useful benchmark for spending. And if it continues forward to 2023-24, it may be sufficient to balance the budget by then \u2014 if royalties grow to $10 billion or so. ANALYSIS | Alberta's debt is growing, so how much is too much for Albertans? \nMy own estimates \u2014 based on entirely independent, cruder methods \u2014 suggests this is enough. But why leave such analysis to people outside government? We don't have all the information, or the time, to put forward a credible plan \u2014 and no mandate to make tough choices. \nThe government has all this. So why not put some meat on the bones? \nMaking bold statements about future policy with little to no detail is what opposition parties do, not governments. Lofty rhetoric doesn't substitute for a credible plan. \nThis matters. A lot. Because what global credit agencies are looking for, this budget doesn't offer. A ratings downgrade? \nFor starters, Albertans have now seen five deficit budgets in a row. \nLow oil prices made this unavoidable. But with economic recovery underway, we must turn to balancing the books without relying on royalties. If not now, when? \nCredit rating agencies are also a factor. \nAlberta has seen many downgrades in recent years, but not because we're drowning in debt as some suggest. Alberta has the strongest balance sheet in the country, now and for the foreseeable future. From such a position of strength, Alberta's government can make far more careful, nuanced, and longer-term fiscal decisions. But they aren't. \nInstead, rating agencies worry about the risk of Alberta voluntarily exposing itself to volatile oil prices. By continuing to require substantial resource royalties to balance, this budget fails to address the core concern of investors. \n\"It appears to us that the government is partly looking to a recovery in oil prices to improve its fiscal position,\" wrote S&P in its report last year. And DBRS (another ratings agency) is concerned \"that the plan to return to balance relies on a recovery in resource revenues, rather than fundamental adjustments to the budget\u2026 [and] there is no clarity as to when the credit profile will stabilize.\" \nBudget 2018 fell short. It may even risk another downgrade. Yet again, the government kicked the fiscal can down the road. \nAnd it's only getting heavier. Looking to get lucky \nWe're as reliant on royalties as ever. Despite government claims to the contrary. \nIn Budget 2018, we need $12.6 billion in resource revenues to balance \u2014 an amount Alberta has only seen once before (in 2005/06). To shrink our reliance, we need to shrink the deficit without relying on royalties. And we aren't. \nBetween now and 2023-24, royalty growth delivers three-quarters of what the government is counting on to balance. \nHere's another way to think about it. Below I plot the fraction of government revenue we need to come from royalties to balance. If fewer royalties come in, we run a deficit. If we're lucky enough to have more, then we run a surplus. \nWe need roughly one in five dollars of government revenue to come from royalties in order to balance \u2014 and this will only modestly decline in the coming years. \nThe problem with Budget 2018 was not so much in what it contained, but in what it didn't. \nWorse, there was a complete divergence between public statements made by the premier and the minister of finance and what Budget 2018 ultimately revealed. \nIf the government wanted to provide a plan, they could have. They chose not to. \nMaybe there's a good reason. Perhaps they couldn't agree. Perhaps they're worried about making the tough choices. Regardless of the reason, the bait-and-switch the government pulled risks lowering its fiscal credibility further \u2014 at precisely the wrong time. \nWith fiscal challenges as large as Alberta's, a full and frank public debate is needed. With Budget 2018 as the last full budget cycle before the next election, this was their opportunity. \nThey blew it. \nCalgary: The Road Ahead is CBC Calgary's special focus on our city as we build the city we want \u2014 the city we need. It's the place for possibilities. A marketplace of ideas. So. Have an idea? Email us at: calgarytheroadahead@cbc.ca \nMore from the series:", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "trevor "2018-03-23T15:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "Man alleges West Edmonton Mall security used excessive force at waterpark party", "text": "Man alleges West Edmonton Mall security used excessive force at waterpark party Adrian Cornwell says he suffered a black eye when a security guard tackled and handcuffed him By Travis McEwan, CBC News Posted: Mar 23, 2018 7:00 AM MT Last Updated: Mar 23, 2018 5:54 PM MT Adrian Cornwell stands outside of West Edmonton Mall\u2019s World Waterpark. He says the bruising and scrapes on his right eye were suffered when a security guard tackled him to the floor and handcuffed him at a Friday party in the waterpark. (Travis McEwan/CBC) \nTravis McEwan Videojournalist \nA Calgary man who attended an adult DJ event at West Edmonton Mall's waterpark alleges he was subjected to excessive force by a mall security guard, and wrongfully locked up for hours in only his swim trunks. \nAdrian Cornwell, 22, was attending the March 16 Soundwave EDM music event, billed as World Waterpark's \"wildest indoor beach party.\" At around 12:30 a.m., he left his identification and cellphone with his younger brother so he could go use the washrooms in the waterpark locker rooms. \nEdmonton woman alleges assault by mall guards \nCornwall said he asked a security guard if he could use the washrooms and was told he could not. He said he started to return to the pool when the same security guard told him he needed his ID to do so. \nFrustrated, he said he tried to run past a security guard to go get his ID but said he only got a few steps before the guard tackled and handcuffed him, his face hitting the ground in the process. A photo of swelling on Adrian Cornwell\u2019s face was taken after he was released from West Edmonton Mall on March 17. (Adrian Cornwell) \nOn Wednesday, four days after the alleged incident, Cornwall had a scrape, swelling and green bruising around his right eye. \n\"He didn't need to use as much force. He didn't need to be so unreasonable,\" Cornwell said. \nAfter he was handcuffed, Cornwall said, security guards escorted him to the mall's holding cells, told him he would be charged with trespassing and said he would have to remain locked up until Edmonton police arrived. \nHe estimates he spent more than two hours locked up in the room. \nAfter police arrived, he was escorted out of the building and into a cruiser, where he was asked to explain what happened. Afterwards, he was told he was free to go without any charges being laid. \nCornwell was still in his swim trunks, without his phone or identification. With the officers' assistance, he contacted his brother at around 3 a.m. \nOn Thursday, the Edmonton Police Service confirmed it is investigating use of force by West Edmonton Mall security in relation to the incident. Cornwell has not yet filed an official complaint with the mall. \nCornwell said he thinks the force used by the security officer was excessive and that he was wrongfully detained in the holding cells. \n\"I would like that guy to not have his job,\" he said. \"He shouldn't have a job like that. \n\"They can't hold you in a cell. They're security guards. They're supposed to escort you off the premises. They're supposed to be there for your safety.\" \nReached on Wednesday, a West Edmonton Mall spokesperson confirmed there had been an incident but declined to comment on any details. "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "cbc", "published": "2018-03-22T21:40:00.000+02:00", "title": "Alberta's balanced budget plan relies on pipelines and debt climbing to $96B", "text": "Alberta's path to balanced budgets is built on hopes for construction of three new pipelines, including the controversial Trans Mountain expansion, plus reaping extra revenue generated by the federal carbon tax.\nBut the five-year plan unveiled Thursday in the province's 2018-19 budget will also see accumulated debt climbing from $54 billion in the coming year to a whopping $96 billion by 2023.\nTitled \"A Recovery Built to Last,\" the budget forecasts a reduction in the annual deficit each year until it reaches a $700-million surplus by 2023-24.\nAlberta budget to lay out plan to end deficits by 2023 The Road Ahead: All about the Alberta budget \nThe plan rests on the assumption the proposed Trans Mountain pipeline expansion from Edmonton to Burnaby \u2014 currently facing legal challenges from First Nations and environmental groups, plus opposition from B.C.'s NDP government \u2014 will get built.\n\nThe government is also factoring in revenue from the Enbridge Line 3 and Keystone XL projects.\n\n\"The pipelines will get built,\" Finance Minister Joe Ceci insisted at a news conference prior to reading the budget. \"They will get built because they're important for Canada, they're important for Alberta.\"\nBalanced budget tied to Trans Mountain completion Alberta deficit forecast drops to $9.1B \nBy the time the government eliminates the deficits, it will have accumulated an estimated $95.7 billion in debt, with $3.7 billion in annual debt servicing costs, and a debt-to-GDP ratio of 21 per cent.\n\nNone of those figures appeared in the budget documents tabled Thursday, but were provided by finance officials in response to questions from journalists.\n\nCeci seemed defensive when asked by reporters how long he thought it would take the province to pay off $96 billion.\n\n\"I'm focused on balancing, thank you, first. Once we get to balance we will continue to work and come up with plans to address our debt,\" he said.\nA protester is pulled from a piece of heavy equipment being delivered to Kinder Morgan in Burnaby, B.C., on March 19. The Alberta government's plan rests on the company's controversial Trans Mountain pipeline expansion. (Darryl Dyck/Canadian Press)\nJason Kenney, leader of the Official Opposition United Conservative Party, slammed the NDP government for putting Alberta on track to $96 billion in debt. \n\"If there was any indication the NDP was going to change its course and become fiscally responsible that was blown out in a spectacular way in today's NDP budget,\" he said. \nKenney said the revenue projections aren't plausible either. \n\"This is one part recklessness, one part completely unrealistic projections, higher taxes, massive increases in debt, all of which will burden future generations of Albertans,\" he said. \n\n\n$1B into general revenues \nThere currently is a $30 per tonne tax on carbon, which Albertans pay on home heating bills and gasoline, for example. All the revenue is now spent on rebates and emission-reduction programs.\n\nWhen the tax, which the federal government ordered provinces to impose, reaches $40 a tonne in 2021, Alberta intends to still use $30 for projects intended to reduce carbon footprints, the remainder will go to general spending purposes.\n\nThat will translate into an additional $1 billion per year being pumped into general revenues by 2023-24.\n$1B  upgrader  plan aimed at getting Alberta off boom-bust  rollercoaster \nThe government continues to emphasize that adoption of the federal carbon plan is tied to go-ahead of construction of the Trans Mountain expansion.\nThe budget has very few goodies for the average Albertan, and most major spending projects have already been announced.\nThey include a tax credit to encourage gaming and digital media companies to locate in Alberta, and a grant and loan program to encourage companies to build two to five partial bitumen upgraders.\n\u200b Alberta offers tax break to digital gaming, media companies There are no changes in personal and corporate income tax rates, nor are there increases for liquor and tobacco.\nThe government is expanding two social programs promised in the 2015 provincial election, which were rolled out on a limited basis over the last two years. The school lunch program will expand from 5,000 to 30,000 students, while a $25-a-day childcare program will be hiked by 4,500 spaces.\nThere's also money to build 20 new schools and hire 600 new teachers. And the province is also allocating $11 million to organizations that help survivors of sexual assault.  \u200b\nAlberta government bill proposes $43M to create 3,000 tech training spaces over 5 years Child intervention services will get an additional $800 million.\nThe government intends to hold spending below population growth plus inflation, Ceci said. There are no major cuts in services.\nThe government is slowing down infrastructure spending and is expecting zero salary increases from its major public service unions. The Alberta Teachers' Association, United Nurses of Alberta and the Health Sciences Association of Alberta have already agreed to zero increases.\nNegotiations with the Alberta Union of Provincial Employees are still underway.\nThe deficit forecast for the 2018-19 fiscal year is $8.8 billion, with $47.9 billion in revenue and $56.2 billion in expenses.\nThe debt is forecast at $54.2 billion by the end of the fiscal year, a figure that is 15.4 per cent of the province's gross domestic product. Interest costs on that debt are estimated at $1.9 billion a year from now.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [], "2018-03-22T14:28:00.000+02:00", "title": "Yellowknife couple overwhelmed by support after baby born missing 1 heart valve", "text": "TaraLee Wedzin was 12 weeks pregnant when doctors gave her the news \u2014 her baby was going to be born missing a heart valve.\nDoctors discovered the Yellowknife resident's unborn son had only three heart chambers, meaning he would have trouble later in life and would ultimately need multiple surgeries.\nWith the discovery, she and her partner, Clyde Elias, began travelling between Yellowknife and Edmonton for medical treatment throughout her pregnancy to make sure the baby was alright.\nBaby Jackson was born on Nov. 3, five weeks early. He's now four months old, and has already had two surgeries in less than two months. His parents are still waiting to find out if he'll need to undergo a third.\n\"It gives you anxiety,\" said Wedzin.\nJackson Elias is waiting to find out if he'll need a third heart surgery. (Submitted by TaraLee Wedzin)\n\"It's really scary honestly, not knowing what's going to happen next, and just having to be patient. All we really want is just my little boy back home with us.\"\nWedzin said it breaks her heart to see her baby in hospital, connected to tubes.\nOther stress related to caring for their child is piling up \u2014 with constant flights to Edmonton, Wedzin and her partner haven't been able to work in a year. They say they're struggle even to buy toiletries.\nWedzin's partner has even considered looking for work in Edmonton while the couple waits to find out what's next for their son.\nNow, a family friend has started a GoFundMe page to help the couple. As of Wednesday afternoon, it had raised more than $3,500.\n\"Honestly it's so overwhelming and it's hard to believe there's so many people, especially people of Yellowknife who care so much,\" she said.\nA silent auction is scheduled for Friday at Sam's Monkey Tree Pub in Yellowknife, with proceeds going to help pay the couple's expenses.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-23T03:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "RCMP investigating fatal collision on Hwy 19 | CTV Edmonton News", "text": "RCMP south of Edmonton are investigating after a two vehicle collision left one individual dead, and two in hospital Friday morning.\nLeduc RCMP were called to the scene of the collision on Highway 19, near Range Road 260 Friday at about 8:45 a.m.\nPolice completely closed the highway for several hours in order to investigate the collision and clear debris \u2013 and re-routed traffic headed in both directions onto local roads,\nLater Friday, RCMP said two pickup trucks were involved in the collision.\nOne of the trucks had three males inside \u2013 one of the passengers was pronounced dead, the other two were taken to hospital in Edmonton by ambulance.\nThe other truck had a male driver and a male passenger inside, both were treated on the scene by paramedics.\nBefore 11:45 a.m. Friday, police said one lane of the highway had been reopened to traffic, and it was expected the other would reopen within an hour.\nRCMP are investigating the collision, and said road conditions at the time of the crash undetermined injuries.\nTwo males in the second truck were treated locally for unknown injuries, police said.\nFew details are available, but road conditions were very poor, RCMP said.\nTraffic began moving slowly in both directions with one alternating lane of traffic, shortly before noon. The highway is expected to fully open early Friday afternoon.\nCollision analysis investigators are on scene.\nDevon is about 26 kilometres southwest of Edmonton.\nFriday's face-blasting, vehicle-burying winter storm arrived early in the capital region as heavy, wet snow left roads covered in ice and slush.\nHere comes the snow #yegwx #abstorm yeg pic.twitter.com/j1oFcbYBMz\n\u2014 @lonesomebilydad The snowfall warning issued by Environment Canada for the capital region on Wednesday has been lifted, but two more centimetres of snow is expected to fall in Edmonton before the storm ends.\nThe storm is just beginning to hit some areas of the province. Snowfall warnings remain in place for a large swath of northern and central Alberta, stretching from High Level to Hanna.\nUp to 15 centimetres is expected to fall in some areas, as a low-pressure system moves northeastward through the province.\nStrong winds of up to 80 kilometres per hour will cause some localized blowing and drifting snow in exposed areas, Environment Canada said.\nDrive safe, morning commuters. "author": "Maurice", "published": "2018-03-23T16:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "Mayor Jorritsma: Parties new coalition have to get firm grip on the city\u2019s finances", "text": "Posted By: Maurice 35 Views 0 Comment \nMayor John Jorritsma will do everything it takes to ensure the coming coalition parties in Eindhoven will come to grips with the city\u2019s finances on a \u2018fundamental level\u2019. \nHe said this after the presentation of the definitive end results of the city council elections on Thursday afternoon. According to Mayor Jorritsma, the new coalition should not be too ambitious. \u201cMore ambitions on a weak foundation; that is not going to work.\u201d \nThe mayor emphasised that the new term of the council must have a professional board, which will address the problems firmly. These include the financial shortages but also the malfunctioning organisation of the city. \u201cI will do everything within my powers, also regarding the new coalition parties, to steer them clearly towards these aspects.\u201d \nMayor Jorritsma says he is satisfied by the outcome of the election. Beforehand he was worried about the possible splintering of the Eindhoven city council because sixteen parties took part in the election. \u201cThe council will be made up of twelve parties; fortunately not 16. A city has to remain governable. Parties will, after all, have to make compromises. Now there is a framework of bigger parties who can form a coalition.\u201d \nHe did, however, let it be known that he thinks forming a coalition will not be easy, especially between the two biggest parties, the VVD, who are conservative liberal, and GroenLinks, who social-democratic. \u201cThese two have polar opposite opinions about, for example, climate, Vestdijk, and Eindhoven Airport. These will be the important issues in the coalition talks.\u201d", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "jorritsma", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "john jorritsma", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "maurice", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "eindhoven", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "eindhoven", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T19:06:17.002+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "3316a92b1fcfd3f3643aa84ac93100769acf361f", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZRlrfDnGbe3cGLzX3fcBmj2kpkt94l5sdzplIUzjm7dk_K6BktYNyTZAcBJNMkVA34-", "site_full": "e52.nl", "site": "e52.nl", "site_section": "https://e52.nl/feed", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "E52", "title": "Breakfast with\u2026 Bjorn van de Langenberg", "title_full": "Breakfast with\u2026 Bjorn van de Langenberg", "published": "2018-03-25T08:00:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "NL", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://e52.nl/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/Screen-Shot-2018-03-23-at-5.29.49-PM.png", "performance_score": 0, "domain_rank": null, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 0, "comments": 0, "shares": 0}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "3316a92b1fcfd3f3643aa84ac93100769acf361f", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZRlrfDnGbe3cGLzX3fcBmj2kpkt94l5sdzplIUzjm7dk_K6BktYNyTZAcBJNMkVA34-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Renske Mehra", "published": "2018-03-25T08:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "Breakfast with\u2026 Bjorn van de Langenberg", "text": "Geen\u2193 Deel \nHet is een ijskoude donderdagochtend in Eindhoven als Bjorn van de Langenberg binnenloopt in het afgesproken cafe. De gevoelstemperatuur buiten is dertien graden onder nul. Uit het oosten waait een straffe wind. Bjorn is vandaag \u2018toch maar niet\u2019 uit Boxtel komen fietsen. Hij kijkt erbij alsof het een lastige keuze was. Bjorn fiets namelijk graag. Heel graag. \nTijdens een ontbijtje blikken we alvast vooruit op het nieuwste wielerfestival van Eindhoven. \nBjorn van de Langenberg sportondernemer \nOntbijt broodje carpaccio met cappuccino \nOrganiseert het High Tech Crit Festival \nHij groeit op als oudste in een gezin van vijf kinderen. Voorbestemd om de boomkwekerij van zijn ouders over te nemen. Maar ondanks een opleiding aan de HAS in Den Bosch besluit Bjorn van de Langenberg zijn eigen weg te gaan. \nHij wordt sportondernemer. Met zijn bedrijf organiseert hij clinics met topsporters en ontwikkelt hij vitaliteitsprogramma\u2019s voor bedrijven. Deze zomer komt alles samen in een spiksplinternieuw wielerfestival op de High Tech Campus. \nEen festival dus, met muziek en goed eten. Maar vooral ook een plek waar fietsen en innovatie samenkomen. Als amateur kun je technologische hoogstandjes testen die normaal alleen voor profs zijn weggelegd. Tegelijkertijd wil Bjorn dat het High Tech Crit Festival laagdrempelig is. Dus ook voor kinderen, opa\u2019s, oma\u2019s en mensen met alleen een \u2018gewone\u2019 fiets. \nDeelnemers kunnen toertochten \u2013 75, 110 en 150 km \u2013 maken en high tech e-bikes proberen. Heel bijzonder: bedrijventeams die meedoen aan de ploegenrit kunnen een gratis test doen in de nieuwe windtunnel op de TU/e. \nDat is in juni. Eerst is Bjorn nog gericht op de \u2018pre-party\u2019 op 21 april. Dan vindt een kleiner sportevent plaats op de Campus, de MTB Challenge . Mountainbikers leggen een parcours van 10 km dwars over de Campus af. \u201cDus hoogtemeters maken in de parkeergarages en racen over de vlonders van de grote vijver.\u201d \nHet ontbijtje wordt ondertussen geserveerd. We zitten bij de Velosoof op het NRE-terrein. Op de achtergrond hangen de fietsen van Bert Oosterbosch . De succesvolle wielrenner uit Eindhoven die helaas al op 32-jarige leeftijd overleed. \nBjorn vertelt hoe de puzzelstukjes langzaam op z\u2019n plaats lijken te vallen. Sinds de start van zijn bedrijf heeft hij ingezet op een goed netwerk. Hoe je dat opbouwt? In het geval van Bjorn: wielercaf\u00e9s organiseren. \u201cEen gezellige avond in een caf\u00e9setting waar wielerfans komen luisteren naar verhalen uit de koers.\u201d \nHij kent aanvankelijk alleen ex-wielrenner Karsten Kroon, die weer twee ploeggenoten meeneemt naar het eerste caf\u00e9. En zo gaat het balletje rollen. Nog geen jaar later schuift Tom du Moulin al aan om terug te blikken op zijn seizoen. Voor het High Tech Crit Festival heeft hij wielrenners Puck Moonen en Bram Tankink als ambassadeurs aan boord. \nDe caf\u00e9s leveren hem naast een netwerk onder de professionals ook contacten op met andere ondernemers. Hij voert verschillende gesprekken over een wielerfestival. Er blijkt veel enthousiasme voor zijn plan en sponsors als Shimano haken aan. \n\u201cIedereen hunkert weer naar een mooi wielerevent in Eindhoven\u201d, zegt Bjorn enthousiast. In juni is het zover. \n\nBeeld: Corine Spaans \nIt is a cold Thursday morning in Eindhoven when Bjorn van de Langenberg walks into the cafe. The temperature outside feels like thirteen degrees below zero. A strong wind is blowing from the east. Bjorn \u201cwas in doubt this morning\u201d but decided not to come by bike from Boxtel (a 30 km ride). He looks as if it was a difficult choice. Bjorn likes to ride his bike. Very much so. \nWe meet for breakfast to talk about the newest cycling festival in Eindhoven. \nBjorn van de L angenberg sports entrepreneur \nBreakfast carpaccio sandwich with cappuccino \nOrganizes the High Tech Crit Festival \nHe grew up being the oldest in a family of five children. Destined to take over the tree nursery from his parents. But despite an education at the HAS in Den Bosch, Bjorn van de Langenberg decides to pursue his own path. \nHe becomes a sports entrepreneur and starts organizing clinics with top athletes and developing vitality programs for companies. This summer, everything comes together in a brand new cycling festival on the High Tech Campus. \nA festival, so expect nice music and good food. But most of all, this will be the place where cycling and innovation come together. As a bike lover, you can test high tech tools that are normally reserved only for professionals. At the same time, Bjorn wants the High Tech Crit Festival to be accessible for everyone. So also for children, grandparents and people with just a \u2018normal\u2019 bike. \nParticipants can sign up for tours \u2013 75, 110 and 150 km \u2013 and try high tech e-bikes. A very cool detail: business teams taking part in the team ride can do a free test in the new wind tunnel at the TU/e. \nThat is June. First, Bjorn is still focused on the \u2018pre-party\u2019 on 21 April. A smaller sport event taking place on the same Campus, called the MTB Challenge . For mountain bikers that want to try something different (making altimeters in the parking garage, for example). \nMeanwhile breakfast is being served. We are at the Velosoof , where Bert Oosterbosch\u2019s bicycles are hanging from the ceiling. The successful cyclist from Eindhoven who unfortunately died at the age of 32. \nBjorn tells how everything seems to be falling into place. Since the start of his company he has been building a network. How? By organizing \u2018wielercaf\u00e9s\u2019 (cycling meetups). \u201cA cozy evening in a pub-like atmosphere where cycling fans come to listen to stories from the professional cyclists.\u201d \nAt first he only knows former cyclist Karsten Kroon, who brings two team mates to the first pub evening. But then things go fast. Not even a year later, Tom du Moulin is attending the wielercaf\u00e9 and sharing his stories with the audience. \nBesides a network among the professionals, the Wielercaf\u00e9s also bring him in contact with other entrepreneurs. Many meetings about a possible cycling festival follow. There is a lot of enthusiasm for his plan and sponsors like Shimano decide to join. \n\u201cEveryone is craving for a new cycling event in Eindhoven\u201d, says Bjorn enthusiastically. In June, it will finally happen. \nHe becomes a sports entrepreneur and starts organizing clinics with top athletes and developing vitality programs for companies. This summer, everything comes together in a brand new cycling festival on the High Tech Campus. \nA festival, so expect nice music and good food. But most of all, this will be the place where cycling and innovation come together. As a bike lover, you can test high tech tools that are normally reserved only for professionals. At the same time, Bjorn wants the High Tech Crit Festival to be accessible for everyone. So also for children, grandparents and people with just a \u2018normal\u2019 bike. \nParticipants can sign up for tours \u2013 75, 110 and 150 km \u2013 and try high tech e-bikes. A very cool detail: business teams taking part in the team ride can do a free test in the new wind tunnel at the TU/e. \nThat is June. First, Bjorn is still focused on the \u2018pre-party\u2019 on 21 April. A smaller sport event taking place on the same Campus, called the MTB Challenge . For mountain bikers that want to try something different (making altimeters in the parking garage, for example). \nMeanwhile breakfast is being served. We are at the Velosoof , where Bert Oosterbosch\u2019s bicycles are hanging from the ceiling. The successful cyclist from Eindhoven who unfortunately died at the age of 32. \nBjorn tells how everything seems to be falling into place. Since the start of his company he has been building a network. How? By organizing \u2018wielercaf\u00e9s\u2019 (cycling meetups). \u201cA cozy evening in a pub-like atmosphere where cycling fans come to listen to stories from the professional cyclists.\u201d \nAt first he only knows former cyclist Karsten Kroon, who brings two team mates to the first pub evening. 20:14:48 Ad hoc: MorphoSys Files Registration Statement in the United States for a Proposed American Depositary Shares Offering Teilen Teilen \nAd hoc: MorphoSys Files Registration Statement in the United States for a Proposed American Depositary Shares (ADS) Offering \nMorphoSys AG (FSE: MOR; Prime Standard Segment, TecDAX; OTC: MPSYY) announced today that it filed a Registration Statement on Form F-1 with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for a proposed offering of ordinary shares in the form of American Depositary Shares (\"ADSs\") in the United States. The final number of ADSs to be offered and the price for the offering have not yet been determined. \nMorphoSys's ordinary shares are listed on the Prime Standard Segment in Frankfurt, Germany. Application has been made to list the ADSs to be offered in the proposed offering on the Nasdaq Global Market in the United States under the ticker symbol \"MOR\". \nGoldman Sachs & Co. LLC, J.P. Morgan Securities LLC and Leerink Partners LLC, are acting as lead book-running managers, and Berenberg Capital Markets, LLC and JMP Securities LLC are acting as co-managers for the proposed ADS offering. \nA Registration Statement relating to these securities has been filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission but has not yet become effective. The securities may not be sold, nor may offers to buy be accepted, prior to the time the Registration Statement becomes effective. \nThe securities referred to in this release are to be offered only by means of a prospectus. A copy of the preliminary prospectus, when available, can be obtained from Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC, Prospectus Department, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282, telephone: 1-866-471-2526, facsimile: 1-212-902-9316 or by e-mailing ; J.P. Morgan Securities LLC, c/o Broadridge Financial Solutions, 1155 Long Island Avenue, Edgewood, New York 11717, telephone: 1-866-803-9204; Leerink Partners LLC, Attention: Syndicate Department, One Federal Street, 37th Floor, Boston, MA 02110, by telephone at 1-800-808-7525, ext. 6132, or by emailing . \nThis announcement does not constitute an offer to sell nor a solicitation of an offer to buy, nor shall there be any sale of these securities in any state or jurisdiction in which such an offer, solicitation or sale would be unlawful prior to registration or qualification under the securities laws of any such state or jurisdiction. \nEND OF AD-HOC RELEASE \n\nInformation and Explanation of the Issuer to this News: \nAbout MorphoSys MorphoSys is a late-stage, biopharmaceutical company devoted to the development of innovative and differentiated therapies for patients suffering from serious diseases. Based on its technological leadership in generating antibodies, MorphoSys, together with its partners, has developed and contributed to the development of more than 100 product candidates, of which 28 are currently in clinical development. This broad pipeline spans MorphoSys's two business segments: Proprietary Development, in which the Company invests in product candidates for its own account, and Partnered Discovery, in which product candidates are developed exclusively for a variety of Pharma and Biotech partners. In 2017, Tremfya(R) (guselkumab), marketed by Janssen, became the first therapeutic antibody based on MorphoSys's proprietary technology to receive marketing approval for the treatment of moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis in the United States, the European Union and Canada. MorphoSys is listed on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange under the symbol MOR. \nHuCAL(R), HuCAL GOLD(R), HuCAL PLATINUM(R), CysDisplay(R), RapMAT(R), arYla(R), Ylanthia(R), 100 billion high potentials(R), Slonomics(R), Lanthio Pharma(R) and LanthioPep(R) are registered trademarks of the MorphoSys Group. \nThis communication contains certain forward-looking statements concerning the MorphoSys group of companies. Das Rating liegt nun bei A- nach zuvor BBB+. Der Ausblick ist positiv. \nDie politischen Unruhen in Katalonien h\u00e4tten die wirtschaftliche Entwicklung des Landes nicht beeintr\u00e4chtigt, stellte S&P fest. Das Bruttoinlandsprodukt Spaniens d\u00fcrfte von 2018 bis 2021 schneller wachsen als im Durchschnitt der Eurozone, erwartet die Ratingagentur. F\u00fcr 2018 rechnet S&P mit einem Wirtschaftswachstum von rund 2,7 Prozent. Danach d\u00fcrfte es sich etwas verlangsamen. "2018-03-23T01:00:00.000+02:00", "title": "Infrastruktur: Profitabel aber unp\u00fcnktlich", "text": "Aus: Ausgabe vom 23.03.2018 , Seite 2 / Kapital & Arbeit Profitabel aber unp\u00fcnktlich Deutsche Bahn weist Rekordumsatz aus. Es gab mehr Versp\u00e4tungen Der Bahn-Vorstand pr\u00e4sentierte die Zahlen am Donnerstag in Frankfurt am Main Foto: dpa/Soeren Stache \nDer Vorstandschef der Deutsche Bahn AG, Richard Lutz, legte am Donnerstag eine Bilanz mit Rekordumsatz und h\u00f6herem Gewinn vor. Allein in seinen Fernz\u00fcgen, ICE und IC, z\u00e4hlte der bundeseigene Konzern gut 142 Millionen Fahrten, das sind 2,3 Prozent mehr als 2016. Insgesamt nutzten die Kunden die Bahn im Fern- und Regionalverkehr 2,08 Milliarden Mal. Bei Qualit\u00e4t und P\u00fcnktlichkeit m\u00fcsse das Unternehmen jedoch nachlegen. Die Bahn erzielte im Gesch\u00e4ftsjahr 2017 einen Rekordumsatz von 42,7 Milliarden Euro (plus 5,2 Prozent). Unterm Strich stand ein Gewinn von 765 Millionen Euro nach 716 Millionen im Jahr zuvor (plus 7 Prozent). \nProfite wurden vor allem durch den Fernverkehr und das Auslandsgesch\u00e4ft erzielt. Die internationalen T\u00f6chter DB Arriva und DB Schenker machten \u00bbmittlerweile fast die H\u00e4lfte unseres Umsatzes aus\u00ab, sagte Lutz. \nDie Probleme mit der P\u00fcnktlichkeit nannte Lutz \u00e4rgerlich. Im Fernverkehr waren lediglich 78,5 Prozent der Z\u00fcge p\u00fcnktlich, das waren sogar 0,4 Prozentpunkte weniger als 2016. F\u00fcr dieses Jahr strebt die Bahn eine Quote von 82 Prozent an. \nKritik kam von der Gewerkschaft deutscher Lokomotivf\u00fchrer. \u00bbDas h\u00f6rt sich alles gl\u00e4nzend an. Kratzt man jedoch an der Oberfl\u00e4che, kommen tiefe L\u00f6cher zum Vorschein\u00ab, so der Bundesvorsitzende Claus Weselsky am Donnerstag in Frankfurt am Main. Zwar werde nach dem jahrzehntelangen Abbau von Infrastruktur und Personal mit viel Geld versucht, die Schiene auszubauen. \u00bbDie Systemfehler werden aber nicht angegangen. Statt viel Geld in Leuchtturmprojekte wie Stuttgart 21 zu versenken, muss das Netz f\u00fcr den Schieneng\u00fcter- und -personenverkehr konsequent nach einem integralen Taktfahrplan ausgebaut werden\u00ab, so Weselsky. Es sei \u00bbwitzlos, mit 300 Stundenkilometern \u00fcber die Gleise zu sausen und dann eine Stunde auf den Anschlusszug zu warten.\u00ab Schon jetzt fehlten allein 1.000 Lokomotivf\u00fchrer bei der DB und deren Durchschnittsalter liege bei rund 50 Jahren, so dass in n\u00e4chster Zeit viele in den Ruhestand gehen werden. Dass der Konzern 2017 \u00fcberhaupt die P\u00fcnktlichkeit (Versp\u00e4tung unter sechs Minuten) von beinahe 79 Prozent erreicht habe, \u00bblag ma\u00dfgeblich daran, dass Lokomotivf\u00fchrer und Zugbegleiter den Verkehr flexibel und mit \u00dcberstunden aufrechterhalten haben\u00ab, so Weselsky. "published": "2018-03-23T12:47:00.000+03:00", "title": "Laudamotion-Jets gehen f\u00fcr Lufthansa-Tochter an den Start", "text": "  Int Unternehmen , International , Newsletter , Newsletter Daily , Reisen , Style & Reisen \nNiki Lauda und eine Laudamotion-Crew vor dem Premierenflug am vergangenen Dienstag. (Foto: Laudamotion) \nFrankfurt am Main \u2013 Unmittelbar vor Beginn des Sommerflugplans hat sich der Lufthansa-Konzern mit dem \u00f6sterreichischen Luftfahrtunternehmer Niki Lauda geeinigt. Dessen neue Fluggesellschaft Laudamotion werde acht Jets samt Besatzungen an die Lufthansa-Tochter Eurowings vermieten, wie eine Lauda-Sprecherin am Freitag best\u00e4tigte. Zuvor hatte das Fachblatt \u201efvw\u201c \u00fcber die Vereinbarung berichtet, die bereits am Wochenende in Kraft treten soll. \nDie Abmachung sichert der Eurowings bis Ende Mai dringend ben\u00f6tigte Sitzplatz-Kapazit\u00e4ten und lastet gleichzeitig die Lauda-Flugzeuge und Crews aus, die sonst hohe Kosten verursacht h\u00e4tten. Eine Zusammenarbeit \u00fcber den genannten Zeitraum hinaus wollen beide Seiten in den kommenden Wochen pr\u00fcfen. Die Lauda-Maschinen sollen laut \u201efvw\u201c von D\u00fcsseldorf, Wien und Palma starten. \nRyanair will Mehrheit an Laudamotion \u00fcbernehmen Laudamotion ist die Nachfolgegesellschaft der insolventen Air-Berlin-Tochter Niki, die der Lufthansa-Konzern auf Druck der EU-Wettbewerbsh\u00fcter nicht \u00fcbernehmen durfte. Lauda hatte die Airline zun\u00e4chst alleine erworben, sich dann aber \u00fcberraschend mit dem Lufthansa-Rivalen Ryanair verb\u00fcndet. Die Iren wollen perspektivisch 75 Prozent an der Laudamotion \u00fcbernehmen, die \u00fcber attraktive Start- und Landerechte an deutschen Flugh\u00e4fen verf\u00fcgt. Andere Laudamotion-Fl\u00fcge werden \u00fcber die Condor vermarktet. "Animals this Week", "text": "Fact Animals this Week Nutrias fight for a carrot in the mud in a park in Frankfurt, Germany, Thursday, March 22, 2018. (Photo by Michael Probst/AP Photo) An oriental pied hornbill bird eats a seed as it sits on the branch of a tree in Pobitora village, on the outskirts of Guwahati in India's northeast Assam state, on March 19, 2018. The oriental pied hornbill is one of the most common member of the Asian hornbill family, and is found throughout the Indian subcontinent and across southeast Asia. (Photo by Biju Boro/AFP Photo) An iguana is seen as the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission continues its efforts to try and control the invasive species on March 13, 2018 in Miami, Florida. The commission has teams of people that are trying to eliminate the reptiles by killing them, which would prevent them from eating native plants and wildlife as well as disturbing the natural Florida habitat that they are living in. (Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images) A polar bear curls up in the fresh snow in its enclosure in Sosto Zoo in Nyiregyhaza, Hungary, Sunday, March 18, 2018. (Photo by Attila Balazs/MTI via AP Photo) A young Nile goose hides under its mother in Stuttgart, southern Germany on March 19, 2018. (Photo by Sina Schuldt/AFP Photo) Japanese Macaque monkeys soak in the warmth of mountain hotsprings at Jigokudani Monkey Park, in Yamanouchi, central Japan, 21 March 2018. The Japanese Macaques (Macaca fuscata), also referred to as Snow Monkeys, live freely in this area that is covered by snow one third of the year. Jigokudani is the only known place in the world where monkeys bathe in natural hot springs. As a habit, they come down from the mountains where they spend the night and bath during the day. The monkeys can be viewed live on the internet. (Photo by Kimimasa Mayama/EPA/EFE) Japanese Macaque monkeys soak in the warmth of mountain hotsprings at Jigokudani Monkey Park, in Yamanouchi, central Japan, 21 March 2018. (Photo by Kimimasa Mayama/EPA/EFE/Rex Features/Shutterstock) Storks feed on a meadow in the village of Targowisko, central Poland, 23 March 2018. A flock of nearly 200 storks stay already for several days in the village due lack of strenght and lack of food to countinue their flight. Residents of the villages and nearby towns feed birds to help them survive hard conditions, as spring didn't come to Poland yet and in some regions there is still snow. (Photo by Wojciech Pacewicz/EPA/EFE) In this handout from WWF- Australia taken on March 13, 2018, an eastern quoll takes its first steps into the wild during a translocation in Jervis Bay in northern New South Wales. A species of quoll devastated by foxes has been returned to the wild in mainland Australia for the first time in almost 50 years in a rare conservation success story. (Photo by Morgan Cardiff/AFP Photo) A one horned Rhino roams during the Rhino census inside the Pobitora Wild Life Sanctuary in Morigaon district of Assam state, India, 18 March 2018. Pobitora has the highest density of one horned Rhino population in the world, presently numbering about 93 according to 2012 census in just 38.8 Sq. km. area. The Rhino census for the year 2018 has been conducted with the help of elephants and on foot where about 70 forest officials including NGO members took part. (Photo by EPA/EFE/Stringer) A booted racket- tail hummingbird (Chlorophanes spiza) is photographed at the Cloud Forest of San Antonio, in the rural area of Cali, department of Valle del Cauca, Colombia, on March 1, 2018. With over 1,900, Colombia is the country with the largest number of bird species in the world. (Photo by Luis Robayo/AFP Photo) A family of Capybaras (Hydrochoerus hydrochaeris) is pictured, at the Pantanal wetlands, in Mato Grosso state, Brazil on March 7, 2018. The Pantanal is the largest wetland on the planet located in Brazil, Bolivia and Paraguay, covers more than 170,500 km2 and is home to more than 4,000 species of plants and animals. This ecosystem is at risk of collapsing if the rivers' headwaters are not protected from the advance of monoculture plantations, waterways, hydroelectric plants and deforestation warn scientists and activists. (Photo by Carl de Souza/AFP Photo) A red deer stag leaps in the snow in Glenshee, Scotland, Britain March 19, 2018. (Photo by Russell Cheyne/Reuters) World's last male northern white rhino dies. A statement from the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya says the 45-year-old rhino was euthanised on Monday after \u201cage-related complications\u201d had \u201cworsened significantly\u201d and he was no longer able to stand. Sudan had been part of an ambitious effort to save the subspecies from extinction with the help of the two surviving females. The rhinoceros had previously lived at the Dver Kralove Zoo in the Czech Republic before being transported to Ol Pejeta Conservancy, about 250 km (155 miles) north of Nairobi, where he lived with the last two females of the same species, 27-year old Najin and 17-year old Fatu. The world's last male northern white rhino has died, leaving only two females of its subspecies alive in the world. Here: Members of the Maasai Cricket Warriors pose for a photograph with the last surviving male northern white rhino named \u201cSudan\u201d, June 2017. (Photo by Thomas Mukoya/Reuters) In this February 27, 2018 photo, a group of ponies neighed and splashed on a pond cooling off after a polo game at La Carona club, Capilla del Senor, Buenos Aires province, Argentina. \u201cPolo is played in the countryside a lot and in a much more informal way\u201d, said Juan Pablo Alessandrini, spokesman for Argentina's Polo Association. (Photo by Victor R. Caivano/AP Photo) A picture taken on March 16, 2018 shows a newborn black spider monkey at the Artis Zoo in Amsterdam. The young was born on 13 March, its gender is still unknow. (Photo by Koen van Weel/AFP Photo/ANP) Highland cows are photographed as they graze in the Kilpatrick Hills near Glasgow, Scotland, Sunday March 18, 2018, as the cold snap keeps a grip of the UK. (Photo by John Linton/PA via AP Photo) A peacock with its tail covered with snow walks in Lazienki park in Warsaw, Poland, Friday, March 16, 2018, as snow came down in the city in a sudden return of winter weather with the temperature minus 3 degree Celsius (26.6 Fahrenheit). (Photo by Alik Keplicz/AP Photo) A golden lion tamarin monkey holds its newly born baby at a zoo in Jerusalem, Thursday, March 22, 2018. Golden lion tamarins are among the rarest animals in the world, according to the World Wildlife Fund. It is listed as endangered according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature. (Photo by Sebastian Scheiner/AP Photo) In this Tuesday, March 20, 2018 photo, a Vampire Bat drinks bovine blood in the Criaturas de la Noche (Creatures of the Night) Bat House, the Audubon Zoo's new night house in New Orleans. The various species are all from Central and South America, and the building's interior simulates an abandoned warehouse set up to protect Mayan artifacts during a dig.
