"text": "Arbeitskleidung & Schutzkleidung f\u00fcr Beh\u00f6rden und Berufsbildungszentren BBZ von Kolzen connektar 25. M\u00e4rz 2018 Bildung, Karriere, Schulungen -Werbung- G\u00fcnstige und moderne Arbeitskleidung f\u00fcr Stadtwerke, Entsorgungsbetriebe und Berufsbildungszentrum in gro\u00dfer Auswahl. Produktion und Sonderanfertigung von Schutzkleidung nach Vorgabe der Beh\u00f6rden. \nKolzen \u2013 Ihre erste Anlaufstelle auf der Suche nach Arbeitskleidung f\u00fcr Beh\u00f6rden \nSie ben\u00f6tigen die passende Kleidung f\u00fcr Mitarbeiter in Stadtwerken, Stra\u00dfen- oder Forst\u00e4mtern, Polizisten oder auch Feuerwehrleute? Dann sind Sie bei Kolzen genau an der richtigen Stelle. Hier finden Sie nicht nur ansprechende und gepr\u00fcfte Markenware, sondern auch kompetente Beratung durch unseren Kundendienst. \nWir stellen uns vor \nKolzen Arbeitssschutz- und Textilvertrieb ist ein Unternehmen, welches seit 1999 in Hamburg ans\u00e4ssig ist. Seitdem haben wir unseren Vertrieb systematisch ausgebaut und sind nun sowohl national- als auch international t\u00e4tig. Somit konnten wir auch viele namenhafte Hersteller auftun, welche Schutzkleidung mit hoher Qualit\u00e4t herstellen. K\u00fcbler, Mascot, Stabulus und Puma sind nur wenige dieser Vertreter. Wir legen viel Wert auf hochwertige Materialien und Verarbeitung. Bieten antistatische Kleidung f\u00fcr die unterschiedlichsten Arbeitsfelder. Sollten Sie also auf der Suche nach Arbeitskleidung f\u00fcr Beh\u00f6rden sein, dann sind Sie mit uns gut Beraten. \nDenn in der Beratung liegt unsere gro\u00dfe St\u00e4rke. Unsere Mitarbeiter beraten Sie gerne und auch kompetent bei Fragen zur Schutzkleidung. Gerne fertigen wir Ihnen auch nach Kundenvorgabe oder vorgegebener CI die passende Kleidung an, sodass diese zu Ihrer vollsten Zufriedenheit hergestellt wird. Sie m\u00f6chten gerne einen pers\u00f6nlichen Aufdruck? Auch das ist bei Kolzen kein Problem. Einerlei ob Werbeslogan, Logo oder auch Firmenname \u2013 besprechen Sie ihr Vorhaben mit unseren Kundenbetreuern und schon wird die passende Arbeitskleidung f\u00fcr Beh\u00f6rden hergestellt. Zudem \u00fcberzeugen wir mit schnellen Lieferzeiten, g\u00fcnstigen Preisen und Sie haben die M\u00f6glichkeit einen Kauf auf Rechnung zu t\u00e4tigen. \nDie richtige Arbeitskleidung f\u00fcr Beh\u00f6rden finden \nAuf der Suche nach der passenden Arbeitskleidung m\u00fcssen so einige H\u00fcrden genommen werden. Es gibt viele Anbieter, dass auch Sie sicherlich schnell die \u00dcbersicht verlieren. Bei Kolzen finden Sie bereits eine Auswahl an kompetenten Herstellern, sodass Sie sich sicher seine k\u00f6nnen, hier nur Qualit\u00e4tsware zu finden. Die Kleidungsst\u00fccke entsprechen zudem den vorgegebenen Normen und wurden entsprechend gepr\u00fcft, sodass Sie ihren Mitarbeitern den bestm\u00f6glichen Schutz bieten. Haben Sie jedoch Fragen zur Gr\u00f6\u00dfe, den Ausf\u00fchrungen oder auch der Farbe, dann k\u00f6nnen Sie sich immer gerne an unseren Kundendienst wenden. Zudem werden Sie hier auch \u00fcber den Punkt Nachhaltigkeit informiert, denn dieser liegt uns am Herzen. Auf dem Markt finden Sie viele preisg\u00fcnstige Waren, welche in S\u00fcdostasien hergestellt werden. Komplette Set der Schutzbekleidung sind hier zu finden. Diese Waren haben jedoch einen gro\u00dfen Fehler: Sie sind in keinem Fall nachhaltig Produziert. Wir bei Kolzen legen jedoch gro\u00dfen Wert darauf, dass wir nur Kleidung anbieten, welche nachhaltig und unter fairen Bedingungen hergestellt wurde. \nNachhaltige Schutzkleidung \nNachhaltige Berufsbekleidung und auch recyclebare Berufsbekleidung sind eher rah. Demnach haben wir es uns zur Aufgabe gemacht eine Kollektion zu entwickeln, welche bewusst auf die Produktionsverh\u00e4ltnisse, Materialien aber auch auf die Personen, die die Kleidung tragen soll, achtet. Nat\u00fcrliche Stoffe ohne viele Chemikalien sind hier genutzt worden. Auch nachhaltige Materialien sind uns wichtig \u2013 Roh\u00f6l hat in unserer Arbeitskleidung f\u00fcr Beh\u00f6rden nichts verloren. Demnach nutzen wir beispielsweise gerne Bio-Baumwolle. Somit verbessern wir nicht nur den \u00f6kologischen Fu\u00dfabdruck, sondern sorgen auch f\u00fcr hohen Tragekomfort bei Ihren Mitarbeitern. Zudem liegt uns auch das Recycling am Herzen. Demnach haben wir eine spezielle Baumwolle \u2013 die Cradle to Cradle Baumwolle entwickelt. Diese verf\u00fcgt \u00fcber einen hohen Tragekomfort, sondern auch kann ohne Probleme sofort recycelt werden. Und nat\u00fcrlich ist ein Kauf auf Rechnung bei dieser nachhaltigen Ware auch m\u00f6glich. \nUnser Service auf einen Blick \nKolzen kann auf vielen unterschiedlichen Ebenen \u00fcberzeugen: Zum einen haben wir unsere Partner sehr intensiv gepr\u00fcft, sodass Sie hier nur zuverl\u00e4ssige und hochwertige Ware erhalten. Des Weiteren haben wir uns der Nachhaltigkeit von Arbeitskleidung angenommen, einen neue recyclebare Baumwolle entwickelt und legen gro\u00dfen Wert auf faire Arbeitsbedingungen. Somit unterst\u00fctzen Sie mit einem Kauf bei Kolzen faire Produktionsbedingungen. Nat\u00fcrlich erf\u00fcllen diese Kollektionen auch die Sicherheitsnormen und haben das passende Design f\u00fcr den jeweiligen Job \u2013 ob bei der Polizei, der Feuerwehr oder beim Forstamt, hier werden Sie f\u00fcndig. Des Weiteren legen wir gro\u00dfen Wert auf einen kompetenten Kundendienst, welcher Ihnen gerne mit Rat und Tat zur Seite steht und auch bei besonderen W\u00fcnschen gerne unterst\u00fctzt. Auch die Zahlung ist bei Kolzen ganz einfach. Sie k\u00f6nnen in Vorkrasse treten oder auch einen Kauf auf Rechnung t\u00e4tigen. Sollten Sie noch weitere Frage zu unseren Produkten oder unserem Unternehmen haben, dann wenden Sie sich gerne an uns. Sanguinetti, dpa", "text": "Find hotels in 1ST LEAD German police detain fugitive former Catalan leader Puigdemont By Fabian Wegener and Pablo Sanguinetti, dpa Europe By our dpa-correspondent and Hamburg (dpa) - Carles Puigdemont, the fugitive Catalan separatist leader being sought by Spanish authorities on charges of rebellion, was detained by police in Germany on Sunday.Puigdemont was taken into custody as he travelled from Finland back to Belgium. He was detained by police after he crossed the border into Germany from Denmark, Jaume Alonso-Cuevillas wrote on Twitter.\"The treatment has been correct in every moment,\" Puigdemont\u2018s spokesman Joan Maria Pique said in a statement sent to dpa.\"At the moment he is in a police station and his legal defence is already activated,\" he added.Police in the northern German city of Kiel said Puigdemont was taken in by officers at 11:19 am (0919 GMT) while his vehicle travelled south on the A7 motorway.The grounds for pulling Puigdemont over were a European Arrest Warrant, police said.The Spanish Supreme Court on Friday issued fresh arrest warrants against Puigdemont and six other Catalan politicians who currently are abroad.The charges of rebellion were linked to the backing of Catalonia\u2018s bid to secede from Spain in October.Puigdemont and other exiled Catalan leaders have travelled to other countries in Europe despite efforts by Spain to seek their extradition.Puigdemont was recently in Finland, where he attended meetings at the Finnish parliament and gave a talk on Friday at Helsinki University.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "title": "Synthese 4 Tankship PD5964", "text": "Recent News Tank barge allided with bridge\nIn the morning of March 23, 2018, the \"Synthese 4\", 1707 ts (EU-No.: 02326647), allided with a railway bridge over the Rhine-Herne-Canal in Obermeiderich. The top of the wheelhouse was torn off, and the 33 year old master was injured. An ambulance took him to hospital. The unloaded ship was disabled and berthed close to the Gartrop Bridge. In the early afternoon it was taken to a yard for repairs. The \"Synthese 4\" had been underway from Duisburg to Hamburg at the time of the accident. The canal authority and the police investigated the bridge for possible damages, but it was found safe and sound. The cause of the accident was yet unclear. The bridge has a passing height of 5,5 meters, so the barge may not have taken on enough ballast water or lowered the wheelhouse enough to pass underneath. "ide", "published": "2018-03-22T10:16:00.000+02:00", "title": "Wide-neck containers: KHS presents individual PET systems for the food sector", "text": "\u2022Further development of the InnoPET Blomax stretch blow molder \u2022Holistic expert consultancy with Bottles & Shapes \u2022Increasing demand for PET containers in the food sector \nThere is a definite trend towards PET and ever larger bottle neck openings: in the food sector, where to date glass filling was standard, manufacturers are increasingly favoring lightweight plastic. Not only are individual bottle and packaging designs in demand but also wide-neck containers for sauces, dressings and dairy products. In order to give bottlers in this field the greatest possible flexibility, KHS has now further developed its InnoPET Blomax stretch blow molder. The systems supplier is also extending its Bottles and Shapes program for distinctive bottle design. \nFaster, more variable and more efficient: KHS has now further developed its InnoPET Blomax stretch blow molder for PET container filling. \u201cThis latest improvement enables preforms measuring up to 70 millimeters in diameter to be processed\u201d, says Frank Haesendonckx , head of Sales and Technology at KHS Corpoplast in Hamburg, Germany. The machine is available as a modular design with an output of up to 2,500 PET bottles per hour and station. \nPET and wide-neck containers are becoming more important to the food industry in particular, with this type of packaging steadily growing in popularity for products such as sauces, dressings or dairy products. To quote Haesendonckx, \u201cPET has a number of advantages over glass, such as its unbreakability and low weight\u201d. Another plus point is that sensitive products can also be filled into transparent plastic packaging thanks to KHS\u2019 FreshSafe PET coating method. Already tried and tested many times over in the beverage industry, this process finishes the inside of the PET bottle with a wafer-thin layer of pure silicon oxide. \u201cThis barrier gives products a shelf life which is comparable to that of glass\u201d, states Haesendonckx. \nCan be blocked with other systems \nDepending on user requirements the stretch blow molder can be blocked with other KHS systems \u2013 not just with the InnoPET Plasmax for container coating but also with the Innosept Asbofill for the hygienic filling of sensitive products, for instance. The new KHS chunk dosing unit for flexible product design, which adds fruit, vegetables or cereals, can also be integrated into the system. \u201cWe\u2019re vastly expanding the application options and providing system solutions for new markets\u201d, claims Haesendonckx. \nIn combination with KHS\u2019 Bottles and Shapes bottle design program the systems supplier provides all-round service. Together with the customer KHS develops individual PET containers specifically tailored for functionality. \u201cWe offer all producers of food and beverages in PET containers holistic consultancy from the design through technical engineering to production of their PET bottles\u201d, says Haesendonckx. The aim is to produce bottles with a high level of brand recognition which clearly stand out from those of the competition, bottles which can be produced cost effectively through lightweighting and which have a high degree of consumer affinity. The preferential heating system developed by the KHS Group also ensures optimum material distribution and bottle quality while using less energy in the stretch blow molding process. Very precise neck orientation is possible specific to the application, even in the manufacture of very oval containers, assures Haesendonckx. This creates the best possible synchronization between packaging and line production.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": "author": "", "published": "2018-03-25T15:43:00.000+03:00", "title": "Easter witches make the rounds as part of age-old Finnish custom", "text": "updated 25.3.2018 15:46 Easter witches make the rounds as part of age-old Finnish custom Most of Finland celebrates Palm Sunday with the same tradition: children dress up and go door-to-door collecting sweets in return for a willow branch. Finland's Palm Sunday tradition brings witches to the door Image: Antti Haanp\u00e4\u00e4/Yle \nWitches, cats and bunnies are out this Sunday, carrying willow branches ornamented with bright feathers and tissue paper. They might show up at your door, where they will recite a rhyme wishing you health for the following year. The youngsters will then expect Easter candy in trade for the branch, which you get to keep as a memory of their visit. \nReminiscent of the trick-or-treat tradition in the British Isles and North America, this practice is believed to be a mixture of Orthodox Easter blessing customs from Eastern Finland with pre-Christian rituals from Western Finland and Scandinavia. \nIn the northwestern region of Ostrobothnia, kids wait until the Saturday before Easter to partake in the tradition. \nUnna Nummelin from Helsinki put her costume together in the morning, complete with an apron and a scarf for her head. A bit of red rouge on her cheeks and she is transformed into an Easter witch. The tradition requires that the children dress as witches, but in the last few decades, the dress code has been expanded to include all manner of costumes. \n\"I'm not nervous about it anymore. We'll just knock on doors until we run out of branches,\" she says. \nLaura Larres was part of a three-person team that decorated branches for the big day. \n\"I had intended to prepare them during the youngest child's nap, but he didn't end up sleeping very long, so it ended up being a pretty hectic decorating process. I think this is a great tradition, even so. It is rewarded to see the children having fun,\" she says. Unna Nummelin has several years of Palm Sunday witching under her belt. She is trying her luck this year in the Helsinki district of Maunula. Image: Antti Haanp\u00e4\u00e4/Yle Chocolate eggs seem to be the treat of choice. Image: Antti Haanp\u00e4\u00e4/Yle Oiva Sorsa and Roope Prokkola from Helsinki dressed as a wizard and pig. Too young to hand out the branches, little tiger Eero Larres was still along for the fun. Image: Antti Haanp\u00e4\u00e4/Yle . Ville Honkala decided to be a wizard for Palm Sunday after discovering some hair dye at home Image: Antti Haanp\u00e4\u00e4/Yle Ansa Kuusniemi dressed as a not-very-frightening Easter witch.. Image: Antti Haanp\u00e4\u00e4/Yle Several parents reported that the decoration of the branches was a time-consuming effort. Image: Antti Haanp\u00e4\u00e4/Yle Residents in Maunula welcomed children at their doors. Image: Antti Haanp\u00e4\u00e4/Yle . Ilona Nummelin's basket contains four Easter chocolate eggs and assorted candies. Image: Antti Haanp\u00e4\u00e4/Yle Many parents stand nearby to lend a helping hand, if necessary. Image: Antti Haanp\u00e4\u00e4/Yle Photo from Helsinki's Maunula district on Palm Sunday 2018. "published": "2018-03-22T17:40:00.000+02:00", "title": "Finnish solar industry looks for boost from better storage", "text": "updated 22.3.2018 17:46 Finnish solar industry looks for boost from better storage Pricey solar electricity storage units are still selling modestly in Finland, but growth expectations are high. Image: Mikko Savolainen/Yle \nA dozen solar panels gleam in the sun on the roof of a semi-detached house in Herttoniemi, eastern Helsinki. In March, some of the panels are still covered with snow, but the homeowner says that the longer, brighter spring days are already spurring a noticeable increase in electricity production. \n\u201cYesterday we had an output of 1,000 watts. Sometimes the summer it gets up to 3,000 watts a day,\u201d says homeowner Timo Juutilainen. \nWith a gently-sloping south-facing roof on the seashore, the location is ideal for solar energy production in northern Europe. Juutilainen installed the panels two years ago and has been satisfied with how they work. \nA month ago, the family put in an electricity storage unit that retains electricity generated by the panels for 3-4 hours. \nStory continues after photo The inverter tracks how much energy is being produced. Image: Ari Tuhkanen / Yle \n\u201cI want to store the electricity that\u2019s produced during the day so that we can use it in the evening and at night. Up until now, most of the electricity we\u2019ve produced has gone back to the power grid for quite a small compensation fee,\u201d explains Juutilainen. \nFinland's energy regulator allows only small tax breaks for the installation of solar capacity by households, and excludes solar power entirely from the feed-in tariff system intended to encourage renewable energy production by offering set prices for electricity generated by some renewable sources. \nThe government has no targets for solar energy production, preferring to focus renewable energy policy on wind power, biogas and forest industry products. Keep your own power for your own use \nSolar energy storage batteries for private homes are a relatively new concept. Juutilainen\u2019s unit was installed by Helsinki city power utility Helen, which only began offering the product to homeowners late last year. The company estimates that such units can boost solar panels\u2019 capacity utilisation factor to more than 90 percent. \n\u201cWith storage, you avoid having to transfer your own production to the network, where you don\u2019t get very good compensation, and there are no signs that you will be able to do so within the foreseeable future,\u201d says Kristiina Siilin, project manager at Helen. \nThe nominal storage capacity of Helen\u2019s solar electricity packages ranges from six to 16 kilowatt-hours (kWh). \nSeveral other storage unit alternatives for small houses are available on the Finnish market. For instance Naps Solar Systems, also based in Helsinki, sells batteries with a capacity of 4-16 kWh. Meanwhile an Espoo firm, Eaton, plans to bring units with 4.2-9.5 kWh storage capacity onto the market this year. \n\u201cThe batteries are the same as those used in Nissan cars,\u201d notes Pasi Pesonen, an executive at the company. \nStory continues after photo The storage unit fits in beside a coat-rack. Image: Ari Tuhkanen / Yle \nThe Juutilainens\u2019 storage unit is about the height and width of a large refrigerator, but only 25 cm deep. The storage unit must always be set up in a warm indoor location. The control unit is on a wall in the front hall, along with the inverter, which gauges how much energy is coming in. Ecological, not financial reasons \nThe Juutilainens have invested about 20,000 euros in their solar system, and have not made exact calculations as to how long it will take to pay for itself. \n\u201cI haven\u2019t dared to figure that out, because I guess that it probably won\u2019t pay off for at least 20 years. The usage costs are nil, though,\u201d says Juutilainen. \nSiilin acknowledges that buying solar panels and a storage unit does not yet make sense in purely financial terms. \n\u201cThe fact that you save on electricity transfer fees and taxes is not enough to make it profitable within the equipment\u2019s lifetime, but generally the values in these investments come from somewhere else besides the payback time,\u201d says Siilin. \nFor Juutilainen, the investment was motivated by a desire for more environmentally sound energy production. \n\u201cI didn\u2019t buy it for business reasons but for ecological reasons. I also wanted to show the others in our housing association that they could install one of these, too,\u201d says Juutilainen. Prices set to drop \nElectricity storage units are still new, expensive products, so sales have been minimal so far. For instance, Helen has only sold a few of them. \n\u201cThere are several installations underway and several other customers are interested. But we expect sales to pick up,\u201d says Siilin. \nNaps Solar Systems says it has installed about 10 storage units for detached houses in the Uusimaa region so far. \n\u201cAt the moment, these are being bought by people who're interested in technology and those who want to produce their own energy,\u201d says sales director Markus Andersen, who also chairs the Finnish solar technology association. \nGrowth expectations are high at Naps too, though. \n\u201cWithin two years, buying solar panels and electricity storage units will become financially viable and demand will rise significantly,\u201d predicts Andersen, based on price trends for solar electricity systems and developments in battery technology. Roschier hosts Housewarming Seminar with Konecranes and Skadden", "text": "Print \nThe first seminar at our brand new premises in Helsinki was held on Thursday 15 March together with Konecranes and Skadden. The topic of the seminar was one of the most complex cross-border transactions in Finnish industrial history, where Konecranes acquired the MHPS Business from Terex after the parties had replaced the Business Combination Agreement signed in August 2015 with a Stock and Asset Purchase Agreement signed in May 2016. \nThe speakers, who had central roles throughout the eventful transaction, discussed the key business points and the strategies which helped Konecranes to succeed when Zoomlion surfaced as a bidder for Terex in the middle of the process. \nRainer Hilli , Chairman of the Board at Roschier, opened the event, after which Christoph Vitzthum , Chairman of the Board of Konecranes, gave his opening remarks. Stig Gustavson , Past Chairman of the Board of Konecranes and Chairman of the Konecranes/Terex Transaction Team, explained the background to the transaction. Panu Routila , President and CEO of Konecranes, talked the audience through the business side of the case, after which the legal advisors, Scott V. Simpson , Partner and Co-Head of Global Transactions Practice at Skadden; Ivan A. Schlager , Partner and Head of CFIUS at Skadden; and Jan-Anders Wik , Partner at Roschier, went through the transaction timeline and the key legal points. \nThe seminar ended with an interesting panel discussion on the lessons learned, strategy and key business points of the transaction. The panel, consisting of Christoph Vitzthum, Panu Routila and Stig Gustavson elaborated further on the topic and answered questions from the audience. "2018-03-23T12:45:00.000+03:00", "title": "Elderly increasingly targeted by fraud", "text": "updated 23.3.2018 15:36 Elderly increasingly targeted by fraud Helsinki police warn that con artists are getting ever more brazen in their efforts defraud older people of money and valuables. Image: AOP \nThe elderly being conned out of their money and jewelry is nothing new. What is new, though, is how brazen criminals have become in exploiting the trust of older people. \nSwindlers have expanded their range of fictitious professional guises beyond the well-known police imposters to include fake social workers, taxi drivers, bank officers, nurses, and repairmen. \nLast week, police in eastern Uusimaa warned the public of frauds targeting the elderly. On Friday, Helsinki police issued a similar warning. \n\"There have been close to 20 cases. They are being investigated as a number of different crimes, including theft, attempted aggravated theft, fraud, payment fraud, minor fraud and attempted fraud,\" Helsinki Police Detective Chief Inspector Kari Martikainen told Yle. \nThese cons have netted perpetrators bank cards, cash, jewelry and bank account security codes. Targeted at shopping centres \nA new trend among these criminals is to use various pretexts to approach elderly people at shopping centres and to follow them home. \nOnce there, the swindler, often impersonating an official or professional some some sort, presents a plausible story to gain entrance and rifle through the senior's belongings. \nOne woman suspected of conning elderly people once used the ruse of offering free incontinence products. Another time, she claimed to need to check a victim's medical alert phone, and once requested money for a medical monitoring bracelet. \n\"They are well behaved the whole time, none of these elderly people have said they were pressured,\" relates Kari Martikainen. \nAccording to Martikainen, the suspects have been fluent Finnish, or in some cases, Swedish speakers. \nPolice recently took two women into custody on suspicion of carrying out these kinds of scams. Both have confessed to some of the charges. \nMartikainen has advice for people involved with care for the elderly about how to protect them from being exploited. \n\"We urge professionals who work with the elderly, as well as volunteers, to be alert to this and to tell seniors about the danger of getting conned. It's important to tell the elderly and their families in detail how, for example, to recognize a legitimate home care nurse,\" says Chief Inspector Martikainen. Airbus \nFinnish national carrier Finnair has been selected as the Best European Airline at the TTG China Travel Awards. \nThis is the third year in a row that Finnair has won the accolade, at one of the most influential travel industry awards in Greater China. \nTTG China recognises Greater China\u2019s best companies in the travel industry, with the selection made by travel industry professionals. \n\u201cIt is a great honour to receive this prestigious award, and I would like to thank all our customers and partners for the recognition and support,\u201d says Juha J\u00e4rvinen , chief commercial officer at Finnair. \u201cFinnair was the first European airline to open direct flights to Beijing in 1988, and this year we are proud to celebrate the 30th anniversary of serving the Chinese market.\u201d \nChina is a key market for Finnair with the airline flying to seven cities: Beijing, Shanghai, Chongqing, Xi\u2019an, Guangzhou, Nanjing and Hong Kong. \nShare:", "author": "", "published": "2018-03-25T12:22:00.000+03:00", "title": "Demonstration for better daycare teacher pay gathers hundreds", "text": "updated 25.3.2018 12:27 Demonstration for better daycare teacher pay gathers hundreds Hundreds of people gathered in Helsinki's Narinkka Square adjacent the Kamppi shopping complex on Saturday to demand better salaries for Finland's daycare personnel. Protesters at the March 24 event Image: Kimmo Hiltunen / Yle \nIntense discussion of nursery teacher wages in Finland snowballed into a protest in Helsinki on Saturday. A citizens' group that calls itself \"Ei en\u00e4\u00e4 leikkirahaa (No more play money)\" was the instigator of the demonstration in early March on social media. \nThe movement was sparked by a March 5 story from the public broadcaster Yle in which the teachers' union OAJ accused the capital city municipalities of creating an unofficial \"gentleman's agreement\" to not pay higher salaries to hire competent daycare teachers, despite hundreds of vacancies and a severe shortage of skilled professionals. \nThe municipal leaders of Espoo, Helsinki, and Vantaa later denied that any such verbal agreement was in place. \n\"The pact seemed so immoral; we just had to man the barricades. People are very dissatisfied and they feel as if their wages are extremely unfair,\" said Pauliina Sepp\u00e4l\u00e4, one of the organizers of the group, which received over 10,000 likes on Facebook after it was established. Average salary: 2,300 euros per month \nThe minimum monthly salary for daycare teachers in the three municipalities currently stands at around 2,300 euros. This payment is often even a few hundred euros smaller per month for workers in private daycare institutions. \nMany people at the Saturday event called for monthly wages in the sector to be raised to 3,000 euros. Some of the banners at the protest read \"A calling doesn't pay the bills\", in reference to arguments that wages have remained low because people tend to think that people who pursue daycare work do so because they answer a calling to their vocation. \nThe union of daycare teachers in Finland has called for a salary increase to 3,000 euros to match that of teachers in primary and secondary schools, and the OAJ has concurred. \n\"Daycare teachers carry out demanding and valuable work that not only benefits the children, but also the entire society,\" OAJ chair Olli Luukkainen said in statement in support of the demonstration on Friday. Future of early childhood education at stake \nSepp\u00e4l\u00e4 said she was pleased that the demonstration attracted so many participants. She says it will give her group the impetus to continue the fight until daycare wages are improved. \nJari Miettinen was one of the people drawn to the protest. He changed careers and abandoned his work as a daycare teacher after he burned out. He says a wage increase is absolutely necessary if Finland wants to develop early childhood education appropriately. \n\"We need a bigger wage so people will listen to us. If daycare teachers earned 3,000 euros a month, we would be better noticed. Only then would we really be able to press for children's best interests,\" he said. Sources", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "kimmo hiltunen", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "yle", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "oaj", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "espoo", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "narinkka square", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "kamppi", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "finland", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "vantaa", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "helsinki", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "yle.fi", "site_section": "http://yle.fi/uutiset/rss/uutiset.rss?osasto=news", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "Yle News | Tuoreimmat uutiset", "title": "Teenagers put in their two cents at Youth Parliamentary Day", "title_full": "Teenagers put in their two cents at Youth Parliamentary Day", "published": "2018-03-23T14:50:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": "published": "2018-03-23T14:50:00.000+03:00", "title": "Teenagers put in their two cents at Youth Parliamentary Day", "text": "updated 23.3.2018 14:37 Teenagers put in their two cents at Youth Parliamentary Day Youth Parliament day brings 400 students into the ranks of MPs. Some will dip their toes in the role of a cabinet minister while others test journalistic waters. Olavi Sepp\u00e4l\u00e4 ja Julietta Nylund will spend their Friday at the Parliament House. Image: Kalevi Rytk\u00f6l\u00e4 / Yle \nOn 23 March the Parliamentary house opens its doors to 400 students of lower secondary schools across Finland for Youth Parliament day. The event is held once every two years, with 2018 marking the 11th Youth Parliament Day. \nThe Youth Parliament is organised in cooperation between the Parliament of Finland and the Development Centre Opinkirjo. It is the culmination of parliamentary club activities in schools for 15 to 16 year-olds and has been organised since 1998. \nBlack jeans and smart shirts are expected to be sported for the formal event as 15-year old Julietta Nylund walks the steps up to Parliament with a question for the ministers in mind. \nThe question is no small undertaking, as the parliament club of Helsinki\u2019s Porolahti lower secondary school have mulled over the issue since the start of the year. Topics of residency, poverty, and of course the presidential election have been suggested. \nNylund and Olavi Sepp\u00e4l\u00e4, another parliamentary club comrade, are avid followers of politics who regularly tune into the evening news and flick through the pages of daily newspapers. \nThe teens enjoy lunchtime discussion topics of world politics and Finnish news at school, but admit the conversations are fairly superficial. \n\u201dI would not lower the voting age limit. Many people our age have a fairly narrow view of politics,\u201d said Nylund. \nStory continues after photograph Julietta Nylund will ask ministers about expensive living conditions. Image: Kalevi Rytk\u00f6l\u00e4 / Yle \nAbove all, the youths hope for candor from politicians. \n\u201dThey are great speakers, that part is obvious, but I wish that they would state their own opinions more clearly,\u201d said Sepp\u00e4l\u00e4. \nNylund on the other hand would encourage politicians to smile more. \n\u201dPoliticians look so serious. A lot of my friends have the opinion that politicians are quite stuffy with no sense of humor.\u201d A step from schools to politics \nPoliticians will have a chance to hone their facial skills as a record number of students participate in this year\u2019s Parliamentary Youth day. A total of 154 schools will get the chance to send a student representative, as well as one journalism student and one club director. \n\u201dThe new curriculum promotes getting involved and being an influencer, and it shows,\u201d said Tiina Karhuvirta, senior advisor and Youth Parliament organizer at Development Centre Opinkirjo. \nAccording to Karhuvirta, in past years the relationship between schools and politicians has been at times an issue of wary caution, as some teachers still feel reluctant to invite their district MP to their classroom. \nHowever, this mindset is a dwindling notion as the younger generation of teachers approach the topic with progress in mind. \n\u201cI don\u2019t feel that old traumas hamper my job. Civics studies is such a fruitful subject when looking at the development of the real world,\u201d said Laura Parikka, civics teacher at Porolahti school. \nStory continues after photograph Mikael Mikkonen dreams of a politician and musician's career. Image: Kalevi Rytk\u00f6l\u00e4 / Yle A dream to meet Laura Huhtasaari and P\u00e4ivi R\u00e4s\u00e4nen \nCore values are at the centreof the political views of 16-year old Mikael Mikkonen . A student at Vesala upper secondary school, Mikkonen joined the parliamentary club as soon as it started up. \nMikkonen knows he is the school's odd bird because of his strong political opinions. \n\u201cConservative and Christian values are close to my heart. Home, religion, the mother country, and the preservation of these three are of great importance to me.\u201d \nIn current affairs, Mikkonen has focused on the politics of immigration and economic policies. The progress of Sote, the social and healthcare reform, is also of interest. \n\u201cIt feels like such a maze,\u201d said Mikkonen on the topic of Sote, \u201cI can\u2019t really keep up. But it is interesting to follow.\u201d \nWhile Mikkonen himself is a socially conscious individual, he ponders how politicians could reach the youths of this day and age. \n\u201cPoliticians should go to the youth, go to where they are and read the climate of what\u2019s going on. If they only hang around campaign tents, they will only meet the adult voters.\u201d \nStory continues after photograph Mikael Mikkonen will represent Vesala school in the Youth Parliamentary day. Image: Kalevi Rytk\u00f6l\u00e4 / Yle \nWhen asked about his question for the ministers, Mikkonen said it was one which echoed his own values. \n\u201cThe intention is to ask about Christian traditions in schools and daycares. It is not an attack against any minority, but it really is a disservice to immigrants if we\u2019re constantly toning down our own traditions. It also makes integration more difficult.\u201d \nAfter the question hour planned for the teens, Mikkonen has said he plans to do a bit of networking and hopes he will have a chance to talk with a few cabinet ministers. \n\u201cI hope I could meet Laura Huhtasaari and P\u00e4ivi R\u00e4s\u00e4nen. I admire their work.\u201d Sources", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "olavi sepp\u00e4l\u00e4 ja julietta "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "aleksi.teivainen@gmail.com (Aleksi Teivainen)", "published": "2018-03-23T08:08:00.000+03:00", "title": "Task force calls for consolidation of minimum-level social security benefits", "text": "Reading Mode Share This Professor Juho Saari (right) presented the final conclusions of an equality task force he headed to Prime Minister Juha Sipil\u00e4 (Centre) in Helsinki on Wednesday, 21 March, 2018. \n\nA comprehensive social security reform is widely expected to be one of the main reforms of the next electoral term in Finland. \nA government-appointed task force proposed earlier this week that the benefits making up the minimum-level of social security \u2013 the social assistance, basic unemployment allowance, labour market subsidy, sickness allowance, parental allowance and housing allowance \u2013 be consolidated into a basic social security act. \nThe basic component of the new basic security would be 697 euros a month if the recipient is a registered job seeker who meets the criteria laid out in the activation model for unemployment security. \n\u201cConsolidating minimum-level benefits into one basic security act will establish a clearer income transfer system for customers that reduces inactivity traps and marginalisation,\u201d the task force says in its final report. \nThe report was presented to Prime Minister Juha Sipil\u00e4 (Centre) on Wednesday, 21 March. \nHeaded by Juho Saari, a professor of social and health policy at the University of Tampere, the task force estimates that the first stage should be to reform the social assistance act in a way that prevents recipients from being forced into unreasonable situations, increases the act's incentive effect and ensures that as many a social security service as possible is available under one roof. \nThe basic security would, once completed, consist of a basic component, housing allowance, supplementary component and various compensations. It would be disbursed to those who are entitled to unemployment benefits. \nThe task force also argues that the basic security would increase predictability and work incentives by introducing an activity-based supplement and harmonising the concepts and calculation rules of social security benefits. The basic security would decrease as the recipient\u2019s earnings increased but never to the extent that working becomes not worthwhile. \n\u201cThe incentives would be considerably better than the current ones. The proposal would increase social assistance costs by no more than six million euros,\u201d the task force tells. \n ", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-22T16:40:00.000+02:00", "title": "Municipal leaders up in arms amid projected \u20ac300m cuts to social and health care", "text": "updated 22.3.2018 16:44 Municipal leaders up in arms amid projected \u20ac300m cuts to social and health care Finland's most populous province, Uusimaa, faces 300 million euros in budget cuts as part of a planned reform of health and social care. Image: Antti Kolppo / Yle \nMunicipal leaders and decision-makers of Helsinki, Espoo and Vantaa are pressing hard for changes to the government's planned reform of social and health care, known as ' sote ', as the full scale of funding cuts in the country's most populous region becomes clear. \nSome 300 million euros in spending cuts are projected in the government's preferred model, which aims to expand competition and private provision in healthcare while simultaneously transferring responsibility for it from municipalities to newly-created regional governments to be elected this year. \n\u201dThis kind of planned overhaul is not good. People haven't understood all the risks [involved],\u201d said Juha Metso, Espoo's director of basic social services. \nMarkus Syrj\u00e4inen, Espoo city council's Director of Finance and Administration, produced figures this week projecting that the Uusimaa province, which includes the Helsinki area, will face a 300-million-euro shortfall in the first year of the new system. \nThe figure includes transitional expenses that would accompany the shift away from municipal responsibility for providing health care. Another portion is made up of the increasing demand for services by an ageing population. As thousands of new residents flock to the Helsinki region each year, health and social care provision must grow in proportion. \nLeaders in the Helsinki metropolitan area have said that such transitional costs had not been taken into account in calculations made by the Ministry of Finance. Hunting for cuts \nLeading the rebellion is Jan Vapaavuori, the National Coalition Party Mayor of Helsinki who has declared trenchant opposition to the reform advanced by the government coalition that includes his own party. Vapaavuori's power base is strong, with some 30,000 people voting for him in the last municipal elections, and his party includes other critics of the reform including liberal-minded MP Elina Lepom\u00e4ki . \nTheir critique is two-pronged. The new regional governments, which are dear to the rural Centre Party , have no tax-raising powers and therefore no incentive to reduce costs. Private providers, meanwhile, could be incentivised to cherry-pick young, healthy customers and leaver the older, sicker and more expensive patients for public providers to pick up. \nThe chunk of money cut from budgets in the Uusimaa region will be the most substantial due to its population of 1.6 million--nearly a third of the total population of Finland. \nMunicipal leaders interviewed by Yle estimate that of the 300-million-euro deficit that Uusimaa will face, Helsinki will have to cough up 100 million euros per year, Espoo 50 million, and Vantaa 40 million euros. The remainder would be left for the rest of Uusimaa to come up with. \n\u201dThe equivalent to losing 100 million euros per year in Helsinki would be giving up the entirety of child protection services. That gives you an idea of the scale that we are talking about,\u201d says Helsinki deputy mayor Hanna Vesikansa. \nAccording to the Helsinki-Uusimaa Regional Council, the financial deficit would decrease over time, but not by much. In 2030 the deficit would still be 100 million euros for the entire Uusimaa region. Baby steps \nThe Helsinki-Uusimaa Regional Council have agreed with government officials that weekly negotiations will be held to thrash out funding issues. In addition, the leaders of the Helsinki Metropolitan Area said the transition should be carried out with patience and in baby steps. \n\u201dThis should be done in the same manner as the primary education reform was done back in the day. Start from small provinces and proceed step by step,\u201d said Ritva Viljanen, mayor of Vantaa. "author": "", "published": "2018-03-23T19:07:00.000+03:00", "title": "Parliament rejects citizens\u2019 initiative to preserve Malmi airport", "text": "updated 24.3.2018 10:34 Parliament rejects citizens\u2019 initiative to preserve Malmi Airport MPs did not vote on the motion because the Speaker ruled that the proposal was inherently unconstitutional. Image: Derrick Frilund / Yle \nA citizens\u2019 initiative calling on the government to reverse a Helsinki city decision to build housing on the current location of the Malmi Airport was thrown out of the Parliament on Wednesday. \nMPs did not vote on the motion as Speaker Paula Risikko ruled that the proposal was essentially unconstitutional. \nLate last year, the citizens\u2019 initiative ran into a hurdle when Parliament\u2019s Constitutional Law Committee deemed that reversing the decision by Helsinki city authorities would be unconstitutional, because it would fetter municipal sovereignty. \nLex Malmi, as it came to be known, roiled the parliament and the government during last spring\u2019s local government elections and also spawned a grassroots movement to reverse the decision to build housing on the site of the historic airfield. \nAt the time, Prime Minister Juha Sipil\u00e4 even said that his administration would be willing to step in to preserve the location for light aviation on certain conditions. The main criterion would be finding a suitable area in the city to construct much-needed housing by way of a land swap. Appeals point to cultural importance \nCritics of the plan to construct homes on the airfield have pointed to its historical significance. Completed in 1938, the terminal building designed by architects Dag Englund and Vera Rosendahl is considered a prime example of functionalist architecture. \nIn 2016, the state withdrew its support for the light aircraft airport. Once state airports operator Finavia halted operations at the airfield, the Malmi Airfield Association stepped in to maintain the facility, which is an important site for pilot training. \nThe City of Helsinki has zoned the area for residential development for 25,000 residents. If this scale of housing development were to be implemented, the airfield would not be able to continue in operation. \nOther efforts to preserve the airfield included declaring it a site of historical and cultural significance. On 16 March 2016, Europe's leading cultural heritage organisation Europa Nostra selected Malmi Airport as one of the seven most endangered cultural heritage sites in Europe. "author": "John Breech", "published": "2018-03-23T21:52:00.000+03:00", "title": "Eagles' Michael Bennett indicted on felony charge, has warrant out for arrest", "text": "Eagles' Michael Bennett indicted on felony charge, has warrant out for arrest The veteran defensive end has a warrant out for his arrest in Houston \u2022 1 min read \nEagles defensive end Michael Bennett is facing some serious legal trouble in Texas. \nAccording to CBS affiliate KHOU.com , Bennett has been indicted on a felony charge of causing injury to the elderly for an incident that took place at Super Bowl LI in February 2017. According to the indictment , Bennett allegedly injured a a 66-year-old paraplegic, who was working security at NRG Stadium. \nBennett was at the game to watch his brother, Martellus, who was playing tight end for New England. After the Patriots beat the Falcons 34-28, Michael was trying to get down to the field when the incident happened. According to the indictment, Michael was trying to shove his way on to the field when security personnel informed him that he would have to take another entrance. Apparently, Michael didn't listen to their request and he decided to push through security at the field entrance he wasn't supposed to be using. \nDuring the pushing, a 66-year-old disabled female was injured. The indictment for the case came down on Friday from a Harrison County (Texas) jury. The punishment for the charge carries up to ten years in prison and a $10,000 fine. \nPolice in Harris County have issued a warrant for Bennett's arrest. According to prosecutors in Harris County, authorities are working with Bennett's team in regards to his surrender. The indictment comes less than three weeks after the defensive end was traded from the Seahawks to the Eagles. \nThe incident in Houston was one of two times that Bennett had a brush with the law in 2017. The 32-year-old was also involved in an incident in Las Vegas in August. During that incident, Bennett claimed he was racially profiled by members of the Las Vegas Police Department following a skirmish at a nightclub after the Mayweather-MacGregor fight. After investigating the situation, the LVPD denied Bennett's claims .", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "michael bennett", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "bennett", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "michael", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "martellus", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "eagles", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "patriots", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "cbs", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "falcons", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "khou.com", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "nrg stadium", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "texas", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "new england", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "houston", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T22:10:51.000+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "131312cd3af3f648ede8f1910f95ce39f68428cf", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZRMj_JOvUGZS1xZH3Xpr21YgYJ1Ts.boIN4uLLKitynQLMtGnLjsnXGaKuuPucskti7EqkSMTjWrTAiWYpR_uLq12BocMND.RxvIuo.QB.A1VhK7aFjCTcw9K2FI1gY8OhVIwxSBhfKk2QkfKF_iUwTYL__3DqwkfekP9lYxT_2hrn0HOoFjNf3vM1dmsmxdO4FguXR8ff71xGgZChSOJG8DEptug.mk93dIxdHOfgJkbUwQ32EECKi", "site_full": "edition.cnn.com", "site": "cnn.com", "site_section": "http://rss.cnn.com/rss/cnn_latest.rss", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "CNN.com - CNN", "text": "(CNN) NFL defensive end Michael Bennett was indicted Friday in Houston on a charge of injury to the elderly in connection with an incident that occurred when he was a spectator at the 2017 Super Bowl, authorities said.\nThe Harris County district attorney's office said Bennett rushed the field when the game ended to congratulate his brother Martellus Bennett, who played for the winning New England Patriots. Bennett was told to use a different field entrance, but he pushed through the security detail, which included a 66-year-old paraplegic woman in a wheelchair, Houston Police Chief Art Acevedo said at a news conference. The woman suffered a sprained shoulder in the February 5, 2017, incident, Acevedo said. Seahawks' Michael Bennett: Trump stooped so low with his NFL attacks \"It's offensive to me that a man who's supposed to be an example, a professional athlete, thinks its OK to act like this,\" Acevedo said. Read More Bennett's legal team does not have a comment at this time, Frank Perez, a member of the team, said Friday night. CNN reached out to Bennett for comment through his representative Doug Hendrickson but has not heard back. Harris County said the felony charge carries a penalty of up to 10 years in prison and a $10,000 fine. Bennett was one of the most vocal NFL players in protesting the national anthem before games. He appeared on CNN and said he didn't understand why President Donald Trump would \"stoop so low\" as to say that NFL owners should fire players who protest. Bennett, 32, played with the Seattle Seahawks for five seasons and just signed a contract with the Philadelphia Eagles. He played high school football in Houston and college ball at Texas A&M University. Acevedo said Bennett's lawyer has been notified. The chief said Bennett has not been arrested yet but should turn himself into police as soon as possible. When asked why it took more than a year to file charges against Bennett, Acevedo said police had to prioritize more serious crimes. Also, Hurricane Harvey hit Houston in August, he noted. Acevedo said an officer at the game witnessed Bennett pushing the woman but decided to check on the elderly woman rather than immediately arrest Bennett, whom he recognized. \"We knew who the suspect was,\" Acevedo said. \"We knew what he had done and we knew where to find him.\" The Philadelphia Eagles said in a statement Friday: \"We are aware of the situation involving Michael Bennett and are in the process of gathering more information. Because this is an ongoing legal matter, we will have no further comment at this time.\" Last September, Bennett complained that police in Las Vegas unfairly singled him out, threatened him with a gun and detained him briefly after he attended a prizefight between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Conor McGregor. Las Vegas authorities said officers were responding to a call of battery and assault with a gun that had turned into an active shooter situation and thought that Bennett might be involved. "bennett", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "martellus bennett", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "acevedo", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "trump", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "59c553c211464f82fe43ff7458c2930b9616444b", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZSPfVRrC83GDKJbKDRbkYjxNRdF1HRthPDIPtA9_93AU7QM9q0aXJiUv993fmTs9vEk8p6bKrp3RQ--", "site_full": "www.nytimes.com", "site": "nytimes.com", "site_section": "http://nytimes.com/timeswire/feeds/", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "NYT > Most Recent Headlines", "title": "In Austin, a Bomber\u2019s Rampage Exposes Racial Fault Lines Long Buried", "title_full": "In Austin, a Bomber\u2019s Rampage Exposes Racial Fault Lines Long Buried", "published": "2018-03-23T07:16:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "US", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/03/23/us/23AUSTIN-1/23AUSTIN-1-facebookJumbo.jpg", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 98, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 2267, "comments": 0, "shares": 2267}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "59c553c211464f82fe43ff7458c2930b9616444b", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZSPfVRrC83GDKJbKDRbkYjxNRdF1HRthPDIPtA9_93AU7QM9q0aXJiUv993fmTs9vEk8p6bKrp3RQ--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "MANNY FERNANDEZ and RICHARD FAUSSET", "published": "2018-03-23T07:16:00.000+03:00", "title": "In Austin, a Bomber\u2019s Rampage Exposes Racial Fault Lines Long Buried", "text": " Photo Jesse E. Washington, who lives next door to the scene of the explosion that killed Draylen Mason, an African-American teenager. Mr. Washington said he still wonders if race had something to do with the attack. Credit Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times AUSTIN, Tex. \u2014 Ora Houston, an African-American councilwoman here, stood as a proclamation was read inside City Hall on Thursday.\nIt had nothing to do with the Austin serial bomber, Mark Conditt. It had to do with a deeper, older and far more invisible hurt \u2014 the 90th anniversary of a 1928 city plan that created a \u201cNegro district\u201d on the east side of town.\n\u201cThe Negro district was intentionally created by the Austin City Council to force Negros and Mexicans who lived in other parts of Austin to move to the Negro district,\u201d Mayor Steve Adler said as Ms. Houston, a longtime East Austin resident, looked on at his side. \u201cAnd the effects are apparent in the racial and economic disparities found in East Austin today.\u201d\nThree of the five bombs that terrorized Central Texas this month went off in East Austin, where the majority of the city\u2019s black and Hispanic residents live, prompting the police to investigate them as possible hate crimes. When the fourth bomb was planted in an upscale gated and largely white community west of Interstate 35, the issue of race disappeared from most official statements \u2014 a fact that has stirred deep resentment among many black residents. The only two people killed, many have been quick to point out, came from two of the city\u2019s most prominent black families.\n The debate over how to characterize the bomber\u2019s nearly three-week campaign of violence has been a reminder, for many, of the ways in which race, geography and class continue to play out in a city that prides itself on tolerance and diversity.\n Though Austin is widely seen as a liberal island in a deeply conservative state, the attacks have stoked the raw racial, economic, political and geographical divisions that continue to shape life here, 90 years after the city was segregated by decree. Austin and its suburbs remain sharply divided by class, race and even religion. Like Houston, it is an urban, diverse and Democratic hub surrounded by largely white, Republican suburbs, including Pflugerville, Mr. Conditt\u2019s hometown.\n\u201cAustin has gradually started to become aware and conversant about its race issues over the past five years, so the initial suggestion that these bombings could be race-related made people deeply nervous that the problem could be that bad,\u201d said Cecilia Ball\u00ed, a writer and cultural anthropologist who lived in Austin from 2008 to 2014 and who now lives in Houston. \u201cWhether or not the bomber\u2019s motive ends up being race, this brought to the forefront one of the city\u2019s challenges and worst fears.\u201d\nThe police have said that Mr. Conditt, who is white, gave no indication in a 25-minute confession left on his phone that he was driven by racial hatred. News emerged Thursday that one of the explosive packages he sent at a FedEx store was addressed to a spa employee who is white. His past statements, including the views he expressed on a community college blog opposed to gay marriage, have added to speculation that he was anti-gay.\nIn East Austin on Thursday, Daniel Arriaga, 51, a furniture mover, said he still believed the bomber had a hatred for blacks and Hispanics. He had harmed the two white victims, Mr. Arriaga theorized, \u201cjust to throw it off.\u201d\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists.\nPlease verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.\nInvalid email address. Please re-enter.\nYou must select a newsletter to subscribe to.\nSign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. You are already subscribed to this email. View all New York Times newsletters.\nSee Sample Manage Email Preferences Not you? Privacy Policy Opt out or contact us anytime Alejandro Caceres, 30, an organizer for Grassroots Leadership, a prison reform and immigrant rights group, who lives and works in East Austin, said he believed the police were dismissing the concerns of black and Hispanic residents that the bombings were, at least in part, racially motivated.\n\u201cWe\u2019re being told that all of our feelings and our realities are not true, that this person was not targeting black and brown people, that this person was not a terrorist,\u201d Mr. Caceres said.\nMr. Conditt\u2019s world was, like the Austin region itself, multifaceted and defied easy categorization. In his hometown Pflugerville, about 20 miles northeast of Austin, the mayor, Victor Gonzales, is Hispanic. One of the candidates who ran against him was Philip Emiabata, who was born in Nigeria. One of Mr. Conditt\u2019s roommates was black. And one of his friends was Sierra Davis, a transgender woman and Marine veteran who is part Hispanic.\n \u201cHonestly, Mark was a lot like I was,\u201d said Ms. Davis, 23, who got to know Mr. Conditt when they were teenagers. \u201cHe was a home schooler, Christian, and I was the same. I mean, we were all awkward at the time. Growing up, Pflugerville had a small-town feel to it. It was a lot more conservative than Austin, a lot more home-school friendly.\u201d\nMs. Davis said that Mr. Conditt told her she was \u201cgoing to hell\u201d when she was transitioning. \u201cBut I wasn\u2019t surprised by what he said,\u201d she said. \u201cWe were raised like that and I was tied to those beliefs, too.\u201d\nIn Austin, I-35 has long been recognized as the dividing line separating most of the city\u2019s minority residents from its white population, and much of its have-nots from the haves. That dividing line has an ugly, decades-old history. In an online examination of the city\u2019s racial and economic divide by The Austin American-Statesman, a real estate ad circa 1915 reads: \u201cHyde Park is exclusively for white people.\u201d\nJesse E. Washington, 68, a retired city inspector who is black and was born and raised in Austin, lives in a small ranch house his parents built in the 1960s in East Austin. He graduated from a segregated high school in 1967.\n\u201cIf you wanted to buy a home and own property in Austin, you could only get your utilities turned on if you were in East Austin,\u201d Mr. Washington said.\nNow, of course, East Austin is far different.\n\u201cIf you walk up and down here you see the white kids walking their dogs and riding bicycles,\u201d he said. Many of his black neighbors, he said, \u201chave sold off.\u201d\nPhoto A mural in East Austin depicting influential African-American and Latino icons. Credit Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times Mr. Washington lives next door to the scene of one of the explosions, the one that killed Draylen Mason, 17, an African-American classical musician whose grandfather was a well-known dentist. The blast woke Mr. Washington around 6:45 a.m. that morning. At first he thought it was a falling tree limb.\nMr. Washington listened with interest to the police chief\u2019s description of Mr. Conditt\u2019s confession. But he said he still wonders if race had something to do with it.\n \u201cYou know, the possibilities are endless,\u201d he said. \u201cThese mental conditions that are in our minds growing up, the influences people have from the older generations.\u201d\nBlack leaders and residents have accused the police of failing to take the first bombing seriously because the victim was black, an accusation that police officials have denied. At the time of the first bombing on March 2, the authorities believed it was in retaliation for a drug raid the police had conducted on a similar-looking house on the same street three days beforehand.\n\u201cWe had a pretty strong working theory that day that led us to believe it was an isolated incident that day,\u201d the Austin police chief, Brian Manley, told reporters recently. \u201cIt was very unique. We had no information to believe it was related to a larger plan at that time.\u201d\nThe bombings have come at a critical time for the city\u2019s black population. A 2014 University of Texas report highlighted the drastic decline in the number of black residents in Austin, even as the city has boomed. Austin\u2019s overall population growth rate was more than 20 percent between 2000 and 2010, making it the third-fastest growing city in the country. But the number of African-American residents declined by 5.4 percent \u2014 making it the only one of the 10 fastest-growing cities in the United States to experience a loss in black population.\nIt was the result, the researchers wrote, of \u201cpersistent structural inequalities.\u201d The emerging tech industry was not hiring black and Latino residents. People of color were losing trust in the public schools on the traditionally black east side.\nMs. Houston, the city councilwoman, said she now occasionally feels unwelcome in restaurants in the east side neighborhoods where she grew up, and which are becoming whiter.\n\u201cAs a black female they look at me like, \u2018Why is she here?\u2019\u201d she said.\nRace has played out here in the backdrop of the case in other ways. KVUE, an ABC-affiliated TV station in Austin, issued an apology, after the words \u201cthis monkey\u201d appeared in a sentence about Mr. Mason during its breaking-news coverage of the bombings. KVUE\u2019s closed-captioning provider, VITAC, issued its own apology and said the error was \u201cnot intentional.\u201d\nKVUE said it had severed ties with VITAC \u201cdue to the terrible mistake.\u201d", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "austin", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "cecilia Rebilas-USA TODAY Sports Philadelphia Eagles defensive end Michael Bennett has been indicted for a felony charge of injury of the elderly in Houston\u2019s Harris County, and a warrant is out for his arrest. Bennett allegedly injured a 66-year-old paraplegic who was working at NRG Stadium during Super Bowl LI. The employee was controlling access to the field for the game. The incident allegedly happened after the game, when the Patriots had completed their comeback and won the Super Bowl. Bennett \u2019s brother, Martellus, was a tight end for the Patriots in the game. From the Harris County office of the district attorney : Immediately following the game, Bennett shoved his way on to the field where players were gathering to celebrate. NRG Security personnel, including the 66-year-old disabled victim, told Bennett he had to use a different entrance for field access. Instead, he pushed through them, including the elderly woman who was part of the security team. The charge, injury to the elderly, includes intentionally and knowingly, causing bodily injury to a person 65 years or older. According to the Harris County release, prosecutors are working with Bennett\u2019s counsel regarding his surrender. Bennett was traded from the Seahawks to the Eagles this offseason after spending the past five seasons of his career in Seattle. Next Up In NFL", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "michael bennett", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "bennett", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "martellus", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "sports philadelphia eagles", "sentiment": "negative"}], "locations": [{"name": "nrg stadium", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "harris county", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "houston", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T22:08:44.002+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "d0979ef72b0060c8a09fdd12e8e7127d561d0640", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZR12YKHzHc9uTcNpIrEc8ej61SvcDRgHblAzeyAUr2bUu1ILUd3fG1jtEVuUq5py4PMjWdVRSb86Hq8ar9NQN_lDfOhdrf1VbUTqRmHuGOlyLOvzBkrF9Ys3NPxK8bIQmBlTReMamMa3oQCafuZcaPkZKva.RcBI4A6uMdXiSM5u1KUWnT60SseRsDh13gQ9g460Jmi726MEhQlTZ5MkRJsUSP9tD1r7tm5sMCo59hEaQ--", "site_full": "www.theatlantic.com", "site": "theatlantic.com", "site_section": "http://feeds.feedburner.com/TheAtlantic", "site_categories": ["media", "law_government_and_politics", "politics"], "section_title": "The Atlantic", "title": "H.R. McMaster's Choice - The Atlantic", "title_full": "H.R. McMaster's Choice - The Atlantic", "published": "2018-03-23T15:37:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "US", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2018/03/RTS1H7O8/facebook.jpg?1521805063", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 918, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 2492, "comments": 0, "shares": 2492}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 2}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 33}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "55122b898be08bf9368a07f389fb36424bda13dd", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZR12YKHzHc9uTcNpIrEc8ej61SvcDRgHblAzeyAUr2bUu1ILUd3fG1jtEVuUq5py4PMjWdVRSb86Hq8ar9NQN_lI_CXM9OQJ2U-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Emily Buder", "published": "2018-03-23T15:37:00.000+03:00", "title": "H.R. McMaster's Choice - The Atlantic", "text": "By Eliot A. Cohen The Atlantic Read bio March 24, 2018 Before he was the national-security adviser, he wrote a lacerating account of generals who failed in advising Lyndon Johnson. What will he say now that he is free to talk about Trump? \n\u201cThey have their exits and their entrances,\u201d wrote Shakespeare, and so it is, as we see some actors deliver frantic speeches while others leap, slide, or crawl on and off the foreign-policy stage. \nRex Tillerson said farewell to the Department of State much as he entered it: clueless about government service, clueless about his department, and clueless about his boss. He invoked the clich\u00e9 of Washington as a \u201cmean-spirited town\u201d\u2014as though executive suites in Houston were foreign to nastiness, and as though the capital were demonstrably short of the amiability that characterizes Chicago, Miami, Los Angeles, or Las Vegas. He could not accept the true diagnosis of his failure: that he had chosen to work for an immoral egomaniac who predictably treats his subordinates\u2014and treated him\u2014as shabbily as he has betrayed his wives and allegedly attempted to buy his sex partners. \nAt almost the same moment that Tillerson was delivering his meagerly attended soliloquy, National-Security Adviser H. R. McMaster was similarly given the boot. The world was notified by tweet of his dismissal, but the exchange of compliments between the general and the commander in chief was more civil. Like Tillerson, McMaster had been surprised by his initial job offer; like Tillerson he never established a rapport with the president; like Tillerson he suffered repeated humiliations and put-downs from a boss who shared neither his decency nor his regard for public service. But Trump was a bit more gentle in this case: perhaps because he has a sneaking affection for generals, who are, in his parlance, \u201ckillers.\u201d He may also have reflected that in addition to a moralistic streak, McMaster has a temper and a gift for effective writing. \nTillerson and McMaster were good men who answered an unexpected call to serve. Their motives to do so probably included some admixture of ambition or vanity as well as patriotism. They themselves may not know the proportions of such motivations, human nature being the complex compound of pure and impure impulses that it is. They are being replaced by considerably more canny and political figures, Michael Pompeo and John Bolton, whose policy instincts are more in tune with Trump\u2019s tough-guy swagger, but more importantly who are much more skilled at manipulating the president. Neither McMaster nor Tillerson were cynics, and both were Washington outsiders. To find their successors, the president has turned to a corner of the very swamp he had once promised to drain. A former congressmen and a long time in-and-outer are, after all, creatures from the reeking fens, even if they hail from a distinctively boggy corner of the Washington wetlands. Subscribe   \nThe mix of personalities in high office matters more than ideology, particularly with a president so ignorant and unrooted as this one. Bolton; Pompeo; a weakened and not overly principled chief of staff, John Kelly; and an obsequious vice president, Mike Pence, will collectively tend to facilitate Trump\u2019s more pugnacious foreign-policy inclinations. They will attract a darker, angrier, and more aggressive set of subordinates, together with a larger number of opportunists, and in both categories, mediocrities. Who else, after all, would choose to serve in an administration so chaotic, so badly managed, so besieged with special counsels, weekly sex and expense-account scandals, trade wars, disdainful allies, impending electoral debacles, simmering conflicts with a variety of foreign powers, and, on top of it all, indictments and possibly even impeachment looming in the years ahead? Ultimately, they will probably clash with the one remaining foreign- and security-policy outsider, who is also the administration\u2019s most important moderate, Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis. The new team makes dangerous policymaking even more likely in an already fraught world. \nTillerson will probably retreat to Texas and lick his wounds. He may or may not write a memoir: He does not need the money, and although there are ghost writers aplenty to assist him should he choose to do so, his discomfort with the written word would make for a clunky tale. If he writes a memoir it will probably be an attempt to retell and justify his brief, unhappy time as the country\u2019s chief diplomat rather than to indict the administration. \nMcMaster is a different case, whose choices will be more consequential. He will retire from the Army, a course he would have been well-advised to take before taking office. He is not wealthy; he has strong convictions at odds with those of Trump; he is known for his forceful views of right and wrong; he probably would rather have been a four star. And above all, he has already written one powerful book, and now has the opportunity to write another. \nDereliction of Duty, McMaster\u2019s revised Ph.D. thesis on the Vietnam War, made his literary name, presenting as it did a powerful and well-researched case that the Joint Chiefs of Staff of the mid-1960s failed candidly to present and argue their position to President Lyndon Johnson. It is a good book, although it should be noted that LBJ fully understood that the JCS wanted to do more in Vietnam and faster, but chose not to take that course for a number of reasons. Furthermore it is far from clear that the Chiefs\u2019 preferred approach would have made a useful strategic difference. Indeed, it might well have precipitated a clash with China not all that dissimilar from that of the Korean War. No matter: Dereliction of Duty deservedly made a splash when it came out in 1996. \nThe book was a successful young combat veteran\u2019s expression of righteous anger against superiors of an earlier generation whom he thought had failed to speak truth to power. It became the middle-aged general\u2019s hundred-pound rucksack when, much to his surprise, he was plucked by Donald Trump from imminent retirement to become national-security adviser. It became an implicit measuring rod against which any public official would probably fall short. And when McMaster began publicly to praise the president, to echo his dystopian view of international politics, to cover for his reckless compromises of intelligence material, there was no shortage of commentators keen to pounce. \n]McMaster now has a choice. He can simply remain silent about his time in government and his views of the Trump administration\u2019s methods and policies\u2014highly unlikely given his nature and the financial incentives to speak out. He may, alternatively, choose to make only restrained criticisms in a careful memoir; or he may, in accordance with both his character and temperament, write a volcanic account, perhaps angry and self-justifying, but insightful, blunt, cathartic and even, in some way, redeeming. \nThe national-security adviser had to, or in some cases chose to, say things that his inner nature must have abhorred. As a scholar trained by one of the best military historians in the country, for example, McMaster knows just how rancid a slogan America First is, what dangerous and even vile policy sentiments of 1940 and 1941 it reflected. It will be a hard memoir to write if he confronts that and other facts. Whether he chooses to do so will say something about him, of course, but something too about the readiness of decent and prominent men and women who have served or justified this administration to face the truth. From start to finish, the question about Trump and those who have served, supported, or opposed him has come down to character. McMaster\u2019s memoir, should he write one, will, in many ways illuminate the battering to individual integrity the president has caused. It may also indicate whether the cuts can heal, leaving scars, as one hopes, rather than suppurating wounds. Eliot A. Cohen is the director of the Strategic Studies Program at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies. From 2007 to 2009, he served as counselor to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice. He is the author of The Big Stick: The Limits of Soft Power and the ... NFL.com", "text": "Having Deshaun Watson in the building has not precluded the Houston Texans from exploring any and all options at quarterback.\nHouston hosted Louisville QB Lamar Jackson for a private workout on Wednesday, a source told NFL Network Insider Ian Rapoport. The Texans worked out Jackson solely as a quarterback.\nRapoport added that the Texans want to \"be prepared\" for unforeseen scenarios on draft week, like Jackson being available for them at the 68th pick, Houston's first selection in this year's draft.\nHouston's first- and second-round picks this season were both shipped in separate trades last year to the Cleveland Browns . In return, Houston reaped, among other things, Cleveland's second first-round pick in 2017, which was used to draft Deshaun Watson .\nIn light of Watson's dynamite, albeit abbreviated rookie season, the Texans are not expected to take a starting-caliber quarterback in the 2018 draft, but by working out the dual-threat Jackson, their staff is its their due diligence on one of the draft's top prospects.\nTexans quarterbacks coach Sean Ryan told NFL.com recently that it's \"absolutely\" important for him to get a live look at QBs who haven't worked extensively under center in college, like Jackson, emphasizing the ability to \"see them drop a full drop.\"\n\"You understand that there's still gonna be some work to it,\" Ryan explained. \"But you get enough of a feel for, yeah, we're going to be able to get this done. This guy's going to be able to do this.\"\nIn NFL.com's mock drafts , Bucky Brooks has Jackson going 29th to Houston's rival, the AFC South champion Jacksonville Jaguars; Charles Davis sends the Louisville star to the Los Angeles Chargers at No. 17; and Chad Reuter has Jackson landing with the Arizona Cardinals at No. 15. Reuter does not see the Texans taking a quarterback with their four third- and fourth-round picks.\nLouisville's pro day isn't for another week (March 29). Until then, the Texans , a team already set at the quarterback position for the foreseeable future, will have a head start on the other 31 clubs on evaluating the elusive signal-caller.", USA TODAY SPORTS 1:30 UP NEXT Video by CBS Dallas\nMichael Bennett has been indicted on a felony charge by a grand jury in Houston after he allegedly shoved and injured a 66-year-old paraplegic security guard who blocked his access to the field at the Super Bowl, according to a report from KHOU .\nThis alleged incident occurred at the Super Bowl a year ago, where Michael Bennett was watching his brother Martellus, then a member of the Patriots. KHOU details :\nImmediately following the game, Bennett shoved his way on to the field where players were gathering to celebrate. NRG Security personnel, including the 66-year-old disabled victim, told Bennett he had to use a different entrance for field access.\nInstead, he pushed through them, including the elderly woman who was part of the security team. The charge, injury to the elderly, includes intentionally and knowingly, causing bodily injury to a person 65 years or older. It carries a penalty of up to ten years in prison and a $10,000 fine.\nThere is a warrant out for Bennett's arrest, and from that point on the legal system will play its course.\nGiven that this happened not just in an NFL stadium but at the Super Bowl, one would have to imagine that video could emerge of this.\nThe Philadelphia Eagles recently acquired Bennett in a trade from the Seattle Seahawks, and for now it is too early to tell whether this alleged incident will have any impact on his status.\nMORE:\nInstant Analysis: Hurns signing makes Beasley, Williams Cowboys trade bait\nTill
