"section_title": "RSS :: Diariodenavarra.es", "title": "S&P sube la nota de Espa\u00f1a a notable tras el limitado impacto de Catalu\u00f1a", "title_full": "S&P sube la nota de Espa\u00f1a a notable tras el limitado impacto de Catalu\u00f1a", "published": "2018-03-24T19:42:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 0, "site_type": "news", "country": "ES", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "http://static01.diariodenavarra.es/uploads/imagenes/facebook/2017/04/07/_standardpoorsok_2e41f5a6.jpg?c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c", "performance_score": 0, "domain_rank": 51303, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 0, "comments": 0, "shares": 0}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "db9144f408b15c4a71f125cb8fc0d8725eab96b0", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg_aTMJ8YRt3Vl0hcDhLj0BuJrpVRlp9vxlYZinzBQ1jX_iyjlrsxhTS1Yv7BTDLgkEmulYjk8JGDLIDy9I.vFYz2RYMv3VLxiN86SE3z0B2vfQi9yXDihFcFR5h4yDb.uUj7exsjdl9OVL.gRE5ePnI.Pfb_88urPm01q0d.OYgt7CTD0mukB8A", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-24T19:42:00.000+03:00", "title": "S&P sube la nota de Espa\u00f1a a notable tras el limitado impacto de Catalu\u00f1a", "text": "Deuda S&P sube la nota de Espa\u00f1a a notable tras el limitado impacto de Catalu\u00f1a \nLa agencia constata el efecto limitado que sobre la econom\u00eda espa\u00f1ola han tenido las tensiones pol\u00edticas en Catalu\u00f1a \nLa sede de Standard & Poor's en Manhattan. EFE Actualizada 24/03/2018 a las 17:43 Etiquetas Deuda Efe. Madrid \nLa agencia de calificaci\u00f3n de riesgo Standard & Poor's (S&P) ha elevado este viernes la nota de Espa\u00f1a un escal\u00f3n (desde BBB+ a A-), de aprobado alto a notable bajo, tras constatar el efecto limitado que sobre la econom\u00eda espa\u00f1ola han tenido las tensiones pol\u00edticas en Catalu\u00f1a . Adem\u00e1s, S&P sit\u00faa a Espa\u00f1a en perspectiva positiva, lo que deja la puerta abierta a adicionales subidas de nota en los pr\u00f3ximos 24 meses si Espa\u00f1a avanza a\u00fan m\u00e1s en el proceso de consolidaci\u00f3n fiscal (rebaja del d\u00e9ficit p\u00fablico) y si la incertidumbre asociada a Catalu\u00f1a sigue remitiendo. De esta forma la agencia sigue los pasos de Fitch , que en enero subi\u00f3 tambi\u00e9n la nota a Espa\u00f1a, con lo que fue la primera de las tres grandes agencias que lo hac\u00eda desde 2015. Asimismo, S&P ha elevado su previsi\u00f3n de crecimiento econ\u00f3mico para 2018 al 2,7% frente al 2,6% que calculaba en noviembre pasado, aunque con la perspectiva de que el avance se modere en el horizonte de 2019 a 2021. La agencia explica la subida de nota en la fortaleza de la econom\u00eda, el super\u00e1vit de la balanza por cuenta corriente y en la positiva evoluci\u00f3n del proceso de reducci\u00f3n del d\u00e9ficit p\u00fablico. Como punto menos positivo, S&P incide en que la fragmentaci\u00f3n parlamentaria restringe la capacidad del Gobierno para implementar medidas presupuestarias o reformas estructurales, lo que se constata en el retraso que llevan los presupuestos generales del Estado para 2018. Al respecto, no descarta la posibilidad de un adelanto electoral, aunque tampoco cree que se puedan llegar a revertir las reformas llevadas a cabo en los \u00faltimos a\u00f1os. Entre los desaf\u00edos pol\u00edticos m\u00e1s recientes a los que se enfrenta el Gobierno , la agencia destaca las demandas de los pensionistas y de buena parte de la oposici\u00f3n para que las pensiones suban en l\u00ednea con los precios, en lugar del m\u00ednimo del 0,25% establecido por ley. El informe se\u00f1ala que la demanda interna seguir\u00e1 siendo la principal locomotora de la econom\u00eda, con la expectativa de que el consumo privado siga creciendo gracias al mantenimiento de la generaci\u00f3n de empleo. La agencia prev\u00e9 tambi\u00e9n un aumento de la inversi\u00f3n, as\u00ed como una recuperaci\u00f3n del sector de la construcci\u00f3n y la vivienda. Adem\u00e1s, espera que el sector exterior se siga beneficiando de su fuerte competitividad y del aumento de su cuota en el mercado global, aunque alerta del riesgo de un aumento global del proteccionismo y del encarecimiento del petr\u00f3leo. De la tasa de paro dice que sigue siendo la segunda m\u00e1s alta de la UE , a pesar de estar muy lejos del m\u00e1ximo alcanzado a principios de 2013, en tanto que prev\u00e9 que en 2018 se siga reduciendo hasta el 15,6%. La agencia avisa de que la perspectiva podr\u00eda bajar a estable si el crecimiento de la econom\u00eda es m\u00e1s d\u00e9bil de lo esperado, si la deuda p\u00fablica sobrepasa el 100 % del PIB -aunque calcula que ir\u00e1 reduci\u00e9ndose hasta el 86 % del PIB en 2021- o si se deteriora el super\u00e1vit de la balanza por cuenta corriente. Tambi\u00e9n, si una escalada de las tensiones en Catalu\u00f1a lastra la inversi\u00f3n y la confianza empresarial. Sobre Catalu\u00f1a, a\u00f1ade que de momento la incertidumbre persiste a la espera de ver la direcci\u00f3n que toma el pr\u00f3ximo gobierno auton\u00f3mico que todav\u00eda no se ha formado. Dinero", "title": "S&P eleva el rating de Espa\u00f1a a 'A-' con perspectiva positiva", "title_full": "S&P eleva el rating de Espa\u00f1a a 'A-' con perspectiva positiva", "published": "2018-03-24T01:14:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 0, "site_type": "news", "country": "ES", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "", "performance_score": 0, "domain_rank": 50684, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 0, "comments": 0, "shares": 0}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "8bacd7fa4333c0d9239c68d6c263176d5d80b753", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg9i4PIlUgiHD49UyOC7Y52vd_kwBoJtQlZmhZKmX1FD4XjFVQ.CyTPDxUPVQ7FiR1kioy6WEB11N_DEcm3I9_Lr9IgS0u6JxI5rLbEMZzqRahsXnGGIU8Xc", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-24T01:14:00.000+03:00", "title": "S&P eleva el rating de Espa\u00f1a a 'A-' con perspectiva positiva", "text": "S&P eleva el rating de Espa\u00f1a a 'A-' con perspectiva positiva   MADRID La agencia de calificaci\u00f3n crediticia S&P Global Ratings ha mejorado en un escal\u00f3n la nota de solvencia de la deuda soberana a largo plazo de Espa\u00f1a, que sube as\u00ed hasta 'A-' desde 'BBB+', su nivel m\u00e1s alto desde abril de 2012, seg\u00fan ha informado la calificadora de riesgos, que asigna una perspectiva positiva al rating espa\u00f1ol. Compartir Men\u00e9ame \nEn su an\u00e1lisis, la agencia se\u00f1ala que ni la evoluci\u00f3n econ\u00f3mica ni presupuestaria de Espa\u00f1a se ha visto obstaculizada por las tensiones en Catalu\u00f1a y ha expresado su confianza en que el PIB de Espa\u00f1a crecer\u00e1 \"m\u00e1s r\u00e1pido\" que la media de la eurozona entre 2018 y 2021, permitiendo la continuada reducci\u00f3n del d\u00e9ficit. \nS&P se\u00f1ala que la perspectiva positiva del rating supone que podr\u00eda mejorar la calificaci\u00f3n espa\u00f1ola en el curso de los pr\u00f3ximos 24 meses si el Gobierno logra una mayor consolidaci\u00f3n de las cuentas p\u00fablicas de lo que espera actualmente. Asimismo, la agencia prestar\u00e1 atenci\u00f3n a la influencia de la pol\u00edtica monetaria del BCE en las condiciones de cr\u00e9dito del pa\u00eds, as\u00ed como a la evoluci\u00f3n de la banca espa\u00f1ola y apunta que \"una relajaci\u00f3n adicional de las tensiones en Catalu\u00f1a tambi\u00e9n respaldar\u00eda una mejora\" . \nREACCI\u00d3N DEL GOBIERNO \nTras conocerse la decisi\u00f3n de la agencia, el ministro de Econom\u00eda, Industria y Competitividad, Rom\u00e1n Escolano, ha destacado que la subida del rating por parte de S&P, s\u00f3lo dos meses despu\u00e9s de la de Fitch, confirma la confianza en Espa\u00f1a de los mercados y las agencias de calificaci\u00f3n crediticia. \"Es un reconocimiento, adem\u00e1s, del esfuerzo reformista en distintos \u00e1mbitos llevado a cabo por el Gobierno y la sociedad durante los \u00faltimos seis a\u00f1os. Nuestra econom\u00eda se sustenta en un crecimiento robusto, con fuerte creaci\u00f3n de empleo y reducci\u00f3n del d\u00e9ficit p\u00fablico\", indic\u00f3 el ministro, se\u00f1alando que \"S&P pone a Espa\u00f1a en perspectiva positiva, lo que nos permite augurar nuevas subidas en el futuro\". \n\"La agencia considera que las tensiones pol\u00edticas en Catalu\u00f1a han tenido un efecto limitado sobre la econom\u00eda espa\u00f1ola, gracias a la confianza institucional que introdujo la aplicaci\u00f3n del art\u00edculo 155 de la Constituci\u00f3n. Esto ha permitido que Espa\u00f1a haya registrado un crecimiento superior al 3% en 2017 por tercer a\u00f1o consecutivo. Adem\u00e1s, la tendencia positiva con la que hemos entrado en el presente ejercicio nos va a permitir revisar al alza las perspectivas de crecimiento incluidas en el cuadro macroecon\u00f3mico que se presentar\u00e1 el pr\u00f3ximo martes?\", a\u00f1adi\u00f3. \nDe este modo, el ministro ha considerado que la decisi\u00f3n de S&P contribuir\u00e1 a diversificar y ampliar la base inversora del Tesoro P\u00fablico, as\u00ed como a reducir a\u00fan m\u00e1s los costes de financiaci\u00f3n del Tesoro, de la econom\u00eda y, en particular, de las Pymes. KD, Bos Abu Tours \nTRIBUN-TIMUR.COM - Selamat pagi selamat beraktivitas semoga hari ini menyenangkan bersama seluruh keluarga dan sahabat. \nEditor tribun-timur.com kembali menghadirkan rangkuman berita terpopuler satu hari sebelumnya. \nBarangkali pembaca melewatkan karena kesibukan atau hal lain. \nBerikut rangkuman berita terpopuler kemarin, Sabtu (24/3/2018): \nBikin Merinding! 7 Foto Pemilik Abu Tours Ini Mirip dengan Bos First Travel yang Ditahan Polisi \nSetelah sebelumnya heboh di Indonesia kabar penipuan jamaah umrah dan haji oleh perusahaan biro perjalanan First Travel, kini kasus serupa juga terjadi di Makassar. \nPendiri sekaligus CEO Abu Tours Travel Hamzah mamba alias Abu Hamzah ditetapkan sebagai tersangka kasus penipuan ibadah umrah Jumat (23/3/2018). \nHal ini diungkapkan Kabid Humas Polda Sulsel saat menggelar jumpa pers. \nHamzah Mamba disangka telah merugikan puluhan ribu jamaah dengan total kerugian mencapai Rp 1,4 triliun. \nPenetapan tersangka ini "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Emily Heward", "published": "2018-03-23T19:24:00.000+03:00", "title": "This new Manchester restaurant is a cheese-lover's dream", "text": "Get What's On     \nServing chips, cheese and gravy was always going to be a winner in Manchester. \nSo when Brewski opened in Chorlton serving Canadian speciality poutine - French fries piled with squeaky cheese curds and drizzled with gravy - it was an instant hit. \nThe Wilbraham Road bar has been such a success that owners have now opened a second site in the city centre - and it's even more of a cheese-lover's dream. \nThe new Mosley Street site features an expanded menu including raclette - a giant wheel of molten Swiss cheese, brought out to your table and scraped on to dishes including Brewksi's signature poutine and mac'n'cheese creations. Brewski's raclette (Image: Manchester Evening News) \nHead chef Eduardo de Pe\u00f1a said: \"We've served a good few of them already. People love it being served at the table. When it goes out everyone stops and looks. It's got a great wow factor.\" \nThe Alpine speciality can be added to any dish on the menu for an extra \u00a32.50, including a giant new meat platter piled high with fried chicken, seared steak, pulled pork and sausage patties. Read More Manchester pub Bay Horse Tavern launches bottomless brunch Sean Hansford | Brewski's meat tower (Image: Manchester Evening News) \nCatering to the office crowds nearby, Brewski Manchester will also serve deli sandwiches stuffed with buffalo chicken, Philly cheese steak or a daily changing selection of roasted carvery meats, to eat in or take away. \n\"A bit of an untapped market in this area is lunches,\" said Eduardo. \n\"We've adapted the menu to fit working lunches and we're focusing on good quality produce served hot and fast. \n\"All our chefs are proper chefs and a lot of us are from a fine dining background, we're not your average lunch gaff. Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Manchester United FC   Thank you for subscribing!   \nThere were boos at what Manchester United supporters once dubbed the Boo Camp on Friday night. Sergio Romero, Matteo Darmian and Marcos Rojo remained sat on the bench but it is safe to assume the jeers were in response to another unused substitute. Thousands of supporters had bought tickets on the strength of the promo pictures of Lionel Messi, back in town for the first time in 18 months, but Argentina coach Jorge Sampaoli deprived many of a once in a lifetime opportunity. \nFriday night's meeting between the four-time and double World Cup winners still featured ample Premier League interest. Seven Argentinians and three Italians play in England, Nicolas Otamendi was starting in his own back yard, Angel di Maria was back in Manchester and there was also the odd transfer angle for those in the press box. \nNapoli's Brazil-born Azzurri midfielder Jorginho is interesting Liverpool and United, who view Jorginho as a potential replacement for Michael Carrick. It was another Italian midfielder who Mancunians marvelled at on their international evening. Twenty-three minutes in, Marco Verratti, collected the ball in line with his own six-yard box, danced past one Argentinian, then another and then one of his own teammates before he emerged from the Italian area. It was the closest fans got to seeing Messi. Read More United player ratings of the season so far \nThree years ago, Gary Neville awoke after watching Paris Saint-Germain eliminate Chelsea from the Champions League and succinctly said: \"Morning. Verratti - what a player! Thanks.\" \nMourinho will remember that night vividly. PSG's resolute performance is one of the standout 10-man showings in recent memory and Verratti's formidable 82-minute display should encourage United to touch base. \"Verratti bossed the midfield,\" Sky Sports pundit Thierry Henry opined. \nUnited's Mino Raiola stable has halved in the last two months and he represents Verratti, whose Instagram post last summer excited gullible United supporters still celebrating the Romelu Lukaku coup. Verratti apologised for his previous agent Donato di Campli's behaviour and his change of representative in the transfer window was enough to make the player go viral. Or the agent, in Raiola's case. Verratti started for Italy with Jorginho \nRaiola trended on Twitter rather than Verratti and there are not many better holding players in world football than PSG's dynamic Italian. Verratti was never considered by United last summer as Mourinho focused on Premier League pedigree in Nemanja Matic or Eric Dier but the circumstances have changed. \nZlatan Ibrahimovic, Paul Pogba and Romelu Lukaku were all advised to join United over other clubs by their Italian-born agent and Raiola reputedly threw a chair in frustration during negotiations with Borussia Dortmund over Henrikh Mkhitaryan. \nThe furthest PSG have progressed in the Champions League under their Qatari-ownership is the quarter-finals and they reached that stage back in 2013. If ever, or whenever, they do lift the European Champion Clubs' Cup it will be a hollow, petrodollar achievement and the suspicion is some are getting impatient. Read More Two United players send a message to Jose Mourinho \nVerratti was petulantly sent off in their limp defeat to Real Madrid earlier this month and must be the most coveted of the 'old guard'. Verratti is one of three players listed in the quarter-final matchday squad against Barcelona still at the Parc des Princes. \nThis is the 25-year-old's sixth season in Paris and summer after summer he tops rival supporters' midfield wish-lists. If United are to sign an Italian midfielder to complement Matic and Paul Pogba then it should be Verratti rather than Jorginho, who has only hovered onto elite European clubs' radar in the current campaign. \nSigning Verratti would be another statement signing by United but a team focused one. After pipping Chelsea to Romelu Lukaku and using Real Madrid like pawns as Alvaro Morata was left by the road side, Verratti appeals as Barcelona barely conceal their desire to sign him. \nHe would also sell tickets. \nGet all the latest Manchester United news first with our new app. Download it here now. Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email \nA man was dragged out his car before being brutally attacked with a hammer after getting off a tram. \nPolice were called to Derker Metrolink stop in Oldham on Thursday night. \nA man, in his 40s, got off a tram from Manchester at around 7.30pm. \nHe walked to the tram stop car park, on Cromford Street, before being jumped by a group of men. \nThey dragged him from his Vauxhall Corsa and attacked him with a hammer. \nPolice said some of the men drove off in the victim\u2019s car. Others fled in two other vehicles, one of which was stolen. \nThe victim suffered serious head injuries and was taken to hospital, where he is currently awaiting surgery. Read More \nGMP said the other vehicles involved were a blue Fiat Panda, which was reported stolen following a robbery at a supermarket car park on March 18, and a Ford Fiesta. \nAll three vehicles were found on Langham Road in Chadderton. \nOfficers want to speak to seven people in connection with the attack. The men are described as Asian males, aged in their late teens to early 20s. \nThey were all dressed in all black clothing, possibly tracksuits. \nOfficers are not treating the attack as linked to any other incidents but are \u2018keeping an open mind about the full circumstances\u2019. \nDetective Chief Inspector Jim Faulkner said: \u201cFortunately, we\u2019ve been able to recover the three vehicles so officers from our forensic teams will be working quickly to gather as much evidence as possible from them but we need any witnesses to contact us urgently. Read More Pensioner in three-car collision died after falling ill at wheel \n\u201cAs there were a number of cars in the area, I\u2019m sure that someone must have dashcam footage or have seen something that would help us with our investigation. \n\u201cI cannot stress the importance of contacting us with information that could prove vital in catching the people that are responsible for leaving a man with severe head injuries so please, make sure you make that call. \n\u201cWe are putting additional resources into the area over the coming days and I would urge people to speak to those officers about any concerns or with details of anything they have seen.\u201d \nAnyone with information is asked to call police on 101, or 0161 856 8538, quoting reference number 1863 of March 22. Reports can also be made via Crimestoppers, anonymously, on 0800 555 111. Mourinho watches Scott McTominay Jose Mourinho did not stray too far from Manchester during the international fixtures on Friday night as he watched a Man Utd player. Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Manchester United FC   Thank you for subscribing!   \nManchester United manager Jose Mourinho watched Scott McTominay make his international debut for Scotland on Friday night. \nMcTominay started in the Scotland midfield at Hampden Park, where they were beaten 1-0 by 2014 World Cup quarter-finalists Costa Rica in coach Alex McLeish's comeback match. \nUnited academy graduate McTominay wore the number seven shirt and lasted 58 minutes in the 32-ranked side's latest defeat. \nMourinho has repeatedly raved about McTominay, who made his United debut in May last year and started in the recent games against Sevilla, Chelsea and Liverpool. The 21-year-old signed a new contract in October and has played 18 times this term. \nEven after his 'worst performance' against Brighton in the FA Cup quarter-final last week, McTominay was praised by Mourinho. \n\"You have the kid that didn't play well at all and I told him already,\" Mourinho said. \"Was the one I first spoke individually with in the dressing room, and instead of being critical with him I was positive with him. Because you play very bad but did the basic things that a player has to do and one of the basic things is to keep emotional balance. A fan asks Mourinho for a selfie \n\"To play with that red shirt - which is a heavy one, is a heavy shirt to wear - and the kid in his worst performance by far, he was there. He was not afraid to play, he played bad and every player can play bad. \n\"Scott played on his [Matic's] side, Scott played the worst match since he played with me in the first-team, but he is a Manchester United player for sure, because he's the player that made mistakes, passed the ball so bad tonight, lost so many passes. \n\"But big personality to cope with a mistake, big personality to say and to think I am not playing well but at least I will do the basic things of the game, which is to keep position, give balance to the team, recover balls, don't make defensive mistakes. But a few of the other guys were scared to play.\" Read More United might have already found their next number 10 \nMourinho has previously flown to Croatia, Austria and Sweden during international fortnights over the last year to watch prospective signings. The United manager flew to Croatia last year amid interest in winger Ivan Perisic and reportedly watched Red Bull Leipzig's Emil Forsberg play for Sweden against Italy in November. \nThe Portuguese watched Austria beat Serbia in an October World Cup qualifier that Nemanja Matic scored in. Midfielder Sergej Milinkovic-Savic, who has been heavily linked with United, was not included in the Serbia squad. \nGet all the latest Manchester United news first with our new app. Download it here now. Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email \nA teenage girl fought leukaemia with \u2018strength and determination\u2019 but her life was \u2018tragically cut short\u2019 after the disease returned for a second time, an inquest heard. \nMaizy Burke, from Audenshaw in Tameside , was 14 years old when she passed away in January 2017. \nDuring an inquest into her death in Manchester on Thursday, her family said they felt \u2018robbed\u2019 of time with Maizy as they were unaware of how ill she was in the hours before her passing. \nFighting back tears from the witness box, mother Mechelle told the coroner: \u201cIf I thought she was going to die I would have let her have her last few hours with her brother and sister. She was there one minute and the next minute she was gone.\u201d \nSpeaking after the hearing, Mechelle said Maizy \u2018was just our everything\u2019. Maizy with mum Mechelle and nana Jean \nThe youngster first contracted the form of blood cancer in August 2012 when she was aged just 10, it was heard. \nShe was diagnosed after she complained of pain in her legs as she ran for the bus. \nAfter \u2018gruelling\u2019 chemotherapy and several years of follow-up treatment she was given the all-clear in January 2015. \nHowever, in December 2016, Maizy and her family got the devastating news that the disease had returned after she complained of feeling tired. Routine tests showed abnormalities in her blood. \nJust a month later she died after suddenly deteriorating whilst undergoing more chemotherapy in the Royal Manchester Children\u2019s hospital (RMCH), an inquest heard. \nShe suffered a second and fatal cardiac arrest after developing sepsis as a result of her illness, the hearing was told. Read More Maizy was granted her birthday wish to ride in a pink limousine \nCoroner Angharad Davies described her as a \u2018delightful young woman whose life was tragically cut short after she had shown such strength and determination in fighting back\u2019. \nDuring the inquest, the family questioned if the E-coli infection she was suffering from could have been spotted, and treated earlier, for example being moved onto the paediatric intensive care unit sooner than she was. Maizy Burke, 14, died following a battle with cancer in January 2017. (Image: Steve Marsland) \nAn internal investigation by the hospital trust into Maizy\u2019s death was carried out and consultant Dr Denise Bonny, who oversaw it, said the stretched resources and busy wards did sometimes impact on communication with patients\u2019 families. \nHowever, she said she believed \u2018all the right things were done at the right time\u2019 in respect of her treatment. \nMaizy has acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, a rare form of cancer of the white blood cells which prevents the body fighting off other infections and viruses. \nAssistant coroner Angharad Davies ruled the decisions made by all the doctors and nurses caring for her were \u2018appropriate\u2019 given the information available to them. Maizy Burke celebrating her 14th birthday with friends \nRecording a conclusion Maizy died of natural causes Ms Davies said: \u201cMaizy\u2019s family have raised a number of issues that have caused them concern. \n\u201cIt seems to me the staff caring for Maizy had complex decisions to make and it was a balancing act. \n\u201cAnd I don\u2019t find any of those decisions were inappropriate. \n\u201cThere is no evidence earlier treatment would have changed or delayed the outcome for Maizy. \n\u201cYou have my very deepest sympathies about her death but also the devastating impact the circumstances, the fact she deteriorated so quickly, have had on you.\u201d Read More Primary school children paid an amazing tribute to former pupil Maizy Burke \nSpeaking after the hearing, Maizy\u2019s mum Mechelle, 49, said the entire family\u2019s world had been turned upside down. \nShe said: \u201cShe was just our everything. She loved singing, dancing. She was so popular, had so many friends. \n\u201cIt\u2019s just a cruel disease. But just the day before she died she was sat up and talking to everyone. \n\u201cThat\u2019s the bit, especially her brother and sister, are struggling to come to terms with. \n\u201cI never thought she would die. She was so strong. \n\u201cWe\u2019re just devastated. Even now it doesn\u2019t feel real.\u201d \nGot a story or an issue you want us to investigate? Himself", "text": "\u200b Three-Champions League winner Gerard Pique has admitted that his career would have been vastly different had he not joined Manchester United as a 17-year-old, revealing that he learned a lot under Sir Alex Ferguson.\nBarcelona and the club's famed La Masia academy was all Pique had ever known before he made the switch to Manchester in 2004. By his own admission in a post for The Players' Tribune, he was 'almost f*cked' because he was so green and sheltered.\n\"I look back on the last 10 years of my career, and I've won the World Cup, the Champions League, \u200bLa Liga , Copa del Rey\u2026I've won it all, as I like to remind my Madrid friends on WhatsApp ,\" he said.\n\"But 10 years ago, I was almost f*cked. My whole life could have turned out very different if it wasn't for Sir Alex Ferguson.\n\"I arrived at \u200bManchester United a boy, and I left a man. It was a crazy time for me, because I had never been away from home before. I spent my first 17 years growing up in Spain in \u200bBarcelona 's youth academy, and it almost felt like I was playing for the local school team or something. I knew everybody there, and I was close to my family.\n\"To me, football was just fun. I didn't understand the business side of the game at all. Then I arrived at United, and honestly, it was a complete shock.\"\nHaving never played for the Bar\u00e7a first-team before he left home, Pique took his first steps in professional football at United, making his debut against lower league Crewe Alexandra in the League Cup and playing three times by the end of the 2004/05 season.\nPique returned to Spain on loan to play for Real Zaragoza in 2006/07, before playing 13 times as United completed a \u200bPremier League and Champions League double in 2007/08.\n\"Sir Alex was phenomenal to me from the very first day,\" he recalled.\n\"The best managers all have this quality - even when they're not playing you, and even when they're hard on you - they make you believe that they really care about you. Sir Alex was like a second father to me. He made me earn it, but eventually he gave me my chance.\"\nThe standards at United were incredibly high and it wasn't just Ferguson who upheld them, as Pique found out when, at the age of 18, he was berated by Roy Keane when his phone had rung in the dressing room before one of his very first games at Old Trafford.\n\"I was nervous as hell. Imagine it - I'm 18 years old, and I'm sitting in that little dressing room putting on my socks next to Ruud van Nistelrooy and Ryan Giggs and Rio Ferdinand. I wanted to be invisible. I was thinking, Just do your job and go unnoticed,\" Pique said.\n\"We're sitting there waiting for the gaffer to come in and speak to us, and I'm literally sitting right next to Roy Keane. The dressing room is so small that our legs are almost touching. There's no space at all. It's dead quiet. All of a sudden, you could hear this little vibration.\n\"I realise it's my phone. I left it on vibrate, and it's in the pocket of my pants, stuffed in the clothes bag that's hanging right behind Roy's head.\n\"Roy can't find where the noise is coming from. Now he's looking around the room like a maniac. His eyes are darting everywhere, and he's trying to figure it out. He looked like Jack Nicholson in The Shining, when he bursts through the door.\n\"He screams out to everybody, 'Whose phone is that?!' Silence. He asks again. Silence. He asks a third time. 'Whose. Bloody. F*cking. Phone. Is. That?!'\n\"Finally, I spoke up, like a little boy. Very softly, I said, 'I'm so sorry. It's mine. Roy lost his mind! He went nuts in front of everybody! It was incredible. I almost sh*t myself. But it was a good lesson.\n\"Now, in 2018, everything is different. All these kids are on their iPhones before the matches. But back then it was a different world. You didn't do that. Especially not at United. Not in Roy's dressing room. It was one of a thousand mistakes that I made when I was at United.\"", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": "author": "Paul Britton", "published": "2018-03-23T21:45:00.000+03:00", "title": "What the huge new transport plan means for you", "text": "News What the huge new transport plan means for you Metrolink services every six minutes on popular routes, 27 new trams, and \u00a3160m being invested in the region\u2019s cycling and walking infrastructures are part of the plans Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email \nA six minute service could be introduced on more Metrolink lines - and more double trams will be put on to deal with jam-packed rush hour carriages. \nGreater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham has announced that 27 new trams will be added to the network in the next two years, boosting capacity by 25 per cent. \nIt will mean nearly 5,000 extra seats for passengers - and more double trams. \nAll lines currently run a 12-minute service. Where multiple services run along the same line, frequency is around six minutes between relevant stops. \nAt peak times, there is a six-minute service between Manchester and Bury; Manchester and Altrincham ; on the Eccles line as far as MediaCityUK; on the East Didsbury line; and from Rochdale via the Oldham line as far as Shaw and Crompton. (Image: Manchester Evening News) \nTransport bosses say the new trams - which will cost \u00a380m - will primarily be used to boost capacity when the network is at its busiest. \nThere is the potential this summer for current stock to extend the MediaCityUK to Etihad Stadium service to Ashton, providing a six-minute service on the Ashton line. \nThe extra trams are part of a huge \u00a3240m plan to cut congestion in Greater Manchester. \nMr Burnham hailed the investment as a \u2018major increase in capacity\u2019 and said extra security across the tram network would also be addressed, alongside \u2018more regular and frequent\u2019 services. Read More Greater Manchester to get 27 more trams and new 'pre-peak' Metrolink tickets as part of \u2018Congestion Deal\u2019 \nHe said the government has proposed giving Transport for Greater Manchester (TfGM) powers to issue civil injunction orders banning troublemakers from the network - and said 50 extra PCSOs are due to start work on public transport networks, specifically the Metrolink, by the end of April. \nAn extra \u00a3160m is also being invested in the region\u2019s cycling and walking infrastructures. \nIn the largest public transport investment announcement in years, Mr Burnham also asked the public to do their bit to tackle congestion, in what he called a \u2018deal\u2019 with commuters. Andy Burnham (Image: Manchester Evening News) \nOutlining a range of new ideas and funding plans Mr Burnham said he wanted to \u2018unlock the potential for thousands of people to move around by cycling or walking without reliance on private car use\u2019. \nHe told the M.E.N.: \u201cPeople have experienced growing levels of congestion. There is nothing we can do to wave a magic wand. \n\u201cIt is a difficult issue but there are some things that we can do. We are setting out a new approach, one which is based on a deal with the public. \n\u201cThere are things that we can put in place, but they are intended to create incentives to change what people do - to move away from the car.\u201d \nThe money is coming from the Transforming Cities Fund, announced by the government last November. \nAll regions with a city mayor were told they would get cash. Greater Manchester has now been told what the money can be spent on. \nExact details are still being worked out and the plans are due to go before the region\u2019s combined authority next week. \nBut car sharing, the possible creation of a \u2018high occupancy vehicle lane\u2019 pilot scheme, giving priority to cars with three or more passengers on some of the busiest roads, are included. \nBusiness are also being urged to do their bit. Mr Burnham vowed to work with firms to encourage flexible working hours and starting times to stagger traditional rush hours and reduce bottlenecks. \nHe said a \u2018new package of incentives\u2019 would be explored, including offering workers at companies who sign up \u2018early bird\u2019 Metrolink discounts. No prices have been confirmed. Read More Manchester Airport to invest 'six-figure sum' in public transport links \nA group Metrolink discount could also be offered to firms that agree to implement flexible working. \nEx-Olympian Chris Boardman, the region\u2019s cycling and walking Tsar, would get a budget of \u00a350m a year from 2019/20 for three years to create a \u2018world class\u2019 cycling infrastructure for Greater Manchester, the mayor said. One idea is dedicated safe cycling routes to schools. \nOn Twitter Mr Boardman said: \u201cWe aren\u2019t just going to \u2018build infrastructure\u2019. We are going to build space people want to be in. Travel can be an enjoyable part of the day. We have forgotten that.\u201d (Image: MEN Media) \nThe investment covers \u2018walking infrastructure\u2019 and Mr Burnham said it could mean road lay-out changes, pavement alterations and new design strategies to boost pedestrian safety. \nA Manchester-wide scheme to improve junctions, tackle bottlenecks, build new roads and roll out \u2018smart\u2019 traffic signals is also planned, alongside reducing the impact of roadworks through better control, coordination and information. \nA 24/7 transport control centre would also be developed, to keep passengers up to date minute-by-minute across all forms of public transport, alongside a dedicated management team to govern and monitor some of Greater Manchester\u2019s busiest routes. ABS-CBN News", "published": "2018-03-24T03:39:00.000+03:00", "title": "Why urban planner opposes casino-resort in Boracay", "text": "Why urban planner opposes casino-resort in Boracay Arianne Merez, ABS-CBN News Posted at Mar 24 2018 04:39 PM \nShare Facebook Boracay island. Nony Basco, ABS-CBN News/file photo \nMANILA- Architect and urban planner Felino \"Jun\" Palafox on Saturday criticized the plan to build a casino-resort in Boracay island amid government's efforts to rehabilitate the top tourist destination. \nPalafox said construction should not be allowed on Boracay's white-sand beaches since it will damage the quality of the sand. \n\"It might be the wrong land use at the wrong place at the wrong time on a personal basis and a professional basis,\" Palafox told ANC. Watch more in iWantv or TFC.tv \nThe Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corp recently granted a \"provisional license\" to Macau casino giant Galaxy Entertainment and its Filipino partner, Leisure and Resorts World Corp, to build a 23-hectare casino-resort worth $500 million on the island. Palace defends $500-M casino-resort plan in Boracay \nBoracay tourism stakeholders have also expressed dismay over the planned casino construction. \nBoracay Foundation board member Connie Helgen said the island, known for its picturesque waters and sunsets, should not be marketed as a gambling destination. \n\"Boracay island is for beach lovers. Boracay is a wholesome destination. Why go to Boracay to play casino? There are so many casinos in Manila and in Macau,\" Helgen said. \nThe government has tapped Palafox's team to help rehabilitate Boracay during the planned shutdown of the island. \nPalafox is proposing a rehabilitation plan which features more eco-friendly structures. \nIf he was to have his way, Palafox said it might be better to build the casino on the mainland in the town of Malay in Aklan. \nThe veteran architect also agreed that there should be a limit to the number of tourists allowed in Boracay. \n\"So many plans have been done in Boracay but the institutions are not in place and there is issue of governance in all hierarchy of government,\" he said. \nThree government agencies have recommended the closure of Boracay island to tourists starting April 26 to give way to rehabilitation efforts. \nThe cleanup comes after President Rodrigo Duterte's criticism of the tourist destination's environmental woes. Well, one, because this writer loves going to comic conventions when time permits and loves anything involving superheroes. Another reason is that it\u2019s raking in a lot of controversy from netizens, and the event is already happening tomorrow until Sunday.\nWe\u2019re not saying that it\u2019s ultimately a bad event that everyone should boycott altogether. People might still have fun with the activities, find something cool at the booths, and even meet their favorite celebrities. At the same time, you just can\u2019t ignore the ire of people who were either inconvenienced by the event or just observant netizens airing out their concerns. So allow us to break down some of them.\nManny Pacquiao as event ambassador Sen. Manny Pacquiao makes strong pitch as patron of Comicon Asia in Manila on March 2018, showcasing the best in cosplay, gaming, comics, movies, anime and toys. | via @mariovdumaual pic.twitter.com/hzHe55Qnik\n\u2014 ABS-CBN News Channel (@ANCALERTS) January 17, 2018\nWhen ComicCon Asia was revealed last year, they named Sen. Manny Pacquiao as one of their main ambassadors . Apparently because he starred as a superhero that one time in 2009\u2019s Wapakman. Although he isn\u2019t sponsoring the event, the organizers still expressed that his presence will be \u201cinstrumental in presenting the Philippines to foreign exhibitors and investors as \u2018[the] destination of choice for international conventions.'\u201d\nStill, this announcement struck a nerve to many people because of Pacquiao\u2019s views on same-sex marriage , among other issues. One of them was comics artist Gerry Alinguilan, who canceled his appearance at the convention because of the senator\u2019s involvement. \u201cI cannot forget the statements made by Manny Pacquiao in the past. He called same sex couples worse than animals. Worse, in a now deleted Instagram post, he posted Bible Quote: s that preach that gays should be put to death. As someone who believes in equality for all, I find these statements reprehensible and dangerous. Dangerous because Manny Pacquiao is in a position of political power that would enable him to make his personal beliefs a matter of national policy. That is something I cannot abide,\u201d he said in his blog .\nA questionable copyright clause and here's the fucked up part: they're holding a contest called project x where participants submit ideas for new pinoy superheroes. the catch? oh they just get perpetual rights to the winner's creation which THEY can profit off of and the winners won't be able to sue them for it pic.twitter.com/NitzFGQLz7\n\u2014 \ud835\udcb6\ud835\udcbe\ud835\udcc1\ud835\udcc1\ud835\udcb6\ud835\udcbd | the evil is defeated (@thranduilien) January 15, 2018\nComicCon Asia is holding a contest called \u201c Project X ,\u201d which encourages Filipinos to create original superheroes. According to the Terms and Conditions, all copyright goes to the participant. But the catch is that the organizers will also get the rights to use the character for reproduction and distribution, and they can profit from the creation. Although they will properly credit the participant, people still find it a bit sketchy that the organizers will get money out of someone else\u2019s original work.\nHayley Atwell\u2019s cancellation A post shared by Hayley Atwell (@wellhayley) on Mar 22, 2018 at 7:51am PDT\nAgent Carter star Hayley Atwell recently called off her appearance at the convention , but the reasons were conflicting. The initial statement that ComicCon Asia released said that she canceled due to the \u201cpolitical unrest\u201d in the country. However, Hayley clarified that it was not her words and that the real reason was her work schedule. The same reason she gave when she turned down AsiaPOP Comicon Manila in 2016 .\nBecause of this, people are asking why ComicCon Asia made the assumption and why they made it political. Most especially after presidential spokesperson Harry Roque said that it was \u201cher loss\u201d for canceling and that there\u2019s no political unrest here. (Let\u2019s be real: there is .) As of writing, there\u2019s still no statement from the organizers regarding the issue.\nFranco Mabanta is one of the hosts Shame for organizers of ComicCon Asia for choosing Manny Pacquiao, a known bigot and DDS Senator, as the event\u2019s ambassador. And also Franco Mabanta, a BBM/DDS propagandist, as emcee?!\nCome on guys, you can do better!\n\u2014 Ted Pylon (@TedPylon) March 22, 2018\nSome netizens aren\u2019t happy about Franco Mabanta\u2019s presence, mostly because of the contents of his Facebook page . Another reason we\u2019re putting out there is that he made fun of the #MeToo movement and called Jover Laurio of Pinoy Ako Blog an \u201cOgre Lady.\u201d So we\u2019re giving a thumbs down for this part.\nProblems with refunds\nDue to the cancellations of Stan Lee and Hayley Atwell, several fans asked for refunds. Yesterday, ComicCon Asia released instructions that all refunds can be claimed on March 24 and 25, from 1 p.m. to 6 p.m. This raised a few concerns like if they\u2019re giving back the payment in cash or check. Those who won\u2019t attend the event also asked if there\u2019s another option.\nMeanwhile, many aren\u2019t pleased that it took ComicCon Asia a week to address the Stan Lee refunds. ( He canceled on March 16 .) Fans said that they were told by a certain \u201cAnthony\u201d that their refunds will deposited to their bank accounts. They said that they\u2019ve given their details but nothing has happened. (To be honest, it\u2019s also very sketchy that they asked for personal bank details.)\nWhat do you think? Are you still going to ComicCon Asia or are you rethinking it? "author": "Jessica Fenol, ABS-CBN News", "published": "2018-03-22T04:09:00.000+02:00", "title": "16,000 liposuctions later, Belo still finds joy sculpting sexy bodies", "text": "16,000 liposuctions later, Belo still finds joy sculpting sexy bodies Jessica Fenol, ABS-CBN News Posted at Mar 23 2018 06:09 AM \nShare Facebook Beauty doctor to the stars Vicki Belo is shown in one of her clinics after an interview with ABS-CBN News. Jonathan Cellona, ABS-CBN News \nMANILA - Nearly three decades and some 16,000 liposuction procedures later, beauty doctor to the stars Vicki Belo said she still gets excited drawing fat from clients to reveal a sexier and more confident frame, drawing from her own struggles with insecurity. \nLiposuction is still one of the most popular treatments at Belo Medical Group, where 30 percent involve going under the knife and 70 percent are non-surgical. By her own account, Belo said she spent 45,000 hours doing liposuction. \n\"My tip is always find what you love to do, so you don\u2019t feel you\u2019re working. Like ako, I get excited pa rin to do a liposuction. If it makes you a happier person, then I\u2019ve done my calling. It\u2019s a vocation,\" Belo told ABS-CBN News. \nBelo credits late 90s bombshell Rosanna Roces for destroying taboos over liposuction. The sex symbol turned liposuction into a status symbol, she said. \n\"Rosanna Roces was my turning point when you ask when did you become more popular,\" Belo said. \n\"She went on TV and she\u2019s so maingay. 'Nagpa-lipo ako kay Dra Belo, sosyal 'yan at mayaman. Ako kasi nakapunta ako dyan,'\" she said. \n(She went on TV and she's so loud that 'I had lipo with Dr Belo, who is a rich socialite. I go to her.') Beauty doctor to the stars Vicki Belo is shown in one of her clinics on the sidelines of an interview with ABS-CBN News. Jonathan Cellona, ABS-CBN News \nINSPIRATION \nBullied as a child for being fat and adopted, Belo said she channeled such insecurities into building her business, which now has 13 branches. \n\"Other kids would ask 'Why did they give you away, because you\u2019re fat?'. Then other kids would say \u2018No, she\u2019s not fat, she\u2019s just ugly'. They would do that to me and I would cry,\" Belo told ABS CBN News. \n\"So the message that came to me was 'Ah ganon pala \u2018yon' (that's how it is), if you\u2019re fat and you\u2019re ugly they give you away,'\" she said. \nShe said she struggled with acne from when she was 11 until she reached 26, even during medical school. \n\"Sabi ko, 'pretty girls don\u2019t know what it feels like, eh ako I have suffered all my life,' so I have empathy and I really want to be the best anti-acne doctor in the world,\" she said. \nBelo counts singer Regine Velasquez as one of her earlier clients, whose back acne problem she cured. How Belo beauty empire started with Regine Velasquez, pimple fight \n\"If somebody tells me not to do it, then the more I want to do it. So if somebody said 'You can\u2019t be a derma because your skin is bad.' I\u2019ll say 'No, I can!',\" she said. \nA constant figure in society pages, Belo got married late last year to fellow doctor Hayden Kho in opulent style in Paris. \nThe couple's 3-year-old daughter, Scarlet Snow, is an Instagram celebrity. Belo's eldest daughter, Cristalle Belo-Pitt, helps run the family enterprise. \nShare", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": There were feelings between the two of us,\" she said.\nThe pair met in 2006, shortly after Trump's wife Melania gave birth to their son Baron.\nTrump only mentioned Melania once, and \"obviously, 0, "author": "Clare Byrne, Agence France-Presse", "published": "2018-03-22T19:43:00.000+02:00", "title": "U.N. expert 'at grave risk' in Philippines", "text": "U.N. expert 'at grave risk' in Philippines Clare Byrne, Agence France-Presse Posted at Mar 23 2018 09:43 PM \nShare Facebook Victoria Tauli-Corpuz, the U.N. special rapporteur on the rights of indigenous peoples \nVicky Tauli-Corpuz has spent four decades campaigning for indigenous people in her native Philippines, but never feared for her life. That changed last month when she was branded a \"terrorist\" by President Rodrigo Duterte's government. \nThe special advisor to the United Nations on indigenous rights since 2014 was among 600 people accused of terrorism over their alleged links to Maoist rebels in a government document filed in a Manila court in February. \nThe activist, who had condemned alleged rights abuses in the southern Mindanao region where the state is battling an Islamic insurgency and leftist guerrillas, denies the allegations and says she feels like a marked woman. \n\"This is like a target list basically,\" the slightly built, bespectacled 65-year-old from the Kankanaey Igorot ethnic group said in an interview at the UN cultural body UNESCO in Paris. \nWhile waiting to see if the state brings charges, she said she has decided to stay out of the Philippines on the advice of her lawyers. \nTauli-Corpuz is one of several left-wing activists accused by Duterte's government of links to the Maoist rebels with whom he broke off talks last year, after initially saying he would \"walk the extra mile\" for peace. \nDuterte blamed the rebels, whose insurgency has claimed an estimated 30,000 lives since 1969, for ongoing attacks on the security forces. \n'Virtual hit list' \nIn its court petition, the justice department asked for the Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) and its armed wing, the New People's Army (NPA), to be declared \"terrorist organisations\". \nAttached to the submission, seen by AFP, were 600 names of suspected rebels, including Tauli-Corpuz and two other prominent indigenous leaders -- Joan Carling and Jose Molintas -- who have previously advised the United Nations. \nThe targeting of the trio came after Duterte last year accused indigenous Lumad schools of grooming children to become insurgents and threatened to bomb them. \nReacting to the case, U.N. rights chief Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein said it was \"unacceptable for a special rapporteur acting on behalf of the international community whose expertise is sought by the (U.N.) Human Rights Council to be treated in this way\". \nNew York-based Human Rights Watch said those on the \"virtual government hit list\" were \"at grave risk\". \nTauli-Corpuz, who began campaigning for indigenous rights in her native Cordillera region during the dictatorship of Ferdinand Marcos, compared the government list to the lists of suspects used to prosecute Duterte's deadly anti-drugs war. \nPhilippine police say they have killed more than 4,000 drug suspects who resisted arrest, but rights groups estimate there have been more than three times that, including people murdered by vigilante groups. \n\"The president has his police and his death squads who can easily kill people whom they accuse of being terrorists,\" Tauli-Corpuz said. \n'Embarrassing the government' \nThe activist who helped draft the seminal 2007 U.N. Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples said she believed she was targeted over her condemnation in December of alleged rights abuses in the southern region of Mindanao, where Duterte is battling pro-Islamic State gunmen. \n\"They (indigenous people) are being displaced, they are being killed, their lands are being taken over, so I made a statement which came out in the newspapers and the government immediately came out and said I was embarrassing the government internationally,\" she said. \nPhilippine Foreign Affairs Secretary Alan Peter Cayetano has insisted there is evidence linking Tauli-Corpuz to the rebels and said she and others on the list \"should see this as an opportunity to clear their names\". \nDuterte, who enjoys wide popularity despite his rights record, has repeatedly lashed out at his domestic and foreign critics. \nLast week, he announced he was pulling the Philippines out of the International Criminal Court, which is examining his crackdown on drugs. \nHe also recently vowed not to cooperate with the UN special rapporteur on extra-judicial killings, Agnes Callamard. \n\"You're investigating us, fact finding? Well sorry, do not f*** with me,\" he said, in remarks aimed at Callamard. \nShare ", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": Garcia", "published": "2018-03-22T03:55:00.000+02:00", "title": "New eats: Tagaytay favorite Bawai's opens branch in Taguig", "text": "Bawai's Vietnamese spread. Photo by author MANILA -- Bawai's Vietnamese Kitchen is one of the most loved restaurants in Tagaytay. People line up just to have their fill of authentic Vietnamese food. And since it's only open from Thursday to Sunday, days when Tagaytay is brimming with tourists, diners find it difficult to get a table.\nFortunately, guests who come all the way from Manila, don't need to travel to Tagaytay to satisfy their Bawai's food cravings. Because unknown to a lot of the restaurant's loyal patrons, it actually opened a branch at the ground floor of Uptown Parade in Taguig last year.\n\u201cPeople are surprised we have a branch in BGC,\u201d shared Bawai's owner Virgilio \u201cVer\u201d Tatlonghari.\nThe interiors of Bawai's at Uptown Parade. Photo by author The Tatlonghari family partnered with businessman Anderson Hao, his wife Rhea, and their business partners to open a branch in one of the metro's central business districts. They did not do a formal media launch back then that's why diners were unaware of the new location.\nApart from the branches in Tagaytay and Taguig, Bawai's is also in Nuvali in Sta. Rosa in Laguna, and another one along Katipunan Ave. in Quezon City.\nThis family business is going big, planning to branch out to other areas in Metro Manila. And this success all started from humble beginnings.\nVer Tatlonghari and wife My or more fondly called \u201cBawai Dung\u201d started the restaurant in 2007 after friends and family gave them an idea to offer their home-cooked meals to the public. Bawai Dung is from Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam and even formally studied Vietnamese cooking in 2006.\n(From left) Anderson Hao and wife Rhea, Bawai Dung and Ver Tatlonghari. Photo by author \"Bawai\" translates to grandmother and the restaurant was named after the family's matriarch because all the recipes come from her.\n\u201cAfter I finished my formal Vietnamese culinary education, I was ready to share my personal recipes. We sought help of our neighbors and their families, trained them to be our cooks, servers, and staff. Then, we opened Bawai's Vietnamese Kitchen right in our home in Tagaytay in 2007,\u201d Bawai Dung recalled.\nIt was a small operation back then. The couple converted part of their home into a small restaurant with 36 seats, serving lunch and dinner from Friday to Sunday. Soon, the news spread around Tagaytay about this small restaurant that serves delicious authentic Vietnamese cuisine. Then people, from tourists to politicians, started flocking to the Vietnamese eatery.\nToday, the Tagaytay restaurant expanded its business, opening more tables in the garden area to accommodate more guest and including Thursdays in their weekly operations. The whole family is now involved in the growing business including the couple's five children.\nThe Uptown branch has a seating capacity of 50 guests. It has modern and simple interior with a striking Vietnamese mural on one wall.\nPho Bo or traditional Vietnamese beef noodle soup. Photo by author The menu is the same as the original restaurant. To keep everything authentic, the ingredients are mostly sourced from suppliers in Tagaytay and Vietnam as well. Most sauces, noodles, and other specialty ingredients must be sourced from Vietnam.\n\u201cOur chef here actually trained for six months in Tagaytay before we opened,\u201d Anderson Hao explained.\nGoi Cuon or fresh spring rolls. Photo by author Must-tries are the classic Vietnamese dishes like the Goi Cuon or fresh spring rolls (vermicelli noodles, vegetables, pork, and shrimp wrapped in thin rice paper wrapper and served with peanut sauce), Banh Mi or Vietnamese sandwich, and Pho Bo or traditional Vietnamese beef noodle soup.\nCa Phe Sua Da or iced milk coffee. Photo by author They also serve Ca Phe Sua Nuong and Ca Phe Sua Da or Vietnamese hot and iced coffee. These drinks uses Vietnamese coffee and condensed milk.\nBut probably the restaurant's best dishes come from the entree menu. The Curry Ga or chicken curry is the Vietnamese version of the classic Indian dish. It has a more subtle curry flavor and perfectly seasoned with traditional spices.\nTom Rang Me or black tiger prawns in sweet tamarind paste. Photo by author The Tom Rang Me on the other hand, is pan-cooked black tiger prawns served with a flavorful sweet tamarind paste.\nThe Bo Kho is a beef stew like no other. The restaurant uses top round cut, 12 different spices, potatoes, and carrots. The stew is cooked for eight hours until the meat is fork tender and the sauce has a rich and robust flavor.\nBo Kho or Vietnamese beef stew. Photo by author The best part of dining at Bawai's is you are treated as family.\n\u201cWe treat our customers not only as guests but as honorary members of our own family. After all, they are dining in our own home. Every dish is prepared with love,\u201d Bawai Dung said.\nShare\nSave Facebook Share on Twitter GPlus", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": Capricornia", "published": "2018-03-24T06:29:00.000+03:00", "title": "Powerlifter Odell Manuel smashes record after suffering horrific injury - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)", "text": "Odell Manuel was Australia's strongest man until he suffered a horrific quadricep injury that put him out of action for two years. \nThat may have been the end for most people. \nBut the central Queenslander reclaimed his title when he dipped his toe back into competition at ProRaw, one of Australia's biggest powerlifting competitions last weekend, and smashed the Australian all-time powerlifting record. \n\"She proved to be pretty good on the day,\" said Mr Manuel, who lifted a total of 1,090kg, breaking the previous record by 12.5kg at the Melbourne competition. \n\"We were going in there to get 1,080kg. The ultimate would have been to get 1,100kg, but it didn't happen.\" \nHe also broke the squat record of 435kg with his 440kg squat and broke his own deadlift record of 400kg with a 405kg lift, and bench-pressed 245kg. \nMr Manuel was Australia's powerlifting champion for five years in a row until he attended a meet-and-greet in Western Australia. \n\"I just had to tell them my story and they wanted to watch me train, and I was supposed to do just a few squats.\" External Link: Powerlifting FB \nHe made it to 340kg when disaster struck and he ruptured the tendon in his quadricep. \n\"It was more embarrassing because I was trying to teach people how to squat and I fell on my face.\" \nMr Manuel underwent surgery as soon as he returned to his hometown of Rockhampton, and the long road to recovery began. \n\"The doctor told me it was going to take 18 months and I laughed at him, because normally I recover from injuries quite well, even the major ones. \n\"But this time I think he was right.\" Mental scars \nIt took Mr Manuel a year to get back on track physically, but the mental scars have taken a lot longer to heal. \n\"Even when I did that 440kg swat on the weekend and I was in the hole, I was thinking about it, which you shouldn't when you're doing that. \n\"I was thinking, 'Geez, please don't blow,' and I pushed it up and it was good.\" \nHe was worried even when walking up and down stairs that he could have another rupture. \nThis didn't stop Mr Manuel from training, and even three months after his operation he was back into doing what he describes as \"reasonable\" weights. \n\"Not heavy, but enough to scare the doctors, but I didn't tell them what I was doing.\" \nHe took it day by day, week by week, and within a year he started to get better and made the decision to begin extremely heavy weights \u2014 400kg plus. \nWhile recovering, Mr Manuel had his title and record snatched away by Alex Simon, who lifted 1,077.5kg. \nSo when the ProRaw competition approached this year, it was time to dip his toe back into competition waters. \n\"Originally the goal was just to get back on the platform,\" he said. \n\"But as we started prepping, I realised it's starting to come back again, so I had the goal on the record to take a number one spot.\" \nThe aim was to get 1,080kg and reclaim the number one spot, and he did. The physical toll \nPowerlifting does take its toll, and this is not the first time Mr Manuel has been injured. \nThree years ago, he tore the tendon from his bicep during a deadlift and it cost him that particular competition. \n\"I tried to keep going but I could feel my bicep up around my shoulder and I thought, 'Nah, I'd better drop it'.\" \n\"That's the only time I've lost.\" Photo: Odell Manuel was quietly confident a week before the competition, but he didn't want to talk too much in case he jinxed it. (ABC Capricornia: Inga St\u00fcnzner) \nIt also puts pressure on the joints, and this is even more of an issue considering Mr Manuel has osteoarthritis. \nThis condition is why he ended an NRL career that saw him play for the Warriors, NZ Maori and the Canberra Raiders. \n\"It does get painful at times, but as long as you're taking your fish oils and joint formulas and all that, and that's why we use wraps. \n\"Even though it doesn't stop the joint from clinging together, I think with the wraps it helps me too. \n\"Sometimes it gets sore. I get weeks where I can't walk.\" Driving force \nConsidering powerlifting has caused more injuries than league, what drives Mr Manuel? \n\"I think this is a calling for me. \n\"I believe I was born to lift.\" \nAlthough he played in the NRL, Mr Manuel said he was not a natural player and had to work hard. \n\"When it came to lifting, that was different and later on I knew if I pursued it, I would not be too bad at it.\" \nThe focus now is on the biggest powerlifting competition in the country, the international Big Dog, in October. \n\"If we can get 1,100kg there, that will be really good. \n\"Who knows, we might get more \u2014 but we don't want to get ahead of ourselves.\"", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZSJlbPFf2vcZQ7DQwnenE_nlWi4Rzc5PX8gpmmzuUspasen91xWHKKTvubt_wrhibkpR2YsZFctenlEsZRu5z.1le10WPwickeoHIPoOFBalTYss8GTn89E", "site_full": "www.theguardian.com", "site": fight AFL decision | Sport", "title_full": "Katie Brennan turns to Human Rights Commission to fight AFL decision | Sport | The Guardian", "published": "2018-03-23T07:56:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": "https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/77cc26d0fc8b0f9e8d935a3663c1b1f09d59c578/0_87_3000_1801/master/3000.jpg?w=1200&amp;h=630&amp;q=55&amp;auto=format&amp;usm=12&amp;fit=crop&amp;crop=faces%2Centropy&amp;bm=normal&amp;ba=bottom%2Cleft&amp;blend64=aHR0cHM6Ly91cGxvYWRzLmd1aW0uY28udWsvMjAxOC8wMS8zMS9mYWNlYm9va19kZWZhdWx0LnBuZw&amp;s=730e8e474ae77278de3a98fc2e3e40ba", "theguardian.com", "published": "2018-03-23T07:56:00.000+03:00", "title": "Katie Brennan turns to Human Rights Commission to fight AFL decision | Sport", "text": "T he dramatic build up to this weekend\u2019s AFLW grand final escalated further on the eve of the game with Western Bulldogs captain Katie Brennan announcing she will lodge a formal sex discrimination complaint against the AFL with the Australian Human Rights Commission. It\u2019s a savvy legal move that will compel the AFL to completely rethink its approach to sanctioning women.\n\nAFLW grand final 2018: Lions out to capitalise on Brennan absence Read more \nBrennan\u2019s two-game ban raised immediate allegations of sex-based discrimination . The reason was simple: were Brennan were a man, she would have been asked to pay a fine, instead of being suspended. The sole reason women do not get the option of paying a fine is wage disparity (the average wage for a men\u2019s AFL player is $371,000, whereas AFLW rookies receive just $10,500). Rather than opting to have the women pay smaller fines on a pro rata basis, the AFL went with a different system that results in them being sanctioned more severely.\nThere has been an explosion of public interest in the case this week. There have also been many misconceptions about the relationship between elite sporting competitions and the law. Although sporting competitions are entitled to develop their own rules, those rules must comply with overarching legal obligations. In Australia this includes the Federal Sex Discrimination Act, which prevents discrimination against people on the basis of their sex, except in very specific circumstances.\nBrennan twice appealed the suspension. Surprisingly, her legal team didn\u2019t pursue this line of argument at the first hearing. At the second hearing , she did, represented by a team of lawyers including Jack Rush QC and Bulldogs president, Peter Gordon. The AFL argued that Brennan\u2019s legal team should have raised those arguments the first time around, were barred from raising entirely new arguments the second time around, and were simply trying to have a second bite at the cherry. Disappointingly, the appeals board deliberated for just 15 minutes, gave no reasons for its decision, and dismissed the appeal. The failure to provide an explanation for its decision raised even more legal questions, including the possibility that this was itself a denial of a fundamental legal principle \u2013 that of procedural fairness. \nKatie Brennan falls victim to gender pay gap with AFLW grand final ban | Kate O'Halloran Read more \nAll eyes were on the Bulldogs\u2019 next move. Gordon is a renowned litigator who rarely shies away from a fight and as social media exploded with speculation, a #FreeKatieBrennan movement was launched, including a petition . There was growing recognition that Brennan was a victim of circumstance, and an imperfect system which yielded a result only made possible because there are different \u2013 and more severe \u2013 rules for women.\nOn Friday morning, the Dogs announced that they would not seek an injunction in the supreme or federal court. But then came the kicker. In an unexpected move, the club announced that Brennan is lodging a complaint with the Australian Human Rights Commission, alleging that the suspension was unlawful on human rights grounds.\nThe Commission will not deal with the case before the grand final this weekend. Brennan will not play. But the lodging of a human rights complaint is a strategic masterstroke that forces the AFL into an impossible position. Here\u2019s why: the Commission is an independent third party, whose job is to investigate human rights complaints and to help parties resolve their disputes. The Commission will ask the AFL to consider the specifics of Brennan\u2019s complaint, before overseeing a conciliation. There, Brennan will sit down with the AFL to air her concerns and the Commission will try to help them both come to a resolution.\nBrennan will almost certainly demand three things from the AFL: that they admit the tribunal system unfairly discriminates against women; that they overhaul the system so that the rules are fair and no other woman will be put in Brennan\u2019s position again; and finally, that her suspension be wiped from the historic record, as a matter of principle.\nIf the AFL does not accede, Brennan can go to the federal court and seek a hearing. The AFL will be taking a huge risk if it allows things to go that far. It cannot afford a formal court hearing where such arguments are thrashed out by teams of lawyers, with QCs getting paid hourly rates comparable to an entire season\u2019s wage for many of the women. \nBrennan grand final suspension shows AFLW needs stand-alone tribunal Read more \nIt would be a public relations disaster for the AFL, and generate significant bad blood with players and fans, including the new audience it has found through the AFLW. Most of all, the AFL cannot afford to risk the chance of a formal federal court finding that its fledgling AFLW competition \u2013 a pillar of its putative commitment to gender equality and equal opportunity for women \u2013 is inherently discriminatory. It would be a disastrous result for CEO Gil McLachlan, and one that he will be desperate to avoid.\nFor this reason, it\u2019s almost certain that the AFL will capitulate at the first hurdle, and accede to some \u2013 and perhaps all \u2013 of Brennan\u2019s demands at conciliation. The AFL will be asked to admit that its system \u2013 while well-intentioned \u2013 wasn\u2019t perfect and produced a perverse result that has left Brennan on the wrong side of history. Her move is a hugely significant one, not just for current AFLW footballers, but for future generations of girls and women who will play the game. A star on the field, Brennan has now laid down a huge challenge to the code off it. The ball is now in the AFL\u2019s court. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTopics AFLW Australian rules football Australia sport comment", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", \nDashcam video shows the motorists meeting on a narrow road in Toorak but sparks fly when neither agree to move out of the way. \nThe male driver filming the encounter can be heard expressing his frustration moments before the woman exits her car. \n\u201cYou\u2019re holding up the whole road,\u201d he tells the woman as she makes her way to his window. Not backing down. Source: Sunrise The unimpressed woman exited her vehicle to make emphasise her point. Source: DashCam Owners Australia \n\u201cYou are a bully and a nasty, typical man! I have the right of way,\u201d she replies. \n\u201cI came in the street first so you give way to me,\u201d she yells at him. \nAs more traffic began to form behind the man, the woman eventually returns to her car and pulls to the side of the road but their feud is now dividing the internet as to who is at fault. \n\u201cLooks like the guy with the dash cam was going faster than 40km/h as the street was marked plus didn\u2019t slow down when the road work guys were working,\u201d one woman wrote in response to the vision. \n\"The lady should\u2019ve gone thru since she was already there. The man is stubborn and arrogant,\u201d another added. The stand-off eventually came to an end when she returned to her vehicle and pulled over. Source: DashCam Owners Australia \nOthers sided with the male driver, saying they thought the woman deliberately moved forward to block his path. \n\u201cThe woman could of had the common courtesy of pulling to the side for a second to let him through,\u201d one woman replied. \nHowever the majority of viewers suggested both drivers had ample opportunity to pull over prior to the stand-off. \n\u201cNeither has \u2018right of way\u2019 but the situation demonstrates that chivalry & manners are fading from our society,\u201d one woman added. \n\u201cA little bit of courtesy and respect go a long way. Unfortunately it\u2019s something greatly lacking on Australian roads,\u201d another added. ", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "dashcam", "sentiment": "negative"}], "organizations": [{"name": "dashcam owners australia", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "melbourne", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T00:14:30.013+02:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "e024adae70ae3bfcdc18e1b3b98ef9af4df4c733", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg80.l2Zef1N_T6zeCFQfEmRi7zMxr5z2i9gneyY9.UEfMorBpZE45y28xD6XB_deQS9mIkw5lUogczB1muPxLuHZ8x7MpTuF04dMks1PbTMua0gTg2hzHK7P.micu1cjboxCMY9Z3TF6A--", "site_full": "www.abc.net.au", "site": "abc.net.au", "site_section": "", "site_categories": ["music", "entertainment"], "section_title": "", "title": "Vikings: Beyond the Legend at Melbourne Museum reveals truth about Scandinavian raiders - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)", "title_full": "Vikings: Beyond the Legend at Melbourne Museum reveals truth about Scandinavian raiders - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)", "published": "2018-03-22T22:48:00.000+02:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 0, "site_type": "news", "country": "AU", "spam_score": 0.002, "main_image": "http://www.abc.net.au/news/image/9578526-16x9-700x394.jpg", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 1455, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 3291, "comments": 0, "shares": 3291}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 2}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "e024adae70ae3bfcdc18e1b3b98ef9af4df4c733", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg80.l2Zef1N_T6zeCFQfEmRi7zMxr5z2i9gneyY9.UEfMorBpZE45y28xD6XB_deQS9mIkw5lUogczB1muPxLuHZ8x7MpTuF04dMks1PbTMua0gTg2hzHK7P.micu1cjboxCMY9Z3TF6A--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Joanna Crothers", "published": "2018-03-22T22:48:00.000+02:00", "title": "Vikings: Beyond the Legend at Melbourne Museum reveals truth about Scandinavian raiders - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)", "text": "Map: Melbourne 3000 \nThe word \"Viking\" has long conjured images of big burly men who wore helmets with horns and travelled the seas violently stealing land and fighting in wars. \nPopular culture has reinforced these stereotypes but new artefacts on display at the Melbourne Museum's latest exhibition Vikings: Beyond the Legend have debunked some common myths. \nLead Vikings experts Lena Hejll and Katherine Hauptman from the Swedish History Museum in Stockholm have curated almost 500 artefacts that show Vikings lived a more complex life between 750 and 1100 AD. \nThey were farmers, artists, traded goods and were even rich aristocrats. No horned helmets \nMs Hejll said it was believed German composer Richard Wagner was partly responsible for the myth of the horned helmet. \nIn one of Wagner's Operas, his dressmaker wanted to emphasise the evil characters and used the symbol of horns to help the audience understand who was good, and who was bad. \nOther European artists also added horns to helmets to make their paintings more dramatic. A Viking isn't a type of person \nMs Hejll said a Viking was actually something you do. \n\"They were not an ethnic group or anything. You were not a Viking. You went on Viking. That was something you did,\" she said. \n\"A person could be a Viking in part of their life but most people and most of your life, you were farmers.\" \nMs Hejll said the long journeys they embarked on could often last four years. \nThe word has now been adopted to refer to the Scandinavian people living at that time. They were smart \nMs Hejll said that when going on a Viking, the men and women did not have any navigation instruments. \nThey often travelled to the same places several times. \n\"Imagine that you set off from the Norwegian coast for example to Iceland and Greenland,\" she said. \n\"How did they know they would land there the second time? \n\"They were skilled sailors, they were skilled navigators. They could read the nature, the currents, the birds, the stars, the winds.\" \nIntricately-made jewellery, artworks and clothing are on display throughout the exhibition, showing they were more than barbaric warriors. Being clean was important \nIf you search for images of Vikings, you'll get a lot of scruffy looking characters from the television series. Photo: It turns out combs were a must-have accessory for men and women. (ABC News: Joanna Crothers) \nArtefacts like washbasins, combs, ear spoons and tweezers actually suggest a lot of pride was taken in their appearance, according Ms Hejll. \n\"Everyone had a comb and I think you have that for a reason \u2014 to make your hair look good.You dyed your yarnto have colours in your home and on your clothes,\" she said. \nAristocrats also woredelicate brooches and jewellery as a sign of their wealth. \nClothes were also important for showing people which region you came from, as Vikings were centred around family. \n\"You would be buried with your personal belongings, and your own traditional dress,\" Ms Hauptman said. \n\"They had heavy brooches and the shape of the brooch tells people which region you're from.\" Women were powerful \nWhen a woman's husband was away on a Viking, a key that hung from her belt was a symbol to everyone that she was the lady of the house. \nWhen a woman's husband went on a Viking to trade, find new land or take part in wars, the woman looked after the farm and were responsible for all the people working on it. Photo: A bronze key with an animal depicted in the middle of the handle. (Supplied: Museums Victoria) \nIn rich families, a bronze key hung off the woman's belt and was buried with her when she died. \nAt the launch of the exhibition Ms Hejll and Ms Hauptman said they hoped it would show people the Viking Age has a rich history of culture, trade and exploration. \nDespite some facts getting in the way of how we've pictured Vikings, Ms Hejll said mystery still remains and there's always more to discover. \n\"We found crystal magnifying glasses,\" she said. \n\"Maybe they used it for their intricate sewing and artwork. But it's one thing we don't know. We don't know everything.\" \nThe Vikings: Beyond the Legend exhibition runs at the Melbourne Museum until August 26.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "AU", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "http://www.abc.net.au/news/image/9575888-16x9-700x394.jpg", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 1455, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 3435, "comments": 0,
