"ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-22T23:00:00.000+02:00", "title": "Death To Nuggets group targets unhealthy kids' menus", "text": "When Melbourne father of three Jonathan Pangu dines out with his family, he is often disappointed in the kids' menu. \n\"You can predict the menu before you've even seen it,\" he said. \n\"It is nuggets and chips, and the usual suspects of spag bol and fish and chips. \n\"It's all very beige ... it's all pretty boring.\" \nThe sameness of these menus prompted Mr Pangu to start Death To Nuggets, a campaign for better children's food in restaurants and cafes. \n\"I just saw that no-one had really given it any thought since the 1970s, which is amazing in a town like Melbourne where so much energy, talent and passion goes into our food,\" he told ABC Radio Melbourne 's Hilary Harper. \n\"We've got to this lowest-common-denominator approach where as long as the kids just sit and eat quietly, we're happy.\" \nBut Mr Pangu is not happy. \nHe said kids' menus could and should play a role in encouraging healthier eating in children. \n\"When you look at the stats around food \u2014 rising levels of obesity, diet-related health problems \u2014 you see that we need to do something different.\" Photo: Death To Nuggets holds dining events for children and their parents. (Supplied: Andy Diprose) Will reverse fish and chips do the trick? \nDeath To Nuggets works with interested cafes and restaurants to improve their children's menus andalso promotes establishments that serve healthy food to kids. \nIt also leads by example, holding regular events where children aged five to 13 are presented with exciting, healthy meals. \nThe menus for the events are filled with playful dishes such as \"reverse fish and chips\". \n\"The chips look like fish and the fish look like chips,\" Mr Pangu said. \n\"A little bit of fun and imagination goes a long way \u2014 an interesting name, something a little bit daft.\" \nThe dishes are designed to tempt even the fussiest eaters. \n\"We've done a grazing plate in the past [where] there's loads of different things to pick at; if they don't like one thing they'll move onto another,\" Mr Pangu said. \nHe said such dishes took the pressure off children and allowed them to enjoy eating. \nIt was an approach parents could also take when preparing meals at home, he said. \n\"We're role models ... The behaviour that we exhibit rubs off on the kids. \n\"Making time to eat, eating together, all of these things are kind of important.\" We're supposed to limit our sugar to six teaspoons a day, but do you know how much of it is hiding in some of our most popular groceries? Colour and variety is key \nDietician Nicole Dynan said that when at home, young children should be eating the same meal as the rest of the family. \nShe said she would like to see restaurants make kids' menus more like the ones for adults. \n\"If there was some sort of pasta dish for the adults, it would be nice to have a modified version of that [for children],\" she said. \nMs Dynan said the secret to feeding children was colour and variety, and by thinking creatively it was even possible to get children to eat salad. \n\"They love things like iceberg lettuce, cucumber, carrots.\" \nShe said there was no reason for a restaurant to serve a processed chicken nugget when they could serve real chicken instead. \nMr Pangu said he called his initiative Death To Nuggets because they \"were a good symbol of everything that's going wrong with the food that we're eating\". \n\"Most factory-made nuggets are 30 per cent chicken. What's the rest of it? You probably don't want to know.\" Photo: Thinking creatively can help get children eating. (Supplied: USDA) Creative challenge for chefs \nMr Pangu said he wanted to inspire chefs to put as much thought and creativity into kids' food as they did into adult's meals. \n\"Chefs and restaurants have had such an impact on our adult culture, done loads of interesting things \u2014 I think they can have a positive impact here too.\" \nWhile accepting that chefs were \"super busy and stretched\", Mr Pangu said there were ways to incorporate better kids' food into the menu without placing an extra burden on the kitchen. \n\"Some of the cafes we've worked with have adapted items off the adult menu to make it fit for kids,\" he said. \n\"That means less ordering, the kitchen is all set up for it already, it goes through nice and easy.\" \nHe said making good kids' food also required interesting presentation, a skill already \"part of the chef's armoury\". \n\"It's a good creative challenge,\" he said. \n\"Kids are highly creative, highly visual, so that's a good fun brief to have.\" \nMr Pangu said parents also had to be prepared to pay more for better food for their children. \n\"We've got to this point where it's $6 or $7 a plate for some beige fried food,\" he said. \n\"But this is our kids, they're supremely important to us and so is their health and their happiness \u2014 I'd argue its worth spending a little bit more.\"", "highlightText": "", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Campbell Gellie, Mackay Daily Mercury", "published": "2018-03-23T16:50:00.000+03:00", "title": "Why your wheelie bin could cost you more than $2500 | The Courier-Mail", "text": "Close Man locks would-be thief in wheelie bin 1:50\nA \"master of improvisation\u201d has locked a would-be thief in his wheelie bin cupboard after he tried to break into his car in Port Melbourne. Video courtesy Channel 7\nMarch 13th 2018 12 days ago /display/newscorpaustralia.com/Web/NewsNetwork/Network News/National/ Man locks would-be thief in wheelie bin QLD News Why your wheelie bin could cost you more than $2500 Campbell Gellie, Mackay Daily Mercury March 24, 2018 10:50am Share this on Facebook social-facebook_circle Share this on Twitter social-twitter_circle Share this by Email social-email_circle\nWHEELIE bin dawdlers who fail to promptly take their bins back from the kerb face a fine in excess of $2500 under proposed council laws.\nThe new law, Local Law Number 9, could see residents slugged with a $2523 fine if they leave their bins outside on the kerb for more than 24 hours before or after rubbish collection day.\nMackay Regional Council says the creation of the new law, which covers everything to do with waste management, is being forced by the expiration of State legislation.\nThe council told The Daily Mercury it would be in no hurry to enforce the fines.\nBut it does leave open the possibility holiday-makers who deposit their bin before they go away, and those tardy at retrieving it, could get the bill.\nThe rules will be in place by July 1.\nPrevious legislation also allowed a fine of $2523 for those leaving their bins out too long, but it didn\u2019t have a defined time-it said it covered a period \u201cotherwise reasonably appropriate before and after collection\u201d.\nBut the new proposed local law, with the 24-hour limit, is being rolled out by about 20 local councils including Mackay, Townsville, Rockhampton, Burdekin, Bundaberg, Gladstone and the Gold Coast.\nLocal Government Association of Queensland spokesman Craig Johnstone said Gold Coast was the first to adopt the law after the State Government decided to not extend the current legislation.\nHe said the association had been lobbying the government to leave the legislation in place but had lost. He believed 24 hours was long enough for people to bring their bins in after they had been emptied.\nMackay Mayor Greg Williamson said in response to complaints, the waste management team within the council had defined \u201creasonable\u201d to be 24 hours when drafting up the proposed local law.\nAlthough the law would now be able to policed, Cr Williamson said the change was not in response to a problem in the region where bins had been left out.\nSince April there had only been 18 complaints about people leaving their bins out on the street and nobody has ever been fined.\nCr Williamson said the purpose of the local law was to give local officers \u201csome teeth\u201d when dealing with people who were doing the wrong thing.\n\u201cLocal officers are out there trying and making sure (Mackay) has an urban environment that looks good,\u201d he said.\n\u201cIn the case where someone complains that there is a land owner or occupier of a dwelling not doing the right thing by the environment, and people that live in that area, we need this local law or otherwise it is a free-for-all.\u201d\nCr Williamson was insistent that the law wasn\u2019t to raise money and would only be policed if people complained about their neighbours.\nAccording to the draft law, the rightful place for a bin to be kept at a home is \u201cat ground level close to the rear alignment of a building\u201d.\nBrisbane City Council, which allows a fine of $1260, has retained similar working to the old piece of legislation.\nAnother section of the proposed law confirms only the local government- approved tip shop is allowed to take rubbish from the dump.\nShare this on Facebook social-facebook_circle Share this on Twitter social-twitter_circle Share this by Email "site_full": "www.theguardian.com", "site": "theguardian.com", "site_section": "https://www.theguardian.com/au", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "News, sport and opinion from the Guardian's Australia edition | The Guardian", "title": "As a citizen of Melbourne, don't I have the right to question immigration? | Gay Alcorn | Opinion", "title_full": "As a citizen of Melbourne, don't I have the right to question immigration? | Gay Alcorn | Opinion | The Guardian", "published": "2018-03-24T00:00:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 23, "participants_count": 17, "site_type": "news", "country": "AU", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/db6193bf2642c04b52a7677bd49da3a76a20616f/0_155_3479_2088/master/3479.jpg?w=1200&amp;h=630&amp;q=55&amp;auto=format&amp;usm=12&amp;fit=crop&amp;crop=faces%2Centropy&amp;bm=normal&amp;ba=bottom%2Cleft&amp;blend64=aHR0cHM6Ly91cGxvYWRzLmd1aW0uY28udWsvMjAxOC8wMS8zMS9mYWNlYm9va19vcGluaW9ucy5wbmc&amp;s=a1ee3e58742423d71fde0a83536c3d15", "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZSJlbPFf2vcZQ7DQwnenE_nZOCJivZzescL.JpS5yLU1WFJSvlynOcHY5Lbq.tymZlmUJxZKi_DUeAqLBnzj5zdSH78zdlmviKwkZlyNV7HyaGTfQfJcEWJ1weNW0VjK5hI7yE5lKcsQp8dyKamoxomCX5aPKgax4s-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Gay Alcorn", "published": "2018-03-24T00:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "As a citizen of Melbourne, don't I have the right to question immigration? | Gay Alcorn | Opinion", "text": "I \u2019m a citizen of Melbourne . That\u2019s all. Not an economist, nor a politician, a property developer, a demographer. Just a resident with an affection for the city, with all its flaws and idiosyncrasies.\nAs a citizen, nobody has been able to explain to me clearly why Melbourne, and Australia for that matter, should be absorbing so many new people every year, at a rate far higher than the OECD average, faster than other developed nations, with no feasible plan to cope with it.\nThe epicentre of what former New South Wales premier Bob Carr calls Australia\u2019s \u201cweird experiment\u201d is Melbourne, my town. Melbourne is on the brink of being a city of 5 million and is growing at record rates (Victoria grew 2.3% in the year to June 2017, way above the national average of 1.6%, itself exceptionally high by developed nation standards).\nAustralia's fierce immigration debate is about to get louder Read more\nDear old Melbourne added a quarter of its population in just 10 years to 2016. At this rate \u2013 and projecting population growth is a wobbly science \u2013 it will be home to nearly 8 million by mid-century, overtaking Sydney as the country\u2019s largest city.\nThe impact of this growth is the single most important issue in this town (and no doubt in Sydney, too, and to a lesser extent in Brisbane and Perth). As a lowly if curious citizen, the refusal of any major political party, let alone business groups, for whom the more people the better, to question the pace of growth, even to explain it, is astonishing.\nI read report after report which assume with scant elaboration that \u201cthere is no alternative\u201d to record population growth. The result is a rumbling backlash, and a justifiable one.\nAt least this debate is now being held, when for too long it was stuck in our debilitating culture wars, with many progressives wary that questioning immigration rates would give succour to racists.\nWe can ignore the Pauline Hansons who want to stop Muslims coming here. We can ignore, too, those elements of Tony Abbott\u2019s argument that one reason for easing immigration is because in Melbourne, \u201cethnic gangs (are) testing the resolve of police.\u201d That\u2019s a dog-whistle.\nBut we can no longer ignore the tougher questions: the majority of our population growth is due to immigration, particularly in the past decade. Around three quarters of immigrants settle in big cities, where the jobs are.\nThose cities, particularly Melbourne and Sydney, are not coping and this circular argument that all we need is better infrastructure and planning and all will be well is arguing backwards. Can we answer first why we want record population growth, and then discuss infrastructure?\nThe truth is that successive governments, state and federal, have not improved public transport and housing affordability and facilities for the booming outer suburbs anywhere near the rate that is needed for the current population, let alone for the hapless people who arrive each week.\nEven with the will \u2013 and if the public were willing to pay for it \u2013 few state governments could cope with this level of growth. Some of Melbourne\u2019s boom is because people are moving here from interstate \u2013 we can\u2019t control that. Governments have little control over how many babies we have. But we can control immigration, which, absent a population policy, is our de facto population policy.\nThe case for easing immigration is compelling. Even if it\u2019s just for a few years, from an annual permanent immigration intake of around 200,000 to 100,000, to catch up. Even if it\u2019s just so we can take a breath and think about how big this country should be without having it decided for us by default.\nLet me offer two examples from the world\u2019s most liveable city, a wry joke if you live here. We are stuck in traffic, long lines of fumes and angry horns, for weeks of our lives. The state government is spending huge amounts on infrastructure, including Victoria\u2019s biggest-ever public transport project, the Metro Tunnel, an $11bn underground rail project that will add five new stations and ease bottlenecks. When will it open? Around 2025.\nWill our congestion get better? No way. The prediction is that in two decades, half of all car trips in Melbourne at peak times will be congested, up from a third now. And, according to Infrastructure Victoria , that\u2019s taking into consideration the planned road and rail upgrades.\nLet\u2019s take schools. Daniel Andrews\u2019 government a few days ago announced that it would spend nearly $240m to buy land for another 14 schools in suburbs with exploding population.\nEducation minister James Merlino boasted that 10 new schools opened last year, 11 would open this year and nine next year. That\u2019s great. But the Grattan Institute a couple of years ago estimated that Victoria would need 220 news schools within a decade. The school where Merlino chose to make his announcement, the John Henry Primary School in exploding Pakenham, is at capacity and is taking no new enrolments . It opened just last year.\nBusinesses and property developers want more and more people because they want bigger markets and more consumers. Most economists seem to like it because they argue it\u2019s great for the economy although, as a more sceptical Ross Gittins pointed out, the productivity commission has found its net impacts to be \u201cnegligible\u201d .\nAnd it is true that our migrant intake is skewed towards skilled migrants, with a smaller proportion of family reunions, plus this year, 18,750 people on humanitarian visas. There is nothing wrong with our system. The debate is about the sheer numbers, and whether that is serving us well now.\nWhat is immigration for? Who is it for? The most curious argument in favour of large population growth is that, somehow, Australians \u2013 those here for generations and those recently settled \u2013 owe it to the rest of the world to populate quickly. Fairfax\u2019s economics correspondent Peter Martin wrote that \u201cthe rest of the world has granted us a licence to use this continent on the implicit understanding that we populate it.\u201d\nReally? Says who? Fellow Fairfax columnist Jessica Irvine wrote that we need to weigh up the \u201cneeds of Australians versus foreigners\u201d in the immigration debate and she had \u201cnever placed the hopes and dreams of Australians so far above those of foreigners that their needs become unimportant\u201d.\nThat\u2019s bewildering. Apart from our humanitarian intake \u2013 which is a duty for an affluent country like ours \u2013 the primary purpose of immigration is to benefit people who already live here, or at least not to worsen their quality of life. The Productivity Commission made that clear , concluding in a 2016 report that it had \u201ctaken the overarching policy objective of immigration to be maximising the wellbeing of existing Australian citizens and permanent residents\u201d.\nWe have benefited enormously from immigration. We are a land of immigrants. We will, and should, keep growing and much of that growth will be newcomers settling here. That doesn\u2019t mean we shouldn\u2019t pause a tad now. Just for a bit. Just so mug citizens like me can ask a few questions about the city I love.\nGay Alcorn is a Guardian Australia columnist Topics Australian immigration and asylum Opinion Population Australian politics Melbourne Victoria Victorian politics comment", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": ["https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/tony-abbott-s-economic-argument-against-immigration-is-flawed-20180225-p4z1ml.html", "https://www.smh.com.au/national/there-s-a-case-for-immigration-and-it-s-not-about-us-20180314-p4z4bk.html", "https://www.pc.gov.au/inquiries/completed/migrant-intake/report", "http://www.rossgittins.com/2018/03/immigration-cheap-and-nasty-way-to-grow.html", "http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-03-13/victorian-land-schools-growth-corridors-daniel-andrews/9542598", "http://jhps.vic.edu.au/enrolment/"], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "bob carr", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "oecd", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "alcorn", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "melbourne", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "new south wales", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "victoria", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "australia", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-24T00:52:34.022+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "913cf68410a75daa8c4db29370e48123ec468295", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZQ5XXeFXTk11mTUs7NkZF3XZlrofKWTgcXAxJdKnoibSrpFGj.MZjVBC4b287SEPkUU2TnhWE2dDe1r_xnhd2_ImTaWZ_D6bdEfejc27OMkG_3MmkxS0_pSCKzhuZwwmKRIh8Xih3j6hOeTpm2nVnNs_2Dn4deqo3jg49xzUZomm3EI2OcWpV94pX6GjAVNsrn8va_NhxFqQE.fkTfSUUpm4KS.XQH.DvY-", "site_full": "www.foxsports.com.au", "site": "foxsports.com.au", "site_section": "https://www.foxsports.com.au/afl", "site_categories": ["rugby", "sports"], "section_title": "AFL | AFL Ladder, Live Scores, Results &amp; News | Fox Sports | FOX SPORTS", "title": "Gary Ablett says return to Geelong made all the sweeter because of his father", "title_full": "Gary Ablett says return to Geelong made all the sweeter because of his father | Fox Sports", "published": "2018-03-22T12:58:00.000+02:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "AU", "spam_score": 0.022, "main_image": "https://cdn.newsapi.com.au/image/v1/1f9ddd729bf424c6aaae331cdff70758", "performance_score": 7, "domain_rank": 9920, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 723, "comments": 0, "shares": 723}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "913cf68410a75daa8c4db29370e48123ec468295", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZQ5XXeFXTk11mTUs7NkZF3XZlrofKWTgcXAxJdKnoibSrpFGj.MZjVBC4b287SEPkUU2TnhWE2dDe1r_xnhd2_ImTaWZ_D6bdEfejc27OMkG_3MmkxS0_pSCKzhuZwwmKRIh8Xih3j6hOeTpm2nVnNs_2Dn4deqo3jg49xzUZomm3EI2OcWpV94pX6GjAVNsrn8va_NhxFqQE.fkTfSUUpm4KS.XQH.DvY-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Sarah Olle", "published": "2018-03-22T12:58:00.000+02:00", "title": "Gary Ablett says return to Geelong made all the sweeter because of his father", "text": "GARY Ablett says his return to Geelong is made all the sweeter by his father\u2019s determination to become more involved with the footy club. The dual Brownlow Medal winner and premiership player will line up in the blue and white hoops on Sunday against Melbourne \u2014 some eight years after leaving the Cattery for the Gold Coast Suns on a lucrative five-year deal.\nWhile Ablett said it would \u201cmean a lot\u201d to represent Geelong once more, he was most looking forward to reconnecting his father with the club.\n\u201cI think, to come back here, I\u2019m really hoping over the next couple of years my dad can get a bit more involved with the football club,\u201d Ablett said on Fox Footy.\n ", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": ["http://pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/clk?id=4609140175&iu=/7414"], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "gary ablett", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "ablett", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "fox footy", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "geelong", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "gold coast suns", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "geelong", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "melbourne", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T12:16:10.146+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "ef8cb23e95c019054b8a20318a352fdad7e2e79a", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZS85jFjidQBhph_1zL9Q0_gDiNeYrgLVfC5sdYDdIBGGXL26z4G1suQtgJ6q7lYqStzr_JVRqdaRyFoY7z62FGZbomGPRcMIGbELkMRHV7HRgR4_G54KpdGwt8Pv7CfLCv1jLMIdBpZJSt_JSPv9K7m", "site_full": "www.smh.com.au", "site": "smh.com.au", "site_section": "http://feeds.smh.com.au/rssheadlines/top.xml#", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "Sydney Morning Herald - Latest News", "title": "Sian, 18, died from prescription drugs. Her brother finally knows why", "title_full": "Sian, 18, died from prescription drugs. Her brother finally knows why", "published": "2018-03-23T00:42:00.000+02:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 0, "site_type": "news", "country": "AU", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://static.ffx.io/images/$zoom_0.14320096269554752%2C$multiply_2.2408963585434174%2C$ratio_1.776119%2C$width_357%2C$x_0%2C$y_58/t_crop_custom/t_sharpen%2Cq_auto%2Cf_auto/c525c76bf69588e125c1189bbf81e980c9769217", "performance_score": 5, "domain_rank": 1534, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 555, "comments": 0, "shares": 555}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "ef8cb23e95c019054b8a20318a352fdad7e2e79a", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZS85jFjidQBhph_1zL9Q0_gDiNeYrgLVfC5sdYDdIBGGXL26z4G1suQtgJ6q7lYqStzr_JVRqdaRyFoY7z62FGZbomGPRcMIGbELkMRHV7HRgR4_G54KpdGwt8Pv7CfLCv1jLMIdBpZJSt_JSPv9K7m", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-23T00:42:00.000+02:00", "title": "Sian, 18, died from prescription drugs. Her brother finally knows why", "text": "By Paul Biegler Updated 24 March 2018 \u2014 12:37am first published 23 March 2018 \u2014 8:00am I found my sister Sian slumped against the chest freezer in the kitchen. The early rays of a hot Melbourne morning were streaming through the French doors and lighting up the mustard fuzz of the carpet tiles. Leunig's poem My Shoe , cut out from The Age , was turning brown on a cloth-covered pin board on the wall, and a Philips portable radio sat on a sideboard, switched off, but tuned to 3LO.\nSian was wearing her black astrakhan coat and Cuban-heeled ankle boots. I was puzzled that she would have fallen asleep there, like that. I put my hand on her shoulder to wake her up but when I touched her it was cold. I still remember my sudden intake of breath; I'd never felt that coldness on a human being.\n\"There's something wrong with Sian,\" was all I could say to Mum when I ran down to her room. When she'd seen my sister for herself, I asked her if Sian, just 18 years old and my only sibling, was dead. Mum's answer came out hesitant, uncertain, as if her mind were prefiguring an enormous bleakness that was still out of conscious reach. \"I think so,\" she said. The shock couldn't quite erase Mum's Welsh lilt, but the sing-song of the valleys got knocked out of her then, pretty much for good.\nPaul Biegler\u2019s sister, Sian, was only 18 when she died.\nPhoto: Courtesy of Paul Biegler It has been 38 years and I don't really want to go back there, but I'm going to because I've got kids, full of life and energy, and I don't want whatever it was that pulled Sian down to creep up on them. Because creep it did. Mum died in 1997 but Dad is still alive, and he says the thing that really sticks is that none of us knew what was going on. I don't want that to be me. And so, after all this time, I've been trying to shine light on a side of my sister that has always been hidden.\nThere was a coroner's inquest and I have the documents, photocopies tinged with sepia. I learnt from the deposition of a 26-year-old woman called Elizabeth that Sian spent her last night on earth in a flat in Brighton Road, St Kilda: \"I saw Sian go on several occasions to the bathroom and I assumed that she was dropping more Tuinal \u2026 Sian appeared to be depressed because her boyfriend had not been in touch with her for a week and she was worried about him.\"\nAdvertisement Tuinal. The capsules look like little red, brown and blue torpedoes, which is kind of apt, considering how many lives they've destroyed. It's a barbiturate, the same thing they squirt into you when you're having an anaesthetic, and was a popular sleeping pill in the 1970s and '80s.\nSian was taking Tuinal, a barbiturate \u2013 \"the same thing they squirt into you when you're having an anaesthetic\".\nPhoto: Getty Images That was until its stats sheet became so awful \u2013 the overdose rate was 20 times higher than for drugs like Valium \u2013 that by the late 1980s, no one could justify prescribing it. The problem with Tuinal was that people would get tolerant to the sleepy euphoria and have to keep upping the dose to get the same kick. But the lethal dose sat stubbornly the same, so the habitual pill-popper, like a fisherman hooking a monster they'd never land, just reeled themselves in, ever closer to goodnight.\nHow do I know all this? I looked it up, sure. But I ended up studying medicine, so I come with professional bona fides, too. In fact, I did advanced training and practised as an emergency physician. It's a job that's all about keeping control in a crisis \u2013 something of a recurring challenge over the years.\nOn the afternoon of February 6, 1980, the day I found my sister, I played golf. I rang up my mate Stephen, who skipped school on that second day of year 12, and we lugged our golf bags down to Elsternwick Golf Club and played nine holes.\nLooking back now it seems bizarre, even callous, but I remind myself that I was 17, and that grief was uncertain, foreign and painful. I didn't know how to do it. The swing of an iron, or a wood, was predictable, familiar. Perhaps there was reassurance from its simple repetition that it would just keep going, and not cut out on me without warning.\nBut, as air always vents to the water's surface, my loss would rise up periodically to remind me of its presence, deep within, mammoth, silent, immovable. At night in bed I'd have sudden moments where I couldn't draw a breath. At school in a maths exam, I excused myself to take a much-needed piss, but when I got to the toilets it wouldn't come. Back in my seat, wound up with a full bladder, I didn't finish the paper.\nPaul Biegler, now at age 55.\nPhoto: Courtesy of Paul Biegler Years later, when I was faithfully recording my dreams for a Jungian analyst, I learnt that Jung himself thought all neuroses are born of illegitimate suffering. I suspect Dr Jung might have seen me as a straggler; I'm 55, and I'm still trying to feel all those feelings properly.\nAnyway, those Tuinals, traded and shared across sticky St Kilda bar tables as \"tuis\", \"chewies\" and \"lollies\", were embedded deep in the drug culture of the time. Prescription drug abuse itself, of course, is timeless. Eighty per cent of overdose deaths examined by the Victorian Coroner in the seven years to 2015 were from prescription drugs, and most of those were drugs in the same classes as Valium and codeine. In 2016, 372 Victorians died of prescription drug overdoses, a hike of more than 25 per cent in six years, and more than double the state's road toll.\nIn the US, opioid overdoses increased 30 per cent in the 14 months to September 2017, according to a report by the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention. In November, the US President's Commission on Combating Drug Addiction and the Opioid Crisis called it an epidemic of \"epic proportions\".\nSo the question of why, and how you would know that your own baby-turned-teenager is doing drugs, prescription or otherwise, reaches out across the decades.\nMy first clues in Sian's case come from delving into her innermost thoughts, which would never have reached me in her lifetime, guarded, as they were, in a white wooden box under lock and key. I've carried that box with me, sacrosanct and unopened, for years. Until now. There are bits of rice paper with poems, foolscap sheets with meandering words, unsent letters and hotel meal tickets, among other souvenirs of a short life. It's adolescent, maudlin, threaded with loneliness and the hope of love, hinting at a new relationship here, ebbing away to bleakness and solitude there.\nWhat's unnerving is how this silent stream of desolation flowed hidden under a veneer of normality. And there is also the very conspicuous absence of me, Mum and Dad. Sian's pain is oriented to a world outside the weave of family. We're not a bulwark against loss, we're just missing from the equation, with all hope pinned on the horizon of her peers.\nIn 2017's The MassGeneral Hospital for Children Adolescent Medicine Handbook , three Harvard psychiatrists note the importance of choosing your tribe; friends who do drugs are a major risk factor for substance abuse. Family conflict and a lack of caring adults also figure prominently.\nDid we check any of these boxes? Well, before Mum and Dad split in 1976, there were definitely rows. I do recall the banging of kitchen pots. No violence but, yes, highly audible disharmony. And with my father gone, and my mother tearful and acrimonious over her nightly glass of red, Sian had ample opportunity to slip out her window and into the troubled night.\nElizabeth, Sian's companion on that last night in St Kilda, who deposed so helpfully to the coroner, was forthright on Sian's choice of peer group:\n\"I tried to talk to her about her boyfriend, whom I had known for 10 years, and I tried to tell her that he was an absolute no-hoper and wasn't worth worrying about. Unfortunately Sian was the type of girl who took the unfortunate people of this world under her wing in the vague hope of helping them. She was too kindhearted and sympathetic for her own good.\"\nIn the late '70s, Sian's haunts of choice were the Greyhound Hotel and the Gatwick in St Kilda, the latter home to an erstwhile, and much older, boyfriend whose troubles the white box bears witness to, with scripts for antidepressants and phone numbers for a psych ward.\nBoth institutions, as it happens, were subject to seismic real estate shifts in 2017. The Greyhound, where from all accounts a variety of substances could be bought and sold, was vaporised to make way for apartments, and the Gatwick, a modish private hotel of the art deco era, but latterly home to sundry unfortunates, was sold to Channel Nine to be kitted out for more genteel types on The Block .\nIt would be fair to say Sian's peer milieu fell foul of the Harvard doctors' warnings, with both her preferred public buildings sporting illicit substances in spades. But the Gatwick did not lack caring adults. In July last year, proprietors Rose Banks and Yvette Kelly, who had called the Gatty home since 1971, opened their doors for a day to the public. I heard too late and missed it. But, determined to see where Sian had hung out, I rang photographer Sandy Rogulic, who spent a year among its folk with her camera, snapping the etched faces of hard lives, all with the Gatwick's weathered glory as backdrop.\nOne of Sian\u2019s haunts, St Kilda\u2019s Gatwick boarding house.\nPhoto: Thom Rigney Sandy kindly met me beneath the hotel's iconic portico, and took me on a tour past the dark mahogany of reception, whose windows opened onto flowers like some porthole into Eden, up stately staircases jaded with use, past rooms boarded up to stop squatters availing themselves of the emptiness, down dark corridors and into shared bathrooms studded with 1930s tiles where residents once set off crackers and lit fires on the floor.\nBut the epicentre was a little room, lined with shelves still stacked with the articles of care wielded by Rose and Yvette over all those decades; the towels and linen for their displaced, homeless, drug-affected and abused residents. I had the privilege of meeting both sisters and wondered if Sian ever did, sure that if she had felt their stern but patient embrace, she would have been better for it.\nThings were unravelling for my sister. I come across her school report from year 11. \"This is just not good enough! Sian is skipping classes and leaving school without permission. Unless she conforms she will be asked to leave,\" it reads, ominously. Academic decline is another risk factor on the Harvard doctors' list.\nRecently, the wheels have been turning, ever so creakily, on prevention. The federal government pledged $16 million for a national prescription monitoring system in July, and Victoria passed its anti-doctor-shopping legislation, SafeScript, in October. Codeine-containing drugs became prescription-only last month.\nBut none of this will help if the doctors are dodgy. Sian's GP, who said he didn't know he was referred to as the \"lolly doctor\", had, in the preceding year, prescribed Tuinal to four other young people whose deaths were examined by the coroner. He was investigated by the medical board, struck off for \"infamous conduct\" (nowadays called serious professional misconduct), then reinstated a couple of years later. I saw his obituary in my trawling. He passed away in 2014, at 85. It was peaceful, apparently, after a long illness, and he was a beloved husband and proud father.\nPaul Biegler in 1979 with his mother Beryl, sister Sian and family dog Morgan.\nPhoto: Courtesy of Paul Biegler Sian, of course, who had turned 18 only five months before her death, was never to marry or have a child, turn her nascent love of art, music and poetry into a pastime or career, weather years with the love of family, get smile lines from laughing round the dinner table, or be blessed with the cross-hatched brow of the worried mum. Instead her chair just sits empty at our table. She hovers, in conversation, over the lives of my children. Auntie Sian, spoken of but unseen, never to influence how they grow, or what they think and do.\nPerhaps strangely, it never occurred to me that Sian could have taken her own life on purpose. The coroner was equivocal: \"The evidence adduced does not enable me to say whether such overdose was accidental or otherwise.\" His conundrum still echoes around the nation; in Australia nearly half of the roughly 1400 codeine-related deaths between 2000 and 2013 were accidental.\nHow in hell, though, do you kill yourself by accident? Well, as with Tuinal, people get tolerant to a drug's effects and end up taking too much, or mix it with other drugs and alcohol, or stupidly get behind the wheel. But whether or not Sian's death was intentional, she was, undoubtedly, deeply unhappy, and I guess I'll never really understand why.\nRight at the front of my file on Sian is the autopsy report, which reads:\n7 February 80. Woman. Sian Cathryn BIEGLER. 18 (found dead on \u2026 floor)\nThe body was that of a thin, young woman with a bruise beneath the right side of the chin and a short cut 1cm long. There was no evidence of any deeper damage and the skull and brain all appeared normal. The heart weighed 190g. The myocardium was normal. The coronary arteries showed minimal atheroma \u2026 The mucosa of the stomach was congested and the stomach contained a moderate amount of granular material which was probably ingested tablets \u2026\nThat's what happens when your loved one dies and it's a coroner's case. They become organs, weighed and measured, commented on like specimens in a pathology museum.\nMuch of death shocks and rattles, but coronial deaths mean that on the passage from living, breathing and loving, to nothingness, there is also a clinical carving of flesh, and a resewing for the funeral, all of which reinforces just how little they have become. The stock in trade of the autopsist, valuable as it is, becomes the stuff of nightmares for relatives.\nFor some reason, when my mum received the coroner's documents, it appears she also asked for the photos. I discovered them 20 years ago when I was cleaning out Mum's unit after she died. They were horrible to me then, and I gave them to my dad, who locked them away in his filing cabinet.\nMy dad just turned 80, and it seems I've come of age, because I'm now custodian of the photos. They show Sian on the kitchen floor after the doctor came and rolled her away from the freezer, which is why, because of rigor mortis, her arms are held unnatural, still and upraised, in a pose of helplessness, like those plaster casts of the victims at Pompeii.\nHer hair is spread out from her head on those carpet tiles. Her lips are pinched and colourless. Eyes closed, eyelashes a thin line between the lids. There's no real expression, and if there is it's one of being fed up, exhausted, resigned, over it, goodbye. There is no repose, there is no peace, there is no grateful relinquishing of life's breath. It's just a bad death.\nOne that I'm going to place carefully back in its folder, bury deep within my own filing cabinet, and keep well away from my children, out of harm's way. I've got plenty of photos of my dear sister in life. The kids can look at them, and direct whatever thoughts, feelings and sensations they might have, to that Sian.\nPaul Biegler is an adjunct research fellow in bioethics at Monash University.\n Drugs ", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "sian", "sentiment": "neutral"}, {"name": "paul biegler", "sentiment": "neutral"}, {"name": "leunig", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "philips", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "melbourne", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T00:57:24.014+02:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "a29ae46250b746fa39fd1d809d8d079b7b79ed1e", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZQ5XXeFXTk11mTUs7NkZF3X6llCpdpJdkoB2CoyrwqvvDQ0P5o4H7dEzI5bsD4NXy8cEWty2LVot2OgB3P9w7XPcd5Koe2VunmFK2JmB9S7CpKDFL4KM137u_aSYZ645.5R0y7Wv7Ya.L8ZegrJHEWigjX.zWrWAByatY9cT38h6H1FZ1RjIRMoGIBH5kLP4rng5yW.yx0cwacRA33uh2igs4mDuTbMhYw-", "site_full": "www.foxsports.com.au", "site": "foxsports.com.au", "site_section": "https://www.foxsports.com.au/nrl", "site_categories": ["rugby", "sports"], "section_title": "NRL | NRL Live Scores | NRL Ladder &amp; infringements in Melbourne\u2019s 30-14 win over the Cowboys.\n'We have to help the refs'\n1:02 The stop-start nature of the grand final rematch sent Andrew Johns spare, Storm coach Craig Bellamy was "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": Miami\u2014With Our Toddlers", "title_full": "Spring Break in Miami\u2014With Our Toddlers - WSJ", "published": "2018-03-23T18:44:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, 387, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 1441, "comments": 0, "shares": 1441}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "5f4e4150369d7a3deb702a0359a4814d0113f7ba", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZRq9N.uhgW_KXYKp9jLOFdATM6HAj5MeS4GNIqafWTsDpNM_3IZsJjIOoEx9navZrbvb22C8mdQRyNwOofJGrXaIfy6FLL3PVY-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Jason Gay", "published": "2018-03-23T18:44:00.000+03:00", "title": "Spring Break in Miami\u2014With Our Toddlers", "text": "26 COMMENTS Let me tell you about the time I accidentally took my family to Spring Break. (Full disclosure: It\u2019s entirely my fault. Also full disclosure: I am an idiot.)\nLast March, I booked a trip to Miami for me, my wife and our 2-year-old and 4-year-old children without doing even a cursory check of the local calendar. Everybody\u2014except me, apparently\u2014knows that March is Spring Break season. This time of year, you need to use caution in planning a beach getaway\u2014unless you want to spend your family vacation doing Jell-O shots and keg stands, which, I don\u2019t know, maybe you do, you lunatics.\nI learned of my screw-up a few weeks before arrival, when I got an upbeat email from a reservationist announcing that our hotel would be hosting a series of poolside events for the \u201cMiami Winter Music Conference.\u201d\n\u201cThough this is a very exciting time for both our locals and tourists,\u201d the note read, \u201ci t tends to be a more vibrant vibe than our typical tranquil atmosphere.\u201d\nOh dear. I knew what that meant: BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA.\nAs in the throbbing, wordless, molar-rattling, DJ-driven electronic music which forms the soundtrack for a lot of dance party fun for young people who are far cooler than me. I consider myself a reasonably hip adult\u2014I don\u2019t fall asleep on the couch most Saturdays until after 9 p.m.\u2014but I would rather spend a day inside a garbage can being hit with a hammer than endure 10 minutes of BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA.\nThis was a disaster. I wrote back to the hotel, politely asking if there was some alternative situation.\nOK, that\u2019s not true. I threw a hissy fit.\nThe hotel was apologetic and tried to make good. They offered to help us change our dates (not possible, since we\u2019d booked air travel and it was a school vacation week for my wife, a teacher). They offered to move us to another hotel, but that proved difficult, because it was peak season, and besides, every other hotel was having its own BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA bash.\nThen the hotel offered to upgrade our family to a two-bedroom suite.\nA two-bedroom suite? You don\u2019t say. I\u2019d never stayed in a room that nice in my life.\nHow bad could it be? I asked my wife.\n\u201cBad,\u201d she said. \u201cYou\u2019re an idiot.\u201d\nStill, we went. What were we going to do, stay home and freeze in the Arctic? Why not try to tough it out in the fancy suite? Had I gotten so old and cranky that I\u2019d forgotten how to have big, noisy fun? Maybe I would love the dance party.\nWhen we arrived at the hotel, it was tranquil. You could have heard a kitten tiptoe across the lobby. We took the kids to the pool, and they were ecstatic.\nIn a corner, a sound crew worked on a speaker set, but Day One was blissfully quiet. The next day, it began around noon: BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA. It sounded like a jet engine wrestling a jackhammer.\n\u2018 Parents may want relaxation, but kids like action. \u2019\nSoon, the Spring Breakers arrived. First it was a handful, then a truckload. All the BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA didn\u2019t faze them in the slightest. They drank cocktails from plastic cups, floated in the pool, compared sunburns and yelled at each other over the din.\nAnd here\u2019s the thing: My kids thought it was fantastic . They couldn\u2019t believe their luck to be at a place like this, with all these people, loud music and tattoos. Someone threw a pile of beach balls into the pool. Free beach balls!\nIt underlined a truth about family vacations: Parents may want relaxation, but kids like action.\nThe Spring Breakers, meanwhile, thought we were hilarious\u2014the pasty parents who had brought preschoolers to a music festival. They chatted up the children, asking them about dinosaurs, animals, french fries. They were really quite sweet. There wasn\u2019t a boorish drunk in the group. It turns out that the Winter Music Conference isn\u2019t totally a Spring Break bacchanal\u2014there\u2019s an international crowd of electronic music connoisseurs who really know their BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA.\nThere\u2019s also this: the Miami BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA world doesn\u2019t do mornings. We had the early hours at the pool to ourselves. The young guests would trickle in around midday, groggily. The party didn\u2019t really get going until late afternoon, and then we\u2019d escape to the beach or go on a bike ride.\nMore Essays from Review\nSpring Break in Miami\u2014With Our Toddlers March 23, 2018 Who Is the Real Atticus Finch? March 22, 2018 Small Trends Can Be Big March 16, 2018 Soccer Without the Melodrama?\nNo Thank You March 16, 2018 Is the Internet Making Us Worse at Cooking? March 16, 2018 Frankly, it was a fun vacation. And a weird relief. As a parent of toddlers, I\u2019m used to us being the loudest, most objectionable thing in every room we walk into. When we walk into an airplane or restaurant, we\u2019re used to the looks of horror: Please please oh please don\u2019t sit next to me with those horrible kids.\nFor a few days, we were the quiet ones. I loved it almost as much as the cheese plate in the two-bedroom suite.\nNext week, we\u2019re off on another family vacation, to an undisclosed warm location. I\u2019ve made certain that it won\u2019t be the mania of last year. But when we get to the rental car, I\u2019ve got a little something for the stereo and my wife and kids. Just a few minutes of BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA\u2013BOMPA. Rattle our teeth, for old times\u2019 sake.\nWrite to Jason Gay at Jason.Gay@wsj.com\nMore by Jason Gay\nScreen Time for Kids Is Awful\u2014And I Can\u2019t Live Without It Are You Ready for (Even More) Football? College Basketball Is Yuck. His best season came in 2015 when he had 64 receptions for 1,031 yards and 10 touchdowns in 15 games. \nThe Jaguars rewarded Hurns with a four-year contract extension worth up to $40 million in June 2016. Injuries limited the 26-year-old to 19 games over the past two seasons, leading to Jacksonville releasing him Tuesday. \nB/R NFL 1000 Scouts had Hurns ranked as the No. 33 outside wide receiver for the 2017 season with an overall grade of 65 out of 100:\n\"As the Jags' possession receiver, Hurns is used often over the middle, against zone coverage and on third downs. He's a trustworthy route-runner who catches mostly everything within his reach. He's not going to get deep, but he's a solid contested-catch receiver outside and a physical asset in the slot, especially in the red zone.\" \nHurns' recent injury history is a concern, but his age makes it easy to bet on his potential and returning to the 2015 form that made him a star. \nOffensive playmakers are always in demand, so for the Cowboys to land one at this stage of free agency is a boon to their upside in 2018. \nThe Cowboys have had a quiet offseason to this point. Their biggest move came prior to free agency when DeMarcus Lawrence received the franchise tag. \nAdding Hurns brings a new dimension to Dallas' offense in 2018. Dez Bryant didn't have the same explosiveness last season, averaging a career-low 12.1 yards per reception, and he's only caught 50 percent of the passes thrown in his direction over the past three seasons (150 out of 300). \nHurns gives the Cowboys four wide receivers capable of starting for most teams in the league. He will be lining up alongside Bryant, Terrance Williams and Cole Beasley. \nIf Ezekiel Elliott can return to his rookie form, quarterback Dak Prescott will have a wealth of playmakers to spread the ball around to next season. \nThe Cowboys are chasing the Philadelphia Eagles in the NFC East, so having a powerful offense is a good way to try combating the reigning Super Bowl champions.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "allen hurns", "sentiment": "neutral"}, {"name": "hurns", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "jags", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "nfl", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "jacksonville jaguars", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "jaguars", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "dallas cowboys", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "jacksonville", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "miami", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-24T08:16:40.119+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "be6bb032ae9d587a45564a4e2931ec663f05a3a9", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZS242NJEspr7HOZGqM4ulFSto8NLZgBUZR7C2M3LsRiyKhhGrmNJ4EGixiaqYu1zjTiT.BDN7sd4crE41W0VzyzBiulq0rkMf3iRYZtDDT5_LZiPaKPTIVO26VLszCXn1THABDUQf9bJ57tzt434ZcceFy.e.DYMShNJwxNX69.4Q--", "site_full": "www.cbssports.com", "site": "cbssports.com", "site_section": "", "site_categories": ["football", "sports"], "section_title": "", "title": "March Madness 2018: Loyola-Chicago's Cinderella run continues on to the Final Four - CBSSports.com", "title_full": "March Madness 2018: Loyola-Chicago's Cinderella run continues on to the Final Four - CBSSports.com", "published": "2018-03-25T03:00:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 0, "site_type": "news", "country": "US", "spam_score": 0.137, "main_image": "https://sportshub.cbsistatic.com/i/r/2018/03/25/b844164c-becd-48fe-89e3-be024222d593/thumbnail/770x433/456697049162ca12a81dd6dcebcad480/loyola-final-four-kansas-state.jpg", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 438, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 4296, "comments": 0, "shares": 4296}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 5}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "be6bb032ae9d587a45564a4e2931ec663f05a3a9", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZS242NJEspr7HOZGqM4ulFSto8NLZgBUZR7C2M3LsRiyKhhGrmNJ4EGixiaqYu1zjTiT.BDN7sd4crE41W0VzyzBiulq0rkMf3iRYZtDDT5_LZiPaKPTIVO26VLszCXn1THABDUQf9bJ57tzt434ZcceFy.e.DYMShNJwxNX69.4Q--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Chip Patterson", "published": "2018-03-25T03:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "March Madness 2018: Loyola-Chicago's Cinderella run continues on to the Final Four - CBSSports.com", "text": "14h ago \u2022 4 min read \nATLANTA -- Loyola-Chicago has captured the hearts of college basketball fans everywhere this March, and now it will have a chance to compete for a national championship on the game's biggest stage after beating Kansas State 78-62 to be crowned as champions of the South Region. \nSenior guard Ben Richardson scored a career-high 23 points to lead the Ramblers, who will play Michigan in the Final Four. \n\"Ben sat there and watched Donte [Ingram] and Clayton [Custer] and Marques [Townes] and Dre [Jackson] have big shots,\" head coach Porter Moser told CBS Sports after the game. \"And he comes in there. He is the epitome of character and winning. Just so awesome to see him do that. And that's such a great lesson for so many kids. There was no jealousy or envy, it was about winning and he was ready mentally to step up when it was his time.\" \nArguably the toughest corner of the bracket, the one with the overall No. 1 seed and four conference tournament champions, has been where we've found this year's most unlikely outcomes, from the first-ever 16-over-1 upset to a mid-major from the Missouri Valley Conference making a Final Four run as a No. 11-seed. \nOn the court Loyola packed all of the thrills, beating the third-place team in the ACC (Miami), the SEC regular season co-champions ( Tennessee ) and the Mountain West champions ( Nevada ) by a combined four points. Off the court Loyola introduced the rest of the country to Sister Jean, a kind-hearted and noble face of the NCAA Tournament after a season mostly defined by scandal tied to an ongoing corruption investigation by the FBI. \nLoyola's team fits the model of what so many love about college basketball and this tournament as well. This group doesn't wow you with size or speed when they get off the bus, but the ball moves faster than any player and no one passes the ball better as a team than the Ramblers. There isn't a bad passer on the team, and any one of the rotation players has the potential to to be the team's primary offensive threat on a given night. It's one of the things that makes Loyola so good in the closing moments of these close games: opponents can't turn their attention to any one player because anyone on the floor could potentially be the go-to guy of the moment. \nThe unusual way the region unfolded gave Loyola an Elite Eight foe different from the top seeds that George Mason and VCU had to beat in 2006 and 2011. After beating a No. 6, a No. 3 and a No. 7, the last test was No. 9 Kansas State. The way the game unfolded broke the mold from previous tournament wins as well, with Loyola leading by as many as 21 in the second half and then holding on for the program-defining win in the final minutes. It\u2019s a Cinderella story! For the first time since 1963, Loyola is going to the Final Four! pic.twitter.com/6QUQngjbuM \u2014 CBS Sports (@CBSSports) March 25, 2018 \nWhile Loyola's Final Four run certainly counts as a Cinderella story in the the lore of the tournament, these haven't been massive upsets or a big surprise to anyone who has followed the Ramblers in 2018. Winners in 32 of their 37 games this year, Loyola has been one of the most successful teams in all of college basketball this season. \nNow we all will tune in to see if Loyola can eclipse the accomplishments of George Mason and VCU, the last two mid-major teams to make a run to the Final Four from the 11-line. If there's a reason to think the Ramblers can do it, it's their body of work heading into the NCAA Tournament. George Mason and VCU each got bounced from its conference tournaments, requiring an at-large bid. In the case of George Mason, the NCAA Tournament bid came with national criticism. In the case of VCU we know the Rams were one of the last teams in the field because their path began in the First Four. \nLSU also made the Final Four as a No. 11 seed in 1986. All three No. 11 seeds lost in the national semifinals. \nOne of the things that driven Loyola all season has been a hunger to achieve more. Loyola won a share of the MVC regular season title, but there was a drive among the players to win the crown outright. While outsiders buzzed about the Ramblers' need to win the conference tournament to avoid sweating out Selection Sunday as a mid-major team on the bubble, the players remained focused on the task at hand and left to question as to their postseason future by winning the league's auto-bid in Arch Madness. \nLoyola had not made the NCAA Tournament since 1985 prior to this season, but it's not totally foreign territory for the program. Though it did not occur in their lifetime, the players talk about how Loyola is the only program in the state of Illinois to have a national championship. With a 33-year tournament drought already snapped, Loyola now gets to fly to San Antonio with a chance to recapture some of that 1963 magic, with Sister Jean front and center, of course.", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Barrett Sallee", "published": "2018-03-24T20:05:00.000+03:00", "title": "Report: Alabama, Notre Dame discussing future home-and-home football series", "text": "1h ago \u2022 1 min read \nAlabama and Notre Dame last met on the gridiron in January 2013 in Miami, where the Crimson Tide stomped the Fighting Irish 42-14 in the BCS National Championship Game to claim the 2012 national championship. \nA chance at redemption for the Fighting Irish could be on the way. Two chances, in fact. \nAccording to a report from the Tuscaloosa News , the two sides are hammering out details for games in Tuscaloosa, Alabama, and South Bend, Indiana , although no specific years were mentioned. The report also cited Crimson Tide athletic director Greg Byrne's desire to schedule additional home-and-home series, which would mark a departure from the norm for the program during the Nick Saban era (2007-present). \nDuring that time period, the Crimson Tide have typically participated in Power Five out-of-conference matchups at neutral sites, including: two neutral site games vs. Florida State (2007, 2017), one with Clemson (2008), two with Virginia Tech (2009 and 2013), one with Michigan (2012), one with West Virginia (2014), one vs. Wisconsin (2015) and one against USC (2016). They play Louisville in Orlando to open the 2018 season, Duke in Atlanta in 2019 and Miami in Atlanta in 2021. \nThe only Power Five home-and-home series they've played during the Saban era was at Penn State (home in 2010 and on the road in 2011). Saban also took the Crimson Tide to Duke to finish up a previously-existing deal in 2010 -- one week after hosting the Nittany Lions. \nAs an independent, Notre Dame's schedule is a little more flexible. But due to the partnership with the ACC that includes between four and six games games each year, and rivalries with Stanford and USC, there still is some work to be done to hammer down exactly when these games will be played. \nAssuming it happens, though, the series would be phenomenal for college football . Throw the title game blowout aside, the fact is these are two storied programs that have national championship potential most seasons and don't get together often. Notre Dame is 5-2 all-time vs. Alabama, and three of those games were in bowls.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "greg byrne", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "nick saban", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "notre dame", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "usc", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "florida state", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "virginia tech", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "tuscaloosa news", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "clemson", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "alabama", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "miami", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "west virginia", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "indiana", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "tuscaloosa", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "south bend", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "wisconsin", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "michigan", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-24T20:29:59.037+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "24461fa5265b525787e2c03c6415144a5cffe4c5", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZQ7wnGNQCqzsoh1xrl4_DjiirlPK18mVrX3lErJji4IPaCAwVY8ierWmAoJV0Bb5M3ATBL_icnq9WeBJ3JjeaGVhwZ8P17p3dGo6TycAKMXc5t9RcpHTncEZBySBHZiTwdReHTAeC3eEg--", "site_full": "www.nfl.com", "site": "nfl.com", "site_section": "https://www.nfl.com/", "site_categories": ["football", "sports"], "section_title": "NFL.com - Official Site of the National Football League | NFL.com", "title": "Former Dolphins owner H. Wayne Huizenga dies at 80", "title_full": "Former Dolphins owner H. Wayne Huizenga dies at 80 - NFL.com", "published": "2018-03-23T19:13:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "US", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "http://static.nfl.com/static/content/public/photo/2018/03/23/0ap3000000922774_thumbnail_200_150.jpg", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 992, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 1839, "comments": 0, "shares": 1839}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "24461fa5265b525787e2c03c6415144a5cffe4c5", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZQ7wnGNQCqzsoh1xrl4_DjiirlPK18mVrX3lErJji4IPaCAwVY8ierWmAoJV0Bb5M3ATBL_icnq9WeBJ3JjeaGVhwZ8P17p3dGo6TycAKMXc5t9RcpHTncEZBySBHZiTwdReHTAeC3eEg--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Associated Press", "published": "2018-03-23T19:13:00.000+03:00", "title": "Former Dolphins owner H. Wayne Huizenga dies at 80", "text": "MIAMI -- H. Wayne Huizenga, a college dropout who built a business empire that included Blockbuster Entertainment, AutoNation and three professional sports franchises, has died. He was 80.\nHuizenga died Thursday night at his home, said Valerie Hinkell, a longtime assistant. She gave no details on a cause of death.\nStarting with a single garbage truck in 1968, Huzienga built Waste Management Inc. into a Fortune 500 company. He purchased independent sanitation engineering companies, and by the time he took the company public in 1972, he had completed the acquisition of 133 small-time haulers. By 1983, Waste Management was the largest waste disposal company in the United States.\nThe business model worked again with Blockbuster Video, which he started in 1985 and built into the leading movie rental chain nine years later. In 1996, he formed AutoNation and built it into a Fortune 500 company.\nHuizenga was founding owner of baseball's Florida Marlins and the NHL Florida Panthers -- expansion teams that played their first games in 1993. He bought the NFL Miami Dolphins and their stadium for $168 million in 1994 from the children of founder Joe Robbie, but had sold all three teams by 2009.\nThe Marlins won the 1997 World Series, and the Panthers reached the Stanley Cup Finals in 1996, but Huizenga's beloved Dolphins never reached a Super Bowl while he owned the team.\n\"If I have one disappointment, the disappointment would be that we did not bring a championship home,\" Huizenga said shortly after he sold the Dolphins to New York real estate billionaire Stephen Ross. \"It's something we failed to do.\"\nStephen Ross on the passing of Wayne Huizenga pic.twitter.com/Bg9J1e6Yhy\n\u00e2\u0080\u0094 Miami Dolphins (@MiamiDolphins) March 23, 2018 Huizenga earned an almost cult-like following among business investors who watched him build Blockbuster Entertainment into the leading video rental chain by snapping up competitors. He cracked Forbes' list of the 100 richest Americans, becoming chairman of Republic Services, one of the nation's top waste management companies, and AutoNation, the nation's largest automotive retailer. In 2013, Forbes estimated his wealth at $2.5 billion.\nFor a time, Huizenga was also a favorite with South Florida sports fans, drawing cheers and autograph seekers in public. The crowd roared when he danced the hokey pokey on the field during an early Marlins game. He went on a spending spree to build a veteran team that won the World Series in the franchise's fifth year.\nBut his popularity plummeted when he ordered the roster dismantled after that season. He was frustrated by poor attendance and his failure to swing a deal for a new ballpark built with taxpayer money.\nMany South Florida fans never forgave him for breaking up the championship team. Huizenga drew boos when introduced at Dolphins quarterback Dan Marino's retirement celebration in 2000, and kept a lower public profile after that.\nIn 2009, Huizenga said he regretted ordering the Marlins' payroll purge.\n\"We lost $34 million the year we won the World Series, and I just said, 'You know what, I'm not going to do that,'\" Huizenga said. \"If I had it to do over again, I'd say, 'OK, we'll go one more year.'\"\nHe sold the Marlins in 1999 to John Henry, and sold the Panthers in 2001, unhappy with rising NHL player salaries and the stock price for the team's public company.\nHuizenga's first sports love was the Dolphins -- he had been a season-ticket holder since their first season in 1966. But he fared better in the NFL as a businessman than as a sports fan.\nHe turned a nifty profit by selling the Dolphins and their stadium for $1.1 billion, nearly seven times what he paid to become sole owner. But he knew the bottom line in the NFL is championships, and his Dolphins perennially came up short.\nHuizenga earned a reputation as a hands-off owner and won raves from many loyal employees, even though he made six coaching changes. He eased Pro Football Hall of Famer Don Shula into retirement in early 1996, and Jimmy Johnson, Dave Wannstedt, interim coach Jim Bates, Nick Saban, Cam Cameron and Tony Sporano followed as coach.\nHarry Wayne Huizenga was born in the Chicago suburbs on Dec. 29, 1937, to a family of garbage haulers. He began his business career in Pompano Beach in 1962, driving a garbage truck from 2 a.m. to noon each day for $500 a month.\nOne customer successfully sued Huizenga, saying that in an argument over a delinquent account, Huizenga injured him by grabbing his testicles -- an allegation Huizenga always denied.\n\"I never did that. The guy was a deputy cop. It was his word against mine, a young kid,\" he told Fortune magazine in 1996.\nHuizenga was a five-time recipient of Financial World magazine's \"CEO of the Year\" award, and was the Ernst & Young \"2005 World Entrepreneur of the Year.\"\nRegarding his business acumen, Huzienga said: \"You just have to be in the right place at the right time. It can only happen in America.\"\nIn 1960, he married Joyce VanderWagon. Together they had two children, Wayne Jr. and Scott. They divorced in 1966. Wayne married his second wife, Marti Goldsby, in 1972. She died in 2017.\nWe mourn the loss of a beloved member of the Dolphins family.\nYour kindness and generosity can be felt throughout South Florida.\nWe will miss you Mr. H. pic.twitter.com/bWrNjbU17q\n\u00e2\u0080\u0094 Miami Dolphins (@MiamiDolphins) March 23, 2018 Copyright 2018 by The Associated Press.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": ["https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js", "https://t.co/bWrNjbU17q", "https://twitter.com/MiamiDolphins/status/977273898071969792", "https://twitter.com/MiamiDolphins/status/977225659838861312", "https://t.co/Bg9J1e6Yhy"], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "h. wayne huizenga", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "huizenga", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "valerie hinkell", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "huzienga", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "dolphins", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "waste management", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "waste management inc.", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "nhl florida panthers", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "florida marlins", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "autonation", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "nfl miami dolphins", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "miami", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "united states", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-24T00:11:55.001+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "abe149161d9b72d71cc3edc56fb74bb6cee44fae", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/_0JOtn.4SCo2O1fWYpUdITlflLgDfpnvrowJmXozvGODFLjwbmm5zvpsn3W7Dn1TNqt7yoCfDDaeWrUepKoubu1acdehvsZTUZOpq1sOf2xPZO__cSeYYOb2XfW5qwZcR4LZBzXv7fxFOGFvthhIOJEjpy9S6ppRuSV8jxCL_jk-", "site_full": "bleacherreport.com", "site": "bleacherreport.com", "site_section": "http://bleacherreport.com/articles/feed#", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "Bleacher Report - Front Page", "title": "Loyola-Chicago Earns Place Among All-Time Cinderellas with Trip to Final Four", "title_full": "Loyola-Chicago Earns Place Among All-Time Cinderellas with Trip to Final Four | Bleacher Report", "published": "2018-03-25T04:33:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "US", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://img.bleacherreport.net/img/images/photos/003/731/577/hi-res-2c6a3055d0278e9de4eb0d0b175b9509_crop_exact.jpg?w=1200&amp;h=1200&amp;q=75", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 506, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 3905, "comments": 0, "shares": 3905}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "abe149161d9b72d71cc3edc56fb74bb6cee44fae", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/_0JOtn.4SCo2O1fWYpUdITlflLgDfpnvrowJmXozvGODFLjwbmm5zvpsn3W7Dn1TNqt7yoCfDDaeWrUepKoubu1acdehvsZTUZOpq1sOf2xPZO__cSeYYOb2XfW5qwZcR4LZBzXv7fxFOGFvthhIOJEjpy9S6ppRuSV8jxCL_jk-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "David Kenyon", "published": "2018-03-25T04:33:00.000+03:00", "title": "Loyola-Chicago Earns Place Among All-Time Cinderellas with Trip to Final Four", "text": "Loyola continued its magical run Saturday. Now, the Ramblers are headed to the Final Four. Ronald Martinez/Getty Images The Loyola of Chicago Ramblers arrived at the Big Dance with only a bit of attention. Four victories later, they're guaranteed to leave March Madness as a legendary team.\nThanks to a 78-62 victory over the Kansas State Wildcats, the Ramblers earned a spot in the Final Four and secured their place in men's college basketball history.\nLoyola, the No. 11 seed in the South Regional, joined 1985-86 LSU, 2005-06 George Mason and 2010-11 VCU as the lowest seed to ever reach the national semifinals. That alone is reason enough for the Ramblers to be remembered in the annals of the NCAA tournament.\nBut because of how they kept surviving and advancing, Loyola will be one of the most memorable Cinderella stories.\nOn their way to the Elite Eight, the Ramblers edged sixth-seeded Miami just before the buzzer. They clipped No. 3 seed Tennessee when a jumper rattled home in the closing seconds. They buried No. 7 seed Nevada with a late three.\nBased on margin of victory, this unexpected run is unparalleled in March Madness history.\nOnly 1980-81 Saint Joseph's also won its first three games by a combined four points, per ESPN Stats & Info . But in the Elite Eight, that squad lost by 32 points. Loyola, on the other hand\u2014with a trip to San Antonio at stake\u2014led for the final 36 minutes of Saturday's game.\nThe Ramblers left no doubt they deserved a spot in the Final Four.\nNicole Auerbach @NicoleAuerbach Loyola to the Final Four. And it ain\u2019t even close.\nOne noteworthy point the coming years will determine is whether a specific player will be immortalized. That seems improbable, since Donte Ingram, Clayton Custer and Marques Townes all hit clutch shots and no player has consistently taken over games a la Stephen Curry for 2007-08 Davidson.\nGranted, Sister Jean\u2014the 98-year-old team chaplain whose likeness was featured on a collectible bobblehead \u2014could fill that role.\nStill, it's more likely Loyola will be remembered for its collective success as a scarcely known mid-major program. 2005-06 George Mason and 2010-11 VCU also fit that description.\nReally, that would be the most fitting legacy for Porter Moser's team. For many\u2014if not all\u2014of these players, this will be the glory days story they tell their children and grandchildren.\nCuster paced the Ramblers with 14 points in their opening game. Aundre Jackson's 16 led the way during the second round. Townes notched a team-best 18 in the Sweet 16. Ben Richardson eclipsed his previous season high of 14 by pouring in 23 during the South Regional-clinching victory.\nNCAA March Madness @marchmadness BIG BUCKET from Ben Richardson! \ud83d\udc4c Loyola Chicago stops a 10-0 run by the Wildcats with the SWISH! #MarchMadness #Elite8 https://t.co/Ihc9d0Vh90\nLoyola is team basketball exemplified. And given its coach's path, that shouldn't be a surprise.\nMoser utilizes concepts he learned from his former boss, Rick Majerus. The Ramblers showcase a free-flowing motion offense and a pack-line defense\u2014a similar philosophy to what Virginia was decried for using because it \"led\" to a historic upset in the first round.\nIn the not-too-distant future, the 49-year-old Moser may be fielding calls from power-conference schools. That's a common theme in the history of remarkable tournament runs.\nJim Larranaga\u2014who oversaw George Mason's surge\u2014eventually headed to Miami, and he's guided the Hurricanes to four of the 10 NCAA tournament bids in program history. Shaka Smart made VCU into an annual tourney qualifier prior to leaving for Texas.\nBut no matter whether Moser stays at Loyola for a long time, he'll always be the coach of a legendary Cinderella journey.\nExactly where does this one rank all-time? That question will be debated now and in the future. But that's not as important as one concurrent truth.\nThe glass slipper fit.\nAnd now, Loyola is unforgettable.\n\nStats via Sports Reference and NCAA.com unless otherwise noted. Follow Bleacher Report writer David Kenyon on Twitter @Kenyon19_BR .", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "ronald "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "John Breech", "published": "2018-03-23T23:39:00.000+03:00", "title": "Brock Osweiler reportedly agrees to terms with Dolphins, will reunite with Adam Gase", "text": "Brock Osweiler reportedly agrees to terms with Dolphins, will reunite with Adam Gase Brock Osweiler is taking his talents to South Beach \u2022 1 min read \nBrock Osweiler is taking his talents to South Beach. \nAccording to ESPN.com , Osweiler is going to sign with Miami in a move that reunites him with Adam Gase. The Dolphins head coach has played a big part in Osweiler's development during the quarterback's first three years in the league (2012-14). During Osweiler's rookie year in Denver, Gase was the Broncos ' quarterbacks coach. In 2013, Gase was promoted to offensive coordinator, which was his role in Denver until he left to take the same job with the Bears in 2015. \nWith the Dolphins, Osweiler will likely provide insurance for Ryan Tannehill , who has had some trouble staying healthy over the past two years. The Dolphins starting quarterback has suffered a total of two ACL injuries over the past two seasons and it's still unclear when he might be 100 percent. Tannehill has only played in 13 of 32 regular season games over the past two seasons. \nOsweiler is coming to Miami from Denver, where he spent the 2017 season. Although the terms of Osweiler's deal haven't been released, we can probably safely assume the numbers will be nowhere close to the contract he received after leaving Denver following the 2015 season. \nIn March 2016, Osweiler signed a massive four-year, $72 million contract with the Texans that included $37 million in guaranteed money. After an ugly year in Houston, the Texans unloaded Osweiler (and his contract) in a March 2017 trade that sent him to Cleveland. However, Osweiler never actually played a regular season game with the Browns in 2017 because he was cut before the regular season started . \nThe 27-year-old quarterback visited with the Dolphins on Thursday and Miami clearly liked him enough that they didn't let him leave the building. With both Jay Cutler and Matt Moore no longer on the roster, the Dolphins were in desperate need of a quarterback. \nOsweiler, who was a second round pick in the 2012 NFL Draft , has a 13-12 career record as a starter after going 0-4 with the Broncos last season. With Osweiler on board in Miami, the Dolphins could still draft a quarterback this year , but Gase may have brought the veteran in so he doesn't feel forced to make a pick for a QB in April.", "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZSPfVRrC83GDKJbKDRbkYjxNRdF1HRthPAOE8.Q_Wh8ZBrQV5AvtAc40BEFcXjkgtRtpoFfuf_F8el.6ye2I9OAmnacJJqRBH0cspOAL795qA--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "JOE DRAPE", "published": "2018-03-23T08:58:00.000+03:00", "title": "Loyola-Chicago Holds Off Nevada for a Third Straight Upset", "text": " Loyola-Chicago\u2019s Marques Townes celebrated a late 3-pointer in the Ramblers\u2019 69-68 victory over Nevada. Credit John Amis/Associated Press ATLANTA \u2014 Sister Jean Dolores Schmidt knew she was going to have to rip up one of the two N.C.A.A tournament brackets she filled out after her beloved Loyola-Chicago Ramblers faced Nevada here Thursday. Before Sister Jean, the 98-year-old nun and team chaplain, surged to Kardashian-level fame on social media \u2014 albeit chaste and devout \u2014 she served both as Loyola\u2019s divine inspiration and as a scout who crafted detailed basketball reports that even Mike Krzyzewski would love.\nLoyola\u2019s 69-68 victory over Nevada here on Thursday ensured that Sister Jean would get to rip up the right bracket, which actually was the wrong one. See, the Mother Teresa side of Sister Jean\u2019s personality moved her to slot her beloved Ramblers into the national title game. She called it her Cinderella bracket, and now, after the No. 11-seeded Ramblers upset No. 6 Miami, No. 3 Tennessee and then Nevada, Sister Jean and her dreams are very much alive.\nBut, alas, she could not dismiss the other side of her soul, that of the basketball lifer. So Sister Jean hedged: She filled out another bracket with the Ramblers being eliminated here, in the semifinals of the South Regional.\nIn the first half, the No. 7-seeded Wolf Pack (29-7) looked every bit the powerhouse that had erased a 22-point deficit to stun No. 2-seeded Cincinnati, 75-73, to reach the round of 16. It was a 20-minute chess match punctuated by Loyola fast breaks that were rarely finished. Nevada blocked five of Loyola\u2019s shots, all at point blank range, as the Wolf Pack took a 12-point lead late in the half.\n There was reason, however, for the Wolf Pack to worry even then.\nNevada had struggled to score from long range, shooting just 2 of 13 from beyond the 3-point arc and were 9 of 27 from the field. The Ramblers did not quit, found their scoring touch and put together a 12-0 run to take 28-24 lead into halftime.\nPhoto Sister Jean Dolores Schmidt observing during the first half of Loyola\u2019s victory. Credit David Goldman/Associated Press In the second half, the Wolf Pack doubled down on a smothering defense that forced Loyola into three shot-clock violations and another half-dozen hurried, off-balance attempts. With 3 minutes 18 seconds left, Nevada tied the score at 59-59 when Cody Martin floated through the lane for a soaring layup.\n Now Sister Jean and the Rambler faithful had reason to murmur some prayers.\nAundre Jackson drained a 3-pointer to give Loyola a 62-59 lead with 2:38 left. But with 1:20 left, Martin nailed a 3 of his own to bring Nevada within one, 64-63. But with 41 seconds left, Jackson drew a foul and hit both free throws to put the Ramblers up, 66-63.\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story\nPlease verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.\nInvalid email address.
