"ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Carlos Fr\u00edas", "published": "2018-03-22T20:58:00.000+02:00", "title": "Cuban Coffee 101: Everything to know about ordering coffee in Miami", "text": "READ: No Cuban abuela ? No problem. These are Miami\u2019s best Cuban restaurants \nIf you\u2019re new to Miami or here on vacation, you may have already discovered our devotion to \u201cventanitas,\u201d the ubiquitous walk-up windows where a coffee queen will whip up a cup of jet fuel while calling you cari\u00f1o or mi amor . ( One guy even spent a summer visiting more than 100 of them across Miami .) Gabriela Carbone, 20, a barista at Amelia\u2019s 1931, prepares a cortadito. \nThere\u2019s a right way to order coffee in Miami that won\u2019t earn you a strange look. Locals know there are only four acceptable coffee drinks to order at the ventanita: Cafecito Cafecitos are life. Matias Ocner \nOrder \u201cun cafecito\u201d and la se\u00f1ora at the ventanita will set down a cup and saucer in front of you that looks like it came from a child\u2019s play set. \nDo not be fooled. \nThat ounce-and-a-half or so of Cuban coffee may be a single serving, but it\u2019ll be enough to power you through lunch \u2014 until someone inevitably shows up to work with una colada . (See below). When done right, the cafecito will be sweet but not cloying, covered in a rich, creamy head that\u2019ll stick to your hipster mustache \u2014 and your ribs. Colada A colada is the perfect way to share Cuban coffee with soon-to-be new friends. Matias Ocner/Miami Herald \nAsk for \u201cuna colada\u201d and the ventanita waitress will pour you a four-ounce Styrofoam cup of hot, sweet Cuban coffee \u2014 to go. You may be tempted to peel off the plastic lid and drink it like a Starbucks espresso. \nDo not do this. This is \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d dragonfire. \nThere\u2019s a reason she will hand it to you with a half-dozen corrugated, thimble-sized plastic cups. Bring these back to work after your lunch break, share with five of your closest friends, and you\u2019ll quickly be caught up on office politics. \nPro tip: Pinch the lip of the Styrofoam cup to make a spout that makes the coffee easier to pour. Cortadito Cortadito: when a straight cafecito is just too much Matias Ocner \nFor some people, even locals, it\u2019s just too much to pour the gasoline that is Cuban coffee into an empty stomach. For that, order a cortadito \u2014 a single serving of Cuban coffee \u201ccut\u201d with steamed, whole milk. \nFor a special treat, ask for a cortadito con evaporada and the waitress will substitute milk with sweet, steamed evaporated milk. It makes the perfect finish to a meal in lieu of dessert. Caf\u00e9 con leche Don\u2019t talk to me until I\u2019ve had my caf\u00e9 con leche. Matias Ocner \nMornings in Miami don\u2019t begin until after a caf\u00e9 con leche: a cup of warm, steamed or boiled milk with a shot of Cuban coffee. They may ask you if you want it clarito or oscurito \u2014 light or dark \u2014 depending on how much coffee you want to darken you drink. Feel free to say mediano for Goldilocks perfection. \nDone right, the sugar in the Cuban coffee should be enough to sweeten the caf\u00e9 con leche. (This also applies to the cortadito.) But you can always ask for it sin azucar if you prefer to sweeten it yourself or sub out (gasp!) Splenda. Some of our favorite ventanitas: Amelia\u2019s 1931, 13695 SW 26th St., Miami, 305-554-4949 Cacique\u2019s Corner, 100 W. Flagler St., Miami (downtown), 305-371-8317 Chicos, 4070 W. 12th Ave., Hialeah, 305-556-8907 David\u2019s Caf\u00e9, 919 Alton Rd., South Beach, 305-534-8736 El Pub, 1548 SW 8th St., Miami (Little Havana), 305-642-9942 Enriqueta\u2019s, 2830 NE 2nd Ave., Miami (Wynwood), 305-573-4681 Islas Canarias, 13695 SW 26th St, Miami, 305-559-6666 La Carreta, nine locations throughout Miami-Dade County, including a sublime one on Key Biscayne, 12 Crandon Blvd., 305-365-1177, and a convenient stop at Miami International Airport, 305-871-3003 La Fragua, 7931 NW 2nd St., Miami, 305-266-3226 La Minuta, 14615 W. Heroes Fallen in the Battle for the Unity of Georgia to start the second day of his official visit to Georgia on 23 March, BelTA informs. \nThe memorial honors all those who died protecting the territorial integrity of Georgia in 1992-1993. The monument was erected in Heroes Square in Tbilisi. The memorial is 25 meters long and three meters high, with the Eternal Light placed in front of the sculpture. The names of those killed in the event are engraved on three white-marble walls. There is also a sculpture of a woman with a grapevine in her hands to symbolize the people's grief. \nToday, the Belarusian head of state is set to meet with Georgia Prime Minister Giorgi Kvirikashvili, and also Catholicos-Patriarch of All Georgia, Archbishop of Mtskheta-Tbilisi and Metropolitan Bishop of Bichvinta and Tskhum-Abkhazia Ilia II. \nOn 22 March, the Belarusian president held talks with his Georgian counterpart Giorgi Margvelashvili in Tbilisi. The parties discussed a wide range of issues on the bilateral agenda, the situation in the world and the region. The two heads of state were present at the ceremony to sign the agreements to boost cooperation in education, healthcare, banking sector, agriculture and interregional interaction. The two presidents signed the agreement on cooperation between Belarus and Georgia. \nA business forum was held ahead of the Belarusian leader's official visit to Georgia. host the 2021 ISU World Speed Skating Championships, taking into account the tournaments held at the Minsk Arena stadium, the chairman of the ISU Technical Committee said that the chances are good. If we decide on one tournament, many countries will be bidding to host it in 2021, and Minsk has good chances to host it,\u201d Alexander Kibalko said. \nThe chairman of the ISU Technical Committee stressed that the International Skating Union supports Belarus in its intention to host big international competitions. Minsk Arena has already successfully hosted the ISU European Speed Skating Championships and the ISU World Figure Skating Championships. These and other agreements were discussed at the meeting between Belarus' Ambassador to France with concurrent accreditation to Spain Pavel Latushko and Jose Luis Kaiser, Director General for International Trade and Investments at the Spanish Ministry of Economy, Industry and Competitiveness, BelTA learned from the Belarusian embassy in Spain. \nThe parties discussed the implementation of the agreements reached at the first meeting of the joint Belarusian-Spanish intergovernmental commission on economic and industrial cooperation on 18 October 2017. They also discussed the possibility of holding joint events to strengthen cooperation in the field of trade and investment. An agreement was reached to organize a forum for businessmen of Belarus, Spain and Latin American countries. The prospects of cooperation were talked over with representative of the Belarusian Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Spain Olesya Slizheva. \nAt the meeting, Jose Luis Kaiser was provided with the bilateral trade statistics. The growth of Belarusian exports to Spain exceeded 12% in 2017. \nThe parties confirmed their interest in developing the legal framework of the bilateral relations. Apart from the signed agreements on cooperation in tourism, economic and industrial cooperation, the two countries are completing the ratification of the convention on the avoidance of double taxation, and also working on the agreements on international road transportation, cooperation in the field of accreditation, mutual protection of investments, and an agreement between the Justice Ministries of the two countries. \nPavel Latushko also met with Juan Lopez Herrera, Director General of Bilateral Relations with European Union Countries at the Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs. "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-22T15:22:00.000+02:00", "title": "Belarus-Russia Union State announces contest of young political scientists", "text": "vk ok t m An archive photo \nMINSK, 22 March (BelTA) \u2013 Students, postgraduates, graduates, and young scientists from Belarusian and Russian universities will take part in a contest of young political experts of the Belarus-Russia Union State at Belarusian State University, BelTA learned from the university's press service. \nThe contest includes two nominations: Main and Debut. The former features original articles that have never been published before. The latter refers to resumes, short summaries of conclusions of courseworks, bachelor's and master's theses. These papers must be written by one author and must be dedicated to the Union State, Belarus-Russia relations, integration processes in Eurasia with the participation of Russia and Belarus. The works may cover the topic from the standpoint of political science, economics, sociology, history, or philosophy. \nThe best academic papers will be commended by the state secretary of the Belarus-Russia Union State. The finalists will get invitations to a summer school at the Institute of Europe of the Russian Academy of Sciences in Moscow in July. The winners in the Main nomination will be able to participate in expert events held as part of information support for the Union State construction. Their works will be published in the leading scientific editions. \nThe contest is organized by Belarusian State University, the Institute of Europe of the Russian Academy of Sciences, the Russian-Belarusian Expert Club, and the \u201cEurasia. Expert\u201d analytical edition. The event is aimed at promoting research on the Union State, Belarus-Russia relations, and integration processes in Eurasia with the participation of Russia and Belarus.", "highlightText": "", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-20T16:36:00.000+02:00", "title": "Samarasinha: UN disability convention is changing society's view on this category of citizens", "text": "vk ok t m \nMINSK, 20 March (BelTA) - The Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is changing society's view on these people, UN Resident Coordinator/UNDP Resident Representative in Belarus Sanaka Samarasinha told the media in Minsk on 20 March. \n\u201cI have been in Belarus for more than five years already. During the first two years and a half I worked to get the convention signed and ratified. Then the focus shifted to raising the awareness of disability, fighting the stereotypes, social and economic barriers that get in the way of these people and prevent them to lead a decent life and realize their potential. The convention is changing the opinion of people on disability. Through the convention we try to show that people with disabilities have equal rights with us,\u201d Sanaka Samarasinha said. \nThe information strategy on the full inclusion of people with disabilities was developed in Belarus within the framework of the national plan of action to implement the provisions of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. A journalism contest for the excellence in reporting on disability will be held in Belarus from 20 March to 15 November. \u201cWe would like the contest to provoke more conversations about people with disabilities not only in Minsk but throughout the country. Therefore, we have given a few months to the journalists who will take part in the contest so that they could really get deep into the topic, embrace and understand people's stories,\u201d Sanaka Samarasinha noted. \nHe believes that this contest will also help journalists to cover the inclusion of people with disabilities in a more profound way. \u201cFirst and foremost, the target audience of the contest are the journalists themselves. They often present people with disabilities either as victims who need sympathy or as superheroes who we should admire. While people with disabilities want to be seen as ordinary people. I think that thanks to this contest the journalists will learn how to cover the topic more accurately and deeper,\" he said. \nAccording to the UN resident coordinator, the jury will include representatives of civil society, members of various organizations and people with disabilities. They will select the best entries in three categories: Best Journalistic Story, Best Photo Story, Best Video Story. The prize in each category will correspond to the professional activities of journalists. \u201cBut I think that the most important thing is not a material prize but the platform that will help journalists take their works to the international level: this is a very good opportunity to show their works and tell about the country,\u201d Sanaka Samarasinha said.", "highlightText": "", "published": "2018-03-24T03:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "Canadian cities hold March for our Lives events", "text": "MONTREAL -- More than a dozen Canadian cities hosted marches Saturday to call for stricter gun control laws in both Canada and the United States, adding their voices to a global movement calling for change in the wake of a high school shooting that left 17 people dead in Parkland, Fla.\nIn both Montreal and Toronto, several hundred people joined local events in support of the massive March for Our Lives rally in Washington, D.C., which was organized by American students pushing for stricter gun-control legislation in the wake of the tragedy.\nIn one of Montreal's two marches, hundreds of protesters swayed together, singing to the tune of \"Glory, Hallelujah,\" before setting off towards the city's U.S. Consulate.\nThey also seized the opportunity to ask Ottawa to ban assault weapons such as the AR-15 -- the rifle allegedly used in the deadly Florida shooting on Feb. 14.\nEllen Gozansky Malka, a Montrealer now living in Parkland, told the crowd that two of her children were at the school during the shooting and saw things no child should see.\n\"Our children should never fear going to school, and they should never jump at the sound of a book falling on the floor,\" she said to applause.\nA few blocks away, a slightly smaller event was organized by 11-year-old elementary school student Lexington Vickery, who led about 150 cheering classmates and supporters on a raucous march in support of American students.\n\"Its about making them feel better, and making them feel more supported and working to help them so they can have more courage to go to the government and get their gun legislation,\" the sixth-grader explained in an interview beforehand.\nIn Toronto, marchers carried signs protesting both gun violence in the United States and recent shootings that have plagued the city as they marched from a downtown square to the U.S. Consulate.\nJoan Howard, whose son Kempton was shot to death in 2003, said that while Canada doesn't experience mass shootings on the same scale as the U.S., it's hardly immune.\nShe pointed to several high profile Toronto shootings, including one where two people were shot and killed outside of a bowling alley -- one of the victims was allegedly targeted, and the other was described by police as a bystander.\n\"Look how much shooting we have of innocent people, (such as) those near the bowling alley,\" said Howard, who calls herself a member of the zero gun violence movement.\n\"These are innocent people. My colleagues are innocent, my son, all these kids are innocent.\"\nBodil Geyer, who organized the march in Vancouver, said hundreds of people showed up despite a fake Facebook event showing the wrong time.\n\"We had a great turnout, all things considered,\" she said.\nGeyer said the real event page was also peppered with pro-gun comments she believed were generated by bots or international users, because the grammar was often incorrect and some messages were threatening.\nWhile the march was largely a show of support for the American gun control movement, Geyer said gang violence in Surrey also makes it a local issue.\nAll of the speakers at the Vancouver event were students, said Geyer, who represents both Democrats Abroad Vancouver and March On Vancouver.\n\"The crowd was amazing, they were awe-inspired, everyone was quite emotional listening to these kids,\" she said.\nTens of thousands of people were expected to attend the march in Washington, D.C., with smaller gatherings to take place in hundreds of cities across the world.\nRallies were also planned in most major Canadian cities, including St. John's, Ottawa and Calgary.\nMelissa Hennig, a survivor of the Oct. 1 mass shooting at an outdoor concert in Las Vegas, joined about 150 people for a rally outside the Alberta legislature in Edmonton.\n\"While I don't know the ins and outs of assault rifles, I can tell you what it's like to be on the other end of one,\" the Edmonton-area woman told the crowd. She said it's difficult to talk about the \"terror, confusion and panic.\n\"I can tell you something more needs to be done -- something more than thoughts and prayers.\"\nWith files from Ben Singer and Nicole Thompson in Toronto, Rob Drinkwater in Edmonton and Amy Smart in Vancouver \nHundreds out for Ottawa's March for Our Lives rally @ctvottawa pic.twitter.com/dJwlTbUAp0 \n\u2014 Annie BergeronOliver (@AnnieClaireBO) March 24, 2018 McGill student Cyril Yared graduated from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High in Parkland FL. He\u2019s marching for #GunControl in downtown Mtl pic.twitter.com/gl4aA63hN9 \n\u2014 St\u00e9phane Giroux (@SGirouxCTV) March 24, 2018 March for #GunControl in support of #Parkland students now heading east of Ste-Catherine. Destination US consulate. pic.twitter.com/QL45Z6Htxi \n\u2014 St\u00e9phane Giroux (@SGirouxCTV) March 24, 2018 The #yeg turnout for the #MarchForOurLives . Sending their support to the victims of school shootings in Canada and the US.\n\nThe message here: \"Enough is enough\" @ctvedmonton pic.twitter.com/nfIaPMVrW9 \n\u2014 Nahreman Issa (@NahremanIssaCTV) March 24, 2018 March for our Lives event begins in Vancouver calling on US lawmakers to pass gun safety legislation @CTVVancouver pic.twitter.com/gdodvPdmdC \n\u2014 Michele Brunoro (@ctv_michele) March 24, 2018 Families taking part in the March for our Lives rally in Vancouver. @CTVVancouver pic.twitter.com/6EZAozvSfp \n\u2014 Michele Brunoro (@ctv_michele) March 24, 2018 Related Stories Gun control rally begins where the movement was sparked Jennifer Hudson, Paul McCartney join students' gun-reform rallies 'I have a dream that enough is enough': Americans march for gun control Parkland teens keep gun-control grown-ups at arm's length Photos People hold up signs during a 'March of Our Lives' rally to show solidarity with the U.S. gun control movement in Montreal, Saturday, March 24, 2018. "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "cbc", "published": "2018-03-24T22:24:00.000+03:00", "title": "Gun control rallies being held in over a dozen Canadian cities in support of March for Our Lives", "text": "More than a dozen Canadian cities hosted marches to call for stricter gun control laws in both Canada and the United States in the wake of a deadly high school shooting that killed 17 people in Parkland, Fla.\nIn both Montreal and Toronto, several hundred people joined local events in support of the massive March for Our Lives rally in Washington, D.C. , which was organized by American students calling for change in the wake of the tragedy.\n\nMarch for Our Lives: Crowds gather across U.S., world for student-led gun control rallies Protesters across U.S. and beyond rally for gun control \nIn one of Montreal's two marches, hundreds of protesters swayed together singing Glory, Hallelujah  before setting off towards the city's U.S. consulate.\nEllen Gozansky Malka, a Montrealer now living in Parkland, told the crowd that two of her children were at the school during the shooting and saw things no child should see.\nElementary school students in Montreal's Westmount rally for tighter gun control measures. (Sarah Leavitt/CBC)\nA few blocks away, a slightly smaller rally was organized by Grade 6 student Lexington Vickery, 11, who led about 150 cheering classmates and supporters as they weaved their way through Westmount on Saturday morning. \n\"I feel like today I've made a really big difference,\" Lexington told CBC News as the march neared Dawson College, the site of a 2006 mass shooting.\n'Arms are for hugging,' Montreal students say at march for tighter gun control measures \nLexington marched alongside children and parents from the English Montreal School Board, which shared news of the event in its monthly newsletter.\n\"I like that almost everyone who came is helping a little bit more to support people who have been affected by the shooting,\" she said.\nMany attendees bore signs that read slogans like \"arms are for hugs\" and \"books not bullets,\" Lexington said.\nHundreds of people gathered in downtown Toronto by midday Saturday to show their support for the cause. (Natalie Nanowski/CBC)\nIn Toronto, marchers carried signs protesting both gun violence in the U.S. and recent shootings that have plagued the city, pointing out that Canada is not immune to tragedy.\nDemonstrators began the 1.5-kilometre march from Nathan Phillips Square to Queen's Park.\n'No more silence': Hundreds rally in Toronto for tighter U.S. gun controls \nAlong the way, organizers held a moment of silence in front of the U.S. consulate for the victims of the Florida shooting killed on Valentine's Day.\n\"I think it's important to have this march today in solidarity with students in the United States because gun violence is taking its toll on families, individuals, communities across North America\u2026,\" said Louis March, a co-founder of Toronto's Zero Gun Violence Movement.\n\"We can do better.\"\nA former Parkland student, who plays hockey at the University of Calgary, and his teammates were some of the over 200 people that attended the March for Our Lives in Calgary in front of the U.S. consulate.\n\"Heartbreaking is not a strong enough word,\" said Matthew Greenfield, recalling the Feb. 14 mass shooting at his former high school.\nGreenfield remembered one of the victims, assistant football coach and security guard Aaron Feis, who died after throwing himself in front of students to shield them from bullets.\nFormer Parkland student voices 'gut-wrenching' heartbreak at Calgary march for gun control \n\nIn Vancouver, Democrats Abroad Vancouver and March on Vancouver held a rally, which began at 10 a.m. PT at Jack Poole Plaza with speeches by students. Protesters walked to the U.S. consulate before returning to the plaza. \nVancouver students stage March for our Lives rally to protest gun violence \"The gun violence epidemic in America touches both Americans and Canadians living in Vancouver,\" said spokesperson Bodil Geyer in a release.\n\"You can't just stand silently and watch your neighbour go through a crisis like this.\" \nOttawa's rally was organized by students from high schools across the city. \nAinsley Skelly, a Grade 11 student at Nepean High School and one of the organizers, said, \"We want to show other students, Americans, that we're with them \u2014 and we want to march alongside them.\"\n\"We want to send a message to politicians that they need to do something, you know. No more thoughts and prayers. We need to take action.\"\nOttawa students to rally against U.S. gun violence Elsewhere in Ontario, the Waterloo region's rally took place at Wilfrid Laurier University. \nHundreds of thousands of people attended the march in Washington, D.C., with smaller gatherings held in over 800 cities across the world.\n\nWith files from CBC News \u00a9 The Canadian Press, 2018", "highlightText": "", "Gun control rallies held in over a dozen Canadian cities in support of March for Our Lives Over 800 demonstrations worldwide called for change in the wake of the Florida school massacre The Canadian Press Posted: Mar 24, 2018 2:24 PM ET Last Updated: Mar 25, 2018 9:12 AM ET Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School student Delaney Tarr speaks at the March for Our Lives rally in Washington on Saturday. (AFP/Getty Images) Related Stories Protesters across U.S. and beyond rally for gun control \nMore than a dozen Canadian cities hosted marches to call for stricter gun control laws in both Canada and the United States in the wake of a deadly high school shooting that killed 17 people in Parkland, Fla. \nIn both Montreal and Toronto, several hundred people joined local events in support of the massive March for Our Lives rally in Washington, D.C. , which was organized by American students calling for change in the wake of the tragedy. Protesters across U.S. and beyond rally for gun control \nIn one of Montreal's two marches, hundreds of protesters swayed together singing Glory, Hallelujah before setting off towards the city's U.S. consulate. \nEllen Gozansky Malka, a Montrealer now living in Parkland, told the crowd that two of her children were at the school during the shooting and saw things no child should see. Elementary school students in Montreal's Westmount rally for tighter gun control measures. (Sarah Leavitt/CBC) \nA few blocks away, a slightly smaller rally was organized by Grade 6 student Lexington Vickery, 11, who led about 150 cheering classmates and supporters as they weaved their way through Westmount on Saturday morning. \n\"I feel like today I've made a really big difference,\" Lexington told CBC News as the march neared Dawson College, the site of a 2006 mass shooting. \n'Arms are for hugging,' Montreal students say at march for tighter gun control measures \nLexington marched alongside children and parents from the English Montreal School Board, which shared news of the event in its monthly newsletter. \n\"I like that almost everyone who came is helping a little bit more to support people who have been affected by the shooting,\" she said. \nMany attendees bore signs that read slogans like \"arms are for hugs\" and \"books not bullets,\" Lexington said. Hundreds of people gathered in downtown Toronto by midday Saturday to show their support for the cause. (Natalie Nanowski/CBC) \nIn Toronto, marchers carried signs protesting both gun violence in the U.S. and recent shootings that have plagued the city, pointing out that Canada is not immune to tragedy. \nDemonstrators began the 1.5-kilometre march from Nathan Phillips Square to Queen's Park. \n'No more silence': Hundreds rally in Toronto for tighter U.S. gun controls \nAlong the way, organizers held a moment of silence in front of the U.S. consulate for the victims of the Florida shooting killed on Valentine's Day. \n\"I think it's important to have this march today in solidarity with students in the United States because gun violence is taking its toll on families, individuals, communities across North America\u2026,\" said Louis March, a co-founder of Toronto's Zero Gun Violence Movement. \n\"We can do better.\" \nA former Parkland student, who plays hockey at the University of Calgary, and his teammates were some of the over 200 people that attended the March for Our Lives in Calgary in front of the U.S. consulate. \n\"Heartbreaking is not a strong enough word,\" said Matthew Greenfield, recalling the Feb. 14 mass shooting at his former high school. \nGreenfield remembered one of "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "CTV Montreal", "published": "2018-03-24T03:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "Irish Embassy pub severely damaged in fire Montreal", "text": "The Irish Embassy bar on Bishop St. was severely damaged in an early morning five-alarm fire on Saturday.\nFirefighters received a call at 5:20 a.m. reporting smoke coming out of the building\u2019s third floor. When they arrived, the third floor was completely engulfed in fire.\n\"The fire started on the third floor of the same building as the Irish Embassy pub,\" said fire department chief of operations Danny Ciavaglia. \"The damage is extensive to the three-story building.\"\nCiavaglia said while the third floor was totally destroyed, it was unclear if the rest of the building would be salvageable. \n\"The way a building is designed and the materials used will all affect the way a fire will spread throughout a building,\" said Ciavaglia. \"Seeing as this one was very old and probably renovated numerous amounts of times made it very difficult to open up and make sure the fire is out.\"\nMore than 150 firefighters were deployed to the scene. One firefighter was taken to hospital with injuries but Ciavaglia said their life did not appear to be in danger. \nThe fire spread to two buildings north of the bar and 10 people were evacuated and are being tended to by the Red Cross. \nRed Cross spokesperson Stephanie Picard said seven of those people have been given housing, food and clothing to help them through the next few days, but said she expected the rest to be in touch within the day. \n\"Everybody goes through this differently but it's very difficult,\" she said. \"You're eating breakfast, or you're still sleeping, you get woken up by the fire department who do a great job of getting you out of your home but you're out on the street, it's cold and you don't know where you're going to be sleeping that night.\"\nMichel Desjardins, who lives across the street from the bar, said he was woken by his dog barking.\n\u201cI could see an orange and red reflection in my window, so I went out,\u201d he said. \u201cYou could see flames coming out of the windows on the second floor, it was really blazing hard.\u201d\nFirefighters said they have yet to determine the cause of the fire.\nPolice have closed off Bishop St. and said it\u2019s likely the road will remain closed for most of the day. \nPhotos Bishop St. bar Irish Embassy was severely damaged in an early morning fire on Sat., March 24, 2018. When Belisle answered in the negative, Jean Gilles responded that the crime for which he was charged was municipal-related.\nThe four-year term will begin once Jean Gilles' current sentence for assaulting a police officer expires. He is eligible for parole in July in that case.\nBelisle said the dog attack was not a \"one-off incident but rather part of repeated behaviour that has been going on for years.\"\n\"The table was set for a tragedy,\" the judge said. \"The problem wasn't so much if the tragedy would occur but rather when it would happen.\"\nThe conviction carried a maximum 10-year prison term.\nMagdalena Biron said during the trial the attack in a park left her daughter Vanessa with fractures to the cranium and hand, as well as a cheekbone broken in seven places. She still has scars on her face.\nHer partner, Bernard Biron, said at the time Vanessa did not bear any grudges, even though the attack left her unable to eat solid food for months.\n\"She had to go to school with a device connected to her veins because her brain was infected,\" he said. \"Because her skull was crushed in the back and the saliva of the dog infected her system.\"\nIn a brief statement on the last day of his trial, Jean Gilles suggested to Belisle his animal might have been provoked.\nThe judge rejected the claim.\nThe dogs -- another of Jean Gilles' dogs was also at the park that day -- weren't wearing collars the day of the attack and were not on a leash, Belisle said. The accused's property was not adequately fenced in and he didn't have the ability to subdue the animals, the judge added.\nRelated Stories Accused at Quebec pit bull trial tells the court he won't testify Owner of pit bull-type dog found guilty Photos Magdalena Biron and Bernard Biron, whose daughter Vanessa was severely mauled by a pit bull-type dog, leave the courtroom in Longueuil, Que., on Feb. 20, 2018. Another 14 people were injured in the massacre, including Nathalie Provost, who sustained four gunshot wounds, including one to the forehead.\nOn Saturday, Provost joined hundreds of thousands of others in Washington D.C. for the March for Our Lives rally against gun violence.\n\u201cI had the feeling that it may be a historic moment,\u201d Provost said in a telephone interview with CTV News Channel on Saturday.\n\u201cIt was amazing because they believe in what they say and they are strong and courageous,\u201d she added, speaking of her fellow demonstrators, many of whom are demanding stricter gun-control laws in the U.S.\n\u201cThey have a very, very extraordinary determination to change the world and they believe they can do it.\u201d\nThe growing momentum behind the U.S. gun control movement should offer lessons to Canada, Provost said. For example, the Ruger Mini-14 -- the semi-automatic rifle used in the \u00c9cole Polytechnique massacre -- is still classified as a \u201cnon-restricted firearm\u201d in Canada, despite resembling an assault rifle.\n\u201cThe Liberals and all the politicians in Canada must have political courage to change our laws, and they are not strong enough now,\u201d Provost said. \u201cI think that even if we\u2019re not talking about the long gun registry, we can improve other things. We don\u2019t have any strong laws banning assault weapons.\u201d\nSuch weapons, Provost argues, should be banned altogether -- something protesters were also demanding in Washington.\n\u201cWe must show our support clearly to those kids in the United States,\u201d she added. \u201cAnd if they do something before us, shame on us.\u201d\nProvost says she was also heartened to meet fellow survivors at the march.\n\u201cThey want things to change,\u201d she said. \u201cThe \u2018never again\u2019 shout is very, very strong here.\u201d\nRelated Stories 'I will vote you out': Teens vow to shake up U.S. politics at gun control rallies Canadian cities hold March for our Lives events Jennifer Hudson, Paul McCartney join students' gun-reform rallies 'I have a dream that enough is enough': Americans march for gun control Gun control rally begins where the movement was sparked Photos Nathalie Provost poses for a photograph following a news conference at Ecole Polytechnique in Montreal, Friday, November 28, 2014. The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the US Department of Justice have resumed the discussion on technical and legal opportunities to access encrypted data from mobile phones and other gadgets, local media reported Saturday, citing sources. \nThe employees of the two agencies met with cybersecurity experts to find out whether it is possible to install software that would allow US authorities to view encrypted data on users' devices, The New York Times reported. \nFollowing the talks, officials concluded that such a mechanism could be created, and asserted that it would not make smartphones more vulnerable to hackers. \nSimultaneously, DOJ and FBI staff members have been negotiating with other departments the possibility of requesting that Congress adopt legislation to allow intelligence services to collect encrypted data from mobile devices. \u00a9 AP Photo/ Evan Vucci Twitter Ignites As Bannon Says 'Facebook Data Is For Sale' After statements made by former contractor of US National Security Agency ( NSA ) Edward Snowden, who disclosed a number of US surveillance programs in 2013 and was forced to flee the United States, the conflict escalated between the FBI and other US government departments on the use of data encryption on mobile devices.\nIn 2016, IT giants such as Google, Facebook , Apple and Microsoft filed lawsuits demanding the right to notify customers if access to their emails was given to third parties, including US intelligence agencies. \nAccording to media reports, the fight against encryption technology on mobile devices was one of the priorities of former FBI Director James Comey, who was dismissed by US President Donald Trump in May 2017. ... year", "text": "Akash Ambani and Shloka Mehta will tie the knot later this year Akash Ambani, the eldest son of India\u2019s richest man Mukesh Ambani, on Saturday proposed to Shloka Mehta in Goa, it is learnt. The wedding will happen in Mumbai later this year.\nShloka Mehta is the daughter of Russell Mehta, who heads Rosy Blue Diamonds, one of the country\u2019s leading diamond companies. The Ambanis and Mehtas know each other well. Akash and Shloka are alumni of the famed Dhirubhai Ambani International School (DAIS), in the Bandra Kurla Complex in Mumbai.\nAkash and Shloka are seen during a pre-engagement ceremony in Goa After schooling at DAIS, Akash studied at Brown University, a private Ivy League institution based in Rhode Island, and among the most prestigious in the US. On her part, post-schooling at DAIS in 2009, Shloka left for the US to study anthropology at Princeton University and later completed her Masters in Law from the London School of Economics and Political Science.\nAkash and Shloka\u2019s wedding rumours have been rife for quite some time with both families keeping the news under wraps.\nWhile Akash is on the board of Reliance Jio, Shloka is a Director with Rosy Blue Foundation and is a co-founder of ConnectFor, an organisation that helps NGOs get volunteers for various causes.\nAkash and Shloka are alumni of the famed Dhirubhai Ambani International School (DAIS), in the Bandra Kurla Complex in Mumbai. Mumbai Teenager Stabbed 54 Times By Friend For Speaking Only In English! SAVE \nFelt mocked by his friend who only spoke to him in English, which he couldn't understand, a 21-year-old Mumbai youth stabbed his 18-year-old friend to death. \nThe incident happened on Thursday in Mumbai\u2019s Bandra. The accused, Mohammed Amir Abdul Wahid Rahin slit the throat of his friend Mohammed Afroz Alam Shaikh and stabbed him 54 times, in a fit of rage, for being mocked by the latter. \nAccording to Rahin, he had been plotting the murder for sometime now, after being fed up with everyday mocking by Shaikh for his lack of knowledge in English. \nRahin told the cops that Shaikh only spoke to him In English, knowing well that he did not understand the language. \nOn the day of the crime, Rahin took Shaikh out for a drink and when the victim went to the toilet the accused followed him and slit his throat with a knife and stabbed him multiple times. \nRahin then went to the Shahu Nagar police station and confessed he had killed his friend. Written by Sana Farzeen | Mumbai | Updated: March 24, 2018 11:37 pm Bishal Sharma took home Rs 15 lakh and winners trophy. \nSuper Dancer Chapter 2, which made history for being the longest-running single season of a dance reality show, has finally found its winner. After a live voting, Bishal Sharma was announced as the champion by judges Shilpa Shetty, Anurag Basu and Geeta Kapur on Saturday night. He beat three other finalists Ritik Diwaker, Vaishnavi Prajapati and Akash Thapa to take home the trophy. The 12-year-old, who hails from Assam, mesmerised the judges and had the maximum number of votes from the audience coming his way. The live voting turned out to be quite a record breaking one with million votes being registered. Along with a lot of goodies from sponsors, Bishal received a prize money of 15 lakh and a dazzling trophy, while his mentor received a cheque of Rs 5 lakh. \n12-year-old Bishal Sharma from Assam had been an adorable livewire in the show. Whenever the dynamic dancer took the stage, the judges and audience were enthralled. Bishal is an inquisitive young boy, always smiling and chattering away with his friends. Guided by Super Guru Vaibhav Ghuge, the super kid impressed all with his contemporary, hip-hop styles. \nThe finale episode also saw the presence of Bollywood youth sensation Varun Dhawan , who was there to promote his upcoming film October. The Student of the Year actor also shook a leg with judge Shilpa, that got the audience cheering for them. While the gala episode also saw Shilpa grooving to some peppy numbers and showing off her belly dance moves, Geeta in a breathtaking act paid a special tribute to yesteryear heroines. \nProduced by Frames Productions, Super Dancer 2 launched on September 30 and aired on Sony Entertainment Television. While Rithvik Dhanjani and Paritosh Tripathi hosted the show when it launched, with it getting an extension, Jay Bhanushali came in place of Rithvik, who had to quit the show owing to prior commitments. Even before the premiere, the show faced a major roadblock, when its set located at RK Studio was destroyed after a fire broke out. \nHere\u2019s wishing the young winner Bishal congratulations. Singapore, the world\u2019s most expensive city, leads the list, which was released earlier this month. TNN   09:32 IST Highlights Bengaluru holds the 129th spot in a list of 133 countries, ranked according to their cost of living Singapore, the world\u2019s most expensive city, leads the list, which was released earlier this month The survey is based on a comparison of more than 400 individual prices across 150 products and services BENGALURU: War-torn Damascus in Syria, picturesque Caracas, the capital of Venezuela, Almaty, former capital of Kazakhstan, and Nigerian metropolis Lagos are the only cities that are cheaper than Bengaluru, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit\u2019s Worldwide Cost of Living Survey 2018. Bengaluru holds the 129th spot in a list of 133 countries, ranked according to their cost of living. Singapore, the world\u2019s most expensive city, leads the list, which was released earlier this month. The survey is based on a comparison of more than 400 individual prices across 150 products and services. Two other Indian cities \u2014 Chennai (126) and New Delhi (124) \u2014 are among the 10 cheapest, while Mumbai is not too far behind at 121. While Damascus and Caracas are the cheapest because of the political scenario, cities in Asia, including Bengaluru, are structurally cheap, the report notes. Asia is home to some of the most expensive and cheapest cities, the survey found, with the continent continuing to provide the best value for money. While noting that India is tipped for rapid economic expansion, the report, however, said in per head terms, wage and spending growth will remain low. Singapore, the world\u2019s most expensive city, leads the list, which was released earlier this month.\nThe survey is based on a comparison of more than 400 individual prices across 150 products and services. Two other Indian cities \u2014 Chennai (126) and New Delhi (124) \u2014 are among the 10 cheapest, while Mumbai is not too far behind at 121.\nWhile Damascus and Caracas are the cheapest because of the political scenario, cities in Asia, including Bengaluru, are structurally cheap, the report notes. The crime took place on March 4 at their Kharghar flat. The accused is a homemaker and her husband a civil contractor. Two of their children\u2014the victim and a 12-year-old son\u2014lived with them in Kharghar while the other two\u2014a 20-year-old daughter and a 14-year-old son\u2014resided in their native hometown in Rajasthan. \n\nSenior inspector Dilip Kale said, \u201cThe accused allegedly strangulated her daughter with her dupatta inside their flat around 10.30am on March 4. At 1.45pm, her husband returned home for lunch. When he saw their daughter in the bedroom, his wife told him that she was fast asleep. Then, around 4pm, she called and informed him that their daughter was motionless. He rushed home to find her dead. By around 7pm, their relatives began to gather at their residence and called the police. Since there were strangulation marks on the girl\u2019s neck, we suspected foul play. Initially, we registered an accidental death case but sent her body for post-mortem to the Panvel rural hospital.\u201d \n\nKale further said, \u201cThe victim\u2019s parents took her body to their native place in Rajasthan where they conducted her last rites. Since the post-mortem report revealed the cause of death as choking, we registered a murder case and started a probe.\u201d \n\nCops recorded statements of the girl\u2019s schoolmates, one of whom said the victim had allegedly once told her that her mother had been assaulting her for the past six months as she suspected her of being in a sexual relationship with her father. Her mother had threatened to either kill her or her husband. \n\nThe schoolmates told cops that the girl had allegedly attempted suicide by consuming phenyl in February and had made up her mind to jump from her building\u2019s terrace, saying she was unable to bear the harassment by her mother. \n\nAfter the victim\u2019s parents returned from Rajasthan on Wednesday, they were summoned to the police station where the woman was grilled. She confessed to the crime and said her daughter always answered back and even hit her on being scolded. \u201cWhen the accused beat her up a day after the festival of Holi, the girl retaliated and her mother ended up strangulating her with a dupatta,\u201d said Kale and added that they are exploring the possibility of the father protecting the accused despite learning of the crime. \n\n\u201cWe will probe his role in the crime. As of now, we have registered an FIR under the Indian Penal Code\u2019s Section 302 (punishment for murder) against the accused woman. Shami,\" the release further stated.\nThe BCCI top brass had always maintained that they will not sit in judgement about Shami's personal life. Times of India", "text": "MUMBAI: For the first time in two decades, at least 80 newly hatched Olive ridley turtles were spotted at Versova beach on Thursday morning, waddling towards the sea. \nEnvironmentalists attributed the \u201chappy phenomenon\u201d to the sustained efforts by lawyer-activist Afroz Shah and his team over 127 weeks to clean Versova beach. \n\n\u201cThis is indeed very good news for our Versova beach. The 80 Olive ridley turtles hatched in the morning and made a dash towards the sea,\u201d said Shah. \u201cEarlier, this beach was very dirty, with piles of plastic trash. No sea turtles were hatching here as garbage is a huge hurdle for them to cross. But now, thanks to the Clean Versova Beach drive, we are all happy and blessed to have seen these newly hatched Olive ridley turtles.\u201d \n\n\nClean-up activists and animal welfare groups together ensured that the little turtles navigated their way into the sea safely, from the hatching site, which was 30-35m from the shoreline. \n\n\n\nAs news of the newly hatched turtles spread, morning walkers and locals thronged the beach to enjoy the experience. \n\n\n\nSocial networking sites, including Twitters, were also abuzz with photographs and videos of the newly hatched turtles. \u201cI have witnessed something surreal today. A life changing experience. 80 Olive Ridley turtles walking back into the sea,\u201d tweeted Shaunak Modi of Marine Life of Mumbai, a group promoting marine life welfare in the city. \n\n\n\nState chief conservator of forests (mangroves cell) N Vasudevan said the department was happy to see the photographs and videos of the turtles on Versova beach. He, however, said: \u201cSome locals, who later went to the beach, informed my department that they could not find any egg shells. I do not know if their doubts are real or not, but if we get any formal intimation on it, I will have to inquire into the matter.\u201d \n\nShah added that a Mumbai-based forest official also came to the beach in the afternoon to do a panchanama after being informed about turtle hatchings. \u201cFor the last few weeks, we had been noticing turtles coming up to the Versova beach and digging into the sand, near Sagar Kutir wadi end. We had also contacted a marine biologist to learn more about it and are today happy that so many turtles hatched,\u201d Shah told TOI. \n\nEnvironmentalist D Stalin said: \u201cThis is a very good development at the cleaned up Versova beach. However, care should be taken that the lights at the beach are made dimmer and the area cordoned off till the nesting period is fully over, as human poachers are a threat for these turtles. Also, bright lights may confuse the young hatchlings.\u201d \n\nThe return of turtles has brought cheer among marine biologists who lament that nearly 80-90% of beaches in Maharashtra have been damaged to such an extent that it becomes unfavourable for Olive ridley turtles to lay their eggs. \n\n\u201cWhile today is certainly a day of celebration since Olive ridley turtles nesting and hatchings have been seen after a very long time period, I cannot help but think of so many other beaches which have been damaged and destroyed due to encroachments and other illegal activities which make it impossible for these sea turtles to step on for their natural nesting,\u201d pointed out Dr Deepak Apte, marine biologist and head of Bombay Natural History Society. \n\nBarely 30- 35 isolated beaches on the Konkan coast are currently hosting their nesting. \u201cThe females lay their eggs above the high tide line, in a sandy shore. How many such sandy shores are really there? Often people illegally steal sand or put up hawking stalls on beaches.\u201d \n\nHe, however, added that it is commendable that consistent efforts by the citizens to clean Versova beach have led to this rare turtle nesting site there.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "afroz shah", "sentiment": "none"}, "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-23T04:08:00.000+03:00", "title": "Sustainable drive on the dream road: the MINI Countryman Panamericana Plug-In Hybrid.", "text": "Sustainable drive on the dream road: the MINI Countryman Panamericana Plug-In Hybrid.   An exclusive version of the MINI Cooper S E Countryman ALL4 kicks off a long-haul journey from North America to Tierra del Fuego, unveiled at the 2018 New York International Auto Show. MINI Countryman PressClub Africa, DOM, East Europe PressClub Canada PressClub Romania German and English language version available. Photos will follow on March 26th. \nMunich / New York. At the New York International Auto Show (March 30 through April 8, 2018), MINI-style electro mobility will conquer new terrain with the presentation of an exclusive model specially designed for extremely challenging routes. With its underpinnings taken from the brands first plug-in hybrid vehicle, the MINI Countryman Panamericana has been designed for a long-distance tour from North America to Tierra del Fuego, showcasing the power and durability of the brand\u2019s largest model.Additional headlights, tires with emergency running characteristics and a roof rack for transporting a spare wheel will make the compact five-door fit for a road trip in a class of its own. Based on the MINI Cooper SE Countryman ALL4 (fuel consumption combined: 2.3 - 2.1 l / 100 km, combined power consumption: 14.0 - 13.2 kWh / 100 km, combined CO2 emissions from fuel: 52 - 49 g / km), the combined power and versatility of its two engines make it the perfect endurance athlete for the Panamericana adventure.Three MINI Countryman Panamericana Plug-In Hybrid vehicles will tackle the intercontinental route on the world's longest north-south road link. They will demonstrate the reliability and long-distance performance of the Plug-In Hybrid drive technology used in the MINI Cooper S Countryman ALL4.The Plug-In Hybrid drive of the MINI Cooper SE Countryman ALL4 is an effective contribution to reducing CO2 emissions in road traffic, even beyond urban environments. With a range of up to 40 kilometers, it can reach beyond the city limits and remain fully electric on longer routes. The intelligently coordinated interaction of the electric drive with the combustion engine combines the possibility of local emission-free driving with the freedom of a long range offered by a conventionally powered vehicle.The Panamericana, also known as Pan-American Highway, Ruta Panamericana or Interamericana depending on the region and language, connects the US state of Alaska with the Argentinean Tierra del Fuego and runs between the northernmost and the southernmost point over a distance of about 25,750 kilometers. In both North and South America, numerous intersections and alternative routes are part of the Panamericana road network, covering a total length of more than 48,000 kilometers. In the border area between Panama and Colombia, a ship passage is necessary to continue the journey, as an originally planned section of about 90 kilometers in length, inter alia, to protect the local rainforest area was not completed. The drive over the historic dream road leads through diverse climatic zones, dense jungle and challenging high mountain passes. In addition to well-developed highways, gravel roads and narrow mountain passages are part of the route network that the three MINI Countryman Panamericana Plug-In Hybrids will have to cope with.The MINI Cooper S Countryman ALL4 offers five full-size seats, generous luggage space and numerous comfort features, ensuring an enjoyable drive whatever the terrain. Its two engines generate a combined system output of 165 kW / 224 hp. The precise control of the interaction between the front and rear wheels with the electric motor also ensures intelligent all-wheel drive. From rainy roads to sandy surfaces, gravel tracks or snow-covered mountain passages, the MINI Countryman Panamericana Plug-In Hybrid will tackle them all. Coverage from the journey will be available through the MINI News Instagram Channel at: www.instagram.com/mini.news The BMW Group \nWith its four brands BMW, MINI, Rolls-Royce and BMW Motorrad, the BMW Group is the world\u2019s leading premium manufacturer of automobiles and motorcycles and also provides premium financial and mobility services. The BMW Group production network comprises 31 production and assembly facilities in 14 countries; the company has a global sales network in more than 140 countries.In 2017, the BMW Group sold over 2,463,500 passenger vehicles and more than 164,000 motorcycles worldwide. The profit before tax in the financial year 2016 was approximately \u20ac 9.67 billion on revenues amounting to \u20ac 94.16 billion. As of 31 December 2016, the BMW Group had a workforce of 124,729 employees. The success of the BMW Group has always been based on long-term thinking and responsible action. The company has therefore established ecological and social sustainability throughout the value chain, comprehensive product responsibility and a clear commitment to conserving resources as an 0, "author": "pr-gateway", "published": "2018-03-24T02:16:00.000+03:00", "title": "How can ceramic brake discs be cheaply resurfaced?", "text": "How can ceramic brake discs be cheaply resurfaced? \nRebrake offers resurfaced ceramic brakes in all sizes from 1,050 EUR High-tech materials are standard. \nHigh-tech materials are standard in high HP sports cars. The problem: even the most high-end body includes consumable parts that must be renewed from time to time. Ceramic brake discs are some of the most effective yet most expensive consumable parts. The company FOXX Automotive Components from We\u00dfling to the west of Munich has developed a special process that not only matches the performance of the original carbon ceramic brakes , but exceeds it. Rebrake offers an effective process for both types of ceramic brake discs as well as CCB and CCM disks, whereby the brakes\u201c original performance is restored. Put simply, the process restores the extremely robust surface, i.e. the thin top layer on the carbon ceramic brake disc. To ensure that this is achieved, the much thicker core of the ceramic brake disc can be retained to reduce costs compared with completely replacing with a new ceramic brake disc. These can quickly add up to 5,000 to 7,000 EUR or more, depending on manufacturer. \nFrom 1,050 EUR instead of 5,000 EUR for a fully restored ceramic brake disc \nCeramic brake discs come in two different types with different diameters. Rebrake offers a tried and tested resurfacing process for all variants. This restores the special surface of the ceramic brake disc, physically connecting this with the core to form one unit. This is achieved through chemical thermal processes, the most significant being \u201epyrolysis\u201c. At 1,100 degrees Celsius, carbon polymers can be concentrated on the top layer of the ceramic brake disc. \nRebrake: resurfaced ceramic brake discs with a guarantee \nEven if this layer is just a millimetre thick, it\u201cs still very resistant to heat and abrasion. The ceramic brake discs with larger diameters are understandably more expensive to restore than smaller discs. It is somewhat cheaper to resurface CCM discs from Aston Martins, Corvettes, Ferraris, Maseratis, McLarens and Nissans than the CCB brake discs used by Audi, Bentley, BMW, Lamborghini and Porsche. Depending on diameter, prices range from 1,050 EUR to 1,350 EUR plus VAT. Rebrake provides a 12-month guarantee for all resurfaced ceramic brake discs. \nRebrake is the specialists in refurbishing ceramic brakes. The company can used and worn ceramic brakes discs can be refurbished. REBRAKE gives refurbished brake discs the best properties. \nContact", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [], "organizations": [{"name": "ccb", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "foxx automotive components", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "ccm", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "munich", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "we\u00dfling", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-24T04:19:06.005+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "75a5247ea4591cd935845e27461783d7d72a81a3", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZRLwMPjlwq0jSV1ROPWzmAY1PLbmjiMwGnuoB1etQRlmcSaC69kWqm_rUGZ0sODM4dZopBCy6bkpL.bAPgrKQwd0fbBXZMX_sr2pLmofG5.oQ--", "site_full": "www.avitrader.com", "site": "avitrader.com", "site_section": "http://www.avitrader.com/feed", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "AviTrader Aviation News", "title": "Around 250,000 flights on new MUC summer timetable", "title_full": "Around 250,000 flights on new MUC summer timetable", "published": "2018-03-22T21:36:00.000+02:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "DE", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "", "performance_score": 0, "domain_rank": null, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 0, "comments": 0, "shares": 0}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "75a5247ea4591cd935845e27461783d7d72a81a3", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZRLwMPjlwq0jSV1ROPWzmAY1PLbmjiMwGnuoB1etQRlmcSaC69kWqm_rUGZ0sODM4dZopBCy6bkpL.bAPgrKQwd0fbBXZMX_sr2pLmofG5.oQ--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Heike Tamm", "published": "2018-03-22T21:36:00.000+02:00", "title": "Around 250,000 flights on new MUC summer timetable", "text": "March 22, 2018 \nThe new Munich Airport summer timetable will start on March 25th: 91 airlines have booked slots for over 250,000 scheduled flights to 246 destinations in 68 countries. In addition to 17 German airports and 179 medium-range routes, scheduled services will be available to 50 intercontinental destinations. The summer period will continue through to Saturday, October 27, 2018. \nThis summer, passengers in Munich will benefit from additions by Lufthansa and its subsidiary, Eurowings, to the range of destinations served. The decision by Lufthansa to station five A380 jets \u2013 currently the world\u2019s largest passenger plane \u2013 at its Munich hub represents a substantial increase in capacity. From the start of the new summer timetable, Lufthansa will offer daily departures with the giant Airbus to the Asian cities of Hong Kong and Beijing and to Los Angeles. Lufthansa is resuming services to Singapore, departing five times a week with modern Airbus A350 aircraft. It is also adding three new weekly flights to Chicago, bringing the total to 10. There will no longer be services to Riyadh and Tehran, however. Along with the new intercontinental services, Lufthansa is making major additions to its European and domestic routes this summer, offering 219 more weekly departures from Munich than in the summer of 2017. \nWith the start of the new timetable, budget airlines will also operate long-haul services in Munich for the first time, with the Lufthansa subsidiary Eurowings offering a number of attractive intercontinental connections from the Bavarian capital. The low-cost carrier will operate flights to Bangkok, Cancun, Fort Myers, Las Vegas, Mauritius, Montego Bay, Punta Cana and Puerto Plata, along with Varadero and Windhoek. \nEurowings is expanding its European services, too. With the addition of 20 weekly flights to Palma de Mallorca, it will depart from Munich for the Spanish holiday hotspot 26 times per week. On domestic routes, the budget carrier is adding a total of 100 departures per week to Dortmund, D\u00fcsseldorf, Hamburg and Cologne/Bonn. In total, Eurowings will offer 140 more flights per week in Munich than in last year\u2019s summer timetable period. \nThe Estonian airline Nordica will fly daily to Groningen in the Netherlands along with its daily service to Tallinn. The new summer timetable also includes the first-ever non-stop flight from Munich to Denmark\u2019s second-biggest city, Aarhus. The service will be offered by SAS. The Spanish airline Volotea is adding Saragossa to its routes served from Munich for the first time. The Norwegian carrier Wideroe will celebrate its debut in Munich: It will operate three weekly flights with Embraer 190 E2 to Bergen on the south-west coast of Norway. Cyprus Airways is making a comeback in Munich with a weekly flight to the Cypriot port city of Larnaca. Croatia Airlines will serve Dubrovnik on the Adriatic coast five times per week. \nThe Russian cargo airline AirBridgeCargo is doubling its capacity in Munich: With the start of the summer timetable, jumbo freighter service will fly back and forth between Munich and Moscow four times instead of twice a week as before.
