"published": "2018-03-23T03:12:00.000+03:00", "title": "Mass whale stranding leaves dozens dead at remote West Australian beach", "text": "Mass stranding of 150 whales at Hamelin Bay near Augusta sparks shark alert Updated March 23, 2018 23:28:08 Map: Hamelin Bay 6288 \nMore than 140 whales are dead after a mass stranding at Hamelin Bay, 315 kilometres south of Perth, sparked a shark advice alert for the area and a major rescue operation. \nAbout 150 whales were spotted on the beach by a fisherman about 6:00am on Friday after washing up about one kilometre north of the boat ramp at the beach, 10 kilometres north of Augusta. \nAlmost all of the mammals \u2014 short-finned pilot whales weighing between 1-4 tonnes \u2014 have now died, with six survivors helped back out to sea late in the afternoon. \nAuthorities used large cranes with slings to transport the whales about 1 kilometre down the beach. \nPeople cheers, clapped and hugged as the surviving whales swam out to sea. \nVolunteers \u2014 many of them just regular beachgoers who wanted to help \u2014 swam into the water with the mammals to try to encourage them back into the water. \nOne whale got caught on rocks as it tried to swim back to shore, but wetsuit-clad rescuers plunged into the cold water to push it to safety. \nShannon Stent was one of the volunteers who worked to try to save the whales. \n\"Most of us have been there all day,\" he said. \n\"We're focussing on the positives \u2026 we're doing all we can.\" Photo: The vast majority of the stranded whales could not be saved. (Supplied: Leaarne Hollowood) \nSpeaking earlier, Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions (DBCA) incident controller Jeremy Chick said the welfare of the surviving whales was the priority. \n\"Unfortunately, most of the whales beached themselves on dry land overnight and have not survived,\" he said earlier. \n\"There are only [a few] surviving in shallow waters. \n\"Rescue operations will be hampered by deteriorating, weather conditions and we need to ensure the safety of everyone involved.\" \nVisitor service coordinator Ben Tannock said people were being asked to keep well clear of the animals. \nAn incident management team including veterinarians spent the day on site. \n\"We're obviously managing the animals and the palliative care of those animals, and the rescue of the animals that are still alive, if possible,\" Mr Tannock said. Photo: One of about 150 pilot whales that have beached themselves at Hamelin Bay near Augusta. (Supplied: Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions) Race against time before ex-cyclone approaches \nMr Tannock said while their efforts were focused on the whales, it was also a big job to manage the public who had gathered at the scene. \n\"Obviously in these certain incidents there's high requirement to manage the public interaction as well,\" he said. \n\"It becomes quite an emotive issue and the public will themselves want to get involved. \n\"It is certainly terrific to have them on site, but they need to work under the guidance of Parks and Wildlife Services staff and make sure the incident is controlled and managed properly.\" Photo: It is estimated more than 150 whales have stranded themselves at Hamelin Bay, near Augusta. (Supplied: Leaarne Hollowood) \nHamelin Beach is closed from Hamelin Caravan Park to North Point including Grace Road and Reserve Road. External Link: Tropical Cyclone Marcus \nDBCA said that could make the rescue effort a race against the clock. \nSurfers who had been looking forward to the super swell have also been warned by the Fisheries Department the whales are expected to attract sharks. Photo: The whales beached themselves about 300 kilometres south of Perth. (Supplied: Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions) \n\"It is possible the dead and dying animals will act as an attractant, which could lead to sharks coming close in to shore along this stretch of coast,\" the alert said \n\"While it's not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Western Australian coast throughout the year, people should exercise additional caution until the stranding incident is resolved.\" \nSurf Life Saving WA have tweeted that a three-metre shark of unknown species has been spotted in the area. Big job to remove dozens of carcasses \nThe DBCA is working with the Shire of Augusta-Margaret River to remove the dead whales from the beach. \nDNA samples are being taken from the deceased whales to try to determine why the whales became stranded. \nIt will be the local shire's responsibility to dispose of the whale carcasses, which are already creating a powerful smell. Photo: Dead whales lie on the beach at Hamelin Bay after a mass stranding. (ABC News: Megan Morris) \nDBCA wildlife officer Pia Courtis said the team was waiting on an excavator to arrive at the beach to be able to save the whales which are still alive. \nDozens of volunteers and wildlife officers will remain there overnight, or for as long as it takes to move the whales to the boat ramp and safely push them back out to sea. \n\"The plan is to get the excavator down here and move the live ones to an area closer to the boat ramp,\" Ms Courtis said. \"Hopefully we'll refloat them and send them back out as a group.\" \nShe said they had no indication of when that might be. \n\"At the moment we've got officers and volunteers down there and they're stabilising the whales,\" she said. \n\"Of course for us our biggest concern is them being out of the water and sunburn. So we've got them covered and we're trying to keep them as moist as we can.\" Photo: Rescuers at Hamelin Bay splash water on a beached whale to try to keep it alive. (ABC News: Megan Morris) Rescuers left distressed \nUK visitor Barrie Brickle said the scene on the beach earlier on Friday was distressing, as the whales repeatedly beached themselves after being pushed back to sea \n\"[Volunteers] seem to drag them up onto the beach, get them the right way up and then they seem to revive,\" he said. \n\"But the ones I've seen that are back in the water, they actually come back around and beach themselves again. \n\"I watched one of them - it happened three times but still it wouldn't go back to sea.\" Photo: At least half the whales have already died. (Supplied: Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions) Scene of previous strandings \nIn 2009, more than 80 pilot whales and dolphins died in a mass stranding at Hamelin Bay on the same day \u2014 March 23. More than 20 whales were also stranded in the South West town of Bunbury in 2015. \nThe biggest mass stranding of whales in WA was in Dunsborough in 1996, when 320 long-finned pilot whales beached themselves. \n\"The South West capes area has had a number of incidents over the years of stranding of short fin and long fin pilot whales, so they're a species that are common in terms of a stranding scenario,\" Mr Tannock said. \nShort-finned pilot whales can grow to up to 5.5 metres long and are occasionally seen in groups as large as several hundred, but more commonly travel in groups of less than 100. \nThey are brownish-grey to black with a pinkish-grey anchor shape on the undersides, and inhabit tropical and sub-tropical waters, according to DBCA.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "jeremy chick", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "hamelin bay", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "leaarne hollowood", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "department of fisheries", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "department of biodiversity", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "augusta", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "hamelin bay", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "perth", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T06:08:43.014+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "b99ced551250ff4f0e57f3e8e1c29d1ff62a9105", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg80.l2Zef1N_T6zeCFQfEmRi7zMxr5z2i.hp0SI6CFFVm_p_QJuinfcgggEWbR8SdgCVrI7xEhNWgmPrCkEglyMs.1_WsmDkMhvDC3Ehp5mg4LlUZQtNxtN", "site_full": "www.abc.net.au", "site": "abc.net.au", "site_section": "http://www.abc.net.au//news/feed/51120/rss.xml", "site_categories": ["music", "entertainment"], "section_title": "Just In", "title": "Do you think midwives are all women? Mr Wright is proof you're wrong", "title_full": "Do you think midwives are all women? Mr Wright is proof you're wrong", "published": "2018-03-25T01:33:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "AU", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "http://www.abc.net.au/news/image/9576396-16x9-700x394.jpg", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 1455, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 3132, "comments": 0, "shares": 3132}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "b99ced551250ff4f0e57f3e8e1c29d1ff62a9105", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg80.l2Zef1N_T6zeCFQfEmRi7zMxr5z2i.hp0SI6CFFVm_p_QJuinfcgggEWbR8SdgCVrI7xEhNWgmPrCkEglyMs.1_WsmDkMhvDC3Ehp5mg4LlUZQtNxtN", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Alisha O'Flaherty", "published": "2018-03-25T01:33:00.000+03:00", "title": "Do you think midwives are all women? Mr Wright is proof you're wrong", "text": "Map: Subiaco 6008 \nIn a profession dominated by women, Christian Wright is used to the occasional pregnant pause when he tells people he is a midwife. \nMr Wright is the first male midwife in the 25-year history of the Family Birth Centre at Perth's King Edward Memorial Hospital (KEMH). \n\"A lot of people are surprised initially \u2014 it's not something they expect \u2014 but they seem to love me, and I've had so many requests from other women asking for me to be their midwife and from their partners as well,\" he said. \n\"I think they appreciate my background, they appreciate me, I include them as part of the care. \n\"I recently did a research study on how we treat male partners and found that a lot of them feel excluded \u2026 so there's a big push that I do especially to try to include them as a family unit. \n\"So I don't really find any resistance.\" \nMr Wright comes from a background in emergency nursing and said being a midwife at the KEMH centre \u2014 designed for women with low-risk pregnancies who prefer to give birth in a home-like setting \u2014 was the best job he had done. \n\"We do all of their antenatal care and then we're on call 24 hours a day, and so we do their labour and birth as well,\" he said. \n\"Afterwards, we visit them in their home for up to five days and if they need any extra support we go longer. \n\"We come from this paradigm where it's like a marathon \u2014 it's not a medical event \u2014 it's a marathon that you train for and you get ready and you achieve it together. \n\"And at the end I'm just standing back and they are doing it, we've done our job and that's just really rewarding.\" From midwife to wedding guest \nMr Wright assisted in the delivery of Sonya McQuire's two children, two-year-old Archer and three-week-old Imogen. Photo: Mr Wright has become good friends with Sonya McGuire's family after the births of Archer and Imogen. (ABC News: Alisha O'Flaherty) \nMs McQuire said he was an \"amazing\" midwife and she never felt uncomfortable about his gender. \n\"We got questioned a bit when we were telling people. Family were really supportive, obviously it was our choice,\" she said. \n\"But we were never uncomfortable at all.\" \nMs McQuire said Mr Wright also helped to involve her husband, Jaime, in the birth. \n\"He doesn't quite get the whole birth thing, as a lot of males don't, but Christian really made him get involved and throughout the whole process made sure Jaime was comfortable with what we were hoping to achieve with the birth,\" she said. \n\"It would be good if there were more male midwives. It does make it more relatable to the partners and a better experience.\" \nMs McQuire said her family had developed a close relationship with Mr Wright after the birth of Archer, and he even attended their wedding last year. \n\"We consider him a good friend, not just a midwife,\" she said. The learning curve: 'It blew my mind' \nMr Wright, who has been named as one of the finalists in the 2018 WA Nursing and Midwifery Excellence Awards in the Graduate of the Year category, said he went into the profession with the aim of one day working in developing countries. \n\"I've worked in East Timor and I've done some work in remote areas in Australia, in communities, and I just love it,\" he said. Photo: Mr Wright says there is too much misunderstanding among men about midwifery. (ABC News: Alisha O'Flaherty) \n\"I love being with the community, with people in their setting \u2026 I just really love investing in people and seeing what they can achieve.\" \nMr Wright said he believed the reason so few men went into midwifery was because they did not understand it. \n\"It's a course taught by women, for women, about women, and I really struggled for the first six months,\" he said. \n\"But when I realised what I was learning, it blew my mind. \n\"I think if more guys understood what it was, they would be coming into it.\" Not just 'women's business' \nStatistics from the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia show that at the end of December, there were 40 men registered as a nurse and midwife in WA as their principal place of practice, and 467 across Australia. Natalie gave birth to her daughter at home, with only her husband to help. It wasn't an accident \u2014 it was her choice. Figures on the number of women choosing to freebirth are not collated, but researchers and midwives believe it's on the rise. \nAnother 17 men were registered as midwives alone across Australia, with none in WA. \nEdith Cowan University associate professor and associate dean of midwifery, Sara Bayes, said it was a profession that struggled to attract men, with some continuing to view it as \"women's business\". \n\"We probably have one or two per cohort in both of our programs here,\" Dr Bayes said. \n\"The guys who do come into it have a really strong reason for doing it, and that might be that they've had not such a great experience themselves, that they have a genuine wish to support women through a life changing experience or they have very practical reasons, like they might want to go and work for RFDS [the Royal Flying Doctor Service] and that is one of the skills that they need.\"", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "christian wright", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "wright", "sentiment": "negative"}], "organizations": [{"name": "kemh", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "king edward memorial hospital", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "perth", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-25T02:55:45.000+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "2aa7913586b5d46ca130670b6bf5a8d6f8d63465", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZS85jFjidQBhh0dPtJ2hgt5bArU0U5Y37wLxb.Tss8d.xNLLxuoubhRD76UmSjgHhOul4G9_ka51gvsunexYIgJ7dBwInSw_u_3rq5lUmvnIM5L.Eq1OvO7t.Uncq0ZJAI5xw.50oLC5y3RCfsAOp__IRezVpN31cayvjt_QtsnQw--", "site_full": "www.smh.com.au", "site": "smh.com.au", "site_section": "http://feeds.smh.com.au/rssheadlines/top.xml#", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "Sydney Morning Herald - Latest News", "title": "Qantas opens direct link to Europe with historic Perth-London flight", "title_full": "Qantas opens direct link to Europe with historic Perth-London flight", "published": "2018-03-24T07:42:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "AU", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://static.ffx.io/images/$width_800%2C$height_450/t_crop_auto/t_sharpen%2Cq_auto%2Cf_auto/18a231c0e9f5ee2f4167624f2934d8d0683ee16c", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 1534, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 1691, "comments": 0, "shares": 1691}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "2aa7913586b5d46ca130670b6bf5a8d6f8d63465", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZS85jFjidQBhh0dPtJ2hgt5bArU0U5Y37wLxb.Tss8d.xNLLxuoubhRD76UmSjgHhOul4G9_ka51gvsunexYIgJ7dBwInSw_u_3rq5lUmvnIM5L.Eq1OvO7t.Uncq0ZJAI5xw.50oLC5y3RCfsAOp__IRezVpN31cayvjt_QtsnQw--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Patrick Hatch", "published": "2018-03-24T07:42:00.000+03:00", "title": "Qantas opens direct link to Europe with historic Perth-London flight", "text": "Qantas opens direct link to Europe with historic Perth-London flight By Patrick Hatch Larger text size Very large text size Aviation history is set to be made on Saturday night as Qantas prepares to launch the first-ever non-stop commercial service connecting Australia and Europe. Flight QF9 is due to take off from Perth just before 7pm (10pm eastern time) and is expected to touch down in London just over 17 hours later. The flight will take about 17 hours and 20 minutes. Photo: Brent Winstone/ Qantas Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce said the service would change Australian aviation forever by connecting \u201cthe last two continents in the world that don\u2019t have a direct link\u201d. \u201cThis is a truly historic flight that opens up a new era of travel. For the first time, Australia and Europe have a direct air link,\u201d Mr Joyce said. \u201cThe original Kangaroo Route from Australia to London was named for the seven stops it made over four days back in 1947. Now we can do it in a single leap.\u201d Advertisement The service operated by Qantas\u2019 first four Boeing 787-9 Dreamliners saves about three hours by removing the need to stop over in places such as Dubai or Singapore. Qantas CEO Alan Joyce. Photo: Kate Geraghty The flight originates in Melbourne, with those passengers saving about an hour compared to other routes to London. At 14,498 kilometres the journey will be the world\u2019s third-longest service in operation. Qatar Airways\u2019 Doha to Auckland service spans 14,535 kilometres, while Air India\u2019s Delhi to San Francisco service can be shorter or longer than Qantas\u2019 new route (up to 15,127 kilometres) depending on which flight path it takes. Loading The Dreamliners carry up to 236 passengers, which is about half the number on the Airbus A380 Super Jumbos that have until now dominated travel between Australia and Europe, with 70 seats reserved for business and premium class customers. Rico Merkert, an aviation expert at the University of Sydney Business School, said Qantas was trying to attract lucrative corporate travellers with a product that was more comfortable and which saved them time. Qantas can charge more for this premium offering and improve profitability in its international operations, which has been its weakest business unit in recent years during a period of record-low international fares sparked by fierce competition. \u201cTwo hours is worth a lot of money to some of these business people,\u201d Professor Merket said. The Perth-London service will also be a testing ground for Qantas as it moves into an era of ultra-long haul flights. The carrier hopes to be flying non-stop from Sydney and Melbourne to destinations including London and New York by as soon as 2022. Those marathon journeys are beyond the range of Qantas\u2019 Dreamliners, and so the airline is looking to buy either Boeing\u2019s 777-8X or Airbus\u2019 A350-900. As it pushes air travel to unprecedented limits, Qantas is investigating how to alleviate the effects of endurance travel on passengers through a partnership with the Charles Perkins Centre\u2019s Sydney Medical School. Ten passengers will have their body movement and sleep activity monitored during the flight to test how specially designed lighting and the timing of meal services affects them. The reporter is travelling to London on QF9 as a guest of Qantas. "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "David Prestipino", "published": "2018-03-23T18:11:00.000+03:00", "title": "One-man WA band Old Young's named Australia's best distillery ... again", "text": "By David Prestipino 24 March 2018 \u2014 12:11pm Emerging Swan Valley distillery Old Young's has smoked the competition again, named best distillery in Australia for the second consecutive year.\nThe one-man band is orchestrated by former sports administrator and marketer James Young, who operates out of a 36sqm shed in the traditional winemaking region just north of Perth.\nThe craft spirits specialist was also awarded two gold medals at the 2018 Australian Distilled Spirit Awards in Melbourne, one for its Six Seasons Gin for the second year running and another for its Common Gin, a new product launched only last Monday.\nJames Young at his Swan Valley distillery and cellar door.\nPhoto: Supplied Entries from the 86 exhibitors were up 20 per cent on last year, with 297 in total, the majority (130) of which were gin, with 24 gold medals being awarded .\nOld Young's triumph is considerable given its short shelf life but James' bespoke concoctions have proved to be nothing but top shelf, the latest gongs among dozens of national and international accolades in its first two years.\nAdvertisement \"To win Australia\u2019s best distillery in our first year could be seen as beginners' luck,\" James said.\n\"By taking out the award again just shows that we\u2019re doing something right.\n\"My philosophy in starting Old Young's was to work smart, be local, embrace silly and get dirty.\"\nSo particular is James about the make-up of his spirits, he somehow persuaded growers in Italy to provide him with enough Tuscan junipers for his new Common Gin to be 100 per cent made from them.\nClearly the distillery's gamble with innovative spirits is paying off.\n\"Common Gin is a new, navy-strength (57.5 per cent), single botanical gin made solely from our Tuscan juniper,\" James said.\n\"We have quadruped the amount of juniper from our other gins \u2013 it\u2019s a gin for purists, awesome in a G&T and reflects the fascination people have with high quality, interesting spirits at the moment.\"\nJames purchased the mothballed former Wild Swan distillery in 2015 and launched Old Young's in May 2016.\nHe currently produces four very distinct vodkas and five flavour-filled gins, including the multi-award-winning Pavlova Vodka (which tastes as awesome as it sounds) and 1829 Gin.\nJames hopes the whirlwind success of the past two years translates into exposure and sales on the international scene.\nOn Saturday he flies to the US, where he hopes to defend Old Young's 2017 title for Best International Vodka at the American Distilling Institute Craft Spirit Awards.\nThere are also plans to expand operations in the Swan Valley.\nLicense this article What's on Comments disabled", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)", "text": "Map: Geraldton 6530 \nA gunman who shot and killed a man at an accountancy firm and then went on the run has been found dead at a house in Western Australia's Mid West. \nWA Police say Rodney Vlahov was found dead at a property in Chapman Valley, about 470 kilometres north of Perth. \nYesterday, paramedics found 49-year-old Philip Chamberlainwith gunshot wounds at Douglas Cross and Chamberlain Chartered Accountants on Flores Road about midday. \nHe died a short time later and a firearm was recovered from the scene. \nA manhunt was underway overnight for Mr Vlahov in connection with the shooting, and police said they could not rule out him still being armed with other weapons, sparking fears in the regional city of about 35,000 people. \nBut police this morning confirmed he had been found at the Chapman Valley home. \n\"Mr Vlahov was deceased when officers located him. His death is not regarded as suspicious and will be subject of a Coronial investigation,\" a police statement said. \n\"This ends a tragic sequence of events that will impact upon the Geraldton community. \n\"We want to thank the public for its support during this operation.\" Geraldton community shocked \nWA Police Regional Commander Jo McCabe said Mr Vlahov and his family were \"well-known to the Geraldton community\". \n\"This tragic incident has shocked the Geraldton community and our thoughts are with the deceased man's family at this time,\" Commander McCabe said. \nMr Chamberlain's family has issued a statement expressing the enormity of its loss. \n\"We are devastated by Philip's death,\" the statement said. \n\"Philip was a much loved husband and father, and was well known in the Geraldton community. \n\"We wish to thank the community for its support at this extremely difficult time.\" \nGeraldton Mayor Shane Van Styn said both men would be sorely missed. \n\"There are two families involved in this tragic set of circumstances and it will have a significant impact on our community,\" he said. \n\"But we are just that, we are a tight community.\" \nHe said Mr Chamberlain will be remembered as a gentleman. \n\"A kind, somewhat reserved fellow \u2026 who always wore a smile and was well known as much for his accounting abilities as he was for being a gentleman,\" he said. \nMr Vlahov and his two brothers and sister lost their father last year. \nAll three brothers are farmers in the Chapman Valley area, north-east of Geraldton. \nIt is understood a succession plan had not been established before the father passed away. \nMr Chamberlain is understood to have been the Vlahovs' family accountant. \nChapman Valley Primary School, which is near the Vlahov family farms, is offering specialised counselling services to families affected. Full investigation underway \nAssistant Commissioner Murray Smalpage would not reveal what sparked the shooting, but said Major Crime Squad detectives, the Homicide Squad and other specialists would conduct a full and comprehensive investigation into the incident. \n\"Mr Vlahov and the deceased were known to each other,\" he said. \n\"But the circumstances of their relationship and the causal factors of the shooting will be the subject of a full investigation.\" \nCommissioner Smalpage confirmed Mr Vlahov was at the business with others, but would not confirm if some of those attending the meeting were family members of Mr Vlahov. \n\"Full details of what happened in that property will be the subject of a coronial investigation, so I am not in a position to outline the full, blow-by-blow description of what happened in that room,\" he said. \n\"But the circumstances are pretty clear we have one man, unfortunately, deceased.\" \nCommissioner Smalpage there were other people inside the building at the time of the shooting and they were assisting police with the investigation. \nHe urged anyone with information about the shooting to contact police.", "http://omgili.com/ri/_0JOtn.4SCo2O1fWYpUdITlflLgDfpnvrowJmXozvGP9o2fJ9umEcEmDolxodHtKuIG7l4.4pz2O46rHiUYqu1OfGzYvx9OcXE.OKwzQGrGs_R7IukD1M3t23vY6dvQTYCfuygHL4rYOdm2OtlEe4UEqRF5F.dQdG7O.0a7bNBc-", "site_full": "bleacherreport.com", "site": "bleacherreport.com", "site_section": "http://bleacherreport.com/articles/feed?tag_id=19", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "Bleacher Report - NBA", "title": "Legendary or Just Another L? Inside Devin Booker's 70-Point Game, One Year Later", "title_full": "Legendary or Just Another L? Inside Devin Booker's 70-Point Game, One Year Later | Bleacher Report", "published": "2018-03-23T18:40:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "US", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "https://img.bleacherreport.net/img/images/photos/003/731/156/9e2d60edd02d94871c779f361a9033be_crop_exact.jpg?w=1200&amp;h=1200&amp;q=75", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 506, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 2405, "comments": 0, "shares": 2405}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "e2cff210738efd0f33c4495c5b74f3a2562a1994", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/_0JOtn.4SCo2O1fWYpUdITlflLgDfpnvrowJmXozvGP9o2fJ9umEcEmDolxodHtKuIG7l4.4pz2O46rHiUYqu1OfGzYvx9OcXE.OKwzQGrGs_R7IukD1M3t23vY6dvQTYCfuygHL4rYOdm2OtlEe4UEqRF5F.dQdG7O.0a7bNBc-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Master Tesfatsion", "published": "2018-03-23T18:40:00.000+03:00", "title": "Legendary or Just Another L? Inside Devin Booker's 70-Point Game, One Year Later", "text": "B/R Devin Booker was fatigued. The Phoenix Suns guard didn't express it, but then-head coach Earl Watson could read it on his face before the game. The Suns arrived in Boston on the final leg of a back-to-back, the fourth stop of a six-game road trip. They had just suffered a 28-point trouncing from the Brooklyn Nets \u2014their sixth straight loss. Nearly half of Phoenix's roster was out because of injury or \"rest.\"\nWatson, sensing Booker's exhaustion, kept his pregame message brief. \"Be legendary,\" he said. Booker was familiar with the phrase: Lakers legend Kobe Bryant wrote those two words on a pair of Kobe 11s that he signed and gifted the Phoenix prodigy the previous season. Booker looked at Watson and nodded. \"It was a tired nod, but like, I'm here to be a professional ,\" Watson recalled.\nWhat transpired next on TD Garden's parquet floor would generate a leaguewide buzz that is still felt a year later: Booker dropped 70. It was the most points scored by a NBA player since Bryant scored 81 on the Toronto Raptors in 2006. But unlike Bryant's outing, Booker's performance came in a loss. It was just the fifth time in NBA history that a player scored 70 points or more in a losing effort. Wilt Chamberlain did it three times. David Thompson, at 23, scored 73 points with the Denver Nuggets in a two-point loss to the Detroit Pistons on April 9, 1978.\nIn the year since last March 24, many have debated the performance's legacy. Booker became the youngest player in league history to reach that mark, but the game's outcome never hung in the balance. Was it a legitimate 70 points or does the performance deserve an asterisk? Was it just an exceptional offensive night or was it the arrival of a budding young star?\n\nAs those at the game tell it, Booker's 70-point effort was a moment worth celebrating. It just wasn't expected on this particular night and at this particular point in his career. Booker was in his second season and just 20 years old. His team boasted the youngest lineup in NBA\u2014according to Elias Sports Bureau, the Suns' average age was just 21 years, 14 days. Marquese Chriss was 19. Derrick Jones Jr. was 20. Tyler Ulis was 21. Alex Len, the team's center, was the starting lineup's elder statesman, at 23 years old. \"Phoenix pretty much had no other option,\" Doug Haller, who covered the game for the Arizona Republic , said. \"It was just Devin.\"\nBooker got off to a slow start. He missed his first three shots and didn't convert on his first field goal until 4:40 was left in the first quarter. The Celtics made it a priority to hinder Booker's offense from the outset. They ran a steady rotation of Jaylen Brown and Marcus Smart, two of their best on-ball defenders, against Phoenix's only scoring threat, and it proved highly effective. By halftime, Boston had opened up a 23-point lead. Booker had 19 points.\nTim Kempton, the Suns' radio color analyst who also played eight years in the NBA, remembered the mood going into the half. \"You're sitting there not really expecting anything,\" he said. \"We're getting drilled by the Celtics. You're just kind of like, Uh-oh. Devin Booker is obviously our best player. He's playing well, but we're getting throttled by the Boston Celtics.\"\n\nEarl Watson Matt York/Associated Press To switch it up, Watson decided to shift Booker over from shooting to point guard\u2014a position normally occupied by Eric Bledsoe, who was sidelined with knee soreness. Phoenix ran a heavy dose of pick-and-roll action, and the Celtics' bigs\u2014Amir Johnson and Kelly Olynyk\u2014struggled to defend it. Booker's numbers soared. He scored 23 points on 5-of-9 shooting in the third, with 11 coming at the foul line. Suddenly, with a quarter left, he had 42 points.\nBut Booker had also taken a beating, physically, against Smart, an aggressive defender who can irritate the opposing team's best player. Booker showed signs of frustration. He complained to the officials that Smart was walking underneath his jumper. At one point, Booker nearly turned his ankle.\nWatson was already low on bodies, and he didn't want to see Booker get hurt, down 97-80 heading into the fourth. \"I kind of looked at [Booker] at the end of the third quarter\u2014it was a look to say, You're done for the game ,\" Watson said. \"He looked at me and shook his head no. I think Marcus Smart kind of got him going. He came out in the fourth quarter, and he just went to work.\"\nBooker took 16 of the team's 27 shots in the final period, and as his numbers climbed, the mood in the arena appeared to shift. \"I remember as he's getting close to 50, I turned and looked at [Kempton] like, Where is this going? \" Haller recalled.\nGary Washburn, a longtime NBA writer for the Boston Globe , was shocked when he looked at the box score during the fourth. \"I saw [Michael] Jordan score 49 on the Clippers way back in the day, and he was just a one-man team,\" he said. \"This was a little different. It was kind like it snuck up on you. All of a sudden he had 55, and you're like, Whoa! Wait a minute. \"\n\nDevin Booker Sue Ogrocki/Associated Press The night took a historic turn with 1:48 left, when a Booker putback gave him 61 points\u2014a new franchise record. (Tom Chambers had set the previous mark of 60 against the Seattle SuperSonics in 1990.) The Boston crowd, normally hostile to opposing players, cheered Booker on. The entire Suns bench was on its feet.\nBut Watson was unaware of the individual performance taking place. During a pair of Booker free throws, Watson turned to his assistant, Nate Bjorkgren, and asked, \"What are they cheering for?\"\n\"Book has 65,\" Bjorkgren responded.\n\"No shit?!\"\n\"Yes, coach.\"\n\"Oh shit. Stay in the game,\" Watson said. In the contest's final 45 seconds, the Suns began intentionally fouling and calling timeouts to stop the clock. Then Watson, during the stoppages, would draw up plays for Booker.\nThe Celtics weren't pleased. Players and coaching staff shouted their disapproval from the bench. The game was already decided, so what was Watson doing?\nHe insisted he was just trying to \"keep chipping the score\"\u2014a lesson he learned from Hubie Brown, whom he considers a mentor. \"If you lose with a young team, you really want those losses to be less than seven,\" Watson said. \"So at the end of the year, you get on the board and you give them a chance to believe.\"", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "devin booker", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "earl wa", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "kobe bryant", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "bryant", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "kobe", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "booker", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "watson", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "phoenix suns", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "suns", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "toronto raptors", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "lakers", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "nba", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "brooklyn nets", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "td garden", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "phoenix", "sentiment": "none"}, "2018-03-24T06:13:00.000+03:00", "title": "NBA: James scores 27 points as Cavs rout Suns", "text": "Cleveland Cavaliers forward LeBron James (23) drives to the basket against Phoenix Suns guard Josh Jackson (20) during the first half at Quicken Loans Arena. Ken Blaze-USA TODAY Sports/Reuters JR Smith hit consecutive 3-pointers during a 20-2, second-quarter flurry Friday night that sent the Cleveland Cavaliers on to a 120-95 victory over the Phoenix Suns at Quicken Loans Arena in Cleveland.\nLeBron James had a game-high 27 points in just 29 minutes as the Cavaliers won their fourth straight game while sending the Suns to their 10th consecutive defeat.\nTroy Daniels had a team-high 20 points for the Suns, who remained tied with Memphis for the fewest wins in the NBA with 19.\nPhoenix led by as many as four points in the first quarter and was up 33-29 in the third minute of the second period before two free throws apiece by Jordan Clarkson and Smith started Cleveland on its decisive run.\nJeff Green and Kevin Love buried 3-pointers to help make it a 12-0 spree, and after Tyler Ulis dropped in a layup for the Suns, Smith began another burst of eight straight Cleveland points with his two 3-pointers.\nThe Cavaliers led 49-35 after the run and went on to hold a 62-45 advantage at the half. A layup by James extended the margin to 21 early in the third quarter, and the Suns never threatened after that.\nJames, who made 11 of his 16 shots, also found time for nine assists and six rebounds for the Cavaliers, who completed a 3-0 homestand.\nLove finished with 20 points, Larry Nance Jr. 15, Clarkson 13 and Smith 11 for Cleveland, which retained third place in the Eastern Conference with the win.\nNance shared team-high rebound honors with Tristan Thompson with 10.\nThe Cavaliers shot 49.5 percent for the game.\nDaniels connected on six of 12 from 3-point range to account for all but two of his points for Phoenix, which has lost its last five games by an average of 23.4 points.\nDaniels' teammates combined to shoot just 1-for-16 on threes, with the Suns finishing at 25 percent (7 of 28).\nMarquese Chriss had a 19-point, 10-rebound double-double, while Josh Jackson added 17 points and Ulis 11 for the Suns, who were beaten 129-107 at home by the Cavaliers last Tuesday.\nUlis also chipped in with a team-high nine assists.\nThe Suns finished at 43.7 percent from the field.\n ", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], Airlines Add Interest Professional skateboarder Justin Mallory, 45, was traveling to a Phoenix skateboarding convention when he claimed he was asked to leave his flight because his shirt, which featured the artwork of two guns, \u201callegedly \u2018made another passenger uncomfortable,\u2019\u201d according to a statement from Mallory\u2019s lawyer, Mawuli Mel Davis.\n\u201cI was flabbergasted. I was taken aback,\u201d Mallory told ABC affiliate WSB-TV.\nMan says he was kicked off flight over business logo on his shirt: https://t.co/lUxIf2AmZc @JustinWilfonWSB gets both sides of this story, tonight at 11 #nightbeat pic.twitter.com/8idRQuvQHW\n\u2014 WSB-TV (@wsbtv) March 22, 2018\nMallory, who was set to perform and sell merchandise at the Phoenix SkaterCon convention, said the artwork was a part of his skateboard brand logo.\n\u201cI have been a frequent flyer with many airlines and my skateboarding brand image has always been received as an artistic expression,\u201d Mallory said in his statement.\nBut Frontier, according to Mallory, failed to check in his skateboard and \u201cbecame argumentative\u201d when he was asked by a crew member to do so.\n\u201cIt is Frontier\u2019s policy that skateboards are not permitted in the cabin,\u201d the airline said in a statement. \u201cAfter eventually checking the item, the passenger boarded the aircraft and continued to exhibit disruptive behavior.\u201d\nFrontier\u2019s account was \u201ctotally false,\u201d Mallory told WSB-TV, adding that he missed the convention because of the ordeal. Terrified passengers say that driver was falling asleep and it led to a confrontation caught on video, CBS Dallas/Fort Worth reports .\nThree of the passengers who were on the bus arrived in Dallas seven hours late from Phoenix.\nSome said they weren't so sure they'd make it in one piece after they caught the driver pinching her cheeks with tweezers just to stay awake. At this point in the bus trip from Phoenix to Dallas, passengers had had enough.\n\"We politely asked her four times to pull over,\" said Jasmine McLellan, who said she was among as many as 60 people who were on board a Greyhound bus who noticed their driver falling asleep behind the wheel.\n\"I got to the point where we saw her going like this and just dozing off,\" said McLellan.\n\"The bus was leaning little and that's when people started to really worry,\" said passenger Philip Hurd. \"She was using techniques to try and stay awake and I think that was the initial concern ... We would go over the white line and everybody would be like wake up and she had tweezers she was poking herself with tweezers to keep herself awake it was awful. It got to the point where we had to raise our voice pull over we have children on this bus pull over.\"\nA confrontation happened while passengers said the bus was still moving and the driver stood up to argue with them.\nPassengers said they got a Border Patrol escort to a safe location where Greyhound replaced the driver.\nThe incident raises serious questions about whether a nationwide shortage of bus drivers is pushing current ones to drive without proper rest.\nDallas-based Greyhound responded with a statement from Senior Communications Specialist Lanesha Gipson:\nOur schedules are now running on time and we're back on schedule. However, we were experiencing delays at the Dallas station earlier today as we waited for drivers to become available once they completed their federally mandated rest. With resources as tight as they have been, any delay that occurs elsewhere can create a domino effect, which can have an impact on a driver's hours of service. We work diligently to accommodate our customers with the limited resources we have available, and we've been actively hiring drivers in order to meet the increasing demand for our service so these types of delays are minimized. All delayed customers have departed the station are now en route to their destinations. \nRegarding the specific incident on the bus headed to Dallas, Gipson issued this statement:\nWe are currently looking into these allegations, as we take the issue of driver fatigue very seriously. Because safety is the cornerstone of our business, we take necessary precautions to prevent drivers from falling asleep while driving and we make it easy for drivers to be reassigned if they do feel fatigued or don't feel confident that they can operate the bus safely for any reason. Our drivers are in regular contact with our dispatch office, and if they state they are feeling tired or fatigued, they are immediately removed from the schedule for at least 12 hours to allow them to get some rest. Once they feel alert and able to return to work, they may do so. \nSome of these passengers said they paid more than $200 for their tickets and would like a refund.\nGreyhound has promised a refund "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Jessica Boehm", "published": "2018-03-22T17:52:00.000+02:00", "title": "Maricopa County sees biggest population growth in nation", "text": "More people moved to Maricopa County than any other county in the country last year, according to U.S. Census Bureau population estimates released Thursday.\nMaricopa County's population jumped by nearly 74,000 people \u2014 a 1.7 percent increase. The county's growth helped it maintain its rank as the fourth most populous county in the country, with 4,307,033 residents.\nClark County in Nevada saw the next largest gain with a 47,355-person increase. All of the top-10 largest-gaining counties were in the South or the West.\nRELATED: Arizona's population tops 7 million for the first time, Census Bureau says\nThe new data only includes population estimates as of July 1, 2017, for counties and metropolitan areas, not individual cities.\nAlthough Phoenix overtook Philadelphia as the fifth largest city last year , the Phoenix-Mesa-Scottsdale metropolitan area is only the 11th largest metro area, with 4,737,270 people (the metro area includes part of Pinal County, which is why the metro area population is larger than the county's).\nThat being said, the Phoenix-Mesa-Scottsdale area added nearly 89,000 people last year, the fourth-largest gain of any metro area.\nMORE: Phoenix is the nation's 5th largest \u2014 but is it a 'real' city?\n\"Post-recession we have worked very hard to build a more sustainable economy \u2014 one rooted in education and focused on exports, and it's working,\" Phoenix Mayor Greg Stanton said.\nHe said, \"We don't want to celebrate growth for growth sake,\" but in Phoenix and the region there has been a focus on quality employment that will sustain long-term growth.\nStanton also noted that people are moving to the county's center city at a disproportional rate because Phoenix has made investments in transportation and infrastructure that boost quality of life.\n\"We want Phoenix to do great and we want the county to do great,\" he said.\nREAD MORE:\nTwo teachers go to Dutch Bros., plan a sick-out that closes 9 Arizona schools\nSen. Republic", "published": "2018-03-25T03:48:00.000+03:00", "title": "Marchers, armed protesters face off at March for Our Lives", "text": "Marchers, armed protesters face off at March for Our Lives Andrew Nicla | The Arizona Republic \nPHOENIX \u2014 Thousands of people gathered at the Arizona Capitol on Saturday, joining hundreds of concurrent marches across the U.S. protesting gun violence in schools and calling for gun-control laws. \nIn the middle of the Phoenix marchers were a few dozen protesters , some carrying AR-15 rifles and other weapons and others waving signs in support of the Second Amendment. \nThroughout the morning, members of both groups clashed \u2014 some yelling at each other, others participating in more conversational debates. \nAccording to the Arizona Department of Public Safety, the march crowd totaled 15,000. There were no arrests, they reported. \nMore: At 1 million plus strong, March for Our Lives rallies crush expectations \nLikewise, in Salt Lake City, about 8,000 protesters collided with 1,000 pro-gun counter-demonstrators, exchanged shouts but remaining peaceful, according to police. \nUtah, a state that also allows open-carry, hosted some in the pro-gun rally carrying pistols on their hips and AR-style weapons slung over their shoulders, \"because I can. It's our right,\" Mark Stewart, a counter protester told the Salt Lake Tribune . \nIn Helena, Mont., a March for Our Guns counter event drew about 150 people. Attendees held signs that said \"No guns, No freedom\" and \"Montana treasures God, guns and family.\" \nMike Opie, 32, of Helena, said he felt sorry for the Florida victims, most of whom were high school students. \n\u201cI\u2019m upset kids got shot,\u201d said Opie, who said he served with in the Marines in Iraq. \u201cBut to take guns away is not constitutional.\u201d About 150 attend March for our Guns rally in Helena. #mtnews pic.twitter.com/aYO0zEJFwv \u2014 Phil Drake (@GFTrib_PDrake) March 24, 2018 \nIn Los Angeles, there were only about a dozen counter protesters. They were dwarfed by more than 15,000 people as they were protected by police along the march route. Counter protest so far is about 12 people at 1st and Spring. They are behind police tape as the main march starts to approach. pic.twitter.com/fOjUo4H9Nx \nHours after an anti-gun violence rally in Lansing, Mich., a pro-Second Amendment group hosted speakers on the Michigan Capitol's steps. \n\"If we do not assert our rights, we will lose them,\" said state Sen. Patrick Colbeck, a Republican candidate for governor, \n\"Where was all this when we were having all these shootings years ago?\" asked Hope Coleman, 40, who said she is affiliated with the Patriot movement for President Trump in Phoenix. \"Why should everyone get punished because of someone else's negligence?\" \nIn Phoenix, marcher Sharon Bedney, 77, of Mesa engaged with some of the protesters. \n\"If you can't shoot, you can't teach?\" she asked in response to a protester. \"Teachers are there to teach. They don't need the added pressure.\" \nWilliam Cairnes, 63, of Phoenix, a U.S. Navy veteran, argued with some of the protesters carrying guns. \n\"We want rational control, that's what we want,\" he said. \"This is happening far too often. If we can control their means for mass shootings, shouldn't we at least look into it?\" \nCasey Goble, 19, was among the counterprotesters at the march. He said he was carrying an unloaded AR-15 to make a statement and to exercise his right to do so. \nHe said he supports some measures of gun reform, such as stricter background checks to keep criminals and those with mental-health issues from accessing guns. But he said he came because he supports the Second Amendment. \n\"I support their (protesters') right to have a gun even if they don't like it,\" he said, saying he brought his unloaded AR-15 \"just in case.\" \nJamila Rahim, 20, an Arizona State University sophomore, came to the march with friends. \n\"I get that this is our Second Amendment,\" she said. \"We're not trying to revoke it or take anything away. We just want common-sense gun laws.\" \nShe said she was surprised to find so many like-minded people at the march. \n\"Being here is reassuring,\" she said, adding that if gun reform doesn't happen, \"we'll be back.\" \nBut Rahim said there was a disconnect between those like-minded marchers and the handful of counterprotesters. She feared people may have missed an opportunity to have one-on-one conversations to further discussions on such a controversial issue. \nPeople may be reluctant to have those conversations because they're \"scared of what they're going to hear,\" she said. \n\"Coming out here, we're kind of preaching to the choir anyways,\" Rahim said. \"But going up to them, talking with them, that's where the real change begins.\" \nVan Gutier, 29, said he was there \"standing up for the Bill of Rights.\" \n\"You're playing the blame game,\" he said to a marcher. \"I don't want the government coming up with definitions of who is mentally ill. The government overreaches. The government cares about power. It will try to retain that power by disarming its citizens.\" \nHe said banning guns won't stop mass shootings. \n\u201cWe need to take ownership over ourselves,\" he said. \nKen and Linda Bielek, both 76, were among the marchers. They said they were fed up with a lack of progress on the issue of gun control. They said they don't want to \"take away anybody's guns,\" but do want to see universal background checks and assault-rifle bans. \n\"I don't know of anybody that's saying take away guns from people who have shotguns, a revolver or pistol for home protection or target shooting,\" Ken Bielek said. \"We're not asking the politicians, we're demanding that they ban assault weapons. There's gun violence happening every day. We're fed up with it.\" \nAt one point, Ken Bielek pulled out his pocket Constitution. As a U.S. Army veteran, he said he supports the Second Amendment. But he said the founders couldn't have predicted the rapid change in gun technology. \n\"They had muskets back then,\" he said. \"Today, they're killing machines.\" \nContributing: Nick Penzenstadler, USA TODAY, Matt Mencarini, Lansing (Mich.) "nytimes.com", "site_section": "http://nytimes.com/timeswire/feeds/", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "NYT > Most Recent Headlines", "title": "Uber\u2019s Self-Driving Cars Were "https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/03/24/business/24UBER-print/merlin_135861465_1d4198b4-77fa-4935-a5b4-6be0e795593a-facebookJumbo.jpg", "performance_score": 10, "domain_rank": 98, "social": "http://omgili.com/ri/.wHSUbtEfZSPfVRrC83GDKJbKDRbkYjxNRdF1HRthPCjVlZv9U2_ikLeOmjL7YOb2LhFRae5FLEf8I1wZQy2DQZYlz.7KPd0Yj3IjcF3AwDASFyQR0W17Q--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI", "published": "2018-03-24T04:46:00.000+03:00", "title": "Uber\u2019s Self-Driving Cars Were Struggling Before Arizona Crash", "text": "Opt out or contact us anytime By September 2017, Uber\u2019s autonomous cars had driven one million miles in a year nationwide. Uber tallied its second million in 100 days and added its next million at an even faster clip, according to company documents. Early on in Phoenix, there were two groups of test drivers. A smaller group \u201cstressed\u201d the cars by putting them in challenging situations where, without human intervention, they would have crashed. A larger group of drivers was focused on picking up customers in the autonomous vehicles. Those drivers were expected to pay more attention to little details, often taking control to prevent a \u201cbad experience\u201d like hard braking, according to a company document. Around October, Uber merged the two groups to get to a point where it could offer a truly driverless car service to customers \u201cas quickly as possible.\u201d The customer pickup service was mostly dropped so drivers could focus on accumulating miles and gathering data to help the system become more reliable. \nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story Around the same time, Uber moved from two employees in every car to one. The paired employees had been splitting duties \u2014 one ready to take over if the autonomous system failed, and another to keep an eye on what the computers were detecting. The second person was responsible for keeping track of system performance as well as labeling data on a laptop computer. Mr. Kallman, the Uber spokesman, said the second person was in the car for purely data related tasks, not safety. Waymo had also moved from two operators at all times to one in some situations in late 2015, said Johnny Luu, a Waymo spokesman. Waymo still uses two test drivers when it is adding new systems or moving to a new location. But Uber\u2019s autonomous cars are not operating nearly as well as those of its competitors. Cruise reported to California regulators that it went more than 1,200 miles per intervention. After its strong California results, Waymo is now testing cars in Chandler, Ariz., a Phoenix suburb, with no safety drivers. Mr. Kallman said miles per intervention was not a measure of safety but a rate of system improvement that could differ depending on where and how the cars were driven. When Uber moved to a single operator, some employees expressed safety concerns to managers, according to the two people familiar with Uber\u2019s operations. They were worried that going solo would make it harder to remain alert during hours of monotonous driving. Mr. Kallman said it delayed the start of its single-driver initiative to allow for more training and to make sure drivers felt comfortable for the new role. Uber also developed an app, mounted on an iPad in the car\u2019s middle console, for drivers to alert engineers to problems. Drivers could use the app anytime without shifting the car out of autonomous mode. Often, drivers would annotate data at a traffic light or a stop, but many did so while the car was moving, said the two people familiar with Uber\u2019s operations. Mr. Kallman said it designed the app to meet government safety guidelines for in-car software to minimize distractions. Waymo had a different solution when it moved to a single safety driver. It added a button on the steering wheel for drivers to create an audio explanation when they took the car out of autonomous mode. Not all drivers followed Uber\u2019s training. One was fired after falling asleep at the wheel and being spotted by a colleague. Another was spotted air drumming as the autonomous car passed through an intersection, according to the two people familiar with Uber\u2019s operations. \nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story Uber was planning to seek regulatory approval by December to start a self-driving car service in Arizona, according to company documents. Uber said the vehicles would have to be safer than human drivers before they would commercialize it. They would not operate around the clock and would stop for bad weather or traffic. And the service did not need to prove \u201clonger-term financial viability.\u201d Already, one milestone will be missed. Mr. Khosrowshahi will not travel to Phoenix next month, because of scheduling problems that came up before the crash, Mr. Kallman said. But it is unclear how the crash will ultimately affect Uber\u2019s plans for autonomous vehicles. \u201cThe collection of bad news around Uber creates a reputation in people\u2019s minds,\u201d said Michael Ramsey, an automotive analyst at Gartner. \u201cEvery other company would get a black eye, too, but they might be forgiven. For Uber, it\u2019s going to be hard to shake.\u201d \nFollow Daisuke Wakabayashi on Twitter: @daiwaka \nMike Isaac and Cade Metz contributed reporting. A version of this article appears in print on March 24, 2018, on Page B1 of the New York edition with the headline: Flaws in Self-Driving Cars Before Fatal Crash. Mr. Melchior said he recently had met many young people who felt that the growing call for stricter gun laws did not represent their views. Among them was Cody Frandsen, 17, a high school senior wearing a \u201cMake America Great Again\u201d baseball cap. \u201cI feel like an outsider,\u201d said Mr. Frandsen, standing with friends who nodded in agreement. \u201cA lot of the millennials, our age group, is left-leaning.\u201d The group began talking about gun laws it might be able to support. \u201cI\u2019m totally for a background check,\u201d said Mr. Frandsen, noting that he supported universal checks. \u201cI think there should be a mental health check\u201d before purchasing a gun, said his friend Logan Coffey, 17. \u201cAnd the government should know where every single firearm is.\u201d Of those who marched in Washington in support of gun control, Mr. Frandsen said he did not agree with anything \u201cthey have to say,\u201d adding, \u201cBut I\u2019m sure we could come up with some kind of compromise.\u201d \nKatharine Seelye and Jeffery C. He said later that this had not been fully achieved but that several countries will consider expelling diplomats. \nOn the sidelines of the summit, the Czech prime minister held a short one-on-one meeting with British Prime Minister Theresa May. Top Republican Paul Ryan to meet with Czech PM Babi\u0161 on Monday \nActing Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babi\u0161 is set to meet with US House speaker Paul Ryan in Prague on Monday. The news was confirmed by government spokeswoman Barbora Peterov\u00e1 on Friday. \nThe top Republican will arrive in the Czech Republic for a private visit and will stay in the country for a few days, the Czech News Agency reported. \nMr Ryan is scheduled to appear at a student debate at Charles University in Prague and attend a conference in the Senate. He will also visit a special meeting of the lower house of parliament on Tuesday. Police confiscate rare stamp after auction house finds it on stolen list \nPolice have confiscated a rare 1990 Czechoslovak postal stamp which was put on the market after it emerged that it had been stolen during a stamp exhibition in Tokyo twenty-five years ago. The stamp\u2019s value is estimated at around three and a half million crowns. \nCzech collector Ludvik Pytl\u00ed\u010dek, who is selling his collection, says he swapped the stamp with another collector and was unaware that it was registered as stolen. The original owner of the stamp was a collector from the Netherlands. The matter is being investigated. Czech foreign debt in 2017 climbs to 4.372 trillion crowns \nCzech foreign debt climbed during 2017 to stand at 4.372 trillion crowns by the end of the year. That\u2019s 875 billion crowns more than at the end of 2016, according to figures from the Czech National Bank. The total foreign debt represents 86.71 percent of the country\u2019s Gross Domestic Product (GDP). \nAround 72 percent of the Czech foreign debt is owned by private entities with the Czech government, state agencies, and majority owned state companies responsible for the rest. Around 44 percent of the overall debt is held by banks. Renowned science-fiction translator Jan Kant\u016frek dies at 69 \nJan Kant\u016frek, a renowned Czech translator of fantasy, science fiction, comics and westerns from English, has died at the age of 69. The news was confirmed on Thursday by the publisher Comics Centre. \nKant\u016frek\u2019s best known translations include the Discworld novels by Terry Pratchett, which sold about 800, 000 copies in the Czech Republic. He also translated books about Conan the Barbarian by Robert E. Howard and others. Football: Rosick\u00fd to play in farewell testimonial in June \nFormer national football team captain Tom\u00e1\u0161 Rosick\u00fd, who played for the clubs Sparta Prague, Borussia Dortmund, and Arsenal, will officially end his professional career at Prague\u2019s Sparta stadium on June 9 of this year. \nThe star midfielder will play in a testimonial match at Sparta\u2019s stadium in Prague, featuring fellow players from the national squad and international stars. \nOrganisers have not released a list of the players yet. Weather \nSaturday is expected to be mostly sunny with daytime highs ranging between sic and ten degrees Celsius. "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-23T16:25:00.000+03:00", "title": "Czech PM: Prague likely to expel number of Russian diplomats over nerve agent incident", "text": "Subscribe to RSS Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babi\u0161 has said the Czech Republic may expel a number of Russian diplomats over the attack on a former double agent and his daughter in Britain. The prime minister made the statement at the end of an EU summit in Brussels which debated a common strategy over the incident. Download: MP3 \nAndrej Babi\u0161, photo: CTK European Union leaders backed Britain on Thursday in blaming Moscow over a nerve agent attack on a former double agent in Britain agreeing to recall the EU envoy to Moscow and opening the door to additional retaliatory steps by some member states. One of the member states likely to take further action is the Czech Republic. Speaking shortly after the summit ended, Prime Minister Andrej Babi\u0161 said Prague would seriously consider expelling a number of Russian diplomats over the incident. \n\u201cWe are seriously considering this course of action and I will discuss the matter on Monday with Foreign Minister Stropnick\u00fd and other members of the cabinet. We are likely to head in this direction.\u201d \nThe prime minister said the number of expelled diplomats would be in the single digits, not dozens and would not include the ambassador. \nThe Czech Republic was directly drawn into the dispute after the Russian Foreign Ministry rejected responsibility for the attack, saying the nerve agent Novichok could easily have come from the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Sweden, or Great Britain itself. Speaking at NATO headquarters earlier, Mr. Babi\u0161 resolutely rejected the idea calling it as a blatant lie. Czech Foreign Minister Martin Stropnick\u00fd earlier summoned the Russian ambassador to explain the accusation. \nAlthough Prague was among the first to condemn the poisoning and express solidarity with Britain over the incident, the prime minister\u2019s statement that the country would most likely expel a number of diplomats came as a surprise, since earlier both the prime minister and foreign minister had stressed the need for coordinated EU action in this respect. To what extent the Czech prime minister\u2019s one-on-one meeting with his British counterpart Theresa May on the sidelines of the summit may have influenced this decision is not clear. \nRussian diplomats leave Russian Embassy in London, March 20, 2018, photo: CTK In any case, centre-right parties in Prague have strongly supported such a move, saying it was long overdue and stressing that Prague does not need to wait for the big players to come to a decision on this matter. The Communist Party, on the other hand, sees the move as premature and opposition is also likely to come from the country\u2019s president who is widely seen as pro-Russian. \nThe Russian representation in Prague is unusually large, with some 48 diplomats in residence. The Czech intelligence service has in recent years issued warnings regarding heightened activities on the part of Russian and Chinese agents in the country, and political scientists say there is no doubt that Prague has become a hub for Russian activities in broader Central Europe. According to them as many as half of the Russian diplomats here could be undercover agents.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "andrej babi\u0161", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "stropnick\u00fd", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "eu", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "ctk european union", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "czech republic", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "prague", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "eu", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "brussels", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "britain", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "moscow", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T16:58:04.017+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "e4486799053e992027a1dd0979aa0f9be3573d03", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg_hzqEh69FLtTXxYKuyRCZWUREb_Ww9wNVxFy1aZ19BtCeXXRKT_YtR_Jv9ruXhZyL59nFLPgONRQB159DSgGTJZM.i8uMP5Lp1zIj8lqPbpg--", "site_full": "www.radio.cz", "site": "radio.cz", "site_section": "http://radio.cz//feeds/rss/en/en.xml", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "Radio Prague - The song \u201cSaxana\u201d was composed by Angelo Mikhailov, an actor, classical musician and one of Czechoslovakia\u2019s most successful composers. The star of films such as Belle de Jour, The Last Metro, and Indochina, arrived in Prague for the close of the festival. Download: MP3 \nCatherine Deneuve, photo: CTK Catherine Deneuve is nothing less than a legend, having worked together with directors like Francois Truffaut, Luis Bunuel, Jacques Dem\u00fd and many others. In Prague for the close of Febio Fest, she spoke candidly about her career: what it had been like to work with Gerard Depardieu, who she called very generous as an actor. On the same topic she said she had been a little nervous before the first time she had worked with her daughter Chiara Mastroianni but that that had quickly changed. \n\u201cWhen I worked with my daughter Chiara I thought it would be a little strange at the beginning, you know, it would be someone you know and suddenly you would have to say things to each other from a script. I thought it would be strange. \n\u201cBut finally, it wasn\u2019t at all. We would go to the make-up room, and everything was very natural. I did another film with here recently that hasn\u2019t been released yet directed by Julie Bertucelli, but the whole thing was much more casual than I thought.\u201d \nReceiving a lifetime achievement award like the Kristi\u00e1n for contribution to cinematography is always an invitation, to a degree, for actors to look back on their career. One journalist present suggested the actress, who is 74, could write her memoirs, speculating on all the stories she could tell. But the actress made clear she had no intention of doing any such thing. Deneuve also made clear she was not nostalgic for the 1960s and 1970s when she first achieved fame. Catherine Deneuve again: \n\u201cMaybe I enjoy [making films] today more today than I did 40 years ago because I know more about filming and being part of the whole troupe, being part of the crew; because I have friends who write screenplays and who are directors or are technicians. I know more about filmmaking and the process so I also more patient. I wouldn\u2019t say I was happier on set 40 years ago, no.\u201d \nCatherine Deneuve, photo: CTK She was also asked if she had the chance, would she do it all over again. \n\u201cAh, if I had a second chance would I decide to be an actress? Well, being an actress happened to me.\u201d \nShe explained that she was just 17 when she got into acting because of her sister and that one film led to another. "published": "2018-03-23T12:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "Saeima endorses EU-Armenia partnership agreement", "text": " 41 Saeima endorses EU-Armenia partnership agreement BC, Riga, 23.03.2018. Print version The Latvian parliament on March 22nd approved in principle a bill on the ratification of the European Union-Armenia Comprehensive and Enhanced Partnership Agreement, informs LETA. \nLETA was told at the Saeima press office that the new agreement will strengthen cooperation between the EU and Armenia, including political dialogue, and will improve exchange in other areas. \nAuthors of the bill from the Foreign Ministry indicated that the agreement contains a section on trade and that the new regulation is expected to improve conditions for bilateral trade, as well as provide a better legislative framework in areas like trade in goods and services, founding and managing of companies, circulation of capital, public procurement, copyrights, sustainable growth and competition. \nThe agreement includes provisions for cooperation in areas like transport, energy, health, environment, climate change, taxes, education and culture, employment and social issues, banking and insurance, industrial policy, agriculture and rural development, tourism, research and innovation, as well as mining. The agreement also covers legal cooperation, the rule of law, as well as combating money laundering, terrorist financing, organized crime and corruption. Print version Bailiff Ainars Susts is organizing an auction to sell three ships of Vexoil Bunkering company in order to repay a loan to Rietumu Banka, according to an announcement published in the official government gazette Latvijas Vestnesis, cites LETA. \nThe three vessels that are being put up for auction are the Ellina, the Dmitrijs and the West Lynda. \nLETA was told at the company that Vexoil Bunkering used a loan from Rietumu Banka to purchase these ships. Since the loan was not repaid on time, it became a debt the bank now wants to recover by auctioning the aforementioned ships. \nAccording to information available at Firmas.lv, Vexoil Bunkering has pledged collateral worth EUR 11.115 million to Rietumu Banka . \nThe auction will take place from March 27 to April 26. Bidders can register for the auction until April 16. \nThe starting price at the auction has been set at EUR 63,000 for Ellina, EUR 83,000 for the Dmitrijs and EUR 270,000 for the West Lynda. \nVexoil Bunkering posted EUR 461,119 in profit on a turnover of EUR 2.742 million for 2016. The company, established in 2001, belongs to Reinis Inkens (20%) and Dmitrijs Cebotarjovs (80%). The team is part of Intrum Global Technologies in Riga and works on debt collection and surveillance system development and maintenance for Switzerland. Requirements: Minimum of 2 years experience in testing; Experience in testing automation; Experience with SQL and PL/SQL; Ability to communicate effectively with business in order to understand system requirements; Ability and desire to work as a team player; Good knowledge of English (written and spoken). Desired skills: Agile/Scrum experience is a plus; Programming experience is a plus. Responsibilities: Test case creation and manual execution; Test case automation and maintenance; Reporting of test results; Suggesting improvements of testing process and test scripts. We offer: Stable, professional and friendly environment; Social security and benefits (including health insurance, etc.); Professional trainings; Possibility to work from home occasionally; Team building events and sport activities. To apply send your CV in Latvian, English or Russian till 23/04/2018. private houses picked up in 2017 in Latvia BC, Riga, 23.03.2018. Print version Activity on the market of private houses in Riga and its area increased in 2017, with transactions in residential land plots and private houses growing against a year before, Maris Laukalejs, a board member of Arco Real Estate, told LETA. \nAccording to the company\u2019s latest housing market review, the number of transactions in residential land plots (larger than 600 square meters) in Riga rose by 17% in 2017, while transactions in private dwelling houses grew 7% year-on-year. \nThe trend to build private houses for one\u2019s own needs and not for selling also continued last year. \n\u201cThe number of building permits issued last year is a clear reflection of the increased activity in the aforementioned segments. Compared to 2016, the number of building permits grew by 47%. A total of 1,948 permits were issued in 2017 for the construction of private houses, which was the highest figure in nine years,\u201d said Laukalejs. Print version The Latvian Consumer Rights Protection Center (PTAC) has imposed an EUR 18,700 fine on Sugar Media concert organizer owner by an Estonian businessman, PTAC reported LETA. \nPTAC informed that in the time period from July 2017 until October 2017 the European Consumers Information Center and PTAC received 15 complaints about two-day festival Retro Beach Fest 2017 in Lithuanian city Zarasai and Egor Kreed \u2019s concert in Dzintari concert hall in Jurmala, Latvia, both organized by Sugar Media . \nPTAC discovered that during the Retro Beach Fest 2017, the performing artists were not those as promised by the organizer, and the organizer had not reduced the ticket price or refunded tickets after receiving complaints from customers. PTAC thus concludes that the company not only has failed to comply with the service agreement, but has deceived consumers, providing false information on artists performing at the festival. \nIn total, 5,000 tickets were sold to the festival, the prices ranged from EUR 18 to EUR 29, and the estimated loss is at least EUR 90,000. \nEgor Kreed\u2019s concert planned on August 8 was cancelled, and only a part of consumers got their tickets refunded because Sugar Media had not transferred all the necessary funds to Bilesu Service ticket office. Thus, 61 tickets for a total sum of EUR 3,055 were not refunded. \nPTAC has tried to contact Sugar Media several times, demanding to stop the unfair commercial practice and provide all the necessary information, but the company did not cooperate and did not settle the problems. \nPTAC thus concluded that Sugar Media \u2019s commercial practice is unfair and deceiving, and decided to fine the company with EUR 18,700. \nAccording to Firmas.lv business database, Sugar Media was registered in Latvia in May 2016. Its share capital is EUR 2,800, and the company belongs to an Estonian citizen. \nThe company closed 2016 with EUR 187,003 in turnover and EUR 742 in profit. According to the State Revenue Service data, on March 7, Sugar Media had a tax debt of EUR 14,920, and the company\u2019s value added tax (VAT) certificate has been annulled. "http://omgili.com/ri/jHIAmI4hxg9iojOX_BfQUl6nmC1RaMCe_cZqQwGoqq0TlbFexsfvi4eaP42Z5pclroLZ3oy6XChrJSvfv.NhZQ--", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "", "published": "2018-03-23T13:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "The parliament passes bills about gradual transition to Latvian-only education", "text": " 40 The parliament passes bills about gradual transition to Latvian-only education BC, Riga, 23.03.2018. Print version The Latvian parliament today passed in the final reading amendments to the Education Law and the Law on General Education under which schools of ethnic minorities will have to start gradual transition to Latvian-only secondary education in the 2019/2020 academic year, reports LETA. \nThe 100-member parliament passed the bills with 58 votes for and 13 votes against. \nEducation and Science Minister Karlis Sadurskis (Unity) proposed the education reform in early October 2017, which caused yet another wave of protests from Latvia's Russian-speaking community. \nPrime Minister Maris Kucinskis (Greens/Farmers) stressed the education reform had to be adopted quickly so that the question would not be used in the election campaigns ahead of the general elections planned in early October this year. \nThe government approved the proposed legislative amendments in late January 2018, and the parliament started discussing the bills at the beginning of January. The lawmakers also turned down the petition calling for preserving bilingual education in Latvia that was signed by over 10,000 Latvian citizens. \nDespite numerous proposals to alter the education reform in the ethnic minority school or to scrap it altogether, the bills submitted to the parliament for the third and final reading are practically the same as approved by the government earlier. The legislative amendments providing for a gradual transition to education in Latvian in all public schools will be implemented gradually from September 1, 2019, to September 1, 2021. \nAlready in preschools, starting from the age of five, new education guidelines will be introduced in 2019/2020 school year, providing for a bigger role of the Latvian language in the study process. \nA new bilingual education model will be introduced in grades 1-6, ensuring that at least 50% of the subjects are taught in Latvian, and in grades 7-9, ensuring that at least 80% of the study contents is in Latvian in 2019/2020. The final exams for the 9th grade pupils will be held entirely in Latvia. \nStarting from 2020/2021 school year all general education subjects in grades 10 and 11 will be taught only in the Latvian language, while children of ethnic minorities will continue learning their native language, literature and subjects related to culture and history in the respective minority language. \nStarting from 2021/2022 school year all general education subjects in high school (grades 10-12) will be taught only in the Latvian language, while children of ethnic minorities will continue learning their native language, literature and subjects related to culture and history in the respective minority language. Print version The printed version of the National Encyclopedia of Latvia will be issued on October 18, while the encyclopedia's online website will launch on December 18, the encyclopedia's editor in chief Valters Scerbinskis told a press conference on March 22nd, informs LETA. \nWork on the printed version, which will be issued to mark the 100th anniversary of Latvia, is nearing completion. Although the price of the encyclopedia has not yet been decided, Scerbinskis said that the encyclopedia should be \"affordable\". \nAfter the digital version of the National Encyclopedia is launched, work will still continue as more different entries will be added on a regular basis. Working on the encyclopedia are seven editors, and over a hundred specialists are involved in analyzing and selecting content for the cyclopedia. In addition, several hundred authors have written more than 1,300 articles and drawn 1,500 illustrations for the encyclopedia. \nThe encyclopedia's online version will also be accessible from smartphones and tablet computers, added Scerbinskis.
