Saudi Gazette", "published": "2018-03-25T19:09:00.000+03:00", "replies_count": 0, "participants_count": 1, "site_type": "news", "country": "SA", "spam_score": 0.0, "main_image": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/uploads/images/2018/03/25/774372.jpg", "performance_score": 0, "domain_rank": 29738, "social": {"facebook": {"likes": 0, "comments": 0, "shares": 0}, "gplus": {"shares": 0}, "pinterest": {"shares": 0}, "linkedin": {"shares": 0}, "stumbledupon": {"shares": 0}, "vk": {"shares": 0}}}, "uuid": "42c986a0751c87c173479062d76f4fecaacaba86", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/7aBdisT0NOpbwcZeGIouv3yUI2mjKb3hdzQ2VtsUyO41UQQ4arpAZ2TupsK0mq.SlYoHcL5.ziV.D5s_e1AULx1UWX6Z74ICWQWrJUUmGCoiJtxwNDgyCdbji2beqSr2jH5G1k9CfPpzEYtgRftDrcnVzimAwFzkJ_7gpdjbC9g-", "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "saudigazette.com.sa", "published": "2018-03-25T19:09:00.000+03:00", "title": "Maalem Financing receives first-time corporate ratings with stable outlook", "text": "RIYADH \u2014 Saudi Arabia based Maalem Financing Company has announced that it has been assigned first-time corporate ratings of \u2018BB-\u2019 Long-Term and \u2018B\u2019 Short-Term by international credit rating agency Capital Intelligence Ratings. The ratings, carrying a \u2018Stable\u2019 outlook, was given based on Maalem\u2019s \u201cvery sound\u201d capital base together with its low leverage, ample liquidity that comfortably covers short-term debt, and improved asset quality.\nMaalem stated that Capital Intelligence also attributed the rating to the growth potential of the financing market in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, in particular financing for small- and medium-sized entities (SMEs), which represents a key target segment for Maalem Financing.\nLicensed by the Saudi Arabia Monetary Authority (SAMA) in 2016, Maalem Financing is a non-banking finance company (NBFC) operating on Shariah basis in Saudi Arabia. It has reported brisk growth in its financing portfolio, consisting entirely of Murabaha receivables in the first quarters of 2017.\n\u201cMaalem Financing has achieved a major milestone, having received its first-time corporate ratings carrying a stable outlook. The ratings reflect Maalem\u2019s status as one of the fastest growing Shariah-based financial institutions in Saudi Arabia with good governance and sound financial management. Maalem aims to consolidate its position in the market by focusing on the strengths of its operations and executive team, built on international best practices as well as its experiences gained from the local market,\u201d said Aymen Sejiny, chairman of MFC.\nWhile assigning the corporate ratings, Capital Intelligence has highlighted the opportunity before Maalem to capitalize on the growth potential of the local financing market, especially in the SME sector, which has a significant gap in lending demand and supply.\nThe rating agency has noted Maalem\u2019s improved asset quality metrics by the end of the third quarter as non-performing financing receivables (NPFRs) declined in absolute terms, driven by higher collections. It has also observed that the ratio of NPFRs to total financing has improved to a level that is considered satisfactory for an NBFC.\nCapital Intelligence has also taken into account the fact that the loss coverage of Maalem\u2019s NPFRs has increased significantly from a very low point in 2016. Besides, its leverage is one of the lowest recorded among Capital Intelligence\u2019s rated NBFCs.\nMaalem Financing\u2019s capital base strengthened considerably after it issued SR50 million in share capital in 2017. This has acted as a mitigating factor for the modest loss reserve of NPFRs by enhancing the effective coverage ratio, while also providing ample scope for further credit growth.\nCapital Intelligence has observed that Maalem\u2019s low leverage means that it is unlikely to encounter vulnerabilities to liquidity pressures as the financial institution had been prudent in matching its rapid lending growth in the first three quarters of 2017 with pre-arranged new funding.\nMaalem\u2019s coverage of short-term liabilities by liquid assets, including cash and short-term financing receivables, was robust at end of the third quarter of 2017. This reflected the long-term maturity of its single debt facility and the short-term nature of the bulk of its financing, together with the enhanced liquidity buffer provided by higher bank balances.\nStarting its operations in 2009, Maalem obtained a license from SAMA in 2016 for delivering finance to individuals and SMEs. Maalem has recorded strong earnings in recent years, enjoying solid financing income generation thanks to good margins on its financing receivables portfolio. As at the end of September 2017, the company reported consolidated assets of SR231 million ($62 million). \u2014 SG", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "maalem", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "maalem financing company", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "capital intelligence ratings", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "capital intelligence", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "nbfc", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "saudi arabia monetary authority", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "saudi arabia", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "riyadh", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "kingdom of saudi arabia", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "murabaha", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-25T20:23:14.007+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "fedc384799c4831a0410afad207692dca7079107", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/7aBdisT0NOpbwcZeGIouv3yUI2mjKb3hdzQ2VtsUyO6x4Do9vn14YkXfdv9aykS072teA.ARyD86MWsl6xpAgdhFbDzHip64K8ezo867.qSHtXGrCU.1Qu2lWppTbw_moQLdWdJlAkn25swjLOnGSV_M7nlgx7kC", "site_full": "saudigazette.com.sa", "site": "saudigazette.com.sa", "site_section": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "Saudi Gazette/ Home Page", "title": "\u2018Reframe Saudi\u2019 Helps Share Saudi Arabia\u2019s Incredible Story", "title_full": "\u2018Reframe Saudi\u2019 Helps Share Saudi Arabia\u2019s Incredible Story - It gives the world a chance to delve deeper into the cultural dynamics of the Kingdom through local artists who are shaping the future and starting conversations with the world by sharing their experiences and perspectives. It features Ahmad Angawi, Dana Awartani, Rashed Al-Shashai, Ajlan Gharem, Zahra Al-Ghamdi, Ayman Yossri Daydban, Jameela Mater, Ahaad Alamoudi and Ali Mogawi working within the confines of their studios between Jeddah, Abha and Riyadh. The movie is shot around the Kingdom showcasing the stunning landscape and never-seen-before footage of rural and present-day spaces in a manner that transports one to Saudi Arabia via a VR headset. \u201cReframe Saudi is a VR documentary about the art scene in Saudi Arabia, showcasing nine artists and how they reflect in their environment,\u201d Lonardi told Saudi Gazette. \u201cI always talk about contemporary issues in society through artists specifically through VR. I have done something similar for Tehran. I worked with many artists especially Ahmed Mater who watched Reframe Tehran. I pitched the idea to him and Stephen Stapleton, and they really wanted to do it. It took us two years to do it,\u201d he added. Visitors at Art Dubai experienced a preview of the film, with a VR headset and headphones. \u201cIt was a wonderful experience, I felt like I was with the artists and I could move around the landscape by just turning around as if I was there. The whole experience was mind-blowing and I can\u2019t wait to watch the film,\u201d Mona Ali, a visitor at Art Dubai told Saudi Gazette. The preview was followed by a panel discussion on VR and Contemporary Art, moderated by Marisa Mazria Katz with World VR Forum Director, Salar Sahna, VR film maker Matteo Lonardi and Saudi Artist Ahaad Alamoudi. \u201cIt took 12 days to shoot the entire footage. We are looking to launch the film in June this year,\u201d Lonardi told Saudi Gazette. The documentary was launched at Art Dubai following the partnership between the fair and Misk Art Institute headed by Ahmed Mater. "saudigazette.com.sa", "published": "2018-03-23T20:22:00.000+03:00", "title": "Labayh, Lucidya make successful start-up pitch", "text": "IN the group of social entrepreneurship start-ups \u201cLabayh\u201d from Madinah and in the group of tech innovation start-ups \u201cLucidya\u201d from Jeddah were the winners in the First German-Saudi start-up competition in Riyadh\nTen start-ups from all over the Kingdom competed for a four-day start-up tour to Germany. The competition at the Rosh Rayhaan Hotel here on Thursday was organized by the German-Saudi Arabian Liaison Office for Economic Affairs (GESALO) and was attended by Princess Johara Bint Talal as guest of honor.\nDetecon Al-Saudia (DETASAD), an end-to-end ICT solution provider and a leading contributor of ICT sector of Saudi Arabia for more than 35 years, sponsored the 1st German-Saudi Startup Competition organized by GESALO. This event gave Saudi entrepreneurs the opportunity to pitch their business models to a jury. The winners will then represent their company at the MENA Business Forum in Berlin during a four-day startup tour in Germany. This will allow them to network with leading investors, potential partners, and other stakeholders in the startup ecosystem.\nIn his welcoming remarks, the delegate of German Industry and Commerce for Saudi-Arabia, Bahrain and Yemen, Oliver Oehms, explained, \u201cToday is about start-ups and entrepreneurship and we will bring the two winning start-ups to Berlin to showcase promising Saudi start-ups at a very interesting conference, the MENA Business Forum. Small and medium-sized companies and innovative business ideas are the key drivers of the German economy and a growing sector in Saudi Arabia.\u201d\nAmbassador Dieter Haller commended the guest of honor for giving a wonderful example for Saudi entrepreneurs and for helping to empower Saudi women. Regarding the start-up competition he went on: \u201cThe Saudi start-up is as vital and dynamic as any other segment of the Saudi society. We have thought that we should bring the Saudi and the German start-up scene together and one of the most fertile places for start-ups is Berlin. I am so happy that the two winning start-ups will be invited to this important conference in Berlin. My hope is that we will establish a continuous platform for the exchange of ideas and best practices between German start-ups and Saudi start-ups.\u201d\nFollowing the official opening, the ten finalists from Riyadh, Jeddah, Dhahran, Taif and Madinah competed in two groups. They had two minutes to pitch their business ideas in front of the German-Saudi business community and a high-ranking jury, which had another two minutes for follow-up questions.\nIn the group of social entrepreneurship start-ups the winner was \u201cLabayh\u201d from Madinah. The project helps individuals who are suffering from family and psychological problems by useful free content and providing consultation sessions through a mobile app, which works as a point of connection between consultants and users.\nIn the group of tech innovation start-ups the winner was \u201cLucidya\u201d from Jeddah. The company aims at empowering businesses in order to make smarter decisions by using artificial intelligence and big data technologies, so that they monitor and analyze all forms of digital media to understand and predict consumers\u2019 thoughts.\nThe two winners will travel to Germany from April 11 to 14 and get the chance to pitch at the Mena Business Forum on April 12. Before and after the event, an exciting dive into the vibrant start-up ecosystem in Berlin awaits the entrepreneurs including individual meetings with successful German founders, investors, and experts.\nMeanwhile, Felix Wass, president and CEO of Detecon Al Saudia, said, \u201cWe\u2019re proud of our leadership position within the high technology space, and delighted to work together with the German Embassy, GESALO, and our partners to support development & building of a vibrant start-up ecosystem in the KSA ICT industry.\u201d\nHe added: \u201cSponsoring this competition as an official partner of the German-Saudi Liaison Office for Economic Affairs (GESALO), is consistent with our corporate mission and is squarely within our vision of fostering creativity, innovation, and entrepreneurship. DETASAD as a prime example of successful Saudi-German partnership with a track record of 36 years in ICT industry is committed to being a key contributor to the realization of Saudi Vision 2030.\n\u201cDETASAD is committed to supporting the Saudi youth start-up entrepreneurs and we believe in the Saudi youth\u2019s high capabilities in ICT industry. DETASAD is not only sponsoring this event but will provide access to DETASAD cloud, other facilities as well as providing other logistical support to selected technology start-ups,\u201d Wass said.\nDETASAD, established in 1982 as a Saudi-German Company, and drawing on the technology leadership of Detecon International, a member of Deutsche Telekom Group, offers tailor-made solutions in Corporate Networks & Connectivity Solutions, ICT deployment solutions, managed services, data center and cloud solutions to corporate and governmental clients and is committed to contributing to the "published": "2018-03-24T13:44:00.000+03:00", "title": "A commercial plane just used Saudi airspace to fly to Israel", "text": "For the first time ever, a commercial passenger plane has used Saudi airspace to fly directly to Israel.\nAir India Flight 139 flew within 60 km of Riyadh as it traveled for about three hours over the kingdom this week at an altitude of 40,000 feet. En route from New Delhi to Tel Aviv, the aircraft traveled for a little over seven hours in total.\nDuring the trip, the plane also passed through Oman&apos;s airspace. Neither Saudi Arabia or Oman officially recognize Israeli sovereignty, and both have yet to officially comment or confirm that they granted permission for the flight to travel the route, according to The Independent .\nIndian media reported that the flight will take place three times per week moving forward.\nAn Air India plane Source: Star Alliance The Israeli transport minister, Yisrael Katz, called the flight \"historic\", referring to it as \"the first civilian connection with Saudi Arabia and the Gulf states,\" The Guardian reported .\nBack in February, reports began circulating in international media suggesting that Saudi Arabia had granted permission for Air India to fly through the kingdom&apos;s airspace to Israel. At the time, a spokesperson for the General Authority of Civil Aviation told Reuters that no such permission was given.\nThe kingdom has had an airspace ban on flights headed to Tel Aviv for some 70 years, meaning such a decision would mark a dramatic shift in official policy.\n\ud83c\uddee\ud83c\uddf3\u2708\ufe0f\ud83c\uddee\ud83c\uddf1 Air India\u2019s inaugural Delhi-Tel Aviv flight has now entered Saudi Arabian airspace. #AI139 is the first commercial flight in 7 decades to fly over Saudi Arabia en route to Israel.\u2070\u2070\n\ud83d\udce1\nhttps://t.co/x5ov2kEcJN pic.twitter.com/DkjtFYg3OR\n\u2014 Flightradar24 (@flightradar24) March 22, 2018 Abdulrahman Al-Rashed, a prominent Saudi journalist, argued last month that the ban on flights to and from Israel should remain in place, along with the bans on Iran and Qatar.\n\"The ban on the flights of these countries should remain in place until the time comes and they are reconciled,\" Al-Rashed wrote in an editorial column for Arab News.\nHowever, he questioned whether it was necessary to block the aircraft of other friendly nations from using its airspace to arrive in Tel Aviv.\n\"Our relations with the countries of the rest of the world are good, and we are supposed to allow their civilian aircraft to pass through Saudi airspace, regardless of their destination,\" he wrote.\n\"So if the Indian flights were going to Athens or New York or other destinations and wanted to stop at an Israeli airport, why punish them with a ban?\"\nAir India makes history, lands in Israel using Saudi airspace https://t.co/Z3piqVkMyr\n\u2014 The Indian Express (@IndianExpress) March 23, 2018 Some analysts and media reports have suggested that ties between Saudi Arabia and Israel are warming up, pointing to their shared concern over Iran&apos;s influence in the Middle East. H owever, Saudi Arabia has consistently denied such claims.\n\"There are no relations between Saudi Arabia and Israel. There is the Arab peace initiative that constitutes the road map to reach peace and to establish normal relations between Israel and the Arab states,\" Saudi Foreign Minister Adel Al-Jubeir said in November .\n\"Saudi Arabia is committed to the Arab peace initiative. When there will be peace, there will be normal relations between Israel and all the Arab states,\" he added.\nSaudi columnist @aalrashed says foreign airlines should be allowed to use the following U.S. President Donald Trump&apos;s controversial decision to recognize Jerusalem as the Israeli capital.\nThe king said Trump&apos;s declaration \"represents an extreme bias against the rights of the Palestinian people in Jerusalem that have been guaranteed by international resolutions,\" according to Al Jazeera .\n\"I repeat the Kingdom&apos;s condemnation and strong regret over the Project of the Year category with three finalists.\n\u201cAcross the region, contractors, consultants and suppliers alike are expecting a better year ahead due to improved oil prices and government reforms. Saudia is the official carrier of the Saudi National Team and official sponsor of the Saudi Football Professional League.\nThe carrier will operate the route with a Boeing 777-300ER widebody aircraft, in a two class configuration of 30 seats in Business Class and 383 in Guest Class (Economy), for a total of 413 seats.\nThe daily flights will depart from Riyadh and Jeddah, operating as a split schedule with one departure daily from either city.\nUnique packages are available to watch all of the Saudi Arabian national team matches \u2014 which are scheduled to take place on: June 14 (in Moscow), June 20 (in Rostov), and June 25 (in Volgograd).\nGuests looking to book with Saudia to attend match games and support the national team, may purchase packages through \u2018Saudia Holidays\u2019 \u2014 the airline\u2019s holiday package division. Package prices start at SR11,721 and includes four nights hotel (double occupancy) with breakfast, airport and stadium transfers and roundtrip airfare. Match tickets are $1,500 per person in addition to the package costs.\nHotels in Moscow can be arranged for 4 night stays, with a selection of 4 star hotels to choose from. Ticketholders traveling to Russia to attend the World Cup football matches can obtain their visas online by following simple steps once they have a Fan ID match ticket.\n*Package prices offered by Saudia are based on double occupancy and match ticket prices are an additional cost to the package and are priced at $1,500 for the opening match, per person for Category 1 tickets. Match tickets for other games are priced at $850 per person. He also did not reveal their number but said the dismissals were neither haphazard nor built on malicious complaints.\n\u201cWe coordinate closely with the security organs and thoroughly investigate before we dismiss any teacher or employee,\u201d he said.\nOssaimi said any teacher who is found to be involved with any of the extremist groups will be immediately sacked.\nEducation Minister Ahmed Al-Issa in a recent statement said the ideology of the Muslim Brotherhood did exist in a number of educational institutions.\nAccording to Al-Issa, Brotherhood symbols who fled Egypt in the 1960\u2019s and 1970\u2019s went to Saudi Arabia where they got involved in teaching at public schools and universities thus influencing some officials, supervisors and teachers leading to the reformulating of religious curricula.\nThey also organized students\u2019 activities according to the Brotherhood\u2019s \u201cdeviant\u201d approach.\nAl-Issa added that it wasn\u2019t until later that they realized the threat of the Muslim Brotherhood and this is when they launched their efforts to rid the educational system of the flaws resulting from its approach.\n\u201cFollowing these statements, the ministry undertook a number of measures to fight this devious ideology,\u201d Ossaimi said.\nHe said the ministry was continuing its procedures to fight the Muslim Brotherhood ideology while adding that any man or woman teacher who was found to be harboring such ideology would be removed from the educational environment and their relationship with the schools would be terminated.\nThe spokesman said there was a committee constituted under an order by the minister to carefully choose people who hold the leading positions in the ministry to make sure that none of them was influenced by the devious ideology.\nHe said the ministry also organized debates and workshops to warn against teachers and staff with perverted thoughts.\n\u201cThe ministry has adopted a number of measures to protect the students from falling prey to extremist ideologies and has redrafted the curricula to ensure that they are free of any extremist content,\u201d Ossaimi said.\n\u201cWe also train teachers in international universities to ascertain that they do not subscribe to extremist views,\u201d he added.\nThe spokesman said within its fight against deviancy, the ministry had established a center for the intellectual awareness to protect its staff and students from adopting any extremist ideology.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "2018-03-22T17:27:00.000+02:00", "title": "Journey to Islam", "text": "Mark Shaffer, an American attorney and millionaire has declared his Islam in Saudi Arabia on Saturday, 17th October 2009. Mark was at that time on a holiday in Saudi Arabia to visit some famous cities like Riyadh, Abha, and Jeddah for 10 days.\nMark is a well-known millionaire and also a practiced lawyer in Los Angeles, specializing in cases of civil laws. The last big case he handled was the case of the famous American pop singer, Michael Jackson, a week before he passed away.\nA tourist guide who accompanied Mark for 10 days in Saudi Arabia, Dhawi Ben Nashir said, \u201cSince he set foot for the first time in Saudi Arabia, Mark already started to ask questions about Islam and the prayer. As soon as he arrived in Saudi Arabia, Mark stayed in Riyadh for two days. While in Riyadh, Mark was very interested in Islam. After moving to Najran, we went to Abha and Al-Ula. There, his fascination for Islam grew more obvious, especially the time when we ventured out into the desert.\u201d\n\u201cMark was amazed to see three Saudi youths who were in our group in Al-Ula, performing the prayer in the expanse of the very wide desert; a very fantastic panorama indeed.\u201d\n\u201cAfter two days in Al-Ula, we went to Al-Juf. As soon as we arrived in Al-Juf, Mark asked if I could get him some books on Islam. I then obtained some books on Islam for him. Mark read all those books. The next morning, he asked me to teach him how to perform the prayer. I then taught him how to pray and make wudhu (ablution). Then, he joined me and performed the prayer beside me.\u201d\n\u201cAfter prayer, Mark told me that he felt peace in his soul. On Thursday afternoon, we left Al-Ula heading for Jeddah. He looked very serious throughout the journey reading those books about Islam. On Friday morning, we visited the old town of Jeddah. Before the time for the Friday prayer approached, we went back to the hotel and I excused myself to go for the Friday prayer.\u201d\nMark said to his companion, \u201cI would like to join you for the Friday prayer so that I can witness myself how the Friday prayer is like.\u201d\nHis friend, Dhawi Ben Nashir, welcomed the idea.\nDhawi Ben Nashir said, \u201cWe then went to a masjid which was not far from the hotel where we stayed in Jeddah. Since we were quite late, I and many others had to pray outside, as the number of worshippers was overflowing. I could see Mark observing the people in congregation, especially after the Friday prayer was completed, when everybody was shaking hands and embracing each other with radiant and happy faces. Mark was very impressed with what he saw.\u201d\n\u201cWhen we returned to the hotel, Mark suddenly told me that he wanted to become a Muslim. So I said to him, \u2018Please take a shower first.\u2019 After Mark took the shower, I guided him in saying the shahadah (declaration of faith) and then he prayed two rakaah. Later on, Mark expressed his desire to visit the Grand Mosque in Makkah and perform prayers there before leaving Saudi Arabia.\u201d\n\u201cIn order to fulfill his wish, we went to the Da\u2019wah Center in Jeddah to obtain a formal proof of his conversion to Islam, so that he would be allowed to enter the city of Makkah and the Grand Mosque. Mark was given a temporary certificate of his conversion to Islam, and he visited the holy city of Makkah.\u201d\nAfter Mark declared his Islamic faith, he had the chance to express his experience to Al-Riyadh Newspaper, saying, \u201cI could not express my feelings at this time but I am being reborn and my life has just started. I am very happy. This happiness that I am feeling could not be expressed in words, especially when I visited the Grand Mosque and noble Ka\u2019bah.\u201d\nRegarding his next step after his conversion to Islam, Mark explained that he wants to learn more about Islam, delve deeper into the religion of Allah (Islam), and come back to Saudi Arabia to perform the Hajj.\nAs to what impelled him into converting to Islam, Mark explained, \u201cI already had information about Islam, but it was very limited. When I visited Saudi Arabia and personally witnessed the Muslims there, and saw how they performed the prayer, I felt a very strong drive to know more about Islam. When I read true information about Islam, I became confident that Islam is a religion of haq (truth).\u201d\nSunday morning, 18th October 2009, Mark left the Airport of King Abdul Aziz Jeddah heading for America. When filling in the immigration form before leaving Jeddah, Mark wrote ISLAM as his religion. \u2014 Courtesy of Discovering Islam", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "mark shaffer", "sentiment": "negative"}, {"name": "michael jackson", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "dhawi ben nashir", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "mark", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "najran", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "islam", "sentiment": "negative"}], "locations": [{"name": "saudi arabia", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "abha", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "jeddah", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "los angeles", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "riyadh", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-23T13:10:02.003+03:00"}, {"thread": {"uuid": "154af6e1453462ee55dc704bb7bef657e7524ae5", "url": "http://omgili.com/ri/7aBdisT0NOpbwcZeGIouv3yUI2mjKb3hdzQ2VtsUyO4.8anus4nzJGsypjV0OrhP8qNgNyPdKLZ2kesijtoktGAG3yKlrA8WHixmgBj0coiqE45jbk__IOGwc1LAl.AfQ7jmEY7szHE-", "site_full": "saudigazette.com.sa", "site": "saudigazette.com.sa", "site_section": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/morearticles/Business/3", "site_categories": ["media"], "section_title": "Saudi Gazette/ BUSINESS", "title": "Saudia to begin flights to Malaga for summer season", "title_full": "Saudia to begin flights to Malaga for summer season - Rome, March 23 - The anti-establishment 5-Star Movement, the rightwing populist League, the centre-right Forza Italia (FI) party and the centre-left Democratic Party (PD) said Friday they would file blank ballots in the first round of voting for parliamentary Speakers, the first act in the hung parliament that convenes Friday. A deal between the centre right, including the League, and the M5S to give the Speakership of the Senate to the former and the House to the latter broke down Thursday. The M5S rejected the F1 candidate for Senate Speaker, former Senate Whip Paolo Romani, because he is under investigation for alleged misuse of a municipal cellphone in the northern city of Monza. The M5S said Friday they would \"never resurrect\" the so-called Nazarene Pact formerly between FI leader Silvio Berlusconi and PD ex-leader Matteo Renzi. \"No blackmail, we won't rehabilitate Berlusconi,\" said M5S Senate Whip Danilo Toninelli. PD caretaker leader Maurizio Martina said \"the stalemate is getting more complicated, and what we need are guarantor figures\". Small rightist Brothers of Italy (FdI) leader Giorgia Meloni said \"the stalemate is due to infantile posturing\". The parties went on to notch their first failure to elect a Lower House Speaker amid the stalemate. No candidate reached the required 420 votes needed in the first ballot in the 630-seat chamber. That corresponds to two thirds of the seats in the Lower House. The second and third ballots lowers the quorum by counting blank ballots. A two-thirds majority is needed to elect the new Speaker in the first three rounds of voting, after which an absolute majority suffices. Some 620 MPs took part in the vote, 592 filing blank ballots and 18 spoiling their ballots. Votes were cast for Brunetta (2), Muroni (2), Stumpo (2), Bonafede (2), Ermini (1), Lupi (1) and Tripiedi (1). The two winners of the general election were the M5S, which got 32%, and the League, which got 17.5% to become top dog on the centre right, which as a whole got 37%. The PD was left reeling after scoring just 19%.", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "matteo renzi", "sentiment": Some 324 civil service workers were fired in 2017, almost half of them for absenteeism, the civil service ministry said Friday. The ministry said 154 sackings, or 48%, had been for persistently missing work. Some 55 clock-in cheats were fired. "author": "", "published": "2018-03-25T03:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "Thomas Amsler: Loves lobster, misses Bratwurst | Swiss News | Expatica Switzerland", "text": "Thomas Amsler: Loves lobster, misses Bratwurst 25th March 2018 , 0 comments After living in coastal Massachusetts for over 50 years, Swiss architect Thomas Amsler says he loves New England, but misses Swiss sausages. \nHowever, the 81-year-old says he has never felt homesick since arriving in the United States in 1964. \n\u201cWe missed certain things, but there were so many new things to explore. And I\u2019m a forward-looking guy who doesn\u2019t spend much time dwelling on whether I should be home again,\u201d says Amsler, born in the north-eastern Swiss canton of Schaffhausen in 1936. On a recent visit to Switzerland, he dropped by swissinfo.ch to talk about his study of a Ticino village with remarkable architecture. \nWithout knowing that he\u2019s an octogenarian, you wouldn\u2019t think to offer the elevator, and Amsler takes the stairs in stride, asking, \u201cIs this a new building?\u201d and looking around with curiosity. Atlantic crossing \nHaving been offered a travel fellowship to see American architecture first-hand, Amsler and his wife and two young children embarked on the five-day cruise from Rotterdam in the Netherlands to New York City. From there they headed up the coast to Duxbury, Massachusetts, where Amsler had a contact. \n\u201cThe idea was to have an experience and then to go back to Switzerland,\u201d laughs Amsler. But it didn\u2019t work out that way \u2013 \u201cprimarily because I immediately got immersed in very interesting and relatively independent work \u2013 even as an employee\u201d. \nOne of his most prominent projects was the control tower at Logan International Airport in Boston. Amsler\u2019s employer, architecture firm Desmond and Lord, assigned him the role of project manager. \n\u201cAt the time it was the highest control tower in the world. It\u2019s unusual because it has two legs and is connected at the top, and that was because Massachusetts required two exits, so there are stairs in each leg,\u201d explains Amsler. Also at Logan Airport, he designed a hangar and worked on the central power plant and international terminal, which was expanding at the time. \nAmsler also designed the Southeastern Massachusetts University campus, which is now the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth. Later, he and two friends started their own firm, and Amsler acted as an independent contractor as well. At home in Marblehead \nWhile working in Boston, Amsler found a dream house north of the city: a small \u201csummer\u201d home across the street from the ocean in Marblehead. \n\u201cIt\u2019s not unlike a small town in Switzerland. We were lucky to end up in a town that is much more European-feeling than American-feeling. All the houses are wooden and the streets are crooked. So we felt very much at home there,\u201d Amsler says. \nBut it was about five years before he and his family could afford a visit to Switzerland. \nAmsler says he was never homesick, but of course he missed friends \u2013 and certain foods. \n\u201cAt the beginning, you only got spongy bread in America, but we don\u2019t have that problem anymore. Same thing with cheeses. You had maybe two or three in the supermarket then, but that\u2019s changed so we can get everything now. We can even buy Swiss chocolate.\u201d \nWhat Amsler still misses is the traditional Swiss-style sausage, called \u201cBratwurst\u201d in German. He sometimes places an order with a special sausage company in Colorado. \n\u201cWhen we have a big party, I\u2019ll order 50 bratwursts to grill, and people love \u2019em,\u201d Amsler says with relish. \nMeanwhile, he\u2019s come to appreciate the local cuisine; particularly sweet corn sold at local farm stands and seafood from the local waters. \n\u201cWe have great fish restaurants in Marblehead. Great lobster, fish, seafood in general,\u201d Amsler notes. Something special about New England \nExcept for visits, Amsler can\u2019t imagine returning to Switzerland at this point. \n\u201cFor one thing, I can\u2019t afford it \u2013 to live in a place as nice as I live now. That\u2019s the main reason. And the other reason is that all my direct family is now American,\u201d says Amsler, now a dual citizen, divorced, and with a new partner. \nAnd besides, he\u2019s in love with New England, too. \n\u201cWhen you\u2019re in another country for that long, it\u2019s not only new friends that you make, but it\u2019s just the place itself. I love New England; there\u2019s something very special about it,\u201d Amsler says. He especially likes the rugged countryside and the ocean, and he also loves Cape Cod for its history, beauty, and the beaches where he goes windsurfing. \nIn winter, he\u2019s drawn to the mountains of New England. \n\u201cI still go snowboarding once a week if you can believe it \u2013 at my age! My kids say to me, \u2018You\u2019re crazy \u2013 you should stop\u2019,\u201d chuckles Amsler. You can tell he has no intention of doing so. \n\u00a9 swissinfo.ch The above content produced by swissinfo.ch is not intended for commercial use and may not be republished by third parties either wholly or in part. "2018-03-25T03:00:00.000+03:00", "title": "PhD Defence Erlis Themeli | Erasmus School of Law | Erasmus University Rotterdam", "text": "Promotie PhD Defence Erlis Themeli \nOn 23 March 2018, Erlis Themeli will defend his thesis, entitled \u201cThe Great Race of Courts, Civil Justice System Competition in the European Union\u201d. The public defence takes place in the Senaatszaal at Erasmus University Rotterdam, at 11.30 a.m. \nThis study focuses on the civil justice system competition in the EU, a form of regulatory competition in which states try to attract parties to litigate in their jurisdictions. In this study, the term civil justice system refers to the whole apparatus involved in the resolution and enforcement of civil disputes. Many institutions and parties are engaged in this process, with courts, lawyers, and governments being the obvious examples. In this context, the present study\u2019s main research question is \u2018How do civil justice systems compete in the EU?\u2019 \nTo arrive at an answer, both a theoretical and an empirical approach are taken. The theoretical part considers various aspects of competition, but most importantly it offers an overview of regulatory competition, an analysis of the legal framework within which Member States operate, and an analysis of the civil justice system market and its elements. Based on the theoretical analysis, the empirical part is divided into two components; the first contains an analysis of data provided by the 2016 EU Justice Scoreboard, while the second analyses a survey on lawyers\u2019 court preferences in the EU that has been conducted for this research. The symbiosis between the theoretical and the empirical part adds more depth to the research, and contributes new data and analyses to the ongoing academic debate. Meer informatie \nDate: 23 March 2018, 11.30 AMLocation: Senaatszaal, Erasmus BuildingPromotors: Prof. mr. X.E. Kramer and prof mr. M.W. "ord_in_thread": 0, "author": "Janene Pieters", "published": "2018-03-22T02:00:00.000+02:00", "title": "Anti-Islam PVV wins city council seats in 30 municipalities", "text": "Anti-Islam PVV wins city council seats in 30 municipalities   09:45 Geert Wilders casts his vote in the municipal elections in Duindorp, The Hague, 21 March 2018. Photo: @geertwilderspvv / Twitter \nGeert Wilders and his PVV won city council seats seats in each one of the 30 municipalities the party participated in during the municipal elections on Wednesday. In total the PVV currently stands on 74 seats, the Volkskrant reports. \nDuring the previous municipal elections four years ago, the PVV only participated in two municipalities - Almere and The Hague. The party got fewer seats in those two municipalities this time around. In Almere the party dropped from nine to seven seats, and in The Hague from seven to two seats. \nIn Nissewaard, which covers Spijkenisse and its surroundings, the party won five seats. Relatively, the PVV got the most votes in Rucphen - 20.3 percent - giving it four seats. The PVV also won four seats in Terneuzen and in Venlo, and two in Rotterdam. The party is now also in the city councils of cities like Zaanstad, Enschede, Zoetermeer, Arnhem, Maastricht and Den Bosch. \nNot all the votes are counted yet, so the PVV may get a few more seats. In Utrecht the party stands on one so far, and in Stichtse Vecht on two. \n\"Fantastic!\" Wilders wrote on Twitter. \"Great results in Nissewaard, Venlo, Terneuzen, Rucphen, Maastricht, Zaanstad, Emmen, Almelo, Lelystad, Dordrecht and many other municipalities where the PVV sound will be heard from now on! The PVV is growing!!\" Tags:", "highlightText": "", "highlightTitle": "", "language": "english", "external_links": [], "entities": {"persons": [{"name": "geert wilders", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "den", "sentiment": "none"}], "organizations": [{"name": "arnhem", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "spijkenisse", "sentiment": "none"}], "locations": [{"name": "rotterdam", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "almere", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "zaanstad", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "venlo", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "terneuzen", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "duindorp", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "the hague", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "rucphen", "sentiment": "none"}, {"name": "zoetermeer", "sentiment": "none"}]}, "rating": null, "crawled": "2018-03-22T21:31:41.019+02:00"}], "totalResults": 6, "moreResultsAvailable": 0, "next": "/filterWebContent?token=e0e8b2b9-80ce-4cdc-bde9-b730ada6c3f9&format=json&ts=1521745836225&q=language%3Aenglish+site_type%3Anews+thread.country%3ANL+location%3ARotterdam&sort=relevancy&from=10&size=10", "requestsLeft": 918, "extra": {"place": "Rotterdam", "country": "NL", "lat": "51.9244201", "lng": "4.4777326"}}]
